title: Project: A Framework for ML Ops
supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (50%)
objectives:
O ciclo de produção de SW, um conjunto de práticas conhecidas como DevOps permitiram enviar software para produção em minutos e mantê-lo funcionando de forma fiável. A DevOps baseia-se em ferramentas, automação e fluxos de trabalho para abstrair a complexidade do processo e deixar que os programadores se concentrem nos problemas reais que precisam de ser resolvidos.

No domínio do Machine Learning, um modelo ML inclui código e dados, tornando o processo anterior mais complexo. O ML Ops tem que lidar com dois fluxos de transformações de dados: os de treino e os de predição.

O objetivo desta dissertação é desenvolver uma framework para o ML Ops, 
que, além de gerir versões de código permita também permita gerir versões de modelos e versões de dados a colocar em produção.

A framework a desenvolver deverá uma extensão às frameworks DevOps,  e deverá ser compatível com os principais frameworks opensource de machine learning, como o Tensorflow, Caffe, Torch, entre outras.
requirements: Conhecimentos Python e Spark

title: Dissertation: Verification of Functional Programs
objectives:
The goal of this project is to explore techniques and methodologies that can be used to verify the correctness of programs written in a functional programming language (such as Haskell or OCaml). The concrete work plan will depend on the chosen programming language (students can use their favourite functional programming language). For example, if the language chosen is Haskell, activities can include:

 * Using hs-to-coq [SZBRW18,BSZL+18]. In this case, the verification process is done within the proof assistant Coq [BC13,Chl13].
 * Using LiquidHaskell [VSJ14,Vaz16,Pen17].
 * A possibility is to compare hs-to-coq with LiquidHaskell (and, potentially, other approaches)

In terms of applications, there are many libraries or algorithms that can be verified. These can be verified in the context of a larger real-world application in areas such as security or web. Both the language and applications to study will be decided jointly by the student and the supervisor.


[BC13] Yves Bertot and Pierre Castéran. Interactive theorem proving and program development: Coq’Art: the calculus of inductive constructions. Springer Science & Business Media, 2013.
[BSZL+18] Joachim Breitner, Antal Spector-Zabusky, Yao Li, Christine Rizkallah, John Wiegley, and Stephanie Weirich. Ready, set, verify! applying hs-to-coq to real-world haskell code. arXiv preprint arXiv:1803.06960, 2018.
[Chl13] Adam Chlipala. Certified programming with dependent types: a pragmatic introduction to the Coq proof assistant. MIT Press, 2013.
[Pen17] Ricardo Pena. An introduction to liquid haskell. arXiv preprint arXiv:1701.03320 , 2017.
[SZBRW18] Antal Spector-Zabusky, Joachim Breitner, Christine Rizkallah, and Stephanie Weirich.  Total haskell is reasonable coq.  In Proceedings of the 7th ACM SIGPLAN International Conference on Certified Programs and Proofs, pages 14–27. ACM, 2018.
[Vaz16] Niki Vazou. Liquid Haskell: Haskell as a theorem prover. University of California, San Diego, 2016.
[VSJ14] Niki Vazou, Eric L Seidel, and Ranjit Jhala. Liquidhaskell: Experience with refinement types in the real world. In ACM SIGPLAN Notices, volume 49, pages 39–51. ACM, 2014.
requirements:
Students should:
1. Enjoy programming and learning about new programming languages and technologies
2. Be interested in functional programming
3. Be interested in software engineering and software reliability
4. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

title: [Dissertação] The multi-objective set covering problem and other related combinatorial problems
observations: The student Gonçalo Paredes (97127) has already manifested interest on this topic.
objectives: The set covering problem is a classical NP-hard problem in combinatorial optimization, with many applications and many approximation algorithms being proposed in last years. Many of those algorithms are also suitable for related problems, but most of them are not suitable for multi-objective formulations of these problems. The aim of this project is to explore multi-objective formulations of the set covering problem, and other related problems. Practical and usable/implementable algorithms are desirable.
requirements: Interest in algorithms and combinatorial optimization.

title: [Projecto] Production Applications’ Health System
supervisors: José Manuel da Costa Alves Marques (97%)
objectives:
Prevenção de potenciais problemas nos sistemas/aplicações que se encontram em produção é crítico para as organizações de modo a evitar situações de catástrofe com impactos financeiros e/ou de imagem.
A identificação dos problemas que podem estar na origem de falhas em sistemas produtivos é complexa, pois as causas poderão ser diversas (problemas/bugs aplicacionais, de segurança, de performance, rede, etc..)

Objectivo: O projeto deverá criar uma plataforma que centraliza num único local toda a informação disponível relativa aos sistemas em produção
O segundo objetivo desta plataforma será o de automatizar e gerir alguns tipos de sanity tests aos sistemas produtivos (nomeadamente testes de carga, segurança e testes funcionais automáticos) que deverão ser realizados periodicamente sem, no entanto, impactar a sua operação.
Por fim a plataforma deverá ter também ter a capacidade de incorporar um serie de mecanismos que com base em algoritmos de machine learning interpretem toda a informação recolhida sobre um sistema ao longo do tempo em consigam detetar padrões e correlacionar eventos de forma a proactivamente identificar potencias problemas que poderão afetar os sistemas em produção e alertar para a mitigação dos mesmos.
requirements: Engenharia de software, dev ops, machine learning

title: Dissertação: Synthesis of self-optimizing network programs
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Prof. Luis Pedrosa (luis.pedrosa@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) and Prof. Fernando Ramos (fvramos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Building the networks that power modern distributed systems has led to new designs and architectures that are often not backward compatible with standard network devices and frameworks. This has led to a recent push for increased programmability and configurability in the network, with different efforts trading off flexibility, performance, and complexity.
 
One of the most recent advances was the emergence of programmable packet switch ASICs. A first system prototype was presented in 2013 [1], and the first commercial Ethernet switch based on a programmable ASIC – the Intel/Barefoot Tofino – came to market in 2016 [2]. These switches extend the control plane programmability offered by software defined networks [3] to the data plane, with better performance than software network functions (NFs) [4]. This new class of commodity switches allow operators to precisely define packet processing using a high-level language (e.g., P4 [5,6]) and run at Tbps scales. These switch architectures enable programmability of packet parsing (i.e., the user can define the packet headers) and match-action tables (enabling users to define the forwarding behaviour and additional packet processing). While simplified to guarantee line rate processing, their computing model enables simple operations and access to (limited amounts of) stateful memory, enabling offloading of packet computations from software to this dedicated switch hardware that runs 100x to 1000x faster.
 
That said, programmable switches trade these factors off for complexity, as it requires specific expertise on a new language for packet processing (e.g., P4) and on packet switch architectures that are very restrictive in terms of memory [7] and computing power [8], therefore limiting the wider adoption of these technologies. This complexity is further compounded by the fact that, in many cases, these devices offer a variety of alternative mechanisms that can be used to offload specific functionality. State, for example, may be encoded in either tables or registers, though each comes with different limitations and performance trade-offs. Often, the overall performance that results from choosing one mechanism over another is workload dependent, varying based on what fraction of packets exercise each option’s fast and slow paths. To achieve optimal performance, the network must continuously measure current traffic patterns and adapt the synthesis strategy accordingly. This is the focus of this project.

In this thesis we will enhance ongoing work on synthesizing P4 programs to accelerate the network data plane by building an online profiler into the synthesis engine. This profiler automatically measures traffic characteristics and reevaluates synthesis choices as the workload changes over time, allowing the network to dynamically adapt to new conditions.
 
References:
 
[1] Pat Bosshart et al., Forwarding Metamorphosis: Fast Programmable Match-Action Processing in Hardware for SDN. ACM SIGCOMM 2013
 
[2] https://barefootnetworks.com/products/brief-tofino/
 
[3] D. Kreutz, F. M. V. Ramos, P. E. Veríssimo, C. E. Rothenberg, S. Azodolmolky and S. Uhlig, "Software-Defined Networking: A Comprehensive Survey," in Proceedings of the IEEE, vol. 103, no. 1, pp. 14-76, Jan. 2015, doi: 10.1109/JPROC.2014.2371999.
 
[4] B. Han, V. Gopalakrishnan, L. Ji and S. Lee, "Network function virtualization: Challenges and opportunities for innovations," in IEEE Communications Magazine, vol. 53, no. 2, pp. 90-97, Feb. 2015, doi: 10.1109/MCOM.2015.7045396.
 
[5] P4 Language Consortium, https://p4.org
 
[6] Pat Bosshart et al., P4: Programming Protocol-Independent Packet Processors, ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, Volume 44, Number 3, July 2014
 
[7] Lavanya Jose et al. Compiling Packet Programs to Reconfigurable Switches. USENIX NSDI 2015
 
[8] A. Sivaraman et al., Packet Transactions: High-Level Programming for Line-Rate Switches, SIGCOMM 2016

title: [Dissertação] Attack SureThing! Vulnerability assessment, penetration testing and attack tournament on location proof system
objectives:
The SureThing project (http://surething-project.eu) is developing a location proof framework that can prevent location spoofing on LBS (Location Based Services). The current prototypes of the project allow the issuance and verification proofs using mobile devices in a variety of use cases. The preliminary security analysis has been positive, but so far no aggressive attackers have been deployed against the system. This work will allow students to practice offensive security techniques and perform vulnerability assessment and penetration testing on a SureThing deployment.

Additionaly, a cybersecurity range (testbed) and respective assessment tools will be developed and prepared, to be deployed in a real world location, where red teams will be using offensive security techniques to break the SureThing system in an organized tournament.
The results of the exercises will be collected, analyzed and used for the improvement and hardening of the existing SureThing architecture. An adversarial evaluation of SureThing is desirable as no security system is truly robust until it comes under attack by skilled and motivated hackers. 

Referências:
Joe Vest and James Tubberville,  "Red Team: Development and Operations”.
http://redteam.guide/

FuzzBench: Fuzzer Benchmarking As a Service
https://google.github.io/fuzzbench/
requirements: Realização do projeto em tempo integral, 40 horas/semana (incluindo cadeiras do curso).White hat integrity, black hat ingenuity

title: Dissertation: Multi-party Coherent Expression of Emotions in Games
observations: This theme was proposed by Afonso Vieira (86458).
objectives:
To increase a sense of uniqueness and bonding between the players and a game’s world and characters, it is important to correctly have the players' avatar portray how they are feeling in term of what is occurring around them in the game. In multiplayer games in particular, it is important for the emotions displayed by each avatar reflect what happens to their partners and opponents on the screen, to create a coherent experience. This work will explore a real-time computational model of emotion expression supporting multiple agents simultaneously modelled through theory of mind.

Main sub-goals:
( 1 ) Literature review (semester 1)
( 2 ) Computational model (semester 1 and 2)
( 3 ) Test scenario implementation (semester 2)
( 4 ) User studies (semester 2)
requirements: This thesis proposal is open to all MSc students from the Master Degree in Information Systems and Computer Engineering of Instituto Superior Técnico. Preference will be given to students that finished the following curricular units: Computer Graphics for Games, Artificial Intelligence for Games, Game Design, Game Development Methodologies.

title: Dissertação: Fault-tolerant On-board Computer system design for a small Cubesat (em parceria com a Spin.Works)
observations: Esta tese decorre inicialmente no Inesc-Id e posteriormente nas instalações da Spin-Works
objectives:
This thesis is centred on the research and development of a fault-tolerant system architecture and its application to the specific case of the On-Board Computer (OBC) of a small Cubesat. The resulting design must explore redundancy and fault detection, isolation and recovery strategies, both at the level of hardware and software. The goal is to achieve a robust OBC design that is able to operate reliably for a period of up to one year in a radiation environment characteristic of low Earth orbit, including the worst case conditions found at the South Atlantic Anomaly. Other aspects to take into account in the design are a driver towards low cost, low power and low weight and size, which characterize the New Space industry.
The development of this work is to be done using hardware description languages or high level synthesis tools from XIlinx. At the end of this thesis it is expected to have a demonstration running on a board with Xilinx FPGAs.
requirements:
The proposed work requires knowledge (or interest in learning about) and research in the following areas:-: Embedded hardware design
-	Programming for embedded systems
-	Fault-tolerant architectures
-	FDIR system features

title: Dissertação: Optimização de Treino de Redes Neuronais
observations: Co-orientação externa: Nuno Lopes (nlopes@microsoft.com), Microsoft Research Cambridge
objectives:
O treino de redes neuronais ou de outros modelos de machine learning em uso é uma tarefa computacionalmente pesada. Modelos mais complexos demoram várias semanas a convergir.

O aparecimento de aceleradores especializados (e.g., Google TPU) reduziu significativamente o tempo de treino. No entanto, estes chips têm ainda uma utilização aquém do throughput máximo.

Este trabalho incide na optimização de algoritmos distribuídos e/ou paralelos para treino de redes neuronais e outras (DNNs, CNNs, RL, etc) em aceleradores especializados, tendo como objectivo melhorar a performance e reduzir o consumo energético. O tipo de algoritmos inclui, por exemplo, multiplicação de matrizes, convolução, compressão, ajuste automático de precisão das operações, escalonamento de tarefas e alocação de memória em sistemas NUMA.

title: [Dissertação] : Delineating Boundaries for Vague Regions
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Patricia Murrieta-Flores ( https://www.lancaster.ac.uk/history/about/people/patricia-murrieta-flores ), and it will be developed in the context of the MIMU and DigCH research projects, currently being executed at INESC-ID in collaboration with the Digital Humanities Hub at Lancaster University.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including a researcher named Jacinto Estima ( https://jestima.github.io/ ) that is also working on the aforementioned projects.

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
A major problem in the context of geographic information systems relates to the vague and imprecise nature of the names and concepts that people normally use in their day-to-day activities involving the use of geographic information. We have for instance that territories, marking the spatial extent of areas associated to given place names, are often vaguely defined (particularly for vernacular place names), in the sense that people are likely to disagree on how the spatial boundaries should be perceived. The ability to establish territorial extents of political, religious, or economic zones, in a quantitative and formally correct way, has many practical applications (e.g., augmenting information on historical gazetteers with polygonal geospatial footprints, estimating areas of influence for particular events, etc.), allowing analysts to move from point to area-based observations.
 
Several previous studies have proposed approaches for automatically discovering the geospatial boundaries associated with imprecise regions, leveraging one-class classification methods ( e.g., https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13658816.2014.916040 ), kernel density estimation ( e.g., https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-45738-3_9 ), methods based on Voronoi tessellations ( e.g., https://archiv.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/propylaeumdok/550/1/08_01_ducke_et_al_xtent.pdf ), or other computational geometry methods ( e.g., https://code.flickr.net/2008/10/30/the-shape-of-alpha/ ). Despite these previous developments, existing approaches still have difficulties in combining distinct sources of information that can help in delineating the boundaries (e.g., information on points estimated to be contained within the region, together with information derived from digital elevation models, land coverage data, or information computed from other types of remote sensing products).

This MSc research project will explore the use of hybrid methods, combining weighted Voronoi tessellations with neural approaches for density estimation, for defining polygonal boundaries for vague geographic regions. In particular, approaches based on weighted Voronoi tessellations will be used to create initial estimates, which will then be refined through the use of approaches based on convolutional neural networks ( e.g., see https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.11194 ) for combining movement costs and terrain information that often correlates with boundaries (e.g., exploring information on terrain elevation and coverage).

Experiments will be performed with data collected and made available in the context of previous historical gazetteers, and also with existing boundary information for modern regions whose geospatial limits are consensual (i.e., the assessment of the results will be made by comparing estimated and ground-truth regions, through metrics such as the area intersection-over-union ratio).

title: Projecto: Side-channel setup for chip testing
objectives:
In current embed systems cryptography is a fundamental component in the so called smart devices, e.g. citizen card or PayTV systems. The resistance of these devices towards side-channel attacks (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Side-channel_attack) needs to be tested in order to determine there reliability. One of the most common side channel attacks classes currently in used is the Differential Power Attacks (DPA) and Differential Electro-magnetic Attacks (DEMA) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_power_analysis). 

These testes imply the realization of the attack it self, either by simulation or in the device itself. In order for these testes to be performed in the devices a measuring apparatus needs to be use in order to measure the consumed power and emanated electromagnetic radiation.

The goal of this thesis is to develop the measuring apparatus needed to perform these side-channel analysis attacks. In order to make these attacks more efficient it is required to identify where in the tested chip the cryptographic units are located. This can be accomplished with the identification of the processing “hot-spots” according to the execution flow. The temporal mapping of this processing “hot-spots” is to be performed by detecting the intensity of the electro-magnetic radiation during the execution period.
This platform is also to be integrated into the side-channel attack platform where real attacks are to be performed over security chips, e.g. smart cards or PayTV systems. The improvement of these attacks will be used to demonstrate the usability of the developed platform.
requirements: Interest in the development of embedded systems and security systems

title: Dissertation: Robots4All: Building Inclusive Robots for Sighted and Visually Impaired Children
observations: You will be part of a multidisciplinary team working on a larger research agenda that aims to build inclusive robots for mixed-visual abilities classrooms.
objectives:
This proposal is within the field of human-computer interaction and accessible computing.

Visually impaired children are increasingly educated in mainstream rather than special schools. However, they still face barriers to social interaction and classroom participation, being often excluded from group activities with sighted peers and putting them at risk of isolation. These barriers are often attributed to assistive technologies that are design to be used by visually impaired children alone, limiting opportunities for inclusive learning experiences.

Groupwork takes a critical role with new educational curricula where the value of innovation and creativity is favoured over standardized knowledge acquisition and repetitive tasks. Creating a truly inclusive environment where mixed-visual abilities children can collaborate is of utmost importance to foster social engagement and increase participation.

Social robots have the potential to reduce barriers to inclusion and promote equally engaging experiences to both sighted and visually impaired children. However, robots are usually designed for sighted users and rely heavily on visual feedback. On the other hand, assistive learning technologies tend to focus on the specific needs of visually impaired children, making them non-engaging to sighted peers. This raises the need to explore the design of social robots that promote collaboration between sighted and visually impaired children.

In this work, you will investigate the potential to use social robots promote collaboration in mixed-visual abilities groups [2, 3] and improve opportunities for peer learning in creative activities [1]. The specific use-case scenario consists of a storytelling activity in which children use a robot as a character for their stories. It is in the interaction with the robot that creativity is intended to be stimulated. The robot is intended to boost creative abilities by providing accessible stimuli and allowing children to develop new storylines for the stories they create. Your goal is to design and develop (or adapt) a cost-effective robot to support inclusive storytelling activities for mixed-visual abilities children.

Tasks that you will undertake include:
1)	Literature review;
2)	Community engagement;
3)	Design the robot and feedback modalities;
4)	Develop robot and storytelling scenario;
5)	Evaluate proposed solution (in collaboration with Centro Hellen Keller);
6)	Write your master thesis.
 
In addition to your master thesis, you are expected to advance the state of the art in the field of human-computer interaction and submit a paper to an international conference or journal.

[2]	Metatla, O., Serrano, M., Jouffrais, C., Thieme, A., Kane, S., Branham, S., Brulé, É. and Bennett, C.L. 2018. Inclusive Eductaion Technologies: Emerging Opportunities for People with Visual Impairments. Extended Abstracts of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (New York, NY, USA, 2018), W13:1--W13:8.

title: Dissertation: Using approximate computing to reduce energy consumption in large-scale parallel computations
observations: Aluno: Vlad Stjona
objectives:
The energy requirements of today's computations is growing to unprecedented levels. In some cases, a single computation for training a model can consume several times more energy than an average person does over an entire year [1]. Many of these energy-hungry computations are large-scale iterative and convergent computations, where data is partitioned across multiple tasks that communicate at the end of each iteration to transmit their partial results, and that tolerate some degree of inconsistency in a subset of these partial results that are transmitted. In this thesis, we will explore the use of approximate computing for lowering this energy footprint. In particular, we intend to show that by systematically running CPUs at a lower voltage in a controlled way, we can find a sweet spot between achieving significant energy savings while still obtaining meaningful results.

objectives:
Sound and Music Generation is an interesting topic of Computational Creativity and Musicology and in this Thesis we aim at continuing with the creation of sound and music from images, in particular we aim at converting changes in images (that compose a video or film) into sound/music.

Previous work (http://web.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/ist173393) has drawn the attention of musicians and musicologist that interpret the sound/music generated solely from the pixels (colours) as interesting and experimental. title: Dissertação: Myriarch: enabling the coexistence of a myriad of Internets
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Fernando Ramos (fvramos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
The Internet is the most successful global communication infrastructure ever built. This is as undeniable as the widely recognized limitations of its architecture [1]. The research community responded to this problem with various clean-slate redesigns of the Internet, including security approaches [2], inter-domain designs [3], or information-centric networks [4]. So far, none of these clean-slate designs have had a significant impact on the commercial Internet, since the Internet architecture is deeply embedded both in networking hardware and in the end-host software.

Trying to close the current deployability gap, this project takes a first step towards the design of a framework for a multi-architecture Internet, Myriarch. We follow the vision originally advocated in [5], entailing translation mechanisms in the network to stitch together different architectures. While [5] presented the vision, its materialisation did not yet occur, due to two difficulties: networking hardware is hard to change, and software-based solutions are too slow. 

Fortunately, recent advances on computer networking hardware can finally pave the way for a radical change. Specifically, the emergence of programmable packet switches (e.g., the Barefoot Tofino [6]) that allow the definition of packet processing using a high-level language (e.g., P4 [7]) and run at Tbps scales. By building the translation mechanisms into this modern networking hardware, Myriarch will enable the interconnection of different network architectures while meeting the performance requirements of today’s networks, to try to close the deployability gap.

The student will be working on the design and implementation of translation techniques for interconnection of different Internets using the latest programmable networking hardware (a Barefoot Tofino we have in our lab). One of the main challenges is therefore the restrictive computing model of the target hardware platform.  Specifically, to guarantee line rate processing, and thus to run 100x to 1000x than the alternatives, the Tofino model enables only simple operations and access to (limited amounts of) stateful memory. If successful, however, it may be a highly relevant step towards a multi-architecture Internet.

The project will be co-advised by Fernando Ramos (Associate Prof. at IST) and Daniel Corujo (Senior Researcher at IT Aveiro). Jon Crowcroft (Prof. at the University of Cambridge), main author of [5], Aurojit Panda (Assistant Prof. at New York University), and Salvatore Signorello (post-doc at FCUL) will act as external collaborators in the project.

References:

[2]ZHANG, Xin, et al. SCION: Scalability, control, and isolation on next-generation networks. In: 2011 IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy. IEEE, 2011. p. 212-227.
[3] TOUCH, Joe; WANG, Yu-Shun; PINGALI, Venkata. A recursive network architecture. ISI, Tech. Rep, 2006, 626.

objectives:

Já existe um estudo prévio sobre a utilização de peer-grading em contexto semi-presencial, mas as conclusões recolhidas ainda são preliminares…

O objetivo é acabar o desenvolvimento de um sistema de peer-grading para o moodle e, no contexto da UC de PCM, estudar o peer-grading. É justo? Como podem os alunos fazê-lo da melhor forma? As relações sociais existentes condicionam a imparcialidade?

Existe já um plugin para o moodle que permite o peer-grading. Podendo ainda ser limadas algumas arestas, o foco desta tese é, no 2º semestre, acompanhar o seu uso na UC de PCM. title: [Dissertação] Machine Learning based on Hyper-Dimensional Computing

objectives:
Hyper-dimensional Computing (HDC), a bio-inspired paradigm defined on random high-dimensional vectors, has emerged as a promising IoT paradigm, namely for Machine Learning (ML). The main objective of this thesis is to develop a programmable an ultra-energy-efficient architecture for supervised classification based on the HDC paradigm. Its simple construction follows from basic HD operations and its massively parallel, with simple datapath, resembling in-memory computing. The architecture should be scalable, by adding cores connected in parallel to increase the effective HD dimension.

A broad evaluation is performed by comparing HDC with ML algorithms on conventional architectures, such as CPU and GPU, considering instructions required, energy consumption and memory requirements.

A atenção tem se deslocado para o estudo de fatores transcriptómicos. O estudo da resposta regulatória de células pulmonares à infeção é, neste contexto, essencial para compreender os fatores moleculares que determinam, por exemplo, a assintomatologia. Adicionalmente, a resposta regulatória à atuação de fármacos permite apoiar o desenolvimento de terapias moleculares e compreender a resposta imunológica do corpo ao vírus.

1) tratar as seguintes duas fontes de dados: GSE147507 e GSE148829
2) estudar o perfil transcriptómico de células pulmonares saudáveis, em particular:
- compreender a assinatura e variabilidade regulatória por célula: NHBE (bronquio-epitelial), A459 (alveolar), H1299 (carcinoma pulmonar)
- analisar diferenças regulatórias inter-celulares
3) estudar a resposta regulatória à infeção, em particular:
- analisar diferenças regulatórias por célula entre estado saudável e infeção pelo SARS-CoV-2
- descobrir padrões regulatórios discriminativos da infeção in-vitro contra SARS-CoV-1, IAV/H1N1, parainfluenza/HPIV3 e RSV
4) estudar a resposta regulatória à terapêutica molecular
- descobrir padrões elicitados por estimulação com IFNA/IFNG/IL17A/IL4 com dosagem variável
- descobrir padrões temporais da resposta à estimulação com IFN-beta
- avaliar a eficácia do fármaco Ruxolitinib

Para responder a estes fins, serão testadas hipóteses estatísticas e aplicados métodos para descoberta de associações em dados tridimensionais de elevada dimensionalidade.

title: [Dissertação] Automatic Extraction of Information from Text Files
objectives:
The extraction of information from text files is a cumbersome task, in particular if the user
is not proficient in a programming language. In many administrative tasks, filtering information
from text files is crucial, but most people are unable to automate this task using a programming
language or a stream editor such as sed.

Although users are unable to program, they can easily specify examples of input-output of
the desired behavior. Given a set of input-output examples provided by the user, the goal

title: [Dissertation] Scalable Symbolic Execution for Preact Web Applications
observations: Strong programming skills.
objectives:
JavaScript is the most widespread dynamic language. It is the de facto language for client-side web applications, used by more than 95% of websites [1]. Its behaviour, described in the ECMAScript English standard [2], is highly complex and full of corner cases. Furthermore, client-side JavaScript programs have access to an ever-growing number of browser APIs, making them extremely hard to analyse and debug.   
Preact [3] is a modern, compact and light version of React [4], a library created by Facebook for developing user interfaces. Despite its small size, Preact is extremely popular and widely used by large companies, such as Uber, Groupon, Domino’s and Pepsi. The library is a client of the DOM [5], an API designed by W3C to allow the manipulation of HTML and XML documents via JavaScript code. 
At Imperial College London, the Verified Trustworthy Software Specification group developed JaVerT [6,7], a JavaScript compositional symbolic execution tool with support for verification [8], symbolic execution [9,13], and bi-abduction [10]. JaVerT has gathered interest from researchers both in academia and in industry. It has been the topic of several publications in top-level Programming Language (PL) venues, won a Facebook research award [11], and is currently being used to verify the Amazon AWS Encryption SDK [10].
Recently, JaVerT has been extended with a core events module that was used to implement DOM UI events and JavaScript promises. The **goal** of this project is to continue this line of work, applying the approach to symbolically analyse React and its open-source clients. The project will consist of the following three main tasks. Firstly, the student will extend the DOM reference implementation in JavaScript to cover Preact’s constructs. Then, the student will perform a study by mining relevant open-source Preact projects in GitHub. Finally, the student will design symbolic tests for the respective projects, with the goal of identifying bugs and antipatterns in web development.

title: Dissertation: Boosting the Ethereum blockchain with hybrid consistency
observations: Possibility of a research grant.
objectives:
Ethereum, like the vast majority of such various permissionless blockchains, relies on the same general design foundations as Nakamoto's seminal proposal. 

The Red-Blue Chain is an ongoing project at our team at INESC-ID. The key insight of Red-Blue Chain is to extend Ethereum to offer two views, each with distinct consistency properties: a strongly-consistent red view and a weaker blue view. When an application submits a transaction to update the replicated data maintained by the blockchain, or when it reads from that state, the application speci fies which view it wishes to access depending on how much consistency it needs. The red view is sequentially consistent and is implemented, at a considerable latency, by the original consensus protocol.

The blue view, in turn, provides causal consistency, while also preventing censorship and double-spending anomalies. Since the blue view does not require consensus, its latency is orders of magnitude lower than the red view.

Once ready, the Red-Blue Chain framework will boost the performance of existing Ethereum applications for which the properties ensured by the blue view are well-known to be enough. Cryptocurrencies are one such example. Furthermore, we envision that a much wider class of applications (most notably, smart-contract-based applications) may be redesigned in order to also bene fit from the Red-Blue Chain framework.

This thesis will design and implement new abstractions that take full advantage of the fast path provided by the blue view. These abstractions will be available, as libraries, to Ethereum smart contract programmers to invoke in their new programs.
More precisely, the thesis will consider one of two options (to be chosen during the thesis work):

a) Conflict-free replicated data types (CRDTs) for Red-Blue Chain
To adapt well-studied CRDT implementations to the context of Ethereum smart contracts, taking the associated programming restrictions into account. The resulting CRDT smart contracts will enable new smart contracts to declare and invoke our CRDT to maintain and access their shared data. The key advantage of smart contracts built on the devised CRDTs (instead of regular data types) is that their methods will become safe to execute on the blue view -- even despite
the weaker semantics of this view, which do not provide agreement on a total order among transactions that are visible through the blue view.
References:
https://hal.inria.fr/hal-00932836/file/CRDTs_SSS-2011.pdf
https://hal.inria.fr/inria-00555588/document

b) Agreement by epidemic voting (AEV): A relevant class of smart contracts needs to have a set of users (of a smart contract) agree on a consensual value, among one or more values proposed by di erent users. A traditional approach to reach this consensus is by having users vote for their desired outcome and wait for the blockchain commit to reach a decision. The blue view of Red-Blue Chain provides an alternative means to support such voting algorithms much earlier than the expensive commit of the blockchain. More precisely, Keleher et al. have proposed epidemic voting protocols (in the scope of non-byzantine mobile systems) whose correctness requirements happen to be met by the blue view of Red-Blue Chain. Hence, by enhancing permissionless blockchains with a hybrid consistency model, we will enable smart contracts to employ these protocols to support voting-based agreement. In particular, we will design and implement an appropriate abstraction that will provide this novel feature as a smart contract library.

References:
https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/301308.301345

title: Dissertation: Automated Detection of Security Issues in Infrastructure as Code Artifacts
objectives:
Modern and scalable applications use so-called infrastructure as code (IaC) scripts to provision servers and development environments. 
Commercial IaC tool vendors, such as Chef and Puppet, provide programming syntax and libraries so that programmers can specify configuration and dependency information as scripts.

The use of IaC scripts is essential to efficiently maintain servers and development environments. For example, the Fortune 500 company  Intercontinental Exchange (ICE), which runs millions of financial transactions daily, maintains 75% of its 20,000 servers using
IaC scripts. The use of IaC scripts has helped ICE decrease the time needed to provision development environments from 1∼2 days to 21 minutes [0].

Despite the clear advantages, while developing IaC scripts, practitioners may inadvertently introduce security issues that can potentially lead to security breaches. Examples include the use of hard-coded secrets, invalid IP bindings, and use of weak cryptographic algorithms.

The goal of this project is to develop a tool capable of automatically detecting security issues in IaC scripts. This project will be developed in collaboration with Unbabel, a company that is developing an artificial intelligence-powered human translation platform (https://unbabel.com). The company has headquarters in Lisbon, Portugal, and San Francisco, California. 

The project will also explore how to deliver the tool as a service (e.g. a Github bot).


Recommended Reading

title: [Dissertação] Exploit Generation for WebAssembly with SE-based Taint Tracking

objectives:
WebAssembly is an emerging technology that promises to bring radical changes to the Web. Currently supported by all major browsers, it consists of a new web standard that defines a low-level binary instruction format and a corresponding assembly-like text format for the executable code in web pages. WebAssembly code can execute nearly as fast as running native code, enabling it to complement JavaScript to speed up performance-critical parts of web applications. However, WebAssembly may bring unexpected security risks. In particular, given that it is compiled from unsafe languages namely C/C++, vulnerabilities presumably extinct with a growing adoption of memory-safe languages like Java, will resurface on the Web under a new guise. In fact, despite WebAssembly's protection mechanisms, some C/C++ coding flaws can still transition into WebAssembly code, for instance buffer overflows, format string bugs, or use-after-free errors. If such flaws exist and can be exploitable, an attacker can leverage them in new ways for launching Web-based attacks such as cross-site scripting. To assess the security impact of existing vulnerabilities, an effective approach is to automatically generate exploits. The synthetic exploits will unambiguously demonstrate that a given vulnerability is security critical, hence its fixing must be prioritized.

The goal of this thesis is to build SWAT, a tool for automatic Synthesis of WebAssembly exploiTs. Our general approach will be to leverage symbolic execution to check Wasm program paths for exploitability properties. This work will proceed in two steps. First, we will extend the WASP symbolic execution engine with support for symbolic taint tracking in Wasm. This technique will allow us to identify security attacks that take advantage of illegal information flows. To tackle the scalability problem of path selection, we will devise path-selection heuristics to guide the program's execution to favor the selection of vulnerable paths in early exploration stages. Second, we will leverage symbolic taint tracking for constructing a sequence of crafted inputs that direct an application's execution to a vulnerable sink. This process will be steered by specific exploitability goals that depend on the type of targeted vulnerabilities. This work will begin with the generation of simple exploits for basic vulnerabilities, and then, time permitting, increase their complexity. For symbolic execution, we will use WASP, the symbolic execution engine currently under development by our team. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. The resulting system will be released as an open source project. If you like programming languages, security, and web programming, this is the right topic for you.
requirements: Interest in programing languages and web application programming. Willingness to learn WebAssembly.

title: Dissertação: GPU based accelerated model checking
objectives:
The verification of discrete event systems have been studied through a combination of simulation and formal methods using a number of software tools. In particular, model checking has been used for more than 30 years for the analysis and verification of both software and hardware systems.

GPU accelerators are highly specialized and highly parallel hardware to perform imaged-based operations. Due to its nature, GPU accelerators have been successfully used to accelerate tasks in various domains.

Efficient symbolic model checkers, such as NuSMV, represent state transition functions using Binary Decision Diagrams (BDDs), an a tree-like efficient discrete data structure. Careful analyses have shown BDD operations represent most of CPU time, being the natural candidate operations to be parallelized. Specially due to the high reuse of smaller BDDs by new bigger ones.

In this thesis the focus is on the optimization the model-checker (http://lvl.info.ucl.ac.be/Tools/NuSMV-ARCTL-TLACE) used in the verification of mixed transition systems, and on the implementation of the most computational intensive parts (the BDD operations) on the GPU accelerator.

It is expected to have a GPU based model checker at the end of the thesis.
requirements: Good programming skills and interest in GPU-based accelerators is a plus.

title: [Dissertation] TimeWarp - Studying animated transitions between time compressed vis
objectives:
As técnicas tradicionais para visualização de informação lidam com conjuntos de dados conhecidos à partida e de pequenas dimensões (mesmo milhares de items é pouco, neste contexto). Se quisermos visualizar Big Data precisamos de algo novo. Temos já uma abordagem que permite ir agregando os dados progressivamente. Cada visualização representa um intervalo de tempo. À direita é real-time, imediatamente a seguir podemos estar a olhar para um agregado dos últimos minutos, em seguida das últimas horas, etc. Mas importa que não se perca o contexto, que se perceba para onde vão os valores…

O objetivo é estudar a resiliência e compreensibilidade de transições animadas entre visualizações representado dados com diferentes níveis de agregação temporal.

Sem que se perca o contexto da análise, quais as transições entre os idiomas visuais que funcionam melhor entre diferentes escalas de compressão? Passar de segundos para minutos é diferente de passer de segundos diretamente para horas. Que técnicas funcionam melhor em que contexto? Deverão ser concebidas as transições, implementadas e (foco principal) feitos os user studies que respondam a estas perguntas! Já existe um sistema que suporta transições, que servirá de base para este trabalho.

title: [Dissertação] Constraint-based Techniques for Finding Representations for Multiobjective Combinatorial Optimization Problems
observations: Andreia Próspero Guerreiro, andreia.guerreiro@ist.utl.pt
objectives:
In multiobjective optimization problems, the goal is to find the solutions that simultaneously optimize two or more objective functions. One example is the problem of finding a route that simultaneously minimizes fuel consumption and travel time. Due to the usually conflicting nature of objectives, typically there is not a single optimal solution, but a set of optimal solutions. Each optimal solution in this set is better than any other in some objective but worse in another objective. The set of optimal solutions may be large, and the Decision Maker (the person, or entity wanting to finding a solution to the problem) is not interested, or cannot analyze, all of them. To overcome this, the goal becomes to find a good subset of optimal solutions, called a representation, to present to the Decision Maker.

The notion of a good representation is frequently linked to quality indicators that map the quality of a set of solutions to a value that reflects the quality of such a set. Multiobjective optimization algorithms that directly search for a representation, and in particular, for a subset of solutions that maximize a given indicator, without the need to enumerate all optimal solutions, are of interest. The goal of this thesis is the development of new constraint-based multiobjective optimization algorithms for finding representations.

title: Dissertação: Vertex Connection and Merging with Vulkan
objectives:
Motivation:
Physically based rendering algorithms are capable of producing high quality images of virtual environments. Since its introduction Vertex Connection and Merging (VCM) has proven itself to be one of the premier rendering algorithms for realistic global illumination offline rendering. It is currently available in such applications as Pixar’s RenderMan and it has been used internally in the movie industry by companies such as Weta Digital (e.g. in The Hobbit). 

Objective: 
The goal of this thesis is to provide an overview of the Vertex Connection and Merging (VCM) [1]  algorithm which combines the benefits of Bidirectional Path Tracing and Photon Mapping, and to describe an implementation of it by using low level Vulkan API capable to achieve real-time performance.
[1] - Iliyan Georgiev, Jaroslav Křivánek, Tomáš Davidovič, and Philipp Slusallek. “Light Transport Simulation with Vertex Connection and Merging.” ACM Trans. Graph. (SIGGRAPH Asia 2012) 31, 6 (2012)

Description:
The implementation of VCM should be done by using the Vulkan Ray Tracing Extensions released by the Khronos Group in March 2020 (https://www.khronos.org/blog/ray-tracing-in-vulkan). Falcor (https://developer.nvidia.com/falcor), which is an open-source real-time rendering framework designed specifically for rapid prototyping, should be also considered during the development.

title: [DISSERTAÇÃO] Efficient transfer in model-based reinforcement learning
observations:
- Description - 

RL algorithms can roughly be categorized as model-free and model-based. And while most of the recent success stories of RL rely on model-free approaches, it is a well-known fact that model-based ap- proaches typically exhibit better sample efficiency and are more transferable [4]. In a recent work, Ha and Schmidhuber proposed a model-based approach inspired by human mental models that at- tained competitive performance in two difficult tasks [1]. The proposed approach includes two key modules: a visual processing module that translates the perceptual information of the agent to an internal representation; and a memory module that corresponds to the agent’s internal model of the world’s dynamics. Based on the information from these two modules, the paper goes on to show that a simple controller is able to attain state-of-the-art results in two complex tasks.

In this work, the student will depart from the aforementioned work and investigate inter-task transfer using model based reinforcement learning. In particular, the student will explore model-based RL in different (but similar) tasks from OpenAI Gym and investigate the ability of such models to create common internal representations that are common across tasks, exploring the notion of disentangled representations [2]. In this context, the student will then consider the impact of such common representations in learning new tasks, along the lines of [3].

- References -

[1] D. Ha, J. Schmidhuber. “Recurrent world models facilitate policy evolution.” In Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 31, pp. 2450-2462, 2018.

[2] I. Higgins, L. Matthey, A. Pal, C. Burgess, X. Glorot, M. Botvinick, S. Mohamed, A. Lerchner. “β-VAE: Learning basic visual concepts with a constrained variational framework”. In Proc. 5th Int. Conf. Learning Representations, 2017.

[3] J. Ribeiro, F. Melo, J. Dias. “Multi-task learning and catastrophic forgetting in continual reinforcement learning.” In Proc. 5th Global Conf. Artificial Intelligence, pp. 163-175, 2019.

[4] T. Wang, X. Bao, I. Clavera, J. Hoang, Y. Wen, E. Langlois, S. Zhang, G. Zhang, P. Abbeel, and J. Ba. Benchmarking model-based reinforcement learning. CoRR, abs/1907.02057, 2019.
requirements: This thesis topic is conceptually quite complex. Interested students should be very comfortable with reinforcement learning and deep learning, as provided in courses such as PADI and Aprendizagem.

objectives:
Enquadramento: 
As growing costs pressure health systems, mainly due to an ageing population, the rise of the private medical service providers has been growing in Portugal.  In 2013, nearly half of Portugal’s hospitals were private. Over the last ten years, private hospitals have grown in consultations, number of beds, emergency rooms and diagnostic tests. The number of outpatient medical consultations increased steadily between 2002 and 2013, from 9,8 million to 17,6 million visits, with private hospitals accounting for 5,1 million consultations, 29% of the total. 
The growth of private health insurance, reduced waiting times and advanced technology, are among the main growth drivers for private medical service providers.
Although major private medical service providers in Portugal have an electronic reservation system, the process of booking a medical consultation is generally a tedious process and always limited to the service provider’s ecosystem. 
MedClick will provide a one-stop platform to book a medical appointment in a fast and user friendly way, across multiple medical service providers. Whether on a PC, tablet or smartphone, patients will be able to conveniently browse all available booking options, based on date, location, price, insurance providers, or customer reviews and recommendations. 
MedClick will be available in English and Portuguese and will also provide doctor data such as languages spoken, years of experience, accreditations, awards and professional background, to ensure our patients make the best choice.
MedClick will help medical service providers increase the efficiency of their practices, by featuring an advanced platform to manage and explore scheduling flexibility, filling available time slots.

title: Dissertação: Harnessing the power of modern heterogeneous multi-core shared-memory systems with tasks with data dependencies
observations: Possibility of a research grant.
objectives:
The full power of modern multi-core systems and accelerators (e.g. GPUs and/or FPGAs) can only be exploited by applications that expose high levels of parallelism. The paradigm of tasks with dependencies is seen as one of the most promising ways of achieving unprecedented parallelism levels in irregular HPC applications. Still, that promise is yet to be validated.

This thesis aims at evaluating the potential of the task with dependencies programming model when applied to the Particle-In-Cell (PIC) method, a well studied means of investigating the behaviour of different kinds of systems involving electrons, ions, neutrals, molecules, dust particles, etc.

Departing from a lower-level solution of PIC, the thesis will design and implement a variant code that relies on tasks with dependencies, eventually running on a set of heterogeneous computational nodes. An experimental evaluation will shed new light on the actual gains (and costs) of this paradigm. Experiments may include both regular shared-memory systems, and distributed shared-memory systems.

https://epeec-project.eu
https://pm.bsc.es/ompss

title: Dissertação: Using Bounded Staleness to Accelerate GASPI-based Bayesian Matrix Factorization
observations: Aluno: Rafael Pestana de Andrade
objectives:
The goal of this thesis is to adapt GASPI-based applications that are
based on an iterative and convergent paradigm to the bounded staleness
processing model. In particular, we will start by studying the SMURFF
application, which uses Bayesian Matrix Factorization in the context
of compound-activity prediction. This application will be adapted to
using an all reduce collective from the GASPI platform, which can then
easily be turned to a bounded staleness enabled all reduce, to
implement the desired model. Then we will have to undergo a careful
evaluation of the performance under the new model, to try to optimize
the performance. Finally, time permitting, we will also analyze other
applications and attempt to apply weakly-consistent collectives to
speed up their performance.

title: Dissertação: Separating Agreement from Execution to Improve the Scalability of Blockchains
observations: Aluno: Diogo Fernandes ist186410
objectives: Existing Blockchains are based on monolithic designs that compound different concerns and features into a single design, implementation, and set of protocols, with consensus-based state machine replication protocols at their core. One of the negative consequences of this fact is that it becomes hard to scale up Blockchain protocols, since scalability bottlenecks become harder to identify and address. This thesis takes the dogmatic stance that consensus-based state machine replication should cleanly separate agreement for execution, and applies this principle to the design of Blockchain systems, with the goal of understanding the implications of this principle in the scalability of existing Blockchains.

title: (Project) Workflow for processing historic digitised works at the United Nations
location: INESC-ID Alameda or TagusPark (opportunity for a visit to ARMS in New York during the second semester of the project)
observations:
This is expected to be an engineering project, to build a framework based on state of the art existing technology
The research will comprise to raise a state of the art of technology for OCR, like for example Tesseract: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesseract_(software), open-source tools for image processing in general (e.g., to improve contrast, etc.), for PDF generation (including an interesting challenge in merging on the same PDF file the text from multiple OCR tasks), etc.
The results will be immediately used by ARMS:
- https://archives.un.org/
But will also be disseminated by:
- UN Technology Bank: https://www.un.org/technologybank/
- The archive of the League of Nations (a twin of ARMS in Geneva): https://libraryresources.unog.ch/leagueofnationsarchives
- The other entities of the UN Systems https://www.unsystem.org/content/un-system
objectives:
The mission of historical archives is to curate and provide access to unique collections of information of intemporal permanent value. In principle, each archive is unique, making the global access to paper born collections a challenge. A solution for that is to digitise those collections and publish them on-line.
The Archives and Records Management Service (ARMS) of the United Nations curates unique historical archives of the United Nations (what will be 75 year hold in 2020). ARMS has been digitising some of those documents (so far >10 million images and >5 TBytes, but needs a proper automated workflow to process the digitised images for an optimal on-line publishing and search, ideally all based on open-source software (reusing existing components or new developed ones). Problems are at three domains: 
- OCR (Optical Character Recognition): some documents have complex layouts; collections can be in several languages
- Document size: some documents can be of hundreds or thousands of pages, of several sizes (fotos, diplomatic cable, investigation reports, etc.)
- Legibility: almost all documents with text are printed/typed, but some are quite old  
 The results of the project are expected to inform ARMS for the re-engineering of its future improved digital archive, which for now has only a minimal functionality: https://search.archives.un.org/
requirements: Experience or willing to learn in detail programming with common languages (mainly JavaScritp for front-ends, as also at least one common language for back-end services, as Java, Python, etc.). Interest in learning about OCR (Optical Character Recognition) with machine learning techniques, and learning about fundamental image processing techniques, especially to improve readability of digitised documents (mainly for PDF/A files, but also to explore other solutions such as for example for "flip page": https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flip_page).Work will be done in close collaboration with ARMS team in New York (video-conference, with communication in English, opportunity for a visit to ARMS in New York during the second semester of the project).

title: My "robot conversation partner" - Development of time-based cues for elderly-robot interaction
location: VisLab, Instituto de Sistemas e Robótica, IST
objectives: Research, Design and implement apt strategies for interaction between elderly and humanoid robots. The study aims at capturing natural elderly-person synergies in order to create scenarios and eventually derives cues for natural elederly-robot interactions,  leveraging of the animated character looking feature of the robot Vizzy .  On one hand we strive towards designing a Elderly-Robots interactions that are cognitively stimulating, emotionally rich and entertaining for the elderly. On the other hand, we aim at supporting the nursing staff taking care of the elderly in several tasks, including, entertaining, and tracking several health and bio metrics of the person.  The research process will unfold as the following (i) Record and analyze interactions between elderly and their younger relatives in natural settings; Data will be collected by means of immersive research (observations, video analysis, interviews etc). The analysis will provide a set of dialog scripts that will be added to natural language processing tools. (ii) Design at least two dialog scenarios where the elderly will interact fully or partially with the robot in an autonomous way. (iii)  Implement the interaction cues and apply them in a study where the robot interacts with the elderly in the designed scenarios.

title: Dissertation: Trustworthy Machine Learning in the Cloud
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Paolo Romano (romano@inesc-id.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
The training phase of modern machine learning (ML) jobs often requires to process large-scale datasets which may contain private and sensitive information of customers. This imposes significant security risks since modern online services rely on cloud computing to store and process the sensitive data. In the untrusted computing infrastructure, security is becoming a paramount concern since the customers need to trust the thirdparty cloud provider. 

This thesis aims at addressing this critical concern by designing a new hardware-assisted approach based on Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs), specifically Intel SGX, to enable secure execution of the machine learning computations over the private and sensitive datasets.

Thanks to the use of TEEs, the data owner can still use cloud resources to build the ML model if it can ship the data encrypted to the cloud. The ML model is built and queried in the cloud by a trusted component that cannot be compromised, not even by the cloud provider with physical and privileged access to the system, and whose integrity can be securely attested by the data owner. The use of TEEs to offer privacy preserving ML has started to be explored in the literature very recently [1], but it is still constrained by a number of limitations of the current technology.

In particular, a major limitation of current state of the art solutions is that they are unable to take advantage of GPUs, which represent the de facto standard for training complex models, e.g., based on deep neural networks.

This thesis will aim at addressing this important limitation of existing TEE-based machine learning frameworks by exploiting a novel method, conceived at INESC-ID, based on the use of data anonymization techniques.

title: [Dissertation] A Scalable Stream Vector extension for the RISC-V instruction set
observations:
- Assignment of this thesis is subject to a prior informal interview with the candidate to assess his motivation and prior knowledge in the fields of research
- This thesis involves challenging aspects recognized by the scientific community; accordingly, the outcome of this work may give rise to the publication of scientific articles.
objectives:
The widespread use of large information sources and storage devices has led to the development of new application domains to process large datasets, either in a distributed fashion (e.g. the edge), or centralized in large computing centers. However, this poses significant computing problems, not only due to increased performance requirements, but also because climate changes call for a significant world-wide reduction in energy consumption. In fact, the Green500 supercomputer list indicates that the most energy-efficient supercomputer attains an efficiency of 17GFLOPS/W, far from the 2015 predefined settings for exascale systems (50GFLOPS/W).

However, achieving significant energy efficiency improvements on general-purpose applications is not easily achievable with current paradigms. Hence, unconventional approaches are now vital. This thesis targets the development of a new Stream Scalable Vector (SSV) instruction set extension, to be integrated with RISC-V, and designed to be deployed on different accelerators, enabling the same code to target different PEs. Additionally, the envisaged SSV extension considers that application memory access patterns can often be described in compile-time and encoded in descriptor representations. This provides a timely and accurate prefetching of data, significantly improving application performance and decreasing energy consumption, even when compared with complex dynamic prefetching solutions that attempt to identify the patterns in real-time. 

The envisaged SSV extension also considers a set of hint instructions to provide information regarding each application kernel characteristics and requirements to the PEs. This provides the means for an informed dynamic offloading of kernels and also promotes opportunities to power-gate unused circuits (saving power) and to deploy decoupled V-F scaling methodologies (improving performance and/or saving energy).

objectives:
Energy management is becoming a priority as organizations strive to reduce energy costs, conform to regulatory requirements, and improve their corporate image. Despite the upsurge of interest in energy management standards, a gap persists between energy management literature and current implementation practices. title: Dissertation: Speech as a health biomarker
objectives: The potential of speech as a biomarker for health has been realized for diseases affecting respiratory organs, such as the common Cold, or OSA, for mood disorders such as Depression, and Bipolar Disease, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s, Huntington’s disease, or ALS. The purpose of this task is to use this potential to automatically detect symptoms of sleep disorders in speech.  Some of these symptoms are visible in features that may be automatically extracted from the acoustic signal: prosodic features, voice quality features, and spectral features  (e.g., pitch, energy, resonance frequencies, jitter, harmonicity, speech rate, pause duration, etc.). Other symptoms may also be visible in the analysis of the text that is automatically produced by a speech recognition system. This analysis may also show signs of sleep deprivation, depression, or cognitive decline, among many other cues. The objective of this thesis proposal is the development of an app for  analyzing speech as a biomarker of speech affecting diseases. This app should be integrated with other remote health monitoring apps that already collect a wide range of other biosignals.

title: Dissertação: Helmholtz Machines Revisited
objectives:
Helmholtz machines are artificial neural networks that, through many cycles of sensing and dreaming, gradually learn to make their dreams converge to reality, and, in the process, create a succinct internal model of a fluctuating world. 
Discovering the structure inherent in a set of patterns is a fundamental aim of statistical inference or learning. One fruitful approach is to build a parameterized stochastic generative model, independent draws from which are likely to produce the patterns. For all but the simplest generative models, each pattern can be generated in exponentially many ways. It is thus intractable to adjust the parameters to maximize the probability of the observed patterns.

title: Dissertation: Reproducible fault-injection on distributed systems
objectives:
Nowadays, large-scale systems are composed of  10s to 100s and even 1000s of nodes that are distributed across the globe. To ensure availability and reliability, such systems must be resilient to faults (such as crashing, network partitioning, etc..) that are common in production environments. 

Unfortunately, debugging and testing the fault-tolerance guarantees of distributed systems is a notoriously complex task.
For instance, one might test the same system two times with the same fault and observed different behaviors - for instance, one time the fault leads to an error in the systems, and the other time the system behaves correctly.
This is due to the non-deterministic nature of distributed systems, where the same fault may not always hamper their correctness or performance. Accordingly, to ensure rigorous testing, we need to be able to deterministically reproduce faults that persist within the system. 

The goal of this thesis proposal is to explore the internal state of a system (via system calls, I/O, logs, etc.) to synchronize fault injection with the state, in order to enable engineers to correctly reproduce - and fix- incorrect system behavior.

title: [Dissertation] A Live JavaScript Specification
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/
objectives:
JavaScript is the de facto programming language of the Web. Not only is it widely used for client-side programming [1], but it is also used for programming server-side applications via Node.js and it even runs on small embedded devices. 

To guarantee that JavaScript programs behave consistently across all platforms, the major browser vendors very early agreed to standardise the language, creating the ECMAScript standard [2]. The ECMAScript standard, currently in its 10th edition, is a long, complex document, written in English, which describes the syntax and semantics of JavaScript. It is written as if it were the pseudo-code of a JavaScript interpreter in that it describes each statement of the language operationally, detailing each step of the evaluation. 

All the major JavaScript stakeholders (browser vendors, web security companies, governmental agencies, international research groups, etc) accept the ECMAScript standard to be the canonical version of the language and try to conform to it as closely as possible in their own implementations and models. This makes the ECMAScript standard one of the cornerstones of the internet of today. Despite its importance, the ECMAScript standard is in constant change. In fact, the ECMA Committee holds various meetings during the year to discuss modifications and additions to the standard in response to requests from the JavaScript community. These modifications and additions must then be propagated to the implementations of the language, which is often highly non-trivial as these implementations rely on various optimisation strategies in order to be as performant as possible [3,4]. 

The **goal** of this project is to design and implement a mechanism to semi-automatically generate an executable version of the standard, the Live JavaScript Specification, from its official textual description. The Live JavaScript Specification will be primarily used as an oracle to test other implementations of the language, thereby contributing to the effort of making JavaScript run uniformly and correctly across all platforms. Further applications can also be envisaged; for instance, one could use the Live JavaScript Specification as a stepping stone for automatically synthesising a correct-by-construction JavaScript compiler [5] or an official language test-suite. 

This project will consist of three main tasks. First, the student will design and implement ECMA-SL, a domain-specific language [6] for specifying and running the ECMAScript standard. Then, the student will apply rule-based natural language processing techniques to (semi)-automatically obtain a JavaScript interpreter written in ECMA-SL from the textual description of the standard. Lastly, the student will test the obtained interpreter against Test262 [8], the official JavaScript test suite.

[2] ECMAScript Committee. The 10th Edition of the ECMAScript Language Specification. ECMA. 2019.

[4] T. Rompf et al. Surgical Precision JIT Compilers. PLDI’14. 
[5] N. Jones et al. Partial Evaluation and Automatic Program Generation. Prentice Hall. 1999.
[6] M. Mernik et al. When and How to Develop Domain Specific Languages. ACM Computing Surveys. 2005.

This thesis is going to be developed in the context of project DE4A in which INESC-ID (an IST research unit) is a participant (https://www.de4a.eu/). The thesis will be developed in the #SecDep Team ( https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~mpc/team.html ), in the Distributed Systems Group ( https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/ ), at INESC-ID (https://www.inesc-id.pt/).

The European Union is promoting the automation of processes that involve transferring documents between countries. Security is a critical aspect. Project DE4A aims to automate processes related to university students that move from one country to another, while ensuring the authenticity of the documents presented (e.g., the bachelor or master certificate).

This thesis is about one of the two directions of that process: a student moving from IST to a university abroad after finishing his bachelor or master (licenciatura, mestrado).

The thesis has two aspects: 

The first is to implement a server that is called by the system of the university abroad. 
The server asks the student to authenticate in Fénix, accesses Fénix using its APIs, and obtains the information about the program the student finished at IST. 
The communication with the university abroad is not part of the project (its a component that already exists, a Docker container with REST API). The project focus on the server and its interaction with the student and Fénix.

The second aspect has to do with the objective of putting the server online: it has to be very secure, as there are many hackers that may be willing to attack it. Therefore, the second aspect involves architecting the security of the server: defining a methodology to protect online services (adapted from existing methodologies), and implementing that methodology to protect the server.

The work plan has the following phases:
- Study of the background and related work
- Design and implementation of the server and methodology
- Experimental evaluation 
- Writing of the thesis and a scientific article

title: Dissertation: Agents for Good: agents in a game for the good of humanity
observations: Interesse pela área de Inteligência Artificial e de Agentes.
objectives:
Imaginemos um mundo virtual populado por agentes autónomos e humanos, que tenta replicar um ecossistema  caracterizado pela existência de recursos nesse mesmo ambiente. Nesse mundo virtual há recursos  são limitados.
O objetivo desta tese é explorar a simulação social baseada em agentes em ambientes virtuais, e ver que tipos de acções e comportamentos os agentes podem existir (por exemplo, através de emoções, ou de expressão cultural) de forma a de forma a estudar qual será a melhor forma de garantir que os agentes não consomem os recursos até à exaustão. Assim, o objetivo é criar agentes prosociais que influenciam os utilizadores (pessoas a jogar nesse ambiente virtual) de forma a que a população evolva para um estado de que garante a preservação dos recursos existentes. Podemos aplicar este caso a um jogo/mundo em que o objetivo é salvar o planeta (e replicar de certa forma um Common Pool Resources Dillemma- CPR).  
 
A tese será desenvolvida em 6 fases:
- Pesquisa bibliográfica sobre a área de agentes em ambientes virtuais bem como em CPR e simulação social baseada em agentes
- Criação/adopção de um jogo que permita fazer a simulação num mundo virtual (3d) em que cada participante terá um avatar e os agentes também vivem nesse ambiente
- Estudo de diferentes configurações de agentes com diferentes arquiteturas
- Desenhar um mundo virtual (3D) baseado nos CPRs e que permita os agentes levarem os humanos à prosocialidade
- Estudo com humanos no jogo de forma a explorar como é que numa população híbrida (de humanos e agentes) emerge a prosocialidade

Descrição geral do projeto:

Pretende-se a identificação dos principais stakeholders, processos, e objectivos do domínio da água, bem como a identificação dos principais recursos digitais existentes (i.e., bases de dados ou repositórios de informação), e a sua caracterização através de metadados adequados. Para este efeito deverão ser considerados standards na área, tal como o WaterML 2.0 do Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC).
Particularmente, serão considerados recursos digitais produzidos e mantidos pela APA, nomeadamente no âmbito do seu sistema SNIRH (https://snirh.apambiente.pt/). Serão ainda considerados recursos obtidos através de outras fontes de dados, tais como imagens de satélite e imagens obtidas através de crowdsourcing ou por recuperação de redes sociais, tais como Flickr, Twitter, ou Instagram, com a correspondende extração e classificação automática de etiquetas e metadados (e.g., de localização).
Os recursos digitais mantidos neste sistema deverão providenciar mecanismos de interoperabilidade com aplicações terceiras, nomeadamente com ferramentas de análise e simulação de fenómenos naturais, tais como inundações, tsunamis, ou secas extremas.

Os principais resultados deste projeto são:
- Conceção do GeoPortal Colaborativo;
- Implementação do GeoPortal Colaborativo (com tecnologias como Python, Django, GeoDjango, Leaflet)
- Implementação de mecanismos de interoperabilidade com ferramentas externas;
- Testes e avaliação com base em dataset a definir; 
- Artigo a submeter a conferência internacional.

Keywords: Information Management; Geographic Information; Geo Data Science; Water; Climate Change; Sustainability.
