title: [Dissertação] Anti-DDoS for the IoT
objectives:
Denial of Service (DoS) attacks are becoming common with sensor networks and IoT. This is because a wide number of wireless sensors being deployed have low or no security at all. Some may have enough security, from an initial assessment, but that may only be authentication or encryption related. Since, DoS attacks are a different class of attacks affecting Availability so, the mechanisms to defend against them will require separate solutions. 

Some of the DoS attacks associated, which may be launched on a sensor network or an IoT system, are :
1.	Replay, 
2.	Man-in-the-Middle (MiM), 
3.	Flooding,
4.	Masquerade attack, 
5.	Blackhole / Selective Forwarding / Wormhole
6.	Jamming,
7.	Power analysis on the mote (e.g. side-channel attack) 

Here it is important to assess which DoS attacks can affect SureThing IoT system the most. An investigative study on this classification will be beneficial for this IoT system.

A DoS attack usually consists of one to one entity i.e. one attacker and one victim. While a Distributed DoS encompasses a many-to-one relationship between its entities. For example, in (Biggest-ever DDoS attack takes down high-profile web services, 2016) the DDoS exploits multiple entities i.e. IoT devices.

So, the scenarios that arise out of these relationships are as follows:
1.	An attacker using multiple devices in an IoT system to attack another device (Computer / server / vital sensor), or
2.	An attacker using its own network of computers or devices to attack a device in an IoT system (a vital sensor / a gateway device)

The goal of this work is to investigate and classify DoS attacks that are most applicable to the SureThing IoT system from a Distributed DoS perspective. The resulting output should provide a list of attacks and prioritise them based on research. This output should also be used to come up with an accepted prototype solution for one out of the top three priority attacks on that list.

Referências:
Roland Atoui, “IoT Botnets and DDoS Attacks: Architecting Against Disaster”, IoT for all 
https://www.iotforall.com/iot-botnets-ddos-attack-architecture/

Biggest-ever DDoS attack takes down high-profile web services. (2016). Computer Fraud & Security, 2016(11), 1,3.

Imperva (accessed 2020). Distributed denial of service attack (DDoS) definition. url: https://www.imperva.com/learn/application-security/ddos-attacks/

Mahjabin, Tasnuva & Xiao, Yang & Sun, Guang & Jiang, Wangdong. (2017). A survey of distributed denial-of-service attack, prevention, and mitigation techniques. International Journal of Distributed Sensor Networks. 2017(13). 155014771774146. 10.1177/1550147717741463.

Mathur, A.; Newe, T.; Rao, M. (2016). Defence against Black Hole and Selective Forwarding Attacks for Medical WSNs in the IoT. Sensors, 2016(16), 118.

title: Dissertação: Método Monte-Carlo para o Cálculo Distribuído da Exponencial de uma Matriz
observations: Co-orientação externa: Prof. Juan Acebron, ISCTE (Juan.Acebron@iscte-iul.pt)
objectives:
Os métodos de Monte Carlo são muitas vezes usados como alternativa aos métodos clássicos para resolver problemas intratáveis. Recentemente foi proposta uma nova abordagem Monte Carlo para o cálculo da função exponencial sobre uma matriz. Este novo método consegue cálcular posições individuais da matriz resultado, permitindo a resolução de problemas significativamente mais complexos. Embora em muitos casos a matriz original seja esparsa, a matriz resultado já não o será, portanto não representável em memória por ser demasiado grande, inviabilizando os métodos clássicos.

O objetivo desta tese é desenvolver um algoritmo Monte Carlo distribuído para o cálculo da exponencial da uma matriz aplicado à resolução das equações de estado de sistemas dinâmicos. A matriz resultado permitirá o cálculo direto do valor das variáveis de estado em qualquer instante de tempo para qualquer nó do circuito. Esta abordagem poderá ser significativamente mais eficiente do que as metodologias atuais, que envolvem a simulação numérica de equações complexas em intervalos discretos de tempo até se chegar ao instante pretendido.
requirements: A frequência da unidade curricular de Computação Paralela e Distribuída é desejável embora não obrigatória. Interesse em computação paralela é um requisito.

title: Dissertation: Automatic Evaluation of Human Post-Editors of Machine Translated Text
observations: José Souza: jose.souza@unbabel.com (orientador externo)
objectives:
Current translation workflows in the translation industry use machine translation and human translators. Machine translation systems generate a translation and the human translators correct, i.e., post-edit the machine translated sentences. This process brings both speed and quality as outcomes. An open problem is how to evaluate the human translators (or editors). They can come from several backgrounds, have different language level proficiency and varied seniority. Editors that are less attentive might produce problematic translations or let problematic machine-generated translations pass and this becomes a quality problem. Identifying what editors are most effective in terms of translation quality and whether editors share traits conditioned to the translation quality level they produce is still an open problem. The work in this thesis is about designing and developing approaches to automatic profiling and evaluating translation editors. It builds on previous work [1] which proposed a way to represent editors based on the keystrokes used to correct the translations. One possible next step is to leverage these representations to build models that can identify what editors are considered to produce good or bad quality post-editions/translations, for example. For that, it might be necessary to identify what kind of characteristics, metadata or other information beyond the keystroke representation is important to recognize an effective editor. The translation flows and the representations are based on data flows coming from "real world environments" and are provided by Unbabel. 

[1] https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.10362

title: [Dissertação] : Reasoning and Inferring Relations Between Natural Language and Photos
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and André Martins ( https://andre-martins.github.io ), and it will be developed in the context of ongoing research projects currently being executed at INESC-ID.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including a PhD student named Rita Ramos that is working on remote sensing image captioning and multi-modal machine learning (under a co-supervision with Prof. Desmond Elliot from University of Copenhagen).

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Multimodal inference across image data and text has the potential to improve the understanding information of in different modalities and the acquisition of new knowledge, which can inform applications such as visual question answering, image captioning, and visual reasoning (e.g., to detect incoherence in news articles using photos to illustrate the contents being discussed).

Taking inspiration on previous textual entailment and natural language inference studies ( e.g., see https://nlp.stanford.edu/projects/snli/ and https://cims.nyu.edu/~sbowman/multinli/ ), previous studies have proposed visual-textual entailment tasks, related to determining if a textual hypothesis can be concluded from a premise image, and assigning to each pair of (premise image, textual hypothesis) a label among entailment, neutral, and contradiction. Neural network methods have also been proposed to address the aforementioned visual-textual entailment task, e.g. combining convolutional networks to encode the visual premise together with recurrent neural networks to encode the textual hypothesis ( e.g., see https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.06706 or https://arxiv.org/pdf/1806.05645.pdf ).

Despite the recent progress in the area, there are still many opportunities to be explored. This MSc research project will involve the study and development of neural models for visual-textual entailment/inferencing, taking advantage of recent developments in convolutional neural networks for encoding visual contents ( e.g., state-of-the-art convolutional architectures discovered through automated search, which feature particular connection patterns, pooling operations, or normalization operations -- see https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.11946 , https://arxiv.org/pdf/2003.13328v1.pdf or https://arxiv.org/pdf/2004.02967.pdf ), transformer-based architectures for encoding text ( e.g., see https://huggingface.co/transformers ), and neural attention/alignment mechanisms for comparing the representations for both modalities. Particular emphasis will be given to the study of joint multimodal embedding methods, which have been used in state-of-the-art methods for visual entailment ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.11740 or https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.02265 ).

Experiments will mostly leverage the SNLI-VE- 2.0 and e-SNLI-VE-2.0 corpora ( see https://arxiv.org/pdf/2004.03744.pdf ), although  other recently proposed datasets can also be explored ( e.g., https://arxiv.org/abs/1811.00491 , https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/D19-1469.pdf or https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.00908 ). The tests will involve assessing model performance under two different multimodal scenarios that involve the use of neural networks for (a) determining if a textual hypothesis can be concluded from a premise image, and (b) determining if a textual hypothesis can be concluded from a premise composed of a textual description and a context image ( e.g., see https://leonidk.com/pdfs/cs224u.pdf or https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.01894 ).

objectives:
Contemporary technologies allow us to work with complex subjects and stories, inviting our audience to be immersed in engaging and innovative storytelling. Advances in Artificial intelligence, Augmented Reality (AR), and Augmented Virtuality, create a rich design space for game designers and storytellers. By mixing the real with the virtual worlds, AR is creating immersive experiences that allow users to feel that they are interacting personally with their digital environment.

In this thesis the student will learn and investigate how different AR scenarios could adapt to real-world objects and placed them in the AR world. AI algorithms can be leveraged to adapt the story in “runtime” depending on the detected object.
Currently most AR game/storytelling scenarios, the AR (3D rendered world) does not react to objects from the real world. How could the characters and story flow (re)adapt when a real work object is placed in the AR scene? How could the story change in real-time depending if an object is placed in the path of the character? 
For example, imagine a scenario where the virtual character is walking around a park, and the user places a plastic bottle in front of her. How would she react? Or how can this event affect the story/game during the AR scene playout (eg. Character lines or actions could be influenced by the type of object).

title: Dissertação: GnuTLS-SGX: a port of the GnuTLS library for Intel SGX
objectives:
Transport Layer Security (TLS) refers to a cryptographic protocol that offers end-to-end communications security over networks, namely communication confidentiality and data integrity. Several versions of the protocol are widely used for Internet communications and online transactions, among other applications. Therefore, multiple implementations of TLS have been proposed as commercial and open source cryptographic libraries, e.g. OpenSSL, Amazon s2n, MbedTLS, Apple CoreTLS, Mozilla NSS, WolfSSL, or GnuTLS. In the latter years, vulnerabilities have been found in several of these libraries, which poses critical security issues to many applications.

Intel Software Guard Extensions (Intel SGX) is a name for an Intel architecture extension designed to increase the security of software by creating Trusted Execution Environments (secure enclaves in the Intel terminology). Using this technology, it becomes possible for user-level and operating system code to define private regions of memory, the enclaves, whose contents are protected and unable to be either read or saved by any process outside the enclave itself, including processes running at higher privilege levels. As such, nowadays several cryptographic libraries provide support for Intel SGX, such as MbedTLS or wolfSSL. However, that is not the case of GnuTLS, a cryptographic library widely used in Linux.

The main goal of this work is to develop a port of the GnuTLS library for Intel SGX, named GnuTLS-SGX.

These sensors span from simple DIY weather stations to more complex devices capable of detecting animals and changes in biodiversity with camera traps and microphones which can process meaningful events using machine learning and data mining algorithms. title: [Dissertation] Developing Communication Skills with Virtual Reality
observations: For more information, please contact Augusto Esteves (augusto.esteves@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) and/or Sofia Sá (sofiasap@tecnico.ulisboa.pt)
objectives:
Developing and analysing exercises, based in VR, that promote specific communication skills (active listening, for example) and provide immediate feedback on strengths and points of improvement.
_______________________________________________________________________________________________
Communication skills are fundamental to the lives of engineers. The Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology criteria clearly states that graduates should “communicate effectively in a variety of professional contexts” [1]. This requirement was initiated by what European commission once called “skills mismatch” [2] - what companies need from their collaborators, in terms of professional skills, and what students develop in their academic path is inconsistent. 
Several higher education institutions, like Instituto Superior Técnico, have specific curricular units dedicated to communication skills, to develop awareness and promote practical exercises to build those fundamental competencies. However, practising communication skills with other students can be challenging due to communication apprehension, “an individual level’s of fear or anxiety associated with either real or anticipated communication with another person or persons” [4]. With this variable at stake, the process of learning communication skills generates a loop - the student feels anxious about communication exercises. Hence, he/she avoids it, limiting the practice of such skills and maintaining the communication apprehension until starting the professional career when these skills will be needed. 
Virtual reality (VR) presents an opportunity to practice and reflect on essential communication skills with immediate feedback, allowing students to perform exercises without the anxiety to be judged by other persons, improving specific techniques and gain a higher perception of their self-efficacy which will also have an impact in the diminish communication apprehension [5]. Examples of systems and studies in this domain include the use of VR for simulated in-situ English learning [3], or overall soft skill training [6].
___________________________________________________________________________________________________
[1] Criteria for Accrediting Computing Programs, 2020 – 2021 (n.d). ABET accreditation. https://www.abet.org/accreditation/accreditation-criteria/criteria-for-accrediting-computing-programs-2020-2021/
[2] European Commission. (2012). Rethinking education: investing in skills for better socio-economic outcomes. https://www.cedefop.europa.eu/en/content/rethinking-education-investing-skills-better-socio-economic-outcomes 
[5] MARVRUS. (n.d.). 마블러스 MARVRUS. http://marvrus.com/ 
[4] McCroskey, J. C. (1977). Oral communication apprehension: A summary of recent theory and research. Human communication research, 4(1), 78-96.
[5] P’Rayan, A., & Shetty, R. T. (2008). Developing engineering students' communication skills by reducing their communication apprehension. English for Specific Purposes World, 4(20), 1-24.
[6] PricewaterhouseCoopers. (2020). How virtual reality is redefining soft skills training. PwC. https://www.pwc.com/us/en/services/consulting/technology/emerging-technology/vr-study-2020.html
requirements: The nature of the project requires a particular interest for topics regarding VR and communication skills. Experience with Unity and C# is beneficial, as well as an interest in human-centred design methodologies.

title: [Projeto] I Am (Still) Here!
objectives:
É frequente, em várias disciplinas, haver um registo de presenças. No entanto, o método tradicional (passar uma folha) não só é moroso (colocar 100 cruzes à mão no Excel) como se presta a “usos criativos” e a um registo pouco fidedigno. Atualmente, temos o classcheck.tk, desenvolvido num mestrado anterior. Mas este pode ir mais longe, e tornar-se mais resiliente.

O objetivo Criar um sistema automático de registo de presenças, que dispense a intervenção humana, e diminua as possibilidades de fraude.

O resultado final será uma evolução do actual sistema Classcheck (desenvolvido num mestrado anterior), que permita maior versatilidade. Por um lado, adicionar funcionalidade como permitir registar a presença várias vezes por aula, etc. Por outro, usar técnicas de device fingerprinting para ajudar a perceber até que ponto pode um aluno estar a registar a presença de outro. O foco está, pois, na salvaguarda dos mecanismos básicos de segurança e fidelidade (não deixar a mesma pessoa registar duas presenças, não permitir registar presenças de fora do IST, etc.). Usar, também, técnicas de InfoVis para ajudar a perceber a evolução das presenças.

title: [Project] WalkAR: Enabling Mobile Input For Smart Glasses
observations: This project will be co-supervised by Prof. Ian Oakley from the Interactions Lab at the Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology: http://interactions.unist.ac.kr/
objectives:
Smart glasses inherently support mobile use scenarios, situations we define as when people are away from their desks (or sofas) and walking, working, travelling or busy with other activities. We argue these situations are critical wearable use cases that represent the situations in which smart glasses can make the greatest impact. the overarching goal of this research project is to study basic input tasks (e.g., pointing, typing) on smart glasses in mobile settings and use the knowledge gained from these activities to design and develop general purpose design guidance and interaction techniques that improve the ability of users to operate smart glasses while mobile. In this way, this project will update and extend the large body of highly impactful prior work that has explored mobility for handheld devices such as smart phones and is now emerging for smartwatches. We note there is currently no corresponding body of literature for mobile input on smart glasses; work in this area is in its infancy and this project seeks to make the first major contributions on this topic.

To increase the value of the project outcomes, a key focus will be on hands-free or unencumbered input, or situations in which users are not holding input devices in their hands. This maximizes the practical scenarios in which the techniques proposed in the project can be used – including during hands-busy work tasks. Project activities will conclude with empirical studies to validate the proposed techniques and the construction of prototypes and demonstrators that embody, instantiate and showcase them. The key project outcome will be techniques that improve the effectiveness and usability of input on smart glasses in situations when users are mobile (e.g., walking, working or otherwise busy).

title: [Dissertação] Who-Fi: Wireless device beHaviOr FIngerprinting
objectives:
Wi-Fi fingerprinting has become the main technique in indoor location solutions. Its most widely known implementation is Google Indoor Maps. This technique creates a map of a physical location, e.g.. a building, by creating a map based on the signal intensities of each reachable Access Point (AP). This collection of intensities is usually done by measuring the Wi-Fi signal strengths on each point in space, which can lead to deviations caused by electromagnetic interference, e.g. a moving lift.
This work studies different approaches to Wi-Fi recognition, by targeting specific instances of AP and communicating with them to generate a unique fingerprint using Wi-Fi handshake and CSI (Channel State Information), or using fine timing measurements of Wi-Fi RTT. The more promising approaches are based on Machine Learning. This technology can be used for indoor location but also for generating location proofs, such as the ones being used in the ongoing SureThing project (http://surething-project.eu)
The same principles can also be applied to other wireless devices, such as Bluetooth and Zigbee.

Referências:
Recent works in Wi-Fi fingerprinting for indoor location include:
Jun, Junghyun, et al. "Low-overhead WiFi fingerprinting." IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing 17.3 (2018): 590-603.
https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/8007254

Wang, Xuyu, et al. "CSI-based fingerprinting for indoor localization: A deep learning approach." IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology 66.1 (2017): 763-776.
https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7438932

Batstone, Kenneth, Magnus Oskarsson, and Kalle Åström. "Robust time-of-arrival self calibration and indoor localization using Wi-Fi round-trip time measurements." 2016 IEEE International Conference on Communications Workshops (ICC). IEEE, 2016.
https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/7503759

objectives:
Os sistemas baseados em micro-serviços baseia-se na decomposição de um sistema complexo em serviços independentes, distribuídos, que são altamente coesos e podem ser desenvolvidos de forma independente. Tipicamente, para assegurar a capacidade de escala e o desacopolamento entre os micro-serviços, as aplicações evitam a utilização de transacções. Trabalho recente na área da engenharia de software mostra que, ao evitar usar transacções, o programador é obrigado a codificar acções de compensação, que corrigem os efeitos da falta de isolamento. Isto pode tornar o desenvolvimento das aplicações muito mais complexo.


O objectivo desta tese consistem em usar métricas de complexidade desenvolvidas por investigadores da área de engenharia de software para aferir as vantagens de oferecer suporte para transacções baseadas em modelos de coerência fraca, que podem ser concretizados de forma não bloqueante.

- Revisão do trabalho relacionado.

- Indentificação de métricas para aferir o impacto de usar diferentes critérios de coerência,  incluindo a coerência causal transaccional (TCC),  em ambientes de micro-serviços.

- Definir metodologias que ajudem o programador a escolher o critério de coerência adequado para uma dada aplicação.

- Relatório com o levantamento e análise do estado da arte.

title: Dissertation: Testing User Experience in Games Using Socio-emotional Test Agents
location: This work will be developed at Grupo Inteligência Artificial para a Sociedade (GAIPS) - INESC-ID, IST-Taguspark and Laboratório de Jogos at IST- Taguspark.
observations: This work will be integrated in the European Research project iv4XR - Intelligent Verification/Validation for Extended Reality Based Systems (https://iv4xr-project.eu/). There is a potential follow-up of the dissertation after completion, into a more deep research work that may lead to a PhD.
objectives:
One challenge in the extended reality (XR) industry, such as games, towards advancing further is the lack of advanced testing tools to address XR systems’ fine-grained and high level of interactivity and realism. These kinds of tests are very hard to automate and there is very little technology support beyond very rudimentary record and replay tools that only work for simple scenarios. Without automation, the XR industry has to resort to expensive user (manual) testing with limited range and furthermore non-regressive. This work aims to build a novel verification and validation technology for XR systems based on techniques from AI to support automatic functional and user experience assessment.
The overall goal is the development of socio-emotional test agents (SETAs) to do such assessment systematically, while minimizing the manual effort. These SETA will make use of emotion appraisal computational models to simulate the affective state of users. The model should be able to represent different profiles of users, expressing social variability, based on different motivations and emotional profiles.
This dissertation will work on the foundations to build socio-emotional test agents and will develop a version of the agents and test them in a set of scenarios to validate the approach.
requirements: The student needs to have very good programming skills, and preferably knowledge of agent methodologies and machine learning methods.

title: Dissertation: Formal Verification of Password Manager Security Properties
observations: Orientador externo: Alexandra Mendes (amendes@di.ubi.pt)
objectives:
This project is part of the PassCert research project, a CMU-Portugal exploratory project that will build an open-source, proof-of-concept password manager that through the use of formal verification, is guaranteed to satisfy properties on data storage and password generation. The selected candidate will be a member of the research team, participating in the meetings with the CMU researchers, collaborating on research papers, and possibly presenting their work at international conferences.

Password managers are important tools that enable us to use stronger passwords, freeing us from the cognitive burden of remembering them. Despite this, there are still many users who do not fully trust password managers.

The goals of this project are: i) to do a survey on important security properties that a password manager must satisfy; ii) to select the base password manager, which is the password manager that will be used and extended in subsequent tasks; and iii) based on the information gathered, formally verify that the chosen password manager (or an extended version) satisfies some of those properties. 

The choice of the base password manager is still open: it might be an existing password manager or a new password manager developed from scratch, specifically tailored to our goals. From our preliminary analysis, it is likely that we will develop our work on KeePass, a popular open-source PM that is used by approximately 20 million users.

In terms of properties, it is important to guarantee certain data location and data security properties of password managers. Researchers recently identified that sometimes users are uncertain about where passwords are stored or whether employees of the company making the password manager can see their passwords. If a user configures the tool to store all secret data locally, then it is desirable to have a formal guarantee that the password manager will not store it remotely. Also, it is desirable to provide formal guarantees of what data is "available" (e.g. in memory) on certain states of the password manager. For example, when the password manager is locked, passwords that have been copied in the previous session should not be in memory. It was discovered recently that five of the most used password managers have vulnerabilities of this kind.
requirements:

Knowledge of and/or interest in formal verification of software is desirable (e.g. knowlege of Coq or Dafny)

objectives:
Estudo e implementação de mecanismos de invocação remota de

A capacidade de fazer invocação remota da funcionalidade
disponibilizada por aplicações abre a porta à possibilidade de

contexto Windows, essa mecanização tem sido feita utilizando a
tecnologia COM.

Há já várias implementações de COM para diferentes linguagens de
programação. No entanto, a linguagem Julia, que foi recentemente
desenvolvida no MIT, ainda não possui nenhuma dessas implementações e,
na prática, não suporta COM, constituindo uma grave limitação à sua

Neste trabalho, pretende-se tirar partido dos mecanismos de
introspecção e de metaprogramação da linguagem Julia para lhe dar o
suporte à tecnologia COM, através do desenvolvimento de um módulo de
COM para Julia.

title: Dissertação: Validação da qualidade de serviço prestada por servidores na periferia da rede.
observations:
Este tema já foi acordado com a aluna Rita Alexandra Rodrigues Prates (86507)

Preferencialmente, o trabalho deverá ser desenvolvido no espaço do Grupo de Sistemas Distribuídos do INESC-ID.

Se a evolução da COVID-19 obrigar a manter medidas de confinamento, o trabalho será realizado maioritariamente por tele-trabalho, com acompanhamento frequente por video-conferência.
objectives:
A computação na periferia da rede é um paradigma que recorre a pequenos servidores, instalados perto dos clientes, e que podem fornecer serviços com baixa latência. O objectivo de usar servidores na periferia da rede é fornecer baixa latência ao clientes. Infelizmente, um servidor controlado por um actor racional pode optar por violar garantias de qualidade de serviço se com isso conseguir obter ganhos. Por exemplo, um servidor pode vender mais espaço de cache do que actualmente possui. Se um cliente solicitar o acesso a item que deveria estar em cache mas que, de facto, não está, o servidor racional terá que descarregar no momento o item a partir da nuvem, servindo cliente com um atraso significativamente ao acordado.

O objectivo deste trabalho é desenvolver mecanismos que permitam detectar estes desvios de forma a penalizar os servidores que se desviem da qualidade de serviço acordada. Estes mecanismos podem combinar acções de auditoria e mecanismos de reputação, que usem avaliação do serviço prestado feitas pelos clientes.

O plano de trabalho consiste nas seguintes fases:

- Revisão do trabalho relacionado.

- Concepção e concretização de mecanismos de auditoria e/ou reputação que permitam identificar servidores que não cumpram a qualidade de serviço negociada.

- Avaliação experimental da solução proposta.

Os resultados esperados são os seguintes:

- Relatório com o levantamento e análise do estado da arte.

- Um conjunto de novas técnicas para auditar servidores na periferia da rede.

- Uma avaliação destas técnicas usando um protótipo.

- Um artigo científico descrevendo estas contribuições.

- Uma dissertação de mestrado.

title: Dissertação: Blended Workflow relaxing domain constraints
observations: More info about the project http://socialsoftware.github.io/blended/
objectives:
The Blended Workflow project fuses an activity-based approach with a goal-based approach. Its environment allows end users to follow a standard pre-defined behaviour when performing their work (following an activity-based view), but to deviate whenever an unexpected situation occurs (following a goal-based view). The Blended Workflow engine is responsible to keep the two different views of any workflow instance synchronised so that end users can decide at any time which view to use to perform their work.

Introduce in the Blended Workflow execution model the ability to relax its data dependencies in order to augment its flexibility, while preserving some level of consistency.

title: Dissertation: On Usable Security and Verified Password Managers
observations: Orientador externo: Alexandra Mendes (amendes@di.ubi.pt)
objectives:
This project is part of the PassCert research project, a CMU-Portugal exploratory project that will build an open-source, proof-of-concept password manager that through the use of formal verification, is guaranteed to satisfy properties on data storage and password generation. The selected candidate will be a member of the research team, participating in the meetings with the CMU researchers, collaborating on research papers, and possibly presenting their work at international conferences.

Password managers are important tools that enable us to use stronger passwords, freeing us from the cognitive burden of remembering them. Despite this, there are still many users who do not fully trust password managers.

The goals of this project are i) to survey usable security techniques that can be applied to password managers; ii) to ensure that the password managers developed in the context of the PassCert project integrate best practice guidelines developed by the usable security community; iii) to explore ways that effectively convey the formally verified properties of the password managers; and iv) to perform user studies to determine the impact of formal verification on the adoption of password managers. Previous work from members of the PassCert project identified the need for better user-experience design and thorough usability testing of password managers. It also found that users of built-in password managers are often driven by convenience, whereas users of separately installed password managers prioritize security. This project will start by studying tailored designs for these two mentalities, focusing on ways to serve users whose primary task is not security and nudge them to use password generators without sacrificing convenience. To increase the impact of the work developed, we will focus on non-expert users. A challenge to be addressed is how to effectively convey the relevance of formal verification in a way that increases the confidence of users in verified password managers.

title: Dissertation: Prosocial Learning Agents
objectives:
Imaginemos uma sociedade de agentes autónomos que existem num ambiente e que consomem recursos nesse mesmo ambiente. No entanto esses recursos  são limitados (por exemplo, o planeta Terra). 
O objetivo desta tese é explorar a simulação social baseada em agentes de forma a estudar qual será a melhor forma de garantir que os agentes não consomem os recursos até à exaustão. Neste contexto, os alunos durante o mestrado deverão explorar o desenho de diferentes tipos de agentes, incluindo diferentes  modelos de aprendizagem, para que num contexto de um Common Pool Resources Dillemma- CPR), a sociedade de agentes (e eventualmente humanos) não esgote a tal common pool (representativa dos recursos do ambiente). Ou seja, ver como é que os agentes evoluem para se tornar “prosociais” e contribuir para a sociedade. 

A tese será desenvolvida em 4 fases:
- Pesquisa bibliográfica sobre a área de CPR e simulação social baseada em agentes
- Criação/adopção de um jogo que permita fazer a simulação adequada para explorar a prosocialidade
- Desenho de diferentes modelos de agentes 
- Estudo de diferentes configurações de sociedades
- Estudo com humanos de forma a explorar como é que numa população híbrida (de humanos e agentes) emerge a prosocialidade
- Obtenção de resultados e escrita da tese.
requirements: Os alunos deverão ser da área de Inteligência Artificial (Sistemas Inteligentes) e ter também efetuado as unidades de Agentes Autónomos e Sistemas Multi-agentes e Redes Complexas.

title: DISSERTAÇÂO: Diagnóstico do cancro de mama usando redes neuronais profundas
supervisors: Jacinto Carlos Marques Peixoto do Nascimento (50%)
location: Instituto de Sistemas e Robótica - Torre Norte
objectives:
Nesta tese propõe-se realizar o estudo em análise de imagem para diagnóstico do cancro mama. Este problema vai ser abordado usando metodologias em deep learning. Especificamente, vai-se usar uma arquitectura recente - a Hyper Dense Net.
O trabalho consiste em realizar a classificação de severidade da lesão da mama. Para isso são usadas imagens de mamografia e de ultrasom. Num primeiro estágio, usam-se somente imagens de mamografia ou imagens de ultrasom, verificando da performance da rede na classificação nestas modalidades em separado. Num segundo estágio, faz-se a extensão para o uso das duas modalidades em simultâneo, para saber se há uma modalidade que é mais predominante que a outra.
Dado que a arquitectura da Hyper Dense Net, é bastante rica há diversos modos de combinar como os dados de input vão ser dados à rede. Especificamente, vão estudar-se os seguintes mecanismo de integração  dos dados:
- Usar dois canais separados na rede. Aqui usa-se uma modalidade de imagem (Ultrasom ou mamografia) por cada canal da rede
- Usar somente um canal, onde os dados de entrada são concatenados logo à entrada (1ª camada) da rede
- Usar um  outro mecanismo que corresponde a uma solução que é intermédia das duas anteriores. Especificamente, usa-se inicialmente os dois canais, realizando-se posteriormente a fusão (ou concatenação) dos dois canais. Aqui o desafio é descobrir qual a melhor camada para realizar a fusão dos dados.

Já existe código (Pytorch) disponível que pode ser usado como ponto de partida para este trabalho
requirements: Deseja-se que o aluno tenha conhecimentos, ou que queira aprender  linguagem de programação PYtorch.

title: [Project] Improving QubesOS Usability
observations: Esta tese foi proposta pelo aluno Francisco Rocha.
objectives:
QubesOS is a security-focused operating system. It uses virtual machines to enforce strict security compartmentalization and integrates them seamlessly on a
desktop environment. Thanks to its security properties it can help mitigate many of the risks associated with desktop computing. But despite its benefits, it hasn't seen a wide adoption by non-technical users. The objective of this thesis is to understand and address the limiting factors of the operating system for user adoption, while making sure increased usability does not lead to security shortcomings.

title: Dissertation: Balancing Randomness and Predictability in Games
objectives:
Games should be intrinsically unpredictable, otherwise they would not be of much interest to play or watch. One form of introducing unpredictability is through the use of randomness. Multiple games require the player to replay certain portions of the content, motivated to a certain degree by the randomness associated with the rewards of the run. This work will research how human perception of randomness could inform game design when designing such player experiences, namely when balancing between the predictability and randomness of content.

Main sub-goals:
( 1 ) Literature review (semester 1)
( 2 ) Computational model (semester 1 and 2)
( 3 ) Test scenario implementation (semester 2)
( 4 ) User studies (semester 2)
requirements: This thesis proposal is open to all MSc students from the Master Degree in Information Systems and Computer Engineering of Instituto Superior Técnico.

title: Dissertation: Next-Gen Pure Function Synthesis in OutSystems
observations: Joana Maria Leal Coutinho 87666
objectives: In the OutSystems platform, business logic is implemented through action flows. Pure functions are one type of action flow that produces an output from a given set of inputs, just like functions in traditional programming languages. Unlike regular action flows, pure functions can be used within OutSystems expressions (e.g. assignments, if conditions, etc), and thus are useful for performing complex data transformations that are recurrent throughout the application. Moreover, because pure functions produce an output from a set of inputs, it makes sense to apply program synthesis techniques (e.g. programming-by-example) to synthesize such functions. Existing approaches are very limited, supporting only synthesis of flows with variable assignments and If expressions. The goal of this MSc thesis is to bring pure function synthesis to the next level, by introducing support for a wider range of constructs, such as database accesses and calls to other pure functions.

title: Dissertação: Método Híbrido para Resolução de PDEs
observations: Co-orientação externa: Prof. Juan Acebron, ISCTE (Juan.Acebron@iscte-iul.pt)
objectives:
Na atualidade um dos métodos mais utilizados na resolução de equações em derivadas parciais (PDE) é o método de elementos finitos (FEM). Na sua implementação numérica é preciso gerar uma malha computacional, discretizar o problema dado e resolver um problema de álgebra linear composto pelos nós do problema discretizado. A natureza global do método numérico impede calcular a solução do problema em pontos individuais no interior do domínio de definição do problema, e portanto para problemas de grande escala e geometria complexas, a execução do algoritmo numérico em máquinas massivamente paralelas sofre de problemas sérios de perda de escalabilidade. Isto é devido ao elevado custo de comunicação entre os diferentes cores envolvidos. Uma alternativa de sucesso consiste em utilizar algoritmos numéricos baseados em métodos probabilísticos. Estes métodos por serem naturalmente paralelos permitem superar a limitação anteriormente mencionada. Além disso permitem calcular a solução em pontos individuais do domínio sem precisar de gerar uma malha computacional onde resolver o problema completo. No entanto, devido à sua lenta convergência não é possível serem utilizados para calcular a solução em todos os pontos do domínio.

Esta Tese tem como objetivo desenvolver um algoritmo paralelo híbrido composto pelo método Monte Carlo e o método de decomposição de domínios. A ideia será utilizar o método Monte Carlo para calcular em paralelo a solução em alguns pontos individuais do domínio especificamente escolhidos de maneira a simplificar o problema de álgebra linear original para um problema equivalente descrito por uma matriz diagonal a blocos. Isto na prática permitirá desacoplar o problema global em problemas independentes cuja resolução será posteriormente atribuída a diferentes cores que trabalharão independentemente sem necessidade de nenhuma intercomunicação. Uma vez implementado o algoritmo paralelo este será testado resolvendo problemas de grande escala de interesse em Física e Engenharia, utilizando diversas infraestruturas de supercomputação europeias.
requirements: Os estudantes interessados em realizar esta Tese de Mestrado deverão ter frequentado a cadeira de Computação Paralela e Distribuída.

observations: Tese enquadrada no projecto do 1º Satélite Universitário Português – ISTsat-1 - cujo objectivo é desenvolver e operar um nano-satélite exclusivamente desenhado no IST, e baseado na plataforma Cubesat. A missão principal do ISTsat-1 é fazer tracking de aeronaves através da captação dos sinais Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast (ADS-B) emitidos regularmente pelas mesmas. Um dos componentes essenciais para a operação do satélite é o sistema de controlo de missão que permitirá recolher informações de telemetria bem como gerar os telecomandos que mantêm o satélite nas condições ideais de operação para realizar a missão para que foi projectado.

Definir, conceber, desenvolver e validar o software de controlo de missão para o 1º Satélite Universitário Português – ISTsat-1 - a partir de uma rede cooperante de estações terrestres.

A missão do satélite, quer dizer, a aplicação que se executa no satélite e as funções de "vôo", é acompanhada - monitorizada e controlada - a partir da Terra em várias "estações terrestres" (ground stations).espalhadas geograficamente de modo a cobrir o melhor possível o movimento do satélite em torno da Terra.

title: [Dissertação] Towards a Persona-coherent Conversational Agent
observations: Tese atribuída ao aluno Gonçalo Melo
objectives:
Recent advancements in deep learning, associated with growing data abundance, have allowed the development of neural dialog systems. However, they still face multiple challenges. One issue is their propensity to inconsistent responses, regarding a coherent "persona", that is, the bot is not able to play a specific character during conversation. Recent works have found that pre-training speaker embeddings on large datasets can significantly boost performance. Another current approach is based in transfer-learning from general language models, which are tuned in more specific data, like the PERSONA-CHAT corpus [Zhang er al., 2018], as described in [Wolf et al., 2019]. In this thesis, we focus in the development of chit-chat bots with a coherent persona. We are particularly interested in understanding what can be done in Portuguese, considering that recent approaches are based on large datasets for the English language. In addition, we will explore the different aspects that compose a persona, such as identity (background facts or user profile), language behaviour, and interaction style [Li et al., 2016].

title: [Dissertação] Geração Automática e Encadeamento de Exploits para Vulnerabilidades em Programas x86
observations: _AEG: Automatic Exploit Generation_, Thanassis Avgerinos, Sang Kil Cha, Brent Lim Tze Hao, David Brumley [link](https://kilthub.cmu.edu/articles/AEG_Automatic_Exploit_Generation/6468296)
objectives:
Todos os dias são reportadas vulnerabilidades ao nível do software e o volume de software produzido todos os dias é incompatível com a sua verificação manual. Tendências recentes de detecção e correcção automática de vulnerabilidades têm por isso ganho adeptos nos últimos anos, em muito impulsionadas pelo _DARPA’s 2016 Cyber Grand Challenge_ organizado em 2016 durante a DefCon em Las Vegas em que 7 sistemas autónomos competiram entre eles com o objectivo não só de detectar e explorar vulnerabilidades, mas também de efectuar correcções ao programa vulnerável.

Esta proposta de investigação segue esta tendência e têm por objectivo a utilização de técnicas de Linguagens de Programação (Symbolic Execution) e Engenharia de Software (Fault-Localization) na detecção de vulnerabilidades, e na subsequente correcção das mesmas. O racional é usar as técnicas de FL para melhor guiar a SE.

Neste contexto já foi desenvolvido um motor de execução simbólica (guiado) capaz de analisar programas x86 e detectar vulnerabilidades em alguns dos programas do dataset da [DARPA Cyber Grand Challenge](https://github.com/CyberGrandChallenge/) pretendendo-se neste momento aumentar a sua capacidade de geração de exploits em particular em vulnerabilidades relacionadas com a Heap.

# Objectivo - Geração de exploits

O motor de execução simbólica executa os traços do programa e colecciona as restrições sobre as variáveis do mesmo por forma a que quando encontra uma vulnerabilidade possa calcular a solução das restrições e gerar o exploit correspondente.

O problema é que por vezes para gerar um exploit é necessário encadear várias vulnerabilidades (e.g., fazer leak de um endereço e depois saltar para lá). O principal objectivo desta tese é conseguir encadear pequenos exploits por forma a explorar este tipo de vulnerabilidades com especial ênfase em vulnerabilidades ao nível da Heap.
requirements: Interesse em Segurança em Software

title: [Dissertação]: Detecção precoce de onset da Psicose através de processamento do Português
supervisors: Helena Sofia Andrade Nunes Pereira Pinto (50%)
observations:
Esta Tese foi desenvolvida para a aluna
nº 86475 Maria Gomes Simas Beato Forjó 

For further inquiry of possible interest on this kind of topic contact  Sofia Pinto sofia@inesc-id.pt
objectives:
Language and speech are the main source of data for psychiatrists to diagnose and treat mental disorders. In psychosis, the structure of language can be disturbed, including semantic coherence and syntactic complexity. Subtle disturbances in language are evident in schizophrenia even prior to first psychosis onset. Using computer-based natural language processing analyses, it was verified that among English-speaking clinical high-risk youths, baseline reduction in semantic coherence (the flow of meaning in speech) and in syntactic complexity could predict subsequent psychosis onset with high accuracy. Apparently subtle features in people’s everyday language may harbor the signs of future mental illness. Machine learning offers an approach for the rapid and accurate extraction of these signs.
All this line of research work  was conducted for English, so the aim of this Thesis is to configure and develop appropriate tools to replicate results for Portuguese.

title: [Dissertation] Exploring ISA extensions for reconfigurable accelerators with RISC-V and the LLVM compiler
observations:
- This thesis will be also supervised by Dr. Nuno Neves, from INESC-ID (Nuno.Neves@inesc-id.pt)
- Assignment of this thesis is subject to a prior informal interview with the candidate to assess his motivation and prior knowledge in the fields of research
- This thesis involves challenging aspects recognized by the scientific community; accordingly, the outcome of this work may give rise to the publication of scientific articles.
objectives:
Recent advances in Deep Neural Networks (DNN) provided important algorithmic breakthroughs in many domains, such as computer vision, speech recognition, natural language processing, drug discovery, genomics, etc. Such breakthroughs have been achieved through deeper and non-uniform neural networks, by integrating new layer types (e.g, convolutional and/or recurrent layers), new activation functions and through advances in the training methodologies. 

However, the computational requirements of these algorithms, allied with the ever-increasing amount of data availability, have pushed the computing capacity of off-the-shelf processing architectures (e.g., CPU and GPU) to their limit. This drove a renewed interest to dedicated accelerator architectures in the industry. However, these new architectures (e.g., Google 's TPU) mostly focus on accelerating the inference phase. In fact, the training phase is still performed in off-the-shelf systems, making developers wait several weeks to train a DNN, a problem which is expected to worsen as DNNs become sparser, more complex and less susceptible to acceleration.

To tackle this issue, a new DNN accelerator is currently under development that exploits reconfigurable technology to enable architecture adaptation. It aims at providing support for both the training and inference phases by dynamically reconfiguring its architecture, to suit the computational requirements of each phase and to match the neural network topology, making the execution as efficient as possible.

Accordingly, the aim of this thesis is to investigate new instruction set architecture (ISA) extensions to the well-established RISC-V ISA, to support dynamically reconfigurable hardware and adaptable data movement. The resulting ISA will be able to describe, configure and map specialized and dynamic computing structures, and the data-flow between them, to the reconfigurable resources of the accelerator under development. The aimed extensions will be included in the LLVM compiler backend for RISC-V, initially supported by inline assembly and/or intrinsics.

title: Dissertação: Serviço de sincronização de relógios seguro para edge computing usando SGX.
observations:

Preferencialmente, o trabalho deverá ser desenvolvido no espaço do Grupo de Sistemas Distribuídos do INESC-ID.

Se a evolução da COVID-19 obrigar a manter medidas de confinamento, o trabalho será realizado maioritariamente por tele-trabalho, com acompanhamento frequente por video-conferência.
objectives:
A computação na periferia da rede é um paradigma que recorre a  pequenos servidores, instalados perto dos clientes, e que podem  fornecer serviços com baixa latência. Devido à sua localização, estes servidores podem ser atacados, pelo que é interessante pensar em  mecanismos tornar os serviços que estes fornecem mais seguros. Uma  tecnologia que pode facilitar esta tarefa são os ambientes de execução seguros, garantidos por hardware, tal como o SGX da  intel.

Infelizmente, este mecanismo, por si só, não garante que os  clientes tenham acesso a um relógio sincronizado, uma vez que as  mensagens geradas pelo enclave podem ser atrasadas por um tempo  indeterminado pelo SO. Esta tese pretende estudar técnicas que  permitam oferecer garantias a precisão e exactidão no acesso a um  relógio sincronizado com ajuda do SGX.

O plano de trabalho consiste nas seguintes fases:

- Revisão do trabalho relacionado.

- Concepção e concretização de mecanismos que aumentem a precisão e a exactidão dos valores de relógio usados dentro do enclave.

- Avaliação experimental da solução proposta.

Os resultados esperados são os seguintes:

- Relatório com o levantamento e análise do estado da arte.

- Um conjunto de novas técnicas para oferecer sincronização de relógios no SGX.

- Uma avaliação destas técnicas usando um protótipo.

- Um artigo científico descrevendo estas contribuições.

- Uma dissertação de mestrado.

title: (Dissertation) A secure content dissemination scheme for the Internet of Vehicles
location: Zoom and/or Skype and INESC-ID Lisboa (Rua Alves Redol 9, 1000-029 LISBOA) and/or Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade de Lisboa (FCUL, Campo Grande)
objectives:
With the rapid development of 5G communication systems, the advancements of vehicular communication technology in assisting Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) can effectively improve passengers’ safety and provide infotainment for enjoyable journeys. There have been significant advancements in electronics aiding car drivers, along with communications outside the vehicle, e.g., vehicle-to-everything (V2X), to enable mobile Internet and entertainment. Together with V2X connectivity, data collected from infrastructure Road Side Units and various other sensors placed on roads, buildings and pedestrians, which constitute the Internet of Vehicles (IoVs), could be disseminated to the vehicle cloud hence ensuring efficient emergency warning notifications, the management of the city traffic levels, and provide drivers with congestion control information.

However, security is a key challenge in ITS for IoVs since, nowadays, there exist a plethora of security attacks that can negatively impact its reliability [1]. Some examples of common threats to vehicles in ITS include denial of service, jamming, man in the middle, Sybil, eavesdropping, and broadcast and message tampering.

The volume of data required by connected vehicles in IoVs will continue to rise, and some of the appealing content vehicle dissemination applications are of upmost importance for the correct functioning of vehicles [2].

The aim of this project is to devise a secure content dissemination scheme leveraging on proxy re-encryption schemes [3] to avoid attackers from tampering with critical data that would endanger vehicles’ passengers. The secure scheme should be implemented on a simulator and its performance evaluated. 

The project shall follow the following phases:
1) Study of the State-Of-The-Art and related research work;
2) Study of a simulator (e.g., The ONE simulator - https://akeranen.github.io/the-one/ or NS3 - https://www.nsnam.org/), implementation of multiple scenarios considering all IoV elements;
3) Implementation of the secure content dissemination scheme among vehicles and between vehicles and the infrastructure;
4) Definition of evaluation plan, including test cases, metrics and evaluation criteria; performance evaluation of the implemented scheme;
5) Writing of the dissertation and extended abstract.

References
[1] C. Bernardini, M. R. Asghar, and B. Crispo, "Security and privacy in vehicular communications: Challenges and opportunities," Vehicular Communications, vol. 10. pp. 13–28, 2017.
[2] N. Magaia, Z. Sheng, P. R. Pereira, and M. Correia, "REPSYS: A robust and distributed incentive scheme for in-network caching and dissemination in Vehicular Delay-Tolerant Networks," IEEE Wireless Communications Magazine, pp. 1–16, 2018.
[3] G. Ateniese, K. Fu, M. Green, and S. Hohenberger, "Improved proxy re-encryption schemes with applications to secure distributed storage," ACM Transactions on Information and System Security, vol. 9, no. 1, pp. 1–30, Feb. 2006.

title: [Dissertation] eSports and Eye-tracking
observations: Tese a ser co-orientada por Argenis Gómez da Universidade de Lancaster: https://www.argenisrg.com/
objectives:
eSports, a form of sport competition using video-games, is rapidly growing in popularity both nationally and internationally. As with traditional sports, eSports teams collect and analyze a vast set of performance data to improve training and efficiency. Most of this data is constrained to the player's input: the actions performed via the mouse or game-pad. A example of such a metric is actions per minute (APM), "a measurement of a player's load-handling capacity". Understandingly, trying to infer cognitive load, attention, fatigue, or response times solely via explicit user input (e.g., a mouse click) is not ideal. As such, eye-tracking technologies have been proposed as a way to better capture and characterize players' performance, as they would allow for trainers to fully understand and quantify a player's decision-making process. Unfortunately, the use of this technology is still in its infancy, with very few examples found outside of multiplayer online battle arena-type games (MOBAs).

In this thesis you accomplish the following:

1. Define which type of eSport(s) would better benefit from eye-tracking data and why
2. Process eye-tracking data in combination with game state and player input
3. Develop rich visualizations that can aid player and team assessment
requirements:
- Strong programming background in Java, C#, etc.- Interest in data processing
- Interest in data visualization

title: Dissertation: Modeling the COVID-19 pandemic with high-performance computing
observations: Possibility of research grant.
objectives:
Agent-based modeling (ABM) is an increasingly popular method for modeling infectious disease transmission. In ABM, a virtual population of individual citizens interact with each other and with their environment according to predefined rules. With the COVID-19 outbreak, these models are seem as one of the most powerful tools to help governments take public health decisions.
The accuracy of ABMs can be substantially improved if they are driven by real data, such as mobility/social contact traces taken in the real world. Furthermore, some of the most interesting features of ABMs require executing the model while varying a large space of parameters (for instance, to evaluate the impact of different public health interventions). 
Together, these require considerable computational power. This can be achieved by exploiting the parallel processing power of today's pre-HPC systems with efficient and scalable solutions.
This thesis will depart from an open source ABM platform, together with a data-intensive COVID-19 model, and develop an improved parallel extension to speed up its performance. This will be done using parallel programming platforms for HPC, such as OpenMP, MPI, OmpSs, GASPI, among others.
When possible, the developed system will be executed with real data from Portugal/EU to produce realistic COVID-19 models.

 

References:

https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3265749

title: [Dissertation] Seamless Transitions between Real and Digital Interactions in Augmented-Reality
observations: For more information, please contact Augusto Esteves (augusto.esteves@tecnico.ulisboa.pt).
objectives:
Augmented reality (AR) is a maturing technology poised to become a popular personal device for everyday use [2]. AR enables the projection of context-relevant information anchored to the real world into our view, facilitating spatial tasks and in-situ knowledge generation and understanding [3]. This introduces a key user interface (UI) challenge of user access to contextual information through interfaces in the form of panels or windows anchored to real world environments. Virtual content, while intended to be beneficial, can also introduce visibility issues as virtual objects are overlaid on real environments, and potentially distract the user when attending to the real world. Therefore, a particularly interesting aspect is how to design for the transition of users between the reality and virtual world as seamless as possible.

Several research examples exist attempting to explore these design issues. For example, Ajanki et al. use gaze as a feature among others to detect interest and provide progressively more in-situ information [1]. In another example, Lu et al.’s work on glanceable AR explores the design of a personal UI that relies on users’ peripheral view as shortcut to applications such as the calendar or a to-do list [4]. However, research in this domain has still not explored what really are the interaction trade-offs with regards to user experience and performance when using a gaze-adaptive UI as a primary access mode to AR information. This is particularly true in the context of real-world applications where the user’s task requires both real-world (e.g., finding a landmark) and digital content (e.g., attending to some information about that landmark), and where these should not get in the way of one another.

The goal of this project is to generate a series of guidelines, parameters, and techniques for AR interfaces with the goal of supporting a seamless transition between the various tasks a user might be engaged with while interacting in the context of an AR experience. This includes transitions between attending to the real-world and digital content, and attending to this content (i.e., reading it) or interacting with it. As such, this work will should describe the following activities:

- Development and evaluation of a series of focused AR experiences that explore different facets of this problem;
- Design and develop a fully-fledged AR prototype that exemplifies and further develops the guidelines, parameters, and techniques explored above.


References
1. Ajanki, A., Billinghurst, M., Gamper, H., Järvenpää, T., Kandemir, M., Kaski, S., ... & Ruokolainen, T. (2011). An augmented reality interface to contextual information. Virtual reality, 15(2-3), 161-173.
2. Feiner, S. K. (2002). Augmented reality: A new way of seeing. Scientific American, 286(4), 48-55.
3. Feiner, S., Macintyre, B., & Seligmann, D. (1993). Knowledge-based augmented reality. Communications of the ACM, 36(7), 53-62.
4. Lu, F., Davari, S., Lisle, L., Li, Y., & Bowman, D. A. (2020, March). Glanceable AR: Evaluating Information Access Methods for Head-Worn Augmented Reality. In 2020 IEEE Conference on Virtual Reality and 3D User Interfaces (VR) (pp. 930-939). IEEE.
requirements: The nature of the project requires a particular interest for topics regarding augmented-reality and biosensing (e.g., eye-tracking). Interest in human-centred design methodologies is beneficial, as well as experience with Unity or the Unreal Engine.

title: Dissertação || DocA: medical Doctor Agenda optimizer
observations: Proposto  por Aluna: … Raquel Pereira: ………………………………………………  Nº Aluno: 76171
objectives:
Enquadramento: 
As growing costs pressure health systems, mainly due to an ageing population, the rise of the private medical service providers has been growing in Portugal. In 2013, nearly half of Portugal’s hospitals were private. Over the last ten years, private hospitals have grown in consultations, number of beds, emergency rooms and diagnostic tests. The number of outpatient medical consultations increased steadily between 2002 and 2013, from 9,8 million to 17,6 million visits, with private hospitals accounting for 5,1 million consultations, 29% of the total. 
The growth of private health insurance, reduced waiting times and advanced technology, are among the main growth drivers for private medical service providers.
Although major private medical service providers in Portugal have an electronic reservation system, the process of booking a medical consultation is generally a tedious process and always limited to the service provider’s ecosystem. 
MedClick provides a one-stop platform to book a medical appointment in a fast and user friendly way, across multiple medical service providers. Whether on a PC, tablet or smartphone, patients conveniently browse all available booking options, based on date, location, price, insurance providers, or customer reviews and recommendations. 
MedClick helps medical service providers increase the efficiency of their practices, by featuring an advanced platform to manage and explore scheduling flexibility, filling available time slots. Additionally, with MedClick’s advanced user registration screening process and automated email and SMS reminders, the number of missed appointments will also be significantly reduced.
requirements:
Descrição:MedClick is an online platform is available online through a web portal and mobile apps for Android and iOS smartphones. The major functionalities are described bellow: 

 
The platform allows the access of several types of users: the patients, the doctors, the administrator, the contact center staff, the sales team personnel, and the insurance company
 
Patients are able to access the portal and immediately search for a doctor and book a medical appointment. 
The major focus of this thesis is a new differentiation functionality of MedClick: the optimization of the medical doctor agenda, considering the patients profile the expected healthcare required, in order to ensure the minimum waiting time for patients and that the medical doctor has always patients (even when noshows occur).
Therefore from a set of existing data, including patient gender, marriage status, age, distance to medical center, patient no show record, MedClick is expected to estimate each patient probability of “noshow”. On the “other side”, each medical doctor past consultation times is considered. Therefore when scheduling a new patient several scheduling strategies may be suggested – e.g., overbooking, schedule specific patients to the end of the day, extra reminders to specific patients, management of last minute no shows (including provide Clinics tools for fulfilling “last-minute” vacancy slots, namely by notifying patients that have less time constraints in exchange for higher discounts).

title: Dissertação: Development of a SCION router towards a secure Internet
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Fernando Ramos (fvramos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
The Internet is the most successful global communication infrastructure ever built. This is as undeniable as the widely recognised limitations of its architecture [1]. The most acknowledged architectural flaw is the lack of security in the original design, leaving the Internet vulnerable to various (and increasingly common) attacks. The research community has recently responded to this problem with a clean-slate redesign of the Internet that includes security by design: SCION [2-4]. So far, this solution did not have significant impact on the commercial Internet, since the Internet architecture is deeply embedded in the networking hardware, and thus is very hard to change.

Fortunately, recent advances on computer networking hardware can finally pave the way for a radical change. Specifically, the emergence of programmable packet switches (e.g., the Intel Barefoot Tofino) that allow the definition of packet processing using a high-level language (e.g., P4 [5]) and run at Tbps scales meet the performance requirements of today’s networks.

In this project the student will leverage these advances towards the design and implementation of a prototype of a SCION router, using the latest programmable networking hardware (an Intel Barefoot Tofino we have in our lab). One of the main challenges is the restrictive computing model of the target hardware platform. Specifically, to guarantee line rate processing, and thus to run 100x to 1000x faster than the alternatives, the Tofino model enables only simple operations and access to (limited amounts of) stateful memory.

One specific challenge is the integration of cryptographic functions in the data plane. In SCION, every packet contains the path it should follow specified in so-called hop fields. Hop fields are protected using cryptographic MACs to prevent unauthorised use of network links. One of the challenges is the lack of support to perform cryptographic operations within the platform, so novel approaches will need to be investigated. We have already a first implementation of the forwarding functionality for SCION [6] in P4, developed by one of the proponents of this project, which the student can use as a starting point. The student will work on several enhancements to the current security model, to fault detection, and/or to dynamic management, and on benchmarking and evaluation.

The student undertaking this project will have the opportunity to study and work with the most advanced networking platforms, to collaborate with leading experts on the SCION network architecture, and to innovate in this field. If successful, the results of the project can represent a highly relevant contribution towards a secure Internet.

The project will be co-advised by Fernando Ramos, Associate Prof. at IST, and Joeri de Ruiter, Research engineer at SIDN Labs, Netherlands, author of the first SCION router prototype developed in P4.

References:
[1] David D. Clark. Designing an Internet. MIT Press. 2018
[2] https://www.scion-architecture.net
[3] David Barrera et al., The SCION Internet Architecture, In Communications of the ACM 60 (6), June 2017
[4] https://www.scion-architecture.net/pdf/SCION-book.pdf
[5] https://p4.org<https://p4.org/>
[6] M. Legner et al., EPIC: Every Packet Is Checked in the Data Plane of a Path-Aware Internet, USENIX Security’20

title: Dissertation: Evaluation of crash-consistency in Persistent Memory Applications
objectives:
Persistent memory (PM) is a recent technology that promises to deliver performance similar to DRAM combined with data persistency guarantees across application and machine restarts. PM is not intended to replace either DRAM or SSD/HDD technology but rather to act as a middle tier between those, opening the opportunity for high-performance application programmers to explore novel designs. 
In fact, in the absence of crashes, PM offers the best of both worlds. However, current PM hardware has limited support for atomic-failure writes. This means that upon crashes, and unlike RAM, whose state is completely reset after an application or machine crash, in PM the state is kept but dirty (partial) reads might still be observed upon recovery as there are no guarantees on the order in which writes are persisted. To overcome these issues, developers rely on hardware constructs such as memory fences and cache flushing instructions to ensure a crash-consistent snapshot in the PM. However, due to the above limitations, to persist larger write operations (e.g., updating complex data structures that require multiple operations), developers must rely on auxiliary techniques such as logging. Such techniques are not trivial and, therefore, developing crash-consistent software for PM is a difficult and error-prone process. As a matter of fact, it has been shown that several recently proposed PM applications do not always recover correctly from crashes. This failure in recovering stems from both design- and implementation-level bugs. Finding such failures with the available state-of-the-art tools requires a substantial amount of work, namely manual inspection, and instrumentation of the application code as well as ad-hoc fault injection to emulate hardware crashes. Moreover, existing fault injection techniques either require modifications to the application code or rely on a randomized or time-based approach to inject faults. The former approach requires an expert programmer with good knowledge of the application domain and also of the underlying hardware guarantees which is expensive and error-prone. The latter is unlikely to yield robust results because: i) a random exploration of the search space is unlikely to find the crash-sensitive states for all but toy applications or ii) time-based approaches to fault injection ignore the inherent variability in consecutive application executions due to the unpredictable nature of operating system scheduling, network interrupts and so on.
Therefore, as PM applications become increasingly popular and complex such manual approaches to application testing become infeasible.

The goal of this thesis proposal is to automate the testing of crash-consistency for both PM as memory and PM as disk applications through the use of reproducible fault-injection techniques.


Bibliography
PMTest: A Fast and Flexible Testing Framework for Persistent Memory Programs. ASPLOS 2019
Recipe: Converting Concurrent DRAM Indexes to Persistent-Memory Indexes. SOSP 2019
Torturing Databases for Fun and Profit. OSDI 14
Yat: A Validation Framework for Persistent Memory Software. USENIX ATC 2014

title: Dissertation: Transactional Memory for Processing-In-Memory Systems
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Paolo Romano (romano@inesc-id.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Processing in memory (PIM, sometimes called processor in memory) is the integration of a processor with RAM (random access memory) on a single chip. The result is sometimes known as a PIM chip.

In PIM chip fabrication, CMOS logic devices and memory cells are tightly coupled; processor logic is directly connected to the memory stack. In effect, the integration of processing and memory increases processing speed and memory transfer rate and decreases latency and power usage.

This allows for overcoming the, so-called, "von Neumann bottleneck", i.e., a limitation on throughput caused by the latency inherent in the standard computer architecture.

This thesis aims to design the first transactional memory (TM) for PIM systems. TM is an abstraction that facilitates concurrent programming in highly multi-threaded systems by allowing complex synchronization code to be abstracted away and replaced with atomic transactions. The implementation of the transaction's abstraction is then delegated to either a software library or a specialized hardware unit.

This thesis aims at investigating the design and implementation of a software-based TM system. This is a very hot research topic and this is, to the best of our knowledge, the first proposal in this sense.

title: Dissertação: Photorealism for Architecture
supervisors: António Paulo Teles de Menezes Correia Leitão (100%)
observations: Este tema de tese destina-se ao aluno Vicente Canas Simões.
objectives:
Recent advances in ray tracing have dramatically improved the quality of rendered scenes and the efficiency of its generation. In particular, efficient ray tracing of reflections, of shadows, of ambient occlusion, of reflection and refraction on translucent surfaces, among others, are now possible.

The objective of this thesis is to explore these advancements in the context of a game engine applied to architectural visualization and find the trade-offs between photorealism and performance.

objectives:
No âmbito da iniciativa de investigação ITLingo/RSL (Requirements Specification Language) tem sido definida uma linguagem textual para especificação rigorosa de requisitos (linguagem RSL), cuja versão preliminar se encontra disponível a partir de  https://github.com/ITLingo/RSL.

Em particular, pretende-se que o aluno defina uma biblioteca de requisitos e testes considerando os seguintes aspetos: 
(i) tipos de requisitos de cibersegurança, e.g. privacidade, proteção de dados pessoais, autenticação, autorização, integridade, não repúdio; 
(ii) ferramentas de testes de aceitação e de cibersegurança, e.g., OWASP ZAP, Robot Framework; 
 (iii) estilos de especificação de requisitos e potencial alinhamento com especificação de testes asociados, e.g., misuse cases, threat modeling, attack trees, behavior driven development (BDD), penetration tests; e 
(iv) que os requisitos/testes sejam definidos de forma a serem (tendencialmente) reutilizáveis e aplicados em diferentes cenários de aplicação concreta.

A primeira fase consiste na análise e definição do problema e na investigação sobre a iniciativa ITLingo/RSL, bem como o aprofundamento do corpo de conhecimento relacionado com a engenharia de requisitos e da cibersegurança.

A terceira fase consiste na definição de especificações de requisitos e de testes de segurança para aplicações/sistemas concretos (a definir), o correspondente mapeamento para test scripts em Robot Framework, que permitam a consequente avaliação e discussão dos resultados produzidos.

title: [DISSERTAÇÃO] Comparative analysis of map matching approaches
observations:
- Description -

Map matching is the process of computing which roads (in a known network of roads) a vehicle traversed using the GPS data from the vehicle. Map matching is important both for in-vehicle navigation systems (which must figure the position of a vehicle given sensor data) and as “traffic probes” (to build models of traffic).

Many different approaches have been proposed to address the map matching problem. The classical approach relies on probabilistic models – such as HMMs – and was pioneered by Newson and Krumm [1], but more recent works have explored inverse planning [2], deep learning [4], among others [3]. Unfortunately, most of the existing map-matching works provide little detail regarding the methodologies for performance assessment, making an adequate comparison hard [3].

In this work, the student will conduct a comparative analysis of different map matching approaches, starting from the classical approach of Newson and Krumm [1] and proceeding to more recent approaches. The work will be conducted in collaboration with the company FuelSave (www.fuelsave.io) and use real world data provided by the company.

- References -

[1] P. Newson, J. Krumm. “Hidden Markov map matching through noise and sparseness”. In Proc. 17th ACM SIGSPATIAL Int. Conf. Advances in Geographic Information Systems, pp. 336-343, 2009. 

[2] T. Osogami, R. Raymond. “Map matching with inverse reinforcement learning”. In Proc. 23rd Int. Joint Conf. Artificial Intelligence, pp. 2547-2553, 2013.

[3] M. Quddus, W. Ochieng, R. Noland. “Current map-matching algorithms for transport applications: State-of-the art and future research directions”. Transportation Research Part C, 15:312-328, 2007.

[4] K. Zhao, J. Feng, T. Xia, L. Chen, F. Sun, D. Guo, D. Jin, Y. Li. “DeepMM: Deep learning based map matching with data augmentation”. In Proc. 27th ACM SIGSPATIAL Int. Conf. Advances in Geographic Information Systems, pp. 452-455, 2019.
