No âmbito da iniciativa de investigação ITLingo tem sido definido linguagens textuais para especificação rigorosa de requisitos (linguagem RSL, Requirements Specification Language) e de aplicações de software (linguagem ASL, Application Specification Language), cuja informação preliminar se encontra disponível a partir de https://github.com/ITLingo/RSL. 
Por outro lado, a empresa Quidgest tem vindo a desenvolver o Genio, que é uma plataforma ágil para modelação e geração automática de sistemas de informação integrados, baseada em metodologias como MDD (Model Driven Development), RAD (Rapid Application Development) e DevOps, especialmente recomendada para projetos complexos, únicos e urgentes (ver https://genio.quidgest.com/).
Pretende-se investigar e desenvolver mecanismos de produção automática de protótipos aplicacionais de sistemas de informação a partir das especificações rigorosas em ASL, e tirando partido das tecnologias de validação, transformação e geração automática de modelos em modelos, nomeadamente de modelos ASL em modelos Genio.

No âmbito deste projeto pretende-se que o aluno investigue e consolide os seus conhecimentos nas áreas da engenharia de requisitos, aplicações empresariais, e desenvolvimento baseado em modelos.

(iii) Validação e avaliação dos resultados obtidos, com base na aplicação a cenários concretos a definir.

(iv) Avaliação e discussão dos resultados.

(v) Escrita de artigo a submeter a conferência internacional.

title: [Dissertation] A Reference Implementation of Web Workers
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
JavaScript is the most widespread dynamic language. It is the de facto language for client-side web applications, used by more than 95% of websites [1]. Its behaviour, described in the ECMAScript English standard [2], is highly complex and full of corner cases. Furthermore, client-side JavaScript programs have access to an ever-growing number of browser APIs, making them extremely hard to analyse and debug.   

The Web Workers API [3] is a W3C API that allows client-side JavaScript programs to spawn background “workers”, which can be thought of as cooperative threads [4,5] that run in parallel with the program’s main page. Web Workers abide the non-preemptive multi-threading discipline as each worker runs to completion or until it voluntarily yields control. 

At Imperial College London, the Verified Trustworthy Software Specification group developed JaVerT [11,12], a JavaScript compositional symbolic execution tool with support for verification [6], symbolic execution [7,13], and bi-abduction [8]. JaVerT has gathered interest from researchers both in academia and in industry. It has been the topic of several publications in top-level Programming Language (PL) venues, won a Facebook research award [9], and is currently being used to verify the Amazon AWS Encryption SDK [10]. 

Recently, JaVerT has been extended with a core events module that was used to implement DOM UI events and JavaScript promises. The **goal** of this project is to continue this line of work, using JaVerT’s core events module to implement the Web Workers API. The project will consist of the following three main tasks. Firstly, the student will extend JaVerT’s core events module to allow for message passing communication between workers. Then, the student will implement the Web Workers API directly in JavaScript, using JaVerT’s event primitives to interact with the core events module. Finally, the student will use the new version of JaVerT to symbolically analyse real world JavaScript projects that make use of Web Workers.

title: Dissertação: Attacking self-driving networks
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Prof. Fernando Ramos (fvramos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Computer networks are growing in importance and complexity. They are therefore increasingly juicier targets for sophisticated attacks, and their management is more difficult than ever. Modern network management still leaves the operator at the middle of the loop, struggling to cope with the challenges ahead. Recently, a change of paradigm has been proposed towards self-driving networks (SelfDN), to move the operator out of the loop [1]. A SelfDN tightly couples measurement with data-driven, Machine Learning (ML)-based control, while leveraging recent advances on network programmability, including Software-Defined Networks [2] and programmable data planes (namely SmartNICs, programmable switch ASICs [3,4], and NFV [5]).

To fully realize the vision of a SelfDN, it is, however, crucial to avoid known vulnerabilities in their design. Unfortunately, several ML architectures are vulnerable to simple adversarial inputs [6], meaning that an attacker armed with relatively simple tools may be capable of wreaking havoc an entire networked infrastructure. Recent work has shown that these data-driven, programmable networks are prone to relatively simple adversarial inputs [7], including malicious traffic patterns that change the expected behaviour of the network infrastructure [8].

In this project, the student will explore adversarial attacks on SelfDNs, including analysing known threats (e.g., [7,8]) and devise new attacks. In addition, the student will investigate counter-measures for a selected set of attacks.

The project will be advised by Fernando Ramos (Associate Prof. at the IST). Laurent Vanbever (Associate Prof. at ETH Zurich, ERC Starting Grant holder, and co-author of [7]), will act as external collaborator in the project.

title: Dissertação: A Virtual Reality platform for Scientific Visualization of Plasma Physics Simulation
objectives:
Motivation:
At the Group of Lasers and Plasmas (GoLP) of Instituto de Plasmas e Fusão Nuclear at Instituto Superior Técnico, researchers use Particle-in-Cell (PIC) method-based simulations to model plasma with little or no approximations. PIC simulations solve the smallest scales of the plasma, so simulating large systems (where dynamical scales are much larger than the smallest scales) is computationally demanding. For this reason, these simulations are massively parallel, and run on some of the largest supercomputers available worldwide. These simulations produce multidimensional grid and particle data sets that generally exceed several gigabytes per file, making their analysis and visualization non-trivial.

Objective: 
This thesis aims to produce a platform for scientific visualization of results of the mentioned numerical simulations resorting to virtual reality (VR) experiences. VR glasses and haptic devices will be available for the development.

Description:
Navigating through these interactive visualizations in VR should be an immersive experience, and provide a completely new way of visualizing and interpreting scientific results. Different VR prototypes will be developed and will show numerical simulations of plasmas in the vicinity of compact astrophysical objects such as neutron stars and black holes, as well as of plasmas produced with intense lasers in the laboratory and used to create compact particle accelerators.

title: Dissertação: Blockchain Low Code Multi-actor Information System
supervisors: David Sardinha Andrade de Aveiro daveiro@uma.pt (50%)
observations: Orientador externo da UMa - daveiro@uma.pt
objectives:
This proposal aims at advancing the knowledge in the scope of information systems generated with low code effort to support the execution of inter-organizational business processes involving multiple actors in a ledger. Inter-organizational business processes occur in an environment where actors may not fully trust each other, therefore a need/opportunity exists for a collaborative and autonomous solution without using third parties. Blockchain is a ledger solution that fits this purpose of promoting trust between participants.
BLoCoMIS, the Blockchain Low Code Multi-actor Information System, aims to integrate the blockchain’s body of knowledge within the areas of business processes and low code based information systems. In specific, we aim to conceptualize, develop and test a Blockchain-based contract and process-aware information system with capabilities of business operation contextualization. For instance: How to collectively model and store contracts formalizing agreed interactions between actors in a network? How to store acts regarding day-to-day business operations and associated communication in a distributed and trusted way?
Some recent initiatives have been proposed regarding combining blockchain technology with the most widely used language for business process modelling (BPMN). However, such initiatives face problems regarding large costs and latency in transactions in the blockchain. Furthermore, BPMN suffers from strong shortcomings, namely: complexity of the language, lack of coherent and rich semantics and difficulty in its interpretation. To address these shortcomings, we intend to explore the more flexible and faster permissioned blockchains. Also, the Enterprise Engineering (EE) body of knowledge will be a core foundation of our work in regards to the design of business processes that include a social and human-centered focus and are semantically richer and easier to model/interpret.
A strong and recent trend that has the potential to disrupt the software and information systems field is the development of information systems with low code platforms. From models of processes, rules and business concepts designed in user friendly Graphical User Interfaces, it’s possible to generate or even execute fully functional systems.

Resultados Esperados: 
Assim, são esperados os principais resultados: 1. levantamento de estado da arte sobre soluções e implementações conhecidas na comunidade científica e empresarial, tendo em vista a identificação exacta do problema a ser resolvido; 2. representação de um modelo conceptual que vise propor uma solução para o problema identificado; 3. definição, desenvolvimento e teste de um protótipo; 4. avaliação dos resultados obtidos no ponto 3 como justificação para a correcta solução escolhida no ponto 2.; 5. publicação de artigo(s) ao longo da execução da tese.
requirements: Disciplinas da especialização de Sistemas Empresariais ou Sistemas de Informação

title: [Dissertação] : Neural Architecture Search for Semantic Segmentation of Aerial Imagery
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Paolo Romano ( https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~romanop/ ), and it will be developed in the context of the MIMU research project, currently being executed at INESC-ID.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers participating in the project, including a PhD student named João Monteiro that is also working on similar topics, and another researcher at INESC-ID named Jacinto Estima.

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Semantic segmentation concerns predicting dense-pixel maps from original input images ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.10230 ), in which each pixel is mapped to a predefined class such as car, tree, building, etc. In remote sensing data analysis, semantic segmentation of aerial images (e.g., collected through satellites, planes or drones) is a crucial research topic with many applications in environmental and urban planning (e.g., segmenting building footprints, road-segments, bridges, and other types of man-made structures, for informing urban settlement analysis, forest management, demography studies, etc.). The main challenge in this task relates to the heterogeneous appearance and high intra-class variances of objects on very high resolution images.

Recently, deep learning methods based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have been used to tackle pixel-to-pixel prediction tasks such as the semantic segmentation of aerial images, using fully-convolutional encoder/decoder architectures (see http://segmentation-models.readthedocs.io/) and loss functions specifically designed for segmentation problems (see http://lars76.github.io/neural-networks/object-detection/losses-for-segmentation/). These models use standard convolution operations to downsample the spatial resolution of the input, developing lower-resolution feature mappings which are highly efficient at discriminating between classes, afterwards using the feature mappings in transposed convolution operations to upsample the feature representations into a full-resolution segmentation map.

Many different architectures have been proposed for semantic segmentation, including approaches exploring recent designs such as residual and/or dense connections, tailored pooling and/or attention mechanisms (see http://arxiv.org/abs/1912.10667 or http://arxiv.org/abs/2003.13328), or approaches for introducing equivariances to rotations or changes in scale (see http://arxiv.org/pdf/2002.03830.pdf or http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.11783). Although CNN-based method have achieved remarkable progress, these models face serious overfitting issues that motivate data augmentation strategies (see http://arxiv.org/pdf/1809.06839v1.pdf) or proper regularisation schemes. Moreover, human expertise is required for designing and optimising architectures. Recently, significant effort has been put into the study of methods for automatically searching and selecting/designing neural network architectures (see the literature survey at http://www.automl.org/automl/literature-on-neural-architecture-search/), leveraging Bayesian methods, evolutionary computation, or gradient-based approaches.

This MSc research project concerns the development and evaluation of neural networks for semantic segmentation of aerial images, leveraging neural architecture search in order to perform the selection of architectures that exhibit interesting trade-offs between model accuracy and computational requirements. The models that are to be developed can take inspiration on recent proposals already leveraging neural architecture search, such as the EfficientDet model ( http://arxiv.org/abs/1911.09070 ) or evolved normalization-activation layers (http://arxiv.org/abs/2004.02967), combining these ideas with the search for architectures that consider particular equivariances to changes in the input data. Another idea to be explored related to the fact that the complexity of the segmentation task should, in principal, impact the improvements than on may expect from deeper neural models. Indexes from the area of landscape ecology ( see https://pylandstats.readthedocs.io/en/latest/landscape.html ) can perhaps be used to estimate how complex are the segmentation masks associated to the training instances, using this information to help in the search for neural architectures that achieve an optimal balance between accuracy and computational performance.

Evaluation experiments will be conducted on standard datasets in the area ( see http://github.com/chrieke/awesome-satellite-imagery-datasets ), with a particular focus on the ISPRS semantic labelling datasets for the cities of Vaihingen and Potsdam.

title: Project: Development of an Innovative Online Whiteboard Application
objectives:
The goal of this project is to develop an innovative online whiteboard application that supports structured editing of handwritten input. The project will use as a starting point an editor such as XBoard [1] or Xournal++[2]; the idea is to extend one of these editors with features that support remote and self-learning. Given the recent shift to online/remote work and teaching, an innovative scientific editor such as the one proposed can have a massive impact.

One of the directions is to enable recognition of mathematical input. There are existing tools and packages that already provide support to recognise handwritten mathematics (e.g. SESHAT [2]), with some even allowing its manipulation (e.g. Windows OneNote Maths Assistant [3] and Graspable Math [4])). In this direction, you will decide if/how these solutions can be integrated into XBoard or Xournal++.

objectives: Atualmente, por inexistência de capacidade instalada para o efeito, apenas uma pequena parte das decisões do Supremo Tribunal de Justiça é publicada. title: Dissertação: Verification of Resource-Centered Concurrency Control Properties
observations:
More information:
Ana Matos - ana.matos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
Jan Cederquist - jan.cederquist@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
objectives:
Parallel processing hardware is currently present in nearly all computational systems, from the nodes that compose cloud infrastructures to small hand-held devices. Concurrent programming thus plays a fundamental role in today’s software development. However, concurrent code is considered difficult to write and its correctness complex to assess, being hence the source of many execution errors.

Classically, expressing concurrency constraints on accesses to shared memory objects requires delimiting explicitly the sequences of instructions that must operate atomically upon such objects, what we refer to as control-centric concurrency control. The main drawback of control centrality is that it is prone to the dispersal of concurrency related bugs, which hampers reasoning about correctness as the code scales: a single missing lock/unlock oper-ation (or atomic keyword) may adulterate an application’s behaviour.  Data-centric concurrency control is a recent approach that promotes local rather than distributed reasoning, by centralising all concurrency control management on data declaration. 

The aim of this thesis is to collaborate on the study of a Resource-Centred Concurrency Control model that builds only upon the individual annotation of the data items (the re-sources) that must be atomically manipulated, to provide a simpler model for data-centric concurrency control.  Locks for concurrency control are to be generated automatically from these annotations.

Several possible tasks are available, including, but not limited to the formalization of the algorithm for generation of locks using an automatic tool (COQ). This task is part of an ongoing research project, and the student is expected to collaborate with the rest of the team.
requirements: Strong record in programming languages, including successful attendance of a masters-level course in security, verification or quality of software.

title: Dissertação: Increasing privacy in interactions between robot and humans using Blockchain - testing in real environment
objectives:
Os sistemas de informação hospitalares apresentam um conjunto significativo de desafios para o Engenheiro Informático. A privacidade localiza-se, hoje, no topo destes desafios afectando uma multiplicidade de pessoas que trabalham, ou usam, cuidados de saúde. Por outro lado, os robots quando inseridos nos ambientes hospitalares introduzem uma capacidade acrescida de benefício social, mas também de recolha de dados em grande quantidade. Estes dados têm que ser tratados atendendo aos requisitos legais, p.e., impostos pelo RGPD. Assim, torna-se clara a necessidade de encontrar novas soluções que suportem esta preocupação. Neste sentido, o Blockchain é uma solução que contem propriedades compatíveis com os requisitos de privacidade impostos pelo RGPD. 
Em específico pretende-se testar uma plataforma já existente, sendo para isso necessário efectuar um levantamento do contexto existente com uma clara definição das variáveis dinâmicas mais relevantes existentes.

Assim, são esperados os principais resultados: 1. levantamento de estado da arte sobre soluções e implementações conhecidas na comunidade científica e empresarial, tendo em vista a identificação exacta do problema a ser resolvido; 2. representação de um modelo conceptual que vise propor uma solução para o problema identificado; 3. definição, de testes de um protótipo que permite integrar dados do ambiente com interacção social entre robot e humanos e a solução Blockchain; 4. avaliação dos resultados obtidos no ponto 3 como justificação para a correcta solução escolhida no ponto 2.; 5. publicação de artigo(s) ao longo da execução da tese.

title: [Projeto] GameCourseUI
objectives:
A Gamificação de cursos universitários tem levado a resultados promissores. Nesta, cria-se um conjunto de mecanismos que permitam adaptar o processo de ensino/aprendizagem ao perfil dos alunos através da utilização de elementos de jogo. Uma instância da Gamificação neste contexto tem sido a cadeira de Produção de Conteúdos Multimédia do Curso de Engenharia Informática e de Computadores do IST ao longo de vários anos letivos. A interface ainda pode ser melhorada, no entanto, especialmente no que diz respeito a novas features relacionadas com um ensino personalizado: mostrar o leaderboard, págians pessoais, etc. de forma diferente a diferentes alunos.

O objetivo desta tese é criar melhorar a interface do GameCourse, tanto em termos de front-end como de back-end que permita otimizar a forma como o jogo é jogado e gerido, e facilitando a criação de vistas alternativas para alunos de perfis diferentes.

title: Projecto: Lab de IoT
observations: A instalar no laboratório de Interacção e IoT do DEI.
objectives:
Criação de um ambiente inteligente em espaço interior (sala, corredor) através do desenvolvimento, prototipagem e instalação de uma rede de sensores que permita medir as condições ambientais e avaliar as condições de utilização/ocupação do espaço.

Descrição:

A miniaturização da electrónica permite dispor actualmente de dispositivos com poder de cálculo suficiente para enriquecer o comportamento de pequenos sensores e actuadores embebidos no meio envolvente.
Usando open-sourced hardware da família Arduino (www.arduino.cc), e as várias ferramentas de desenvolvimento para ela disponíveis, vamos definir, desenvolver e configurar uma pequena rede de sensores interligados numa rede WiFi para instalação futura nos laboratórios de Informática (corredores e salas de laboratório). A rede deverá permitir ligar sensores e actuadores de vários tipos, permitindo a medida das condições ambientais (temperatura, humidade, luminosidade), e o tipo de utilização do laboratório (grau aproximado de ocupação); deverá ainda ser possível controlar algumas funções básicas de ventilação (AVAC) em equipamentos já instalados através da emulação do seu controlo remoto.

Deverão ser abordados ao longo do projecto a definição, desenvolvimento e prototipagem dos sensores (temperatura, luminosidade, movimento), a sua rede (níveis físico e lógico com base em middleware já desenvolvido), os método de identificação e endereçamento dos sensores/actuadores, e as correspondentes APIs. Finalmente dever-se-á definir e desenvolver uma aplicação demonstradora que exercite as funcionalidades desenvolvidas no controlo de um protótipo realista (exemplo, controlo da temperatura numa sala, com ventilação eventualmente dirigida para as zonas críticas) com monitorização em tempo real referenciada numa planta das instalações.
requirements: Interesse por sistemas da IOT (sensores, Arduino, etc.).

title: DISSERTAÇÂO : Desenvolvimento de um classificador baseado em HyperDenseNet para análise da mama
supervisors: Jacinto Carlos Marques Peixoto do Nascimento (50%)
location: Instituto de Sistemas e Robótica - Torre Norte
objectives: Neste trabalho propõe-se o desenvolvimento de um classificado multimodal, para diagnóstico do cancro da mama. O classificador é baseado no uso de um modelo HyperDenseNet. O classificador a desenvolver consiste num ensemble de redes interligadas, que têm como entrada três modalidades de imagem: (i) mamografia (com as vistas de cranio-caudal (CC)  e médio-lateral oblíqua (MLO)), (ii) ultrasom, e (iii) ressonância magnética. O ensemble é conseguido pela fusão de camadas densas (dense layers)  de cada rede para a modalidade de imagem mãe. A modalidade mãe é então conectada ao classificador, que vai classificar a imagem numa de três classes: (i) ausência de lesão, (ii) presença de lesão benigna, (iii) presença de lesão maligna. Os teste serão realizados numa nova base de dados multimodal contendo as modalidades acima mencionadas.
requirements: Conhecimentos da linguagem Pytorch, ou outras (matlab, tensorflow), necessárias à implementação de algoritmos de deep learning

title: Projecto: Drones in Lab
observations: O piloto a desenvolver será integrado no Laboratório de Interacção e IoT, do DEI.
objectives:
Criação em espaço interior (sala/laboratório, corredor) de um sistema de corredores "aéreos" para movimento de pequenos drones que permita a coexistência de múltiplas plataformas voadoras no espaço.

Descrição:
Existem actualmente múltiplas plataformas móveis voadoras (drones) facilmente programáveis e configuráveis com diversas interfaces sensoriais.

Usando open-sourced hardware da família Arduino (www.arduino.cc), ou de outra arquitectura aberta para drones, e as várias ferramentas de desenvolvimento para elas disponíveis, vamos definir, desenvolver e configurar uma pequena esquadrilha de drones capazes de se movimentarem, sem conflitos catastróficos num espaço confinado (ex. laboratório de ensino - RNL na Alameda).

Para tal os drones deverão ser dotados dos sensores, ou outros mecanismos de localização, para suportar o algoritmos de navegação em trajectórias pré-definidas, ou com controlo remoto (preferencialmente a partir de smartphone Android).

Deverá ainda ser desenvolvimento um "centro de gestão do espaço aéreo" que siga e coordene os movimentos das aeronaves, ajudando a resolver situações de congestionamento.

Deverão ser abordados ao longo do projecto a definição, selecção e prototipagem dos sensores a bordo (ultrassons, infravermelhos, imagem?), das comunicações com o centro de controlo, e a programação das funcionalidades correspondentes.

Finalmente dever-se-á definir e desenvolver uma aplicação demonstradora que exercite o funcionamento do sistema global.

Tal como nos sistemas aeroespaciais o sistema global será constituído por dois sub-sistemas bem definidos:
- o "segmento terrestre" (ground station), constituído pelo centro de gestão que visualiza e coordena o espaço aéreo, e
- as "aeronaves" que se movimentam no espaço aéreo.

title: [Dissertação] : Document Geocoding and Toponym Resolution with Neural Language Models
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Maguelonne Teisseire ( https://textmining.biz/Staff/Teisseire/ ), and it will be developed in the context of the MIMU and MOOD research projects, currently being executed at INESC-ID. The MOOD project involves a cooperation with researchers from France's National Research Institute for Agriculture, Food and Environment, i.e. the host institution for the co-supervisor.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including Prof. Jacinto Estima ( https://jestima.github.io/ ) that is also working on the MIMU project.

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Toponym resolution, also known as geo-parsing, geo-grounding or place name resolution, aims to assign geographic coordinates to all location names mentioned in documents. Toponym resolution is usually performed in two independent steps. The first step concerns toponym detection, where the spans of place names mentioned in a document are delimited. In the second step, toponym disambiguation or geocoding, each of the discovered place names is mapped to latitude and longitude coordinates corresponding to the centroid of its physical location. A related problem to toponym resolution is document geocoding, which concerns with assigning an entire textual document to the latitude and longitude coordinates that best match its contents, e.g. summarizing the results of toponym resolution or instead directly leveraging the textual contents. 

Previous methods for toponym disambiguation and document geocoding have explored machine learning approaches based on language modelling (e.g., see https://repositories.lib.utexas.edu/handle/2152/40313 or https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/W16-1721.pdf ), and both tasks can also nowadays be addressed through the use of state-of-the-art deep learning methods for NLP, e.g. related to the use of contextual embedding models such as BERT or roBERTa ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.07278 ). However, previous studies have shown that the performance of these methods varies greatly when applied on corpora of different genres and domains. 

This MSc research project related to the development and evaluation of novel toponym resolution and document geocoding methods, advancing over the state-of-the-art in several directions and specifically envisioning the application to a scientific domain where these tasks can provide crucial knowledge, namely in epidemiology. One aim in epidemiology is to create maps for the locations of specific health problems, which provide tools to monitor and intervene during disease epidemics. Specific information about the locations of these health problems may be present in scientific articles which describe related research work, or even in standard news articles reporting on disease epidemics. 

The work will specifically address the development of multi-lingual methods that can apply to both these domains (i.e., scientific publications are general news text), for instance relying on multi-lingual contextual word embedding models ( see some of the models available from https://github.com/huggingface/transformers ). Evaluation will rely on existing corpora ( e.g., the dataset released in the context of the SemEval-2019 competition on Toponym Resolution in Scientific Papers - https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/S19-2155/ ), as well as on new datasets to be developed through the course of this work. 

Particular emphasis will also be given to the design of innovative approaches for toponym resolution and document geocoding, and ideas that we envision exploring relate to (a) better exploiting the Earth’s spherical geometry in the context of global-coverage approaches ( https://ecmlpkdd2019.org/downloads/paper/63.pdf ), through loss functions based on Mixtures of von-Mises Fisher distributions, (b) exploiting hierarchical knowledge from multiple and/or combinatorial partitionings of the geographic space ( e.g., see  http://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_ECCV_2018/papers/Eric_Muller-Budack_Geolocation_Estimation_of_ECCV_2018_paper.pdf or http://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_ECCV_2018/papers/Paul_Hongsuck_Seo_Enhancing_Image_Geolocalization_ECCV_2018_paper.pdf ), and (c) exploiting additional/external information in the form of remote sensing datasets and/or existing maps describing population, climate, of health-related variables, in order to create priors that can inform the disambiguation models ( e.g., see https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/P18-1119.pdf ).

title: Dissertação: RPA4Traductanet: Languages and Best Practices for Robotic Process Automation
observations:
Orientador: Prof. Alberto Rodrigues da Silva
Co-orientador: Dr. Luís Costa  (Traductanet lda), luis.costa@traductanet.com
objectives:
Robotic Process Automation (RPA) is an umbrella term for tools that operate on the user interface of other computer systems in the way a human would do. RPA aims to replace people with automation done in an "outside-in" manner. This differs from the classical “inside-out” approach to improve information systems. Unlike traditional workflow technology, the information system remains unchanged. Gartner defines Robotic Process Automation (RPA) (Tornbohm 2017) as a set of tools that perform [if, then, else] statements on structured data, typically using a combination of user interface interactions, or by connecting to APIs to drive client servers, mainframes or HTML code. An RPA tool operates by mapping a process in the RPA tool language for the software robot to follow, with runtime allocated to execute the script by a control dashboard. Hence, RPA tools aim to reduce the burden of repetitive, simple tasks on employees (Aguirre and Rodriguez 2017).
There are dedicated RPA vendors like AutomationEdge, Automation Anywhere, Blue Prism, Kryon Systems, Softomotive, and UiPath that offer complete RPA tools (Tornbohm 2017), but there are also RPA open source solutions like RobotFramework, TagUI, Robocorp, or Automagica (Casey 2020).

The student shall research RPA technologies, namely by using open source tools, and their relationship with business processes. The student shall apply and discuss the RPA application to identify, improve and automate human-intense business processes in the context of the company Traductanet. Traductanet is an international multilingual translation and interpreting agency that was established over 30 years ago and specializes in translation, software and website localization, terminology management and interpreting (ver www.traductanet.com). Examples of the considered processes would be in the domains of (to be defined): customer relationship management, and project management. Finally, the student shall produce a paper and a dissertation that discuss the applied research, by reporting the main technical and business decisions and by assessing the main advantages of the RPA adoption.


Keywords: Robotic Process Automation (RPA), Automation, Business Process, Domain-specific language, RPA tools.


References:
Aguirre S, Rodriguez A (2017) Automation of a business process using robotic process automation (RPA): a case study. Appl Comput Sci Eng Commun Comput Inf Sci. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-66963-2_7
Tornbohm C (2017) Gartner market guide for robotic process automation software. Report G00319864. Gartner
Casey K. (2020) Robotic Process Automation (RPA): 6 open source tools. https://enterprisersproject.com/article/2020/4/rpa-robotic-process-automation-6-open-source-tools

title: Dissertação: Development of models to optimize IPST blood collections
observations: Joana Alves - 86439
objectives:
The Instituto Português do Sangue e da Transplantação (IPST) is a public institute of the Ministry of Health, and the recognized authority for the collection and regulation of blood donation and transplantation at the national level. Operational productivity of IPST is crucial for the blood supply chain in Portugal, since it monitors the quality and safety of donation, procurement, processing, storage, preservation and distribution of human blood, blood components, organs, tissues and human origin cells.

Resource location-allocation and planning problems in blood services usually handle inventory allocation and distribution scheduling. Inventory management determines ordering policies along the blood supply chain through simulation-optimization frameworks and metaheuristics. Moreover, stochastic programming and robust optimization approaches have been developed to locate permanent and temporary blood donation centers and for platelet production and distribution planning problems. Multiple objectives such as minimize wastage and shortage of blood products (platelets and red blood cells) and minimize overall cost are often considered.

The main goal is to develop new models and algorithms to optimize blood collection planning to better match transfusion needs in mainland Portugal, in order to deliver the right blood products when they are needed, avoiding dramatic consequences of shortages and ethical implications of waste.

title: Project: Energy Management for Smart Homes
objectives: É muito importante gerir de forma eficaz os consumos energéticos numa habitação, promovendo a realização de poupanças. Pretende-se desenvolver uma aplicação web que recebe informação sobre os consumos (consumo global e discriminado por equipamento ou área), devendo gerar estatísticas e informação que possa ser apresentada ao utilizador em tempo real. Deve também poder aconselhar que cargas podem ser desligadas, reduzidas ou transferidas para um período horário em que a energia seja mais barata. A aplicação deve previamente poder ser configurada usando um conjunto de informação e critérios diversos; por exemplo, poderão ser fornecidas listas com os equipamentos existentes, seus consumos, principais características de funcionamento, se permitem agendamento horário, duração típica do ciclo de funcionamento, se podem ser desligadas e ligadas mais tarde, se o nível de potência pode ser regulado, etc. Deverá ainda ser possível ao utilizador indicar preferências e excepções. A solução deverá poder considerar a existência de produção para auto-consumo (por ex., painéis solares) e optimizar o uso dessa energia. Pretende-se também explorar um modelo em que equipamentos de elevado consumo necessitam previamente pedir autorização para se ligarem, facilitando a sua gestão e evitando que o consumo máximo definido seja ultrapassado. Idealmente poderá ser considerada a existência de equipamentos do tipo "Sonoff Pow 16A" ou outras soluções IoT, mas a aplicação pode ser desenvolvida unicamente num contexto de simulação sem necessidade de interacção directa com medidores de consumo nem com actuadores.

title: Dissertação: Synthesis of network switch programs
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Prof. Fernando Ramos (fvramos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) and Prof. Luis Pedrosa (luis.pedrosa@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Building the networks that power modern distributed systems has led to new designs and architectures that are often not backward compatible with standard network devices and frameworks. This has led to a recent push for increased programmability and configurability in the network, with different efforts trading off flexibility, performance, and complexity.

One of the most recent advances was the emergence of programmable packet switch ASICs. A first system prototype was presented in 2013 [1], and the first commercial Ethernet switch based on a programmable ASIC – the Intel/Barefoot Tofino – came to market in 2016 [2]. These switches extend the control plane programmability offered by software defined networks [3] to the data plane, with better performance than software network functions (NFs) [4]. This new class of commodity switches allow operators to precisely define packet processing using a high-level language (e.g., P4 [5,6]) and run at Tbps scales. These switch architectures enable programmability of packet parsing (i.e., the user can define the packet headers) and match-action tables (enabling users to define the forwarding behaviour and additional processing). While simple to guarantee line rate processing, their computing model also enables simple operations and access to (limited amounts of) stateful memory, enabling offloading of packet computations from software to this dedicated switch hardware, running 100x to 1000x faster.

That said, programmable switches trade these factors off for complexity, as it requires specific expertise on a new language for packet processing (e.g., P4) and on packet switch architectures that are very restrict in terms of memory [7] and computing power [8], therefore limiting the wider adoption of these technologies.

In this thesis we will address this complexity by automatically synthesizing P4 programs for a network data plane to improve performance for software NFs that are given as input. Our specific goal is to build a static analysis tool that analyzes the NF code and subsequently generates a P4 program that offloads as much packet processing functionality to the programmable switch as possible. The end result will be a new version of the original NF, where some or all of the packet processing functionality is done on the P4 programmable switch, thus offering the same programmability of software NFs with the performance of a network ASIC.

References:

[1] Pat Bosshart et al., Forwarding Metamorphosis: Fast Programmable Match-Action Processing in Hardware for SDN. ACM SIGCOMM 2013

[2] https://barefootnetworks.com/products/brief-tofino/

[3] D. Kreutz, F. M. V. Ramos, P. E. Veríssimo, C. E. Rothenberg, S. Azodolmolky and S. Uhlig, "Software-Defined Networking: A Comprehensive Survey," in Proceedings of the IEEE, vol. 103, no. 1, pp. 14-76, Jan. 2015, doi: 10.1109/JPROC.2014.2371999.

[4] B. Han, V. Gopalakrishnan, L. Ji and S. Lee, "Network function virtualization: Challenges and opportunities for innovations," in IEEE Communications Magazine, vol. 53, no. 2, pp. 90-97, Feb. 2015, doi: 10.1109/MCOM.2015.7045396.

[5] P4 Language Consortium, https://p4.org

[6] Pat Bosshart et al., P4: Programming Protocol-Independent Packet Processors, ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, Volume 44, Number 3, July 2014

[7] Lavanya Jose et al. Compiling Packet Programs to Reconfigurable Switches. USENIX NSDI 2015

[8] A. Sivaraman et al., Packet Transactions: High-Level Programming for Line-Rate Switches, SIGCOMM 2016

title: Dissertation: HumourAI- Agentes e robôs com humor
objectives:
Será que a presença de agentes com corpo (virtuais ou robóticos) pode gerar situações hilariantes? Será que é possível colocar um agente a fazer piadas como o Ricardo Araújo Pereira num jogo com humanos?
Este projeto destina-se a usar técnicas de machine learning  (ML) para treinar um agente a  classificar a qualidade de uma frase (piada) gerada por um jogo, e a gerar piadas no mesmo. O jogo escolhido é uma variação do jogo “Cards Against the Humanity” e o grande objetivo do projeto é criar robôs que conseguem jogar um jogo de uma forma humorística. O projeto envolve a criação e o uso de um data set (que será feito em colaboração com a Universidade Carnegie Mellon nos Estados Unidos da Améria) para encontrar forma de gerar combinações que tenham piada. Os robôs a usar são os robôs EMYS que estão disponíveis no GAIPS (ver https://gaips.inesc-id.pt/)

A tese será desenvolvida em 6 fases:
- Pesquisa bibliográfica sobre a área de robôs sociais e de humor computacional
- Criação do jogo para ser jogado com robôs e agentes
- Criação de um dataset anotado de piadas (em colaboração com a faculdade de psicologia no ISCTE) 
- Criação de um algoritmo para detectar se uma dada piada de facto tem piada (usando o dataset criado)
- Usar o algoritmo para gerar piadas para o robô
- Estudo com humanos no jogo de forma a avaliar a performance do sistema criado.
- Obtenção de resultados e escrita da tese.

Esta tese será integrada num projeto em colaboração o com o CMU (com o Prof. Louis-Philippe Morency  https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~morency/) e com uma Prof. de psicologia do ISCTE (Prof. Patricia Arriaga).

title: Dissertação: Mono2Micro - From a Monolith to Microservices: Metrics refinement
objectives:
The microservices architecture allows the existence of several autonomous agile development teams but result in a distributed system where the aspect of consistency becomes critical, the CAP theorem.

As results of previous MSc thesis, a tool was developed for monolith applications that applies static and dynamic code analysis to collect which domain entities are accessed by each one of the application's controllers, uses similarity measures to define clusters, and provides a user interface to allow the software developer analyse different partitioning hypothesis. Additionally, a complexity metric for the cost of migrating a monolith to microservices architecture was defined and implemented in the system.

The goal of this thesis is to extend the existing Mono2Micro tool to explore new metrics metrics and compare the results of their application with the results obtained so far.
requirements: Study the different qualities associated with a microservices architecture and define metric for each one of these qualities.Compare the results of applying the metrics on different candidate decompositions, and analyse their consistency and trade-offs.

title: Dissertação: Gerador de níveis para o jogo Geometry Friends
location: Este trabalho realiza-se no GAIPS - INESC-ID e no Laboratório de Jogos, no IST- Taguspark.
objectives:
O objectivo do trabalho é desenvolver um gerador de níveis para o jogo Geometry Friends. É um jogo colaborativo onde dois personagens com habilidades distintas têm de se coordenar para conseguir passar os diversos níveis. Os níveis colocam desafios de coordenação de movimentos e puzzles num mundo 2D com física aos jogadores. Mais informação sobre o jogo pode ser encontrada aqui (http://gaips.inesc-id.pt/geometryfriends/) na secção “The Game”.
A questão principal para este tese é gerar níveis que apresentem um boa experiência para os dois jogadores. Por exemplo, um nível não pode ser divertido apenas para um jogador devido a ter mais desafio que o outro.
O trabalho seguirá uma abordagem iniciada por um trabalho anterior que usa Algoritmos Genéticos para a geração dos níveis usando algumas restrições definidas pelo designer que usa a ferramenta. Por exemplo, definindo as zonas que são permitidas a cada um dos jogadores.
Como resultado espera-se melhorias nos resultados do algoritmo capaz de gerar níveis interessante para o jogo Geometry Friends. O trabalho envolve a realização de estudos para aferir a qualidade dos níveis em termos da experiência que proporciona aos jogadores.
requirements: Conhecimentos e interesse em Inteligência Artificial Interativa e Design de Jogos. Interesse por temas de investigação.

title: Dissertação: Explorando soluções de Blockchain para aumentar a credibilidade dos certificados digitais - abordagem orientada aos processos de negócio em DEMO
objectives:
O problema da falta de credibilidade de certificados, p.e., diplomas falsos, contrafeitos, ou “comprados” é uma séria ameaça ao correcto funcionamento de processos documentais onde exista seriação baseada nestes dados. A disponibilidade das plataformas digitais aumenta o impacto deste problema com impactos múltiplos para a economia. Por outro lado, as soluções baseadas em Blockchain contem propriedades compatíveis com requisitos de privacidade e controlo fino de assets, que são impostos, p.e., pelo RGPD. Pretende-se modelar os processos de negócio que estão incluídos no projecto QualiChain com o objectivo de obter uma visão integrada e essencial usando DEMO.

Tese irá decorrer no contexto de um projecto Europeu QualiChain com o envolvimento das entidades nacionais AMA e INA, e a plataforma FenixEDU.

Assim, são esperados os principais resultados: 1. levantamento de estado da arte sobre soluções e implementações conhecidas na comunidade científica e empresarial, tendo em vista a identificação exacta do problema a ser resolvido; 2. representação de um modelo ontológico que vise propor uma solução para o problema identificado; 3. Utilizar o modelo ontológico para comparar múltiplas soluções de Blockchain e assim identificar as propriedades essenciais que devem ser consideradas no futuro; 4. avaliação dos resultados obtidos no ponto 3 como justificação para a correcta solução escolhida no ponto 2.; 5. publicação de artigo(s) ao longo da execução da tese.

title: Project: DE4A: A Platform for Students to Move between European Universities
supervisors: Miguel Nuno Dias Alves Pupo Correia (50%)
location: Distributed Systems Group ( https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/ ), INESC-ID Alameda (preferred) or IST Taguspark (alternative) or remote work (if the situation requires it)

objectives:
The European Union is promoting the automation of processes that involve transferring documents between countries. This thesis is going to be developed in the context of project DE4A in which INESC-ID (an IST research center) is a participant (https://www.de4a.eu/). Project DE4A aims to automate processes related to university students that move from one country to another, specifically the process of presenting documents (e.g., the bachelor or master certificate). For example, if a student from IST in a few years moves to another European country to do his master or doctorate, he will be able to apply at the university abroad by showing his Cartão do Cidadão, without first collecting documents like the certificate/diploma of Licenciatura.

The objective of the thesis is to implement a platform that could be used at IST or Universidade de Lisboa as part of that mobility service. The platform will have to support authentication with Cartão do Cidadão and interact with Fénix (using its APIs). It will also have to run and interact with a container provided by the DE4A project that supports the communication with the universities abroad (i.e., that part will not be developed by the student).

The platform has two parts. The first -- Data Provider -- is  a server that is called by the system of the university abroad. The server asks the student to authenticate in Fénix, accesses Fénix using its APIs, and obtains the information about the program the student finished at IST. The second -- Data Consumer -- is a portal for a student from another European country to get his documents from his university when applying to IST. 

The work plan has the following phases:

- Study of the context, technologies necessary, and related work

- Design and implementation of the platform

- Evaluation 

- Writing of the thesis

title: [Dissertação] Correcção Automática de Vulnerabilidades em Software
observations: _AEG: Automatic Exploit Generation_, Thanassis Avgerinos, Sang Kil Cha, Brent Lim Tze Hao, David Brumley [link](https://kilthub.cmu.edu/articles/AEG_Automatic_Exploit_Generation/6468296)
objectives:
Todos os dias são reportadas vulnerabilidades ao nível do software e o volume de software produzido todos os dias é incompatível com a sua verificação manual. Tendências recentes de detecção e correcção automática de vulnerabilidades têm por isso ganho adeptos nos últimos anos, em muito impulsionadas pelo _DARPA’s 2016 Cyber Grand Challenge_ organizado em 2016 durante a DefCon em Las Vegas em que 7 sistemas autónomos competiram entre eles com o objectivo não só de detectar e explorar vulnerabilidades, mas também de efectuar correcções ao programa vulnerável.

Esta proposta de investigação segue esta tendência e têm por objectivo a utilização de técnicas de Linguagens de Programação (Symbolic Execution) e Engenharia de Software (Fault-Localization) na detecção de vulnerabilidades, e na subsequente correcção das mesmas. O racional é usar as técnicas de FL para melhor guiar a SE.

Neste contexto já foi desenvolvido um motor de execução simbólica (guiado) capaz de analisar programas x86 e detectar vulnerabilidades em alguns dos programas do dataset da [DARPA Cyber Grand Challenge](https://github.com/CyberGrandChallenge/) pretendendo-se neste momento usar essa informação e proceder à correcção das vulnerabilidades encontradas.

# Objectivo - Correcção de Vulnerabilidades

Após a detecção de uma vulnerabilidade, e de um potencial ponto de falha, o objectivo é descobrir as condições mínimas necessárias para corrigir essa mesma vulnerabilidade. Idealmente a correcção deveria ser feita por forma a que a vulnerabilidade não pudesse mais ser explorada, ao mesmo tempo que não se perdia nenhuma funcionalidade do programa.

Para além disso, a fonte da vulnerabilidade pode não ser um único ponto e por isso o desafio desta dissertação passa também por corrigir vulnerabilidades que derivam de diferentes blocos de código.
requirements: Interesse em Segurança em Software

title: [DISSERTAÇÃO] Ad hoc teamwork for human-robot interaction
observations:
- Description -

In this work, the student will investigate ad hoc teamwork in the context of human-robot interaction. Ad hoc teamwork investigates the problem of an agent that must coordinate with a team of unknown teammates in a possibly unknown task [3]. Interestingly, collaborative tasks involving humans and robots typically require the robot to be able to figure out the human user’s goals and actions in order to properly adjust/adapt its own behavior to that of the human user. Therefore, human-robot interaction scenarios provide a privileged setup to explore ad hoc teamwork.

Unfortunately, in real world settings robots are plagued with severe perceptual limitations, that convey only a very limited view of the human user’s states and actions. Ad hoc teamwork approaches in the literature [1-3] fail to consider situations where the perceptions of the ad hoc agent are limited and, as such, are unsuited for real world human-robot interaction scenarios. The main goal of this work is, therefore, to extend the ad hoc teamwork formalism to HRI scenarios while accommodating the perceptual limitations inherent to humans.

In order to address this problem, the student will extend the key ideas from [2] to sequential, partially observable settings, using the formalism of online prediction. The resulting algorithms will then be deployed in the robot Astro in a simple indoor navigation scenario.

- References -

[1] S. Barrett, A. Rosenfeld, S. Kraus, P. Stone. “Making friends on the fly: Cooperating with new teammates.” Artificial Intelligence, 242:132-171, 2017.

[2] F. Melo, A. Sardinha. “Ad hoc teamwork by learning teammates' task.” J. Autonomous Agents and Multi-agent Systems, 30(2):175-219, 2016.

[3] P. Stone, G. Kaminka, S. Kraus, J. Rosenschein. “Ad hoc autonomous agent teams: Collaboration without pre-coordination.” In Proc. 24th AAAI Conf. Artificial Intelligence, pp. 1504-1509, 2010.
requirements: The student should be comfortable with reinforcement learning and multiagent systems, as provided in courses such as PADI and AASMA. Familiarity with robots and HRI is also beneficial, as provided in courses such as Social Robots and Human-Robot Interaction.

title: Dissertação || Distributed, Trustless, Service Providing with a Network of Blockchains
observations: Trabalho proposto por José Lino: 70647	MEIC-T
objectives:
Motivation: Given the end of the hype cycle of the Blockchain technology, the technology is now maturing. Blockchain is useful when there are several untrusting parties that need to share data and/or perform computations. When entities need to cooperate, Smart contracts that encompass the business logic can be written and deployed on a blockchain, public or private (e.g. Ethereum or Hyperledger Fabric). Nonetheless, such smart contracts, and cooperative environment suffer from two problems: 1) they are tied to a specific blockchain implementation, 2) services they provide rely on the survivability of a particular blockchain.
The main idea of this master thesis is to leverage a set of blockchains to increase dependability of blockchain powered services, administrated by several stakeholders.  

Description: Currently, there are several options that allow developers to build and interoperable custom blockchains. Popular implementations are Cosmos and Polkadot. Cosmos is a network of many independent blockchains, called zones. Zones are powered by the Tendermint Core. Tendermint Core is an application-agnostic “consensus engine” that can turn any deterministic blackbox application into a distributedly replicated blockchain. Tendermint Core connects to blockchain applications via the Application Blockchain Interface (ABCI). Thus, ABCI allows for blockchain applications to be programmed in any language, not just the programming language that the consensus engine is written in.Zones can also serve as blockchain-backed versions of enterprise systems, where pieces of a particular service that are traditionally run by an organization or group of organizations are instead run as a ABCI application on a certain zone, which allows it to inherit the security and interoperability of the public Cosmos network without sacrificing control over the underlying service. Polkadot allows cross-blockchain transfer of data and assets. In Polkadot, developers can develop side chains - parachains, which implement a custom blockchain-which can be connected to other blockchains. This makes it possible to build applications that get permissioned data from a private blockchain and use it on a public blockchain. For instance, a school's private, permissioned academic records chain could send a proof to a degree-verification smart contract on a public chain.
requirements:
Expected results: 1. Framework for creating, deploying and maintaining services with several blockchains/parachains 
2. Proof of concept implementation with the Cosmos Network or Polkadot
3.  Paper Publication

title: [Dissertação] Security and Trust Management for Censorship-Resistant Overlay Networks
observations: For more information about this project, please visit: https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~nsantos/msc-topics/msc-topics-CA.html. This work will be performed in collaboration with Diogo Barradas, a PhD student with expertise in traffic analysis, censorship resistance systems, and machine learning.
objectives:
Many states all over the world implement censorship mechanisms that prevent free access to information through the outright impairment or blockage of Internet communications. In our research team, we have built a tool, named Protozoa, which allows Internet users located in censored regions to piggyback on WebRTC-enabled streaming applications, such as Whereby.com, in order to establish covert tunnels that can circumvent said mechanisms. A user only needs to make a video call with a friend located in the free Internet region. That friend runs a proxy service that will allow all Internet traffic generated by Alice to securely and secretly cross the boundaries of the censored region and reach blocked services such as Youtube or Twitter. Based on this point-to-point hidden communication capability, our next step is to build CRON, a Censorship-Resistant Overlay Network that will allow those users that do not have direct contacts with trusted peers to access the free Internet region in a mediated fashion, i.e., by leveraging a friend of a friend as a proxy.

Specifically, the goal of this thesis is to design and implement the security monitor system that will supervise the communications between clients and proxies. These communications will take place by stitching up several Protozoa channels along the way which will constitute a covert circuit. This thesis will be concerned with all aspects of the system related with security and trust management issues. Security wise, it will be necessary to provide the means for: i) issuing location proofs for proxies (i.e., proxies must effectively be located outside the censored region), and ii) guaranteeing the end-to-end security of the circuit, preventing for instance man-in-the-middle attacks in between the connections of Protozoa channels. With respect to trust issues, it involves the development of mechanisms for both clients and proxies. On the one hand, clients need to be convinced that a friend of a friend can also be a trustworthy proxy (e.g., it is not a state-controlled agent). On the other hand, proxies need to be convinced that their services will not be abused by malicious clients for accessing illegal content which would make them liable to prossecution in their own countries (e.g., for facilitating access to child pornography). This system will be built on top of the Protozoa system. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. The resulting system will be released as an open source project. If you like building distributed security systems, this is the right topic for you.
requirements: Interest in security and distributed systems. Proficiency in C/C++ programming. Willingness to learn the Rust programming language. (The CRON system will most probably be implemented in Rust.)

title: Dissertação: Letter Spirit and Machine Learning
objectives:
The Letter Spirit project is an attempt to model central aspects of human high-level perception and creativity on a computer using new machine learning methods.

“What is a concept?”. From this key question, many others follow. How do fluid boundaries come about? How do they give rise to generalization? What makes something similar to something else? For example, what makes an uppercase letter ‘A’ recognizable as such. What is the essence of ‘A’-ness? 
The specific focus of Letter Spirit is the creative act of artistic letter-design. The aim is to model how the 26 lowercase letters of the roman alphabet can be rendered in many different but internally coherent styles using new statistical machine learning concepts.

For more information and literature 

http://goosie.cogsci.indiana.edu/farg/mcgrawg/lspirit.html

title: Dissertation: Using Natural Language Processing to Find Bugs in Java Source Code
objectives:
Programmers usually annotate their source code with comments that document how the code works. Often, these comments capture properties and intentions that do not match the semantics of the code. This happens either because the programmer wrote the code incorrectly, or because, at some point, the source code was changed but the comment was not updated.

The goal of this project is to use information available in Java source code comments to analyse source code and detect any mismatches. Interested students will contribute to an existing prototype that integrates with the IntelliJ and already provides facilities to extract source code comments and analyse Java code.

An interesting direction that can be pursued is on the implementation of machine learning algorithms to automatically detecting the scopes of source code comments (see, for example, https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S016412121930055X).
requirements:
Interested students should:
1. Know how to program in the Java programming language
2. Enjoy programming and learning about new programming languages and technologies
3. Be interested in software engineering and software reliability
4. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

title: Dissertação: JMLCUTE++: Automated JML-Based Unit Test Case Generation
observations:
Design by Contract focuses on a module’s design. Design by Contract designs a module by formally specifying contracts. Contracts are obligation-benefit relationships between a module and the other modules that use it. In the context of this thesis, the specification of the program should apply the JML language, 

The tool to develop should be based on the jCUTE tool, that is a concolic testing tool that does not support formal specifications.

The tool to develop should solve some of the drawbacks of jCUTE: 
1) classes need to have the default constructors; 
2) the constraint solver does not handle collection constraints.
objectives: The goal of this thesis is to develop a verification tool that automatically analyzes the program under test, the program’s specification, and the program’s run-time behavior to automatically detect errors and generate a unit test case per error found.
requirements: Aprovação na cadeira de Qualidade de Software/Testes e Validação de Software.

title: [Project] Head-mounted displays as Opera Glasses: using Mixed-Reality to Deliver an Egalitarian User Experience during Live Events
objectives:
From the excellent natural acoustics of ancient Greek and Roman theaters, to Opera glasses, we have always looked for ways to improve our experience of live events. The latter was popularized in the 1850s, due to the poor lighting conditions of the theaters of the day, and the poor eyesight of some of the audience. Nowadays, while still used to improve visual access to plays, Opera glasses are mostly provided as a prop to immerse viewers in a classical theater experience. They have been replaced in most venues by over-head or in-seat displays, which provide a closer view of the event, regardless of where one sits. 

What we propose in this thesis is to explore use head-mounted displays (HMDs) to provide viewers with not only a closer look of the action, but to make them feel as if they are sit ting in the front row. This sense of presence is a different proposition from Opera glasses and in-house displays, but it is not completely novel. 360° video and virtual-reality (VR) headsets have been used to immerse audiences in pre-recorded events, where they can look around as if they were experiencing the live event in person. What we suggest instead is the use of VR headsets to consume a live event, from within the arena where the event is taking place, but from the perspective of someone sitting in the front row. This is more akin to augmented- (AR) or mixed-reality (MR), where unlike VR, users do not experience a fully virtual environment, but instead augment their experience of the real-world with digital content. In the case of a live event, this real-world experience includes not only acoustic and vibrotactile feedback from both the performers and the audience, but also thermal and olfactory information. Furthermore, there is a collaborative dynamic between a live audience and a performer that a pre-recorded or remote VR experience that is difficult to emulate. 

As such, the goal of this thesis is simple (but challenging): develop a working system that is able to stream 360° video content with minimal latency.

title: Dissertação Assistência à parametrização de optimizadores com aprendizagem automática
observations: A parte experimental do projecto de tese será realizada nas instalações da SISCOG-Sistemas Cognitivos, SA em Lisboa, em regime de estágio remunerado. O aluno ficará integrado no Departamento de Inovação, o que lhe permitirá trabalhar numa equipa altamente qualificada que faz investigação aplicada com problemas do mundo real, e que lhe proporciona um ambiente organizacional propício à captação de conhecimento e à geração de ideias.
objectives:
As empresas que desenvolvem sistemas de apoio à decisão que utilizam optimizadores para resolver problemas combinatórios deparam-se frequentemente com o problema de a parametrização desses optimizadores ser demasiado complexa para um utilizador comum.
Em particular um utilizador comum tem frequentemente muita dificuldade em definir os objectivos de optimização com base no conjunto de parâmetros que lhe é oferecido. Face a esta dificuldade os utilizadores acabam por adoptar metodologias de tentativa e erro que na maior parte dos casos são pouco eficientes e eficazes.
Este projecto tem como objectivo o desenvolvimento de um assistente à parametrização de optimizadores que funciona como uma interface inteligente entre o utilizador e o optimizador. O utilizador teria a capacidade de especificar os objectivos de uma maneira simples e o assistente teria a capacidade de encontrar automaticamente a parametrização mais adequada para que o optimizador produza soluções optimizadas de acordo com os objectivos definidos pelo utilizador.
Estão previstas pelo menos duas modalidades simples de especificar objectivos de optimização: uma interactiva e outra não interactiva, baseada numa lista de objectivos hierárquicos.
Na modalidade interactiva o utilizador, no final de cada corrida do optimizador, escolhe a solução que considera melhor (e eventualmente a segunda melhor) e o assistente vai mudando os parâmetros da função objectivo para que na próxima corrida aumente a probabilidade de a solução com melhor valor da função objectivo seja também a que melhor satisfaz o utilizador.
Na modalidade não interactiva o utilizador especificaria uma lista de objectivos hierárquicos em que as soluções de maior valor num nível hierárquico são sempre melhores do que as melhores soluções do nível hierárquico abaixo dele, e, de entre as soluções de maior valor num nível hierárquico, são melhores aquelas que são melhores no nível hierárquico abaixo dele. 
Face a à hierarquia de objectivos especificada pelo utilizador o assistente deverá ter a capacidade de descobrir automaticamente qual a parametrização a atribuir ao optimizador por forma a que ele optimize em ordem à hierarquia de objectivos dada.
O assistente à parametrização de optimizadores deverá ser baseado em modelos de aprendizagem automática ou de metodologias do mesmo tipo. O modelo será testado com dados reais em um ou mais optimizadores dos sistemas de apoio à decisão desenvolvidos pela SISCOG.

•	Conhecimentos de programação em C++.

title: [Dissertation] Cooperative P2P Set-Top-Boxes system for improved TV zapping time
observations:
- This thesis will be realized under an agreement between IST and NOS Inovação and it will be jointly supervised by: Prof. Nuno Roma (IST), Dr. Nuno Sebastião (NOS Inovação), Prof. Tiago Dias (ISEL)
- Assignment of this thesis is subject to a prior informal interview with the candidate to assess his motivation and prior knowledge in the fields of research
- This thesis involves challenging aspects recognized by the scientific community; accordingly, the outcome of this work may give rise to the publication of scientific articles.
objectives:
Digital Video Broadcast (DVB) systems typically suffer from a high channel change (zapping) time. Nevertheless, with the recent advent of Artificial Intelligence systems, it became possible to accurately predict the channels that the user will most likely change to. 

Accordingly, locally available resources have been exploited to perform the pretuning of the predicted channels and, thus, significantly reduce the channel change time. Despite its effectiveness, such method is typically limited by the amount of available resources in the set-top-box (STB) (e.g. memory and number of tuners in the STB). To overcome such constraints, other methods have also been  devised, in particular, the delivery of stream chunks, on request, via unicast on top of an IP network. 

This approach has the advantage of allowing a fast channel change to any channel that cannot be locally pretuned, although not being as effective as the other one due to the dependency on the network conditions. 

Moreover, the implementation of such unicast assisted channel change systems requires a server side infrastructure to support the processing and the delivery of the necessary stream data to the STBs. Considering that nowadays an individual STB already possesses the ability to locally pretune some channels (e.g. two channels), one can envision that those STBs could also act as stream providers for the unicast assisted channel change system in a distributed peer-to-peer model. Such a distributed model would reduce the investment required to setup a centralized infrastructure, thus making this model more attractive to operators.

The goal of this work is to devise and implement a distributed peer-to-peer system capable of delivering stream chunks for unicast assisted channel change in STBs. In such system, the STB should act both as a server, making available to the network the locally pretuned stream data, and as a client, requesting from other STBs the necessary stream data whenever it requires changing to another channel.

title: (PROJECT) Acronym Expander Server and GUI
objectives:
Acronym expansion is the problem of finding an expansion for a given
acronym in a textual document (e.g., ``ATM'' can mean
automatic teller machine in a banking context or asynchronous
transfer mechanism in a communications context). Acronyms are used in all
kinds of textual documents and articles. They are useful as a shorthand,
however the lack of an acronym expansion in the text
can become a communication barrier with non-expert persons.
Our Acronym Expander
system is available online (http://acronymexpander.inesc-id.pt/). Given
a document (either in a textual format or a webpage URL) as input, it
provides the user with access to a simple table of acronyms found in text
and the corresponding expansions. 

The graphical user interface (GUI) is
very simple at this stage of the project and the way we present the
expansions for the acronym should be improved to meet user
requirements. Moreover, we don’t have a proper way to make our system
accessible by other software applications that can highly benefit from
acronym expansions (e.g., sentiment analysis). Finally, 
the acronym expander system improves its accuracy performance by providing
more data (i.e., collections of textual documents).

In this Master's Thesis, the candidate should perform the following tasks:

1) Analyze and propose changes to the system Graphical User Interface
(GUI), e.g., annotate the expansion on the text using mouse over, instead
of providing a list;

2) Provide and explore the best way to present expansions ranked
by confidence and allow
the user to provide feedback by identifying the right expansion (in case
our system fails to predict the right expansion);
3) Add additional data sources to increase the system accuracy performance;
4) Evaluate the new GUI and new components with a user study;
5) Create an Application Programming Interface (API) to allow other
applications to use our service.

We expect the candidate to produce a new version of the system with an
improved GUI adapted to our users needs. The candidate should also present
a user study to prove the new GUI in a realistic scenario.
requirements: Classificação a PO, BD, ESW, SO >= 14; média de mestrado >=16. Disciplina de Ciência de Dados feita.
