title: Dissertação: Synthesizing NVRAM Support in Transactional Systems
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Luis Pedrosa (https://pedrosa.2y.net/) and Paolo Romano (https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~romanop/).

Students interested in this proposal should contact Luis Pedrosa (luis.pedrosa@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Implementing durable transactional systems often poses a challenge due to the constraints of typical persistent storage media. Given the difficulty in testing all possible points of failure, crash consistency issues can arise and the limited performance of hard drives and even SSDs will often become a bottleneck, ultimately constraining the performance of the entire system.

A new class of memory has recently emerged: non-volatile random access memory (NVRAM), such as Intel Optane persistent memory, which offers persistent data storage with the same performance as standard RAM [1]. Using these devices to their full potential, however, requires a significant effort to refactor and implement existing applications around the new programming paradigm.

In this thesis, we will explore automating this refactoring effort by automatically synthesizing the durability functionality in existing in-memory transactional systems (e.g. [2]). Ultimately, you will build a static analysis system that analyzes the code of the in-memory database systems and automatically generates and inserts code that ensures that all transactions are durable and that consistency is preserved when the system crashes and reboots.

We will explore a sequence of optimizations. After replacing any in-memory data structures with transactional equivalents that offer durable commit semantics, the challenge then lies in recognizing when to perform commits. A trivial first approach commits every single access, which ensures durability at the cost of a significant performance penalty. Data flow analysis can then be used to progressively infer when a variety of database manipulation operations are being conducted and to safely commit larger blocks of operations at a time. In the end, the full system should be able to detect transactional commit semantics based on access visibility and to only commit to NVRAM full transactions as they are committed in the larger database system.

References:
[1] Kai Wu, Frank Ober, Shari Hamlin, Qiang Guan, Dong Li, “Early Evaluation of Intel Optane Non-Volatile Memory with HPC I/O Workloads”, https://arxiv.org/pdf/1708.02199.pdf
[2] Redis. https://redis.io/

title: Dissertação: Otimização de Métodos Monte-Carlo na Resolução de Sistemas Lineares para Problemas de Grande Escala
observations: Co-orientação externa: Prof. Juan Acebron, ISCTE (Juan.Acebron@iscte-iul.pt)
objectives:
Os métodos probabilísticos baseados em algoritmos Monte Carlo existem na literatura desde há muito tempo. No entanto para determinados problemas como a resolução de equações em derivadas parciais (PDEs), sistemas de álgebra linear, e cálculo de funções matriciais têm sido escassamente utilizados em geral. Isto é devido basicamente à lenta convergência do método para a solução, inerente a qualquer algoritmo Monte Carlo.

No entanto, nos últimos anos parece ter ressurgido um renovado interesse pelos métodos Monte Carlo como método alternativo aos clássicos na resolução de inúmeros problemas em Física e Engenharia. Fundamentalmente devido à existência na atualidade de supercomputadores compostos por grande número de cores, estes algoritmos podem ser explorados muito eficientemente por serem naturalmente paralelizáveis. Contudo, existe um problema fundamental inerente aos métodos Monte Carlo utilizados especificamente na resolução de PDEs e sistemas lineares para problemas de grande escala. O problema aparece quando o tamanho do domínio e/ou da matriz supera os limites de memória dum dos nós de memória partilhada, sendo portanto necessário distribuir o problema/matriz entre os diferentes nós computacionais de memória distribuída. Por serem as diferentes tentativas das simulações Monte Carlo de natureza aleatória estas criam padrões de intercomunicação muito complexos, e polo que é fundamental dispor de algoritmos fortemente optimizados que permitam reduzir o impacto dessa intercomunicação entre os nós distribuídos, de maneira a melhorar a escalabilidade global do algoritmo.

O objetivo desta Tese é desenhar um algoritmo eficiente de comunicação entre os diferentes nós, optimizado ao máximo para ser executado em arquitecturas híbridas de memória partilhada e distribuída. O algoritmo posteriormente será integrado em algoritmos específicos que resolvem PDEs e sistemas de álgebra linear. A seguir e mediante diferentes benchmarks serão executados diferentes testes de escalabilidade utilizando supercomputadores massivamente paralelos pertencentes a infraestruturas de supercomputação europeias.
requirements: Os estudantes interessados em realizar esta Tese de Mestrado deverão ter frequentado a cadeira de Computação Paralela e Distribuída.

title: Dissertação: Data Enrichment and Preparation for Energy Analytics
observations: Os alunos interessados neste tema deverão contactar o professor Paulo Carreira (paulo.carreira@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) antes de se inscrever.
objectives:
This thesis will design and evaluate appropriate ‘Design Patterns’ that will streamline the development of data enrichment and preparation workflows for Energy Data Analytics. 

The design and maintenance of Data Enrichment and Preparation workflows is known to eat up a significant share of effort in the development of a Data Analytics system, and in particular, of an Energy Data Analytics system.

Data analytics relies heavily on the integration of data from multiple data sources into a model appropriate to be explored by data analytics tools. This integration process, nowadays known as ‘Data Enrichment and Preparation’ (DEP), has traditionally been called the Extract-Transform-Load (ETL) process. Typically, DEP is accomplished by a complex weaving of scripts and tools that, on a first phase, overcome the inherent heterogeneity and data quality issues of distinct sources and, on a second phase, loading reliable data into an integrated schema that supports the data analytics operations. 

Aiming at overcoming the engineering complexity of the problem, tools have emerged that represent data transformation steps and dependencies as first class citizens. The underlying idea is that, a well designed process is simpler to maintain. However, designing one such process is requires a lot of knowledge about data management issues and about the application domain itself, including the data sources and of the multi-dimensional model. This is particularly true for energy data analytics where building energy data analytics solutions are constructed ad-hoc with a new process. 

Indeed, no authoritative reference exists that explains how to create workflows for energy data analytics. Therefore, the creation of a set of Design Patterns for DEP workflows that can be re-used to populate a multi-demensional models for data analytics is an innovative and ground-breaking contribution.

An appropriate methodology to achieve these results has been designed and will be communicated by your advisor.

title: [Project] Code-Stepping Regular Expressions in the Browser
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
JavaScript is the most widespread dynamic language [1]. It is the de facto language for client-side web applications; it is used for server-side scripting with Node.js and it even runs on small embedded devices. JavaScript regular expressions are an essential part of the language. They are often used for parsing user input and messages coming from the network and they play a key role in securing Web applications. In fact, JS developers commonly rely on regular expressions to write complex string sanitisers to prevent a variety of security attacks, such as cross site scripting (XSS) and cross site request forgery [2]. 

The behaviour of JS regular expressions is specified in the ECMAScript Standard (version 10) [3]. The ECMAScript standard is a long, complex document, written in English, about 900 pages long. Furthermore, it keeps growing every year in response to the ever-growing demand of the JavaScript community. Hence, understanding the exact behaviour of JavaScript regular expressions is becoming harder to achieve, whilst new business and cyber-security challenges make it of escalating importance. 

If understanding the behaviour of JavaScript regular expressions is hard, programming them is even harder. It is an extremely error prone task, which often leads programmers to resort to trial-and-error approaches. Furthermore, the debugging facilities provided by all browsers and IDEs for JavaScript programming are lacking when it comes to regular expressions. In fact, browsers do not allow the programmer to code step regular expressions matches. The process of matching a string against a given regular expression is presented to the programmer as a single atomic operation, shedding no light as to why an expected match did not occur or an unexpected match did occur. 

The goal of this thesis is to implement a Chrome plug-in [4] to allow JavaScript programmers to code-step regular expression matches. The student will work with a reference interpreter of JavaScript regular expressions developed by the Verified Trustworthy Software Specification (VetSpec) group at Imperial College London, a world leading group in the specification and verification of Web programs. 

[1] w3techs.com/technologies/details/cp-javascript
[2] J. Weinberger et al. A Systematic Analysis of XSS Sanitisation in Web Application Frameworks. ESORICS’11. 
[3] ECMAScript Committee. The 10th Edition of the ECMAScript Language Specification. ECMA. 2019
[4] Browser Extensions – Developer Guide. Google Chrome. Online documentation.
requirements: Strong programming skills.

title: [Dissertação] : Deep Learning for Medical Visual Question Answering
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and João Magalhães ( http://ctp.di.fct.unl.pt/~jmag/ ), and it will be developed in the context of the IntelligentCare research project, currently being executed at INESC-ID.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including a PhD student named Rita Ramos that is working on remote sensing image captioning and multi-modal machine learning (under a co-supervision with Prof. Desmond Elliot from University of Copenhagen).

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
With the increasing interest in Artificial Intelligence (AI) to support clinical decision making and improve patient engagement, many opportunities to generate and leverage algorithms for automated medical image interpretation are currently being explored. In this specific context, visual question answering is an exciting research problem that combines natural language processing and computer vision techniques (i.e., language generation conditioned on visual inputs), currently attracting a huge interest within the information retrieval and medical informatics communities ( see https://www.imageclef.org/2020/medical/vqa and https://lhncbc.nlm.nih.gov/system/files/pub9992.pdf ).

A particular formulation for the problem involves taking as input a medical image (e.g., a radiology image) accompanied by a clinically relevant question, producing as output a relevant answer for the question, based on the visual image content. State-of-the-art approaches for addressing the problem are based on deep neural networks, with systems following an encoder-decoder architecture that combines convolutional, recurrent, and attention components. In most proposals, a first encoder component corresponding to a pre-trained convolutional neural network generates a representation for the image, whereas a second encoder corresponding to a recurrent neural network generates a representation for the question. Using both types of information, a decoder component generates the answer word-by-word, at each step using neural attention to weight the visual/textual inputs according to relevance for the current prediction.

Despite many interesting previous results, there are also several opportunities for improvement over the aforementioned general architecture. In particular, this MSc research project will address the development and evaluation of innovative visual question answering methods, advancing in several directions over the previous state-of-the-art.

Outside the biomedical domain (i.e., in the context of general image captioning and visual question answering), recent developments relate to pre-training cross-modal methods inspired on large models such as BERT ( and variations such as ClinicalBERT - see https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.05342 ), which can then be fine-tuned to downstream tasks ( see https://arxiv.org/pdf/2002.10832.pdf , https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.08530 or https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.01473 ). Similar ideas can be explored for medical visual question answering, leveraging large multi-modal datasets such as the recently introduced MIMIC-CXR ( see https://physionet.org/content/mimic-cxr/2.0.0/ and https://physionet.org/content/mimic-cxr-jpg/2.0.0/ ). 

The visual encoding and neural attention components ( see https://arxiv.org/1908.06954 ) can also be made to rely on recent developments, namely through the use of state-of-the-art convolutional architectures discovered through automated search, which feature particular connection patterns, pooling operations, or normalization operations ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.11946 , https://arxiv.org/pdf/2003.13328v1.pdf or https://arxiv.org/pdf/2004.02967.pdf ). 

Finally, on what regards model training and the decoder component, improvements can be made over traditional greedy strategies (i.e., when generating the answer word-by-word, use the most likely output at each step) through strategies design to deal with the exposure bias (i.e., accumulated errors caused by different decoding strategies during training and inference) and over-correction (i.e., using strict pairwise matches between predicted and ground truth sequences) problems, e.g. through sampling or sequence-level training ( see https://huggingface.co/blog/how-to-generate or https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.06283 ). The loss function used for model training can also explore multi-task objectives, e.g. under the intuition that joint representations for the generated answer and question should encode information useful for retrieving similar contents to the source images ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.04402 ).

Tests will be performed with data from the 2019 and 2020 editions of the CLEF competition on Medical Visual Question Answering ( https://github.com/abachaa/VQA-Med-2019 ), contrasting the approaches to be developed (i.e., ablated versions of a final model) against current state-of-the art methods, both through exact metrics (e.g., accuracy) or approximate matches ( e.g., through metrics like BLEU or BLEURT - see https://github.com/google-research/bleurt ). To further assess the developed methods, and noting that can also be applied to other specific domains, experiments will also be made with small datasets recently introduced in connection to visual question answering for remote sensing data ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.07333 ).

title: (PROJECTO) Geração automática de testes JUnit para testar projectos de Programação com Objectos
observations:
O artigos mais importantes a ter em conta para a realização da tese:

JCrasher: an automatic robustness tester for Java. Christoph Csallner and Yannis Smaragdakis, In Journal Software - Practice & Experience; 34(11):1025?1050, 2004
Feedback-directed Random Test Generation. Carlos Pacheco and Shuvendu K. Lahiri and Michael D. Ernst and Thomas Ball. In  Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Software Engineering, 2007
Combined Static and Dynamic Automated Test Generation, Zhang, Sai and Saff, David and Bu, Yingyi and Ernst, Michael D. In Proceedings of the 2011 International Symposium on Software Testing and Analysis, 2011
objectives:
Geração de um sistema que analise projectos de programação com objectos com o objectivo de gerar para cada projecto analisado um conjunto de casos de testes JUnit que representam bugs no código do projecto analisado.

O sistema deve ser baseado na conjunção de duas técnicas de teste automáticas: análise estática de código e testes aleatórios
requirements: A ideia desta tese é tendo como base a gera~\ao automática de testes aleatórios, desenvolver um sistema que cria um conjunto de casos de testes que falham. Desta forma será possível os alunos corrigirem de forma mais simples os seus projectos, dado que deverá ser relativamente fácil depois corrigir cada bug encontrado dado que deverá ser fácil perceber o que está ser testado em cada caso de teste.

title: [Dissertação] Intel CPU+GPU Systems: Demystifying the Execution Bottlenecks
supervisors: Leonel Augusto Pires Seabra de Sousa (50%)
location: INESC-ID, Alameda Campus (Rua Alves Redol, 9 - 1000-029 Lisboa)
observations: This thesis is part of the ongoing project with Intel Corporation. The student will have the opportunity to exclusively access and evaluate the state-of-the-art Intel platforms and tools.
objectives:
Current trends in computer architecture move towards heterogeneous designs by incorporating accelerators and specialized units in addition to a set of powerful CPU cores [1]. To pursue energy-efficient execution, it is crucial to consider the capability of relevant micro-architecture components and the characteristics/demands of different applications. To this aim, for fast prototyping and exploration of different design/optimization strategies, insightful modeling is essential for computer architects and application designers, since it allows describing the vital functional aspects of the architecture via intuitive graphical representation, such as the Cache-Aware Roofline Model [2,3]. 

The main objective of this Thesis is aimed at development and evaluation of industry-oriented tools for insightful cache-aware performance modeling of heterogeneous general-purpose systems (e.g., Intel CPU+GPU systems). Depending on the outcomes, the prospective student will also be encouraged to tackle the modeling of future Intel platforms with FPGAs and next generation memories. 

[1] “Intel's Architecture Day 2018: The Future of Core, Intel GPUs, 10nm, and Hybrid x86”, AnandTech, 2018, https://www.anandtech.com/show/13699/intel-architecture-day-2018-core-future-hybrid-x86

[2] A. Ilic, F. Pratas, and L. Sousa, “Cache-aware Roofline model: Upgrading the loft,” IEEE Comput. Archit. Lett., 2014. 

[3] A. Ilic, F. Pratas, and L. Sousa. “Beyond the Roofline: Cache-aware Power and Energy-Efficiency Modeling for Multi-cores”, IEEE Transactions on Computers, 2017.
requirements: Potential candidates are strongly encouraged to arrange a short meeting to discuss the details of the proposal before applying. Simply send an email to ilic@inesc-id.pt.This dissertation should not be selected by students with other professional commitments during the execution of the work.

title: Projecto: Making Smart Homes Smarter
objectives:
Actualmente estão disponíveis várias soluções tecnológicas que permitem automatizar habitações e aceder remotamente às diversas funcionalidades oferecidas. É assim possível ligar e desligar equipamentos, regular a iluminação, controlar a temperatura, monitorizar o consumo de energia, etc. Muitas destas acções podem ser realizadas usando diferentes interfaces ou mesmo comandos voz. 
Porém, se tudo o que acontece na casa necessita ser comandado directamente pelo utilizador, não se pode considerar a casa muito inteligente. Mais interessante seria o utilizador poder definir regras e a casa realizar esses comportamentos de forma automática (exemplo: ao chegar a casa liga a luz se já estiver escuro, baixa o estore da sala, liga o televisor se está na hora das notícias ou, se não, liga o som ambiente).
Pretende-se explorar que mecanismos existem actualmente para dar suporte a estas automatizações (e.g., IFTTT, stringify) e propor e desenvolver mecanismos mais poderosos e flexíveis, que possam facilmente ser adpatados a diferentes habitações, sem necessidade de terem de ser completamente reprogramados.

title: Dissertation: Improving the Security of Password Manager Browser Extensions
observations: Orientador externo: Alexandra Mendes (amendes@di.ubi.pt)
objectives:
This project is part of the PassCert research project, a CMU-Portugal exploratory project that will build an open-source, proof-of-concept password manager that through the use of formal verification, is guaranteed to satisfy properties on data storage and password generation. The selected candidate will be a member of the research team, participating in the meetings with the CMU researchers, collaborating on research papers, and possibly presenting their work at international conferences.

Password managers are important tools that enable us to use stronger passwords, freeing us from the cognitive burden of remembering them. Despite this, there are still many users who do not fully trust password managers.

The goals of this project are (i) to survey usability and security issues of existing password managers; (ii) to explore how browsers can provide additional features that improve password manager extensions. Examples include: (a) allowing password managers to generate a nonce to autofill in place of the password; when the nonce is about to be transmitted on the wire to the website, the password manager then replaces the nonce with the real password. (b) adding HTML attributes that describe a website's password policy, allowing password managers to generate passwords that will be accepted by the website.

References:

Oesch, Sean, and Scott Ruoti. "That Was Then, This Is Now: A Security Evaluation of Password Generation, Storage, and Autofill in Browser-Based Password Managers." 30th USENIX Security Symposium. USENIX, 2020. (USENIX Security 2020)

Ben Stock and Martin Johns. Protecting users against xss-based password manager abuse. In Proceedings of the 9th ACM symposium on Information, computer and communications security, pages 183–194. ACM, 2014.
requirements:
Interested students should:
1. Enjoy programming and learning about new technologies
2. Be interested in usable security and software reliability
3. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

title: Dissertação: Tool for Migrating and Visualizing EA Models
supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (100%)
objectives:
O objetivo desta disseração é recolha de informação de várias fontes para a produção de modelos e a sua visualização através da solução de Arquitetura Empresarial Atlas.
A captura de eventos que acontecem nas organizações e a contextualização dos mesmos em processos de negócio, permite enriquecer e crar novos modelos do funcionamento das organizações que não estão necessariamente explicitos nos processos de negócio da mesma.
  
A captura e correlação de eventos permite explicitar e otimizar os processos de trabaho.
O trabalho consiste na extensão das técnicas de process mining e data science para  a correlação e deteção de padrões entre eventos que possam ser enquadrados nos processos de negócio das organizações.

title: [Dissertação] Known your rights: Applications of Deep Natural Language Processing to Portuguese Consumer Rights Law
observations: This work is integrated in a funded project and can pay a stipend.
objectives:
INCM (Imprensa Nacional – Casa da Moeda) is the publisher for the digital version of Diário da República – the official journal of the Portuguese Republic where all laws and legislation are published. Diário da República Electrónico (DRE) is made available to all citizens as a free and universal public service. Unfortunately, for the common citizen it is often hard to search for and understand available legislation. This thesis aims to explore recent advances in Deep Learning and Natural Language Processing to improve this service for the specific set of Consumer Rights Laws. 
More specifically, a new service for DRE is currently being developed such that:
1.	A citizen can write a question or problem in natural language, and the system should be able to identify the most relevant laws and articles.
2.	The system can extract a semantic representation from the text of consumer rights laws to a formal language such as AMR (Abstract Meaning Representation), which can then be more easily interpreted by a computational process.
3.	Use the semantic representation language to help find laws and articles that are semantically similar to the user’s question, and to explore new visual forms of presenting such information to the user, for instance in the form of decision trees. 
This thesis will focus on one or more of these subproblems. In terms of work, the thesis will be organized in the following stages: a) Elicitation of the state of the art in natural language processing, semantic analysis, and semantic text similarity; b) Analysis of the state of the art and selection of the most relevant approaches; c) Creation of a network architecture and model; d) Training and optimization of the model; e) Integration into DRE system; f) validation of the system in terms of accuracy and user experience; g) Thesis writing.
requirements: (aconselhado) Língua Natural

title: Project: Process Governance Framework
supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (100%)
objectives:
O objetivo desta dissertação é a criação de uma framework para a governação de processos de negócio, consolidando diversidade de aspetos tanto tecnológicos como de negócio visão única e integrada do problema. 

A visão integrada da tecnologia, pois há diferentes tecnologias de implementação de processos, desde soluções de BPM a soluções de gestão documentais passando por soluções de RPAs, todas capazes de suportar a automação de processos.  

A visão integrada do negócio, pois entre os processos de negócio de alto nível, até aos sub-…sub-processos que implementados existe um grande gap que faz com que na prática nem haja visibilidade de como ligar os indicadores dos processos implementados aos indicadores dos processos de alto nível.

title: Projecto: Simulator of a Smart Home
objectives:
Existem várias tecnologias disponíveis para automatizar habitações, embora o maior desafio seja dar inteligência a essas automatizações, torná-las úteis e satisfazer as necessidades ou as preferências dos utilizadores. Várias abordagens podem ser seguidas para tentar satisfazer esses objectivos, mas existe o problema de como testar o funcionamento do sistema, verificar que satisfaz ao que foi definido, que reage correctamente às diferentes situações.
Pretende-se conceber e desenvolver uma aplicação que permita simular os dispositivos existentes numa habitação (e.g., sensores de presença, sensores de temperatura, interruptores, lâmpadas, estores, aquecedores, etc). Deverá ser seguido o modelo DomoBus, em que um dispositivo é representado por um conjunto de propriedades, sendo possível saber o estado do dispositivo ou actuar sobre ele lendo ou modificando o valor das suas propriedades. A aplicação de simulação deverá ter uma interface gráfica que permita representar o estado actual dos dispositivos e permita modificar esse estado interactivamente. Deverá também ser possível ter ficheiros com sequências de acções para, por exemplo, facilmente repetir certas ocorrências (e.g., pessoa ao entrar em casa activa sensor de porta aberta, sensor de presença, liga o interruptor da luz, etc).

title: Gestão de Risco numa Abordagem de Processos
location: INCM - Imprensa Nacional Casa da Moeda
objectives: Descrição: A Gestão de Riscos Corporativos é um processo de gestão que tem como objetivo identificar, analisar e mitigar os riscos que possam interferir com as operações e objetivos da organização. A gestão de risco não é uma prática destinada a um segmento ou setor específico, podendo ser usada por qualquer organização pública ou privada, aplicada a qualquer tipo de risco e em diferentes atividades e operações. A Imprensa Nacional-Casa da Moeda, S. A. (INCM) tem por missão criar, produzir e fornecer bens e serviços que exigem elevados padrões de segurança, focados no cliente e em soluções inovadoras. Destacam-se, entre diversos bens e serviços essenciais à vida em sociedade, a produção de documentos de segurança, como o cartão de cidadão ou o passaporte, a cunhagem de moeda corrente e de coleção, a autenticação de artefactos de metais preciosos, a edição do Diário da República Eletrónico e a publicação de obras fundamentais da cultura portuguesa e universal. Focada na prevenção e proteção dos seus ativos, a INCM assume a Gestão de Riscos Corporativos como parte integrante da gestão com o propósito de promover uma cultura onde são privilegiadas medidas preventivas para assegurar o cumprimento dos objetivos. Tendo em conta as boas práticas e estratégias existentes para processos de Gestão de Risco Corporativo (ISO 31000, IEC31010, OCEG), pretende-se com esta tese conceber um conjunto de requisitos para a definição da gestão de risco em ambientes empresariais (aplicando ao contexto empresarial da INCM) onde, dada a diversidade de atividades e operações, assume-se a necessidade de adaptar as atividades ao contexto sem no entanto perder a capacidade de ter uma visão holística sobre as várias práticas de gestão de risco da organização. Os requisitos definidos devem ser implementados na ferramenta de desmaterialização de processos existente na organização, o JIRA Software.

title: Dissertação: SmartNIC Synthesis
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Prof. Luis Pedrosa (luis.pedrosa@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) and Prof. Fernando Ramos (fvramos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Building the networks that power modern distributed systems has led to new designs and architectures that are often not backward compatible with standard network devices and frameworks. This has led to a recent push for increased programmability and configurability in the network, with different efforts trading off flexibility, performance, and complexity.

One tool that has emerged in this effort is the use of SmartNICs, specialized network interface cards with programmable hardware, such as FPGAs, that act as accelerators for packet processing in networks. SmartNICs offer greater programmability than other approaches such as software defined networks [1] and better performance than software network functions (NFs) [2]. That said, they trade these factors off for complexity, as the expertise in hardware design typically required to program FPGAs has limited the wider adoption of these technologies.

In this thesis we will address this complexity by automatically synthesizing SmartNIC accelerators to improve performance for software NFs that are given as input. Our specific goal is to build a static analysis tool that analyzes the NF code and subsequently generates a SmartNIC application that offloads as much packet processing functionality to hardware as possible. The end result will be a new version of the original NF, where some or all of the packet processing functionality is done on the SmartNIC, thus offering the same programmability of software NFs with the performance of SmartNICs.

References:
[1] D. Kreutz, F. M. V. Ramos, P. E. Veríssimo, C. E. Rothenberg, S. Azodolmolky and S. Uhlig, "Software-Defined Networking: A Comprehensive Survey," in Proceedings of the IEEE, vol. 103, no. 1, pp. 14-76, Jan. 2015, doi: 10.1109/JPROC.2014.2371999.

[2] B. Han, V. Gopalakrishnan, L. Ji and S. Lee, "Network function virtualization: Challenges and opportunities for innovations," in IEEE Communications Magazine, vol. 53, no. 2, pp. 90-97, Feb. 2015, doi: 10.1109/MCOM.2015.7045396.

title: [Dissertação] : Deep Learning Methods for Duplicate Detection and Matching Points of Interest
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Jacinto Estima ( https://jestima.github.io/ ), and it will be developed in the context of the MIMU research project, currently being executed at INESC-ID.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including a PhD student named Luís Borges that is working on neural models for text matching and retrieval (under a co-supervision with Prof. Jamie Callen from CMU/LTI).

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Duplicate detection concerns with identifying pairs of attributes/records that refer to the same real-world object (e.g., matching records in a database for points of interest that refer to the same real-world location), thus corresponding to a fundamental process when ensuring data quality in databases. Existing methods to detect duplicate attributes can leverage heuristic string similarity measures based on characters or small character sequences, phonetic encoding techniques that match strings based on the way they sound, or hybrid techniques that combine different approaches. For matching records composed of multiple attributes, one can use heuristic combinations of multiple similarity metrics, chosen according to each type of attribute and weighted in order to maximize performance on an held-out set of records.

Most previous methods for assessing string similarity, which act as the fundamental components for duplicate detection, rely on common sub-strings between the strings being compared, and they often do not effectively capture semantic similarity or the character replacements involved in duplicate attributes due to complex transliterations. Motivated by the success of neural network approaches in similar problems such as textual entailment and natural language inference ( i.e., problems related to assessing the relation between pairs of natural language sentences -- see https://nlp.stanford.edu/projects/snli/ ), some previous studies have already explored the use of neural network methods for assessing string similarity ( e.g., see https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13658816.2017.1390119 ). However, these are still many opportunities for improving these methods, e.g. exploring recent advances in natural language inference and character-based language modeling tasks related to the use of Transformer models ( e.g., https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.03762 ) or state-of-the-art recurrent architectures ( e.g., https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.01792 ).

This MSc research project will explore the use of deep learning methods for matching duplicate attributes (i.e., pairs of individual strings) and also duplicate records composed of multiple attributes, envisioning applications in the consolidation of databases for points-of-interest. The models to be explored can leverage recurrent units or Transformers for encoding the inputs being compared, afterwards comparing the representations ( e.g., through optimal transport methods -- see https://arxiv.org/pdf/1907.10165v1.pdf ), and finally performing a classification decision on whether the inputs correspond to a match.

Experiments will be performed with existing datasets of duplicate attributes used in previous studies ( e.g., see https://github.com/ruipds/Toponym-Matching ), as well as with novel datasets of duplicate point-of-interest records to be collected from online services such as Google Places or the OpenStreetMap ( e.g., see https://developers.google.com/places/web-service/intro -- one can collect information of POIs from multiple similar services, use unique attributes such as the phone number as a key to infer which are the records that should be considered as attributes, and then attempt to match the POIs with remaining attributes such as the name and the address ).

title: [Projecto] One –Time Passwords (OTP) usage to avoid cloaning and double spending on QRcode tickets
supervisors: José Manuel da Costa Alves Marques (100%)
objectives:
QR ticket codes are a way of identifying rights associated with a user such as a movie ticket, a transport title, an airline ticket, etc. that can be shown to a reader for automatic validation. Although they can be dynamically generated with a limited time validity, for them to be used in real systems it is necessary that they are protected with a mechanism to prevent cloning and double spending 

Objective: Test and demonstrate the use of one time passwords on the generation of dynamic QR code to overcome cloning and double spending problems. This secure mechanism to be developed, should be adapted to the off-line validation performed on the public transportation equipments (ticket validations with delayed asynchronous data synchronization).
requirements: Interest in security, alternative ticketing systems

title: Dissertação - Understanding Bias in Citizen Science
observations:
More information:
Ana Matos - ana.matos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
objectives:
Citizen science involves the collaboration of the general public in scientific research. Recent technological advances such as the bandwidth and ubiquity afforded by smartphones has brought an explosion in participation in citizen science platforms, such as iNaturalist and eBird. This has enabled the gathering of ever growing amounts of data that are of great value for scientific research. However, this data is often collected in casuistic manners, and are do not offer the neutrality of scientific method-based collection of data. In other words, it is subject to bias, and which can stem from a variety of causes, ranging from public interest in specific aspects of what is being studies, to climatic factors that influence the likeliness of certain observations.

The aim of this project is to study different sources of bias that is incorporated into data sets that are sourced from citizen science.
requirements: Proven interest and successful attendance of a masters-level course in data science, network science, or other subjects of relevance to the problem to be addressed.

title: Dissertação: Avaliação da saúde mental no contexto do Covid 19 usando plataformas móveis
supervisors: Miguel Constante (Hospital Beatriz Ângelo / Loures) TBD (50%)
observations: Esta tese de Mestrado vem no seguimento de uma  colaboração do IST com o departamento de psiquiatria do Hospital Beatriz Ângelo em   Loures onde se pretendem utilizar técnicas de monitorização não invasivas e portáteis no diagnóstico de algumas patologias do foro psiquiátrico de prevalência elevada.
objectives:
A generalidade dos métodos de avaliação psicológica ou psiquiátrica são sindromáticos, isto é,  são baseados em sintomas subjetivos, reportados pelo doente, que formam padrões de diagnósticos. Esses sintomas são por vezes difíceis de detetar, caracterizar e quantificar, sendo que na prática clínica o profissional de saúde carece ainda de meios para objetivar a doença mental, ou seja, biomarcadores, à semelhança de outras áreas da Medicina. 

Além disso, a maior parte das patologias apresentam um curso flutuante, com agudizações que alternam com períodos de  remissão dos sintomas. Este comportamento é difícil de detectar com rigor no sistema clássico de acompanhamento médico, baseado em consultas periódicas, onde o doente ou os seus familiares podem fazer descrições enviesadas ou parcelares dos sintomas que são confundentes para o diagnóstico. Por outro lado, o profissional de saúde faz na consulta uma observação transversal, isto é, naquele momento, necessitando de inferir a partir daí o estado mental do doente ao longo do tempo entre consultas.

O registo rigoroso dos sintomas por parte do doente ou familiares, em certas condições agudas ou ligeiras, é por natureza pouco fiável.  No primeiro caso as condições disruptivas associadas à patologia não permitem ao doente ou aos familiares as condições de objectividade necessárias a uma correta avaliação da situação e ao correspondente registo. No segundo caso, os sintomas podem ser de tal forma ténues e ligeiros que simplesmente não são detectados ou não são considerados relevantes. Nesta última classe incluem-se os casos não patológicos, mas de grande prevalência, como seja a depressão ligeira ou a ansiedade.

No atual estado de pandemia do Covid 19 a problemática da saúde mental tornou-se ainda mais importante devido ao estado de confinamento que induz uma pressão psicológica sem precedentes em termos populacionais. Neste contexto o acompanhamento psicológico/psiquiátrico  à distância é da maior importância e para isso há necessidade de desenvolver ferramentas adequadas à avaliação cognitiva e emocional de base tecnológica remota usando toda a informação não intrusiva disponível, como por exemplo os sensores e os registos de atividade (Log files) do telemóvel.

Assim, é da maior importância desenvolver métodos automáticos ou semiautomáticos  de detecção, quantificação, monitorização, acompanhamento e registo objectivo dos sintomas  que ajudem o médico na avaliação da doença com vista à melhor afinação do procedimento terapêutico.

Este trabalho foca-se em informação coletada no telemóvel, seja aquela que é gerada pela sua utilização (Log Files), seja aquela coletada em  diário electrónico ou através dos sensores embebidos do smartphone, tal como GPS, acelerómetro, luminosidade ou ruído ambiental. 

A análise dos padrões de utilização  deste dispositivo omnipresente na vida dos sujeitos em avaliação, permite extrair informação valiosa sobre os seus estados emocionais e cognitivos. Em particular, pretende-se desenhar métodos objetivos de avaliação da estratégia terapêutica adoptada em cada momento. 

Objetivos
Este trabalho foca-se na caracterização emocional de sujeitos em confinamento, especialmente os que estão em quarentena compulsiva, no que diz respeito a  ansiedade, stress, depressão, bipolaridade, distúrbios do sono e distúrbios alimentares.

O trabalho é composto pelas seguintes etapas principais:

1.	Revisão bibliográfica e familiaridade com os dados de registo (log data) do smartphone.
2.	Construção de uma plataforma protótipo em smartphone  para recolha de dados dos sensores embebidos, diário electrónico e testes psicológicos.
3.	Construção da plataforma web de recolha de dados de vários sujeitos para monitorização médica.
4.	Montagem de uma experiência piloto envolvendo sujeitos saudáveis de controlo para prova de conceito.
5.	Desenvolvimento de métricas de análise de dados e geração de alarmes.
6.	Escrita da tese e produção de material para ser usado na publicação de um artigo científico.

Bibliography
1.	Bauer M, Glenn T, Geddes J, et al. Smartphones in mental health: a critical review of background issues, current status and future concerns. Int J Bipolar Disord. 2020;8(1):2. 
2.	Remote assessment of disease and relapse in major depressive disorder (RADAR-MDD): a multi-centre prospective cohort study protocol. BMC Psychiatry 19, 72 (2019). 
3.	Real-time Mobile Monitoring of the Dynamic Associations Among Motor Activity, Energy, Mood, and Sleep in Adults With Bipolar Disorder. JAMA Psychiatry. Published online December 12, 2018. doi:10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2018.3546
4.	Daniel Monsivais, Asim Ghosh, Kunal Bhattacharya, Robin I. M. Dunbar, Kimmo Kaski, Tracking urban human activity from mobile phone calling patterns,  PLOS Computational Biology, November 21, 2017

title: Project: AI Energy Sensor interface for Google Home/Assistant
objectives:
Non-intrusive Load Monitoring is a new sensing strategy to detect energy appliances in a home using a single sensor. By using machine learning the low-cost sensor can detect which appliances are turned ON or OFF and how much energy they are consuming. However, like many AI-infused interfaces, NILM requires training which is usually the main challenge of deploying these systems.
This project will build on previous experience with NILM deployment to develop an Android Home/Assistance interface that it capable of training the NILM sensor using assistant commands and also Google Hub to provide ecofeedback on the household energy consumption.
requirements: Students should be familiar with Android development and have an interest in AI and user experience design. The NILM sensors and the Google Hub will be provided for testing and deployments.

title: [Dissertação] : Neural Approaches for Question Retrieval and Generation from FAQ Databases
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Mariana Almeida ( http://www.lx.it.pt/~mscla/ ), and it will be developed in the context of a collaboration between INESC-ID and a company named Cleverly ( https://cleverly.ai ).

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including a PhD student named Luís Borges that is working on neural passage retrieval (under a co-supervision with Prof. Jamie Callan from LTI/CMU).

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Frequently asked question (FAQ) pages appear often on the Web with various information (i.e., answers to diverse users questions) on the Web, and pairs of frequent questions/answers are often also compiled in the context of customer support services. A FAQ retrieval system, which takes a user’s query and retrieves relevant question/answer pairs, afterwards using the retrieved information to select/compile an answer to present to the users, can be quite useful for supporting the access to these information resources.

While FAQ retrieval has been explored in the past, most previous methods have relied on traditional feature engineering for surfacing similarities between queries and questions/answers, with relatively few previous studies exploring the use of modern retrieval methods based on deep neural networks ( see https://arxiv.org/pdf/1905.02851.pdf ).

This MSc research project will explore neural approaches for question retrieval and generation from FAQ databases, taking inspiration on recent approaches proposed for passage/document retrieval ( e.g., see https://microsoft.github.io/msmarco/ or https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.05125 ) or for question answering ( e.g., see https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/N19-4013/ , https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.11339 or https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.03975 ) from document collections. In particular, the methods that are to be developed with explore the use of pre-trained contextual language models for representing queries and questions/answer pairs ( see https://huggingface.co/transformers ), using these representations to re-rank candidate questions/answers according to term-based retrieval from the user query ( e.g., through https://github.com/castorini/pyserini/ ). Pre-trained contextual language models will also be used to generate the final answer, with basis on the question/answers pairs obtained through neural re-ranking ( e.g., see https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.11401 ).

Given that the existing datasets for evaluating FAQ retrieval systems are relatively small, experiments will explore the idea of generating synthetic queries to support model training ( e.g., see https://arxiv.org/pdf/2004.14503.pdf ), or the use of self-training methods that use BM25 as a noisy supervision signal ( e.g., see https://openreview.net/pdf?id=S1ltj47xdE or https://dl.acm.org/doi/fullHtml/10.1145/3366423.3380060 ).

title: Dissertação: Coding the future data center networks
objectives:
Datacenter networks (DCNs) need to support low-latency and high-bandwidth continuously, to meet the stringent requirements of modern cloud applications. Quickly recovering from network failures is therefore an essential requirement of a modern DCN [1]. However, existing solutions [2-4] are either slow in responding to failures, present scalability problems, and/or add complexity and higher network costs.

The goal of this project is to design NC-DCN, a high-performance, highly robust data center network that uses network coding as its foundation. The rationale for this approach is that the ability to code network packets has been shown to improve a network's throughput, robustness, and security [5]. Given the fundamentally different packet processing required by this new paradigm, until recently it was impossible to perform network coding in real hardware, creating a barrier to its wide-spread adoption. Fortunately, the emergence of programmable switches (such as Intel/Barefoot Tofino [6], the world’s fastest) and of a language to program them (such as P4 [7]) have eventually changed the state of affairs, and enabled very recently the development of the first network coding (NC) switch by our team [8]. 

We anticipate the preliminary design of NC-DCN to have the data center network divided into two classes of devices: preparatory switches at the network edge and network coding switches to form the network fabric. The network fabric performs coding and recoding operations, while the network edge serves as a preparatory stage for the complex coding operations applied within the fabric. The student will have the opportunity to leverage our previous work [8] as an initial step to the design and evaluation of a first prototype of NC-DCN on a cutting-edge programmable switch we have in our lab (Intel Barefoot Tofino [6]) using the P4 language [7].

An NC-based fabric can be a disruptive approach to the design of future data center networks. The student undertaking this project will have the opportunity to study and work with the most advanced networking platforms, to collaborate with leading experts on network coding and network programmability, and to innovate in this field. If successful, the results of the project can represent a highly relevant contribution for modern data centers.

The project will be co-advised by Fernando Ramos (Associate Prof. at IST), and Muriel Medard (Prof. at the MIT, and a leading expert on network coding). Salvatore Signorello (post-doc at INESC-ID) will also be a collaborator in the project. 

References:
[1] ARZANI, Behnaz, et al. "007: Democratically finding the cause of packet drops". In: 15th {USENIX} Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation ({NSDI} 18). 2018. p. 419-435.
[2] WILSON, Christo, et al. "Better never than late: Meeting deadlines in datacenter networks". ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, 2011, 41.4: 50-61.
[3] NIRANJAN MYSORE, Radhika, et al. "Portland: a scalable fault-tolerant layer 2 data center network fabric". In: Proceedings of the ACM SIGCOMM 2009 conference on Data communication. 2009. p. 39-50.
[4] LIU, Hongqiang Harry, et al. "zUpdate: Updating data center networks with zero loss". In: Proceedings of the ACM SIGCOMM 2013 conference on SIGCOMM. 2013. p. 411-422.
[5] C. Fragouli et al., “Network coding: an instant primer”, ACM SIGCOMM CCR, January 2006

title: [Dissertação] Fast matroid intersection and applications
objectives:
Matroids are a very useful abstraction in mathematics and combinatorial optimization allowing to model many different problems, such as optimum spanning trees, optimum arborescences, and optimum assignments. General algorithms can then be used to solve instances of many different problems. The issue with these general algorithms is that their complexity is usually higher than that of problem specific algorithms. One of those general algorithms is the matroid intersection algorithm, which plays also an important role in other general matroid algorithms. The aim of this work is to study a new implementation of the matroid intersection algorithm based on recent techniques proposed from a theoretical point of view. Those techniques might allow us to obtain a general intersection algorithm with a complexity close to that of problem specific algorithms. Hence, an experimental evaluation will be also part of this work to evaluated the practical applicability of the developed implementation on different problems. 


References:
1. Faster Matroid Intersection [https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.10765]
2. A Fast Approximation for Maximum Weight Matroid Intersection [http://chekuri.cs.illinois.edu/papers/matroid-intersection-approx-soda.pdf]
3. Exact and Approximation Algorithms forWeighted Matroid Intersection [https://www.di.ens.fr/~cchuang/work/matroid_intersection.pdf]
4. Combinatorial Optimization: Polyhedra and Efficiency, by Alexander Schrijver (2004)
5. Combinatorial Optimization: Theory and Algorithms, by Bernhard Korte and Jens Vygen (2008)
6. Combinatorial optimization: networks and matroids, by Lawler (1995)
7. Computing in Combinatorial Optimization, by W. Cook (2019).
8. Matroids [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matroid]
requirements: The student should have taken the Advanced Algorithms course and have, or be interested in acquiring, competences in algorithm engineering, algorithms and data structures, combinatorial optimization, and programming.

title: Dissertação: ITLingo/GenTechnicalDocs: Produção Automática de Documentação Técnica
observations: Proposta pré-atribuída ao aluno: João Miguel Nunes Tavares Rodrigues (83483)
objectives:
No âmbito da iniciativa de investigação ITLingo/RSL (Requirements Specification Language) tem sido definida uma linguagem textual para especificação rigorosa de requisitos (linguagem RSL), cuja versão preliminar se encontra disponível a partir de https://github.com/ITLingo/RSL.  
No âmbito deste projeto pretende-se que o aluno investigue e consolide os seus conhecimentos nas áreas da engenharia de requisitos, modelação de sistemas, validação e produção automática de documentação técnica. 

Este projeto deverá desenvolver-se ao longo das seguintes fases:
A primeira fase consiste na análise e definição do problema e na investigação sobre a iniciativa ITLingo, em particular a linguagem RSL e as suas ferramentas e tecnologias de suporte (e.g., ITLingo-Studio, Xtext); bem como o aprofundamento do corpo de conhecimento relacionado com a engenharia de requisitos e da documentação técnica de sistemas. 
A segunda fase consiste na definição e implementação de mecanismos de transformação de especificações de requisitos (em RSL) em documentos técnicos que integrem também modelos visuais de sistemas de informação (e.g., em UML, BPMN, IFML, Wireframe). Estes modelos visuais deverão ser integrados em documentação técnica de requisitos de acordo com templates predefinidos em ferramentas de Office (e.g., MS-Word, Excel), e por esta forma complementarem as especificações textuais.
A terceira fase consiste na definição de estudos de casos (i.e., especificações de requisitos para aplicações/sistemas concretos) que permitam a consequente avaliação e discussão dos resultados produzidos. Este trabalho deverá ainda ser avaliado e discutido com base de trabalho relacionado.

https://github.com/ITLingo/RSL

title: Dissertation: All-to-All Matchmaking for Multiplayer Games
objectives:
Multiple games involve the confrontation of opposing players or teams, generally two e.g. tennis, football, Valve's Defense Of The Ancients, Riot's League of Legends. As a result, most matchmaking approaches in digital games are aimed at finding two opponents or teams with similar skill levels. In this work, the goal is to research matchmaking as well as reward strategies that look beyond this number two, while also taking into account the players' preferred play styles. In other words, how could a game accommodate simultaneously players that value cooperative play, players that value competitive play, and players that have no desire for interaction, while providing an enjoyable game experience for all?

Main sub-goals:
( 1 ) Literature review (semester 1)
( 2 ) Computational model (semester 1 and 2)
( 3 ) Test scenario implementation (semester 2)
( 4 ) User studies / agent-based simulations (semester 2)

title: Dissertation: Migrating Smart Contracts Across Heterogeneous Blockchains
observations: Rafael Belchior (rafael.belchior@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) will also be involved in the supervision of this thesis.
objectives:
Motivation: 
The suitability of a blockchain solution regarding a use case depends on the underlying blockchain properties. As blockchain technologies are maturing at a fast pace, in particular private blockchains, its properties might change. Consequently, this creates an unbalance between user expectations' and the applicability of the solution. It is, therefore, desirable for an organization to be able to replace the blockchain providing the infrastructure to a certain service.

Description:
Currently, when a consortium wants to migrate their blockchain (e.g., the source blockchain becomes obsolete, cryptographic algorithms are no longer secure, etc), the solution is to re-implement business logic using a different platform, yielding great effort. Migrating data to another blockchain currently is not feasible in practice. This is one of the reasons why mass adoption of blockchain technologies amongst enterprises grows slowly. Data migrations have been performed by Frauenthaler et al. (2019) and Scheid et al. (2019), both recent endeavors to render flexibility to blockchain-based solutions. In those works, the authors propose simple data migration capabilities for public, permissionless blockchains, in which a user can specify requirements for its blockchain. The developed solutions allow "switchovers", where a blockchain is migrated, in case there is a blockchain that better satisfies the current requirements. Nonetheless, arguably a more interesting approach would be to consider cross-smart contract execution functionality and migration capabilities for enterprise blockchains.

The goal of this project is to explore existing and, potentially, develop new techniques that enable migration of smart contracts (i.e. functionality) across heterogeneous blockchains.


Expected results:
1. Proof of concept migrating Hyperledger Fabric 2.0 smart contracts to Hyperledger Besu (Ethereum).
2. (optional) This thesis can be framed in the most recent Hyperledger open-source project, Hyperledger Cactus (https://github.com/hyperledger/cactus)

 
References:
Scheid, E., Rodrigues, B. and Stiller, B., 2019, April. Toward a policy-based blockchain agnostic framework. In 2019 IFIP/IEEE Symposium on Integrated Network and Service Management (IM) (pp. 609-613). IEEE.

Philipp Frauenthaler, Michael Borkowski, and Stefan Schulte. 2019. A Framework for Blockchain Interoperability and Runtime Selection.

title: Dissertação || PETA: Privacy by design EnTerprise Architecture patterns
supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (50%)
observations: Proposto  por Aluna: Maria Guerreiro Dias Coelho, 83512
objectives:
Motivation: 

A arquitetura empresarial descreve os processos, informação, aplicações e tecnologia tendo em vista o suporte ao desenvolvimento do negócio da organização. 

Por outro lado, o Regulamento Geral de Proteção de Dados (RGPD) é o diploma legal que regula o tratamento de dados pessoais de pessoa singulares residentes no território da União Europeia (UE). Este documento traz novidades assinaláveis ao nível dos deveres das organizações e dos direitos dos cidadãos relativamente ao tratamento dos dados pessoais.
O RGPD define os direitos dos titulares dos dados pessoais e os deveres dos responsáveis pelo tratamento desses dados. Designadamente o RGPD estabelece os princípios relativos ao tratamento dos dados pessoais: a lealdade, licitude e transparência do tratamento dos dados pessoais; a limitação das finalidades; a minimização dos dados; a exatidão dos dados; a limitação da conservação; a integridade; e a responsabilidade. Também são estabelecidos os seguintes direitos dos titulares dos dados pessoais: de acesso, ao apagamento, à limitação do tratamento, de portabilidade dos dados, de oposição e de decisões individuais automatizadas (profiling).
De forma a garantir a segurança dos dados pessoais o RGPD implica que as organizações analisem o nível de risco de segurança no tratamento, que avaliem o impacto sobre a proteção de dados (PIA – Privacy Assessment Impact) e que adotem medidas de conformidade para reduzir os riscos.

Com esta tese, pretende-se proceder à proposta de padrões arquiteturais, designadamente aos níveis informacionais e aplicacionais, no contexto dos sistemas da Administração Pública, de forma a assegurar o melhor cumprimento e conformidade com o RGPD, assegurando que, desde as fases de preliminares de arquitetura, os sistemas são definidos tendo por base princípios de privacidade.
requirements:
Description:Nesta investigação, numa primeira fase, pretende-se proceder ao levantamento do estado da arte em termos das metodologias, frameworks e padrões para modelação de arquiteturas considerando as restrições do RGPD e da Privacidade em geral, tanto no ponto de vista de aplicações operacionais como aplicações analíticas que alavancam os dados registados nas primeiras.
Numa segunda fase, o aluno inserido em contexto de organismo público de referência, deverá analisar as obrigações impostas pelo RGPD e legislação nacional existente e propor padrões e princípios ao nível da arquitetura informacional e aplicacional para contemplar os requisitos definidos pelo RGPD, incluindo: a identificação das finalidades, a exatidão, a limitação da conservação, a integridade, a responsabilidade, os direitos ao acesso, ao apagamento, à limitação do tratamento, à portabilidade dos dados, à oposição, e profiling.
 
Figura 1 – Exemplo de Classificação de Dados de acordo com a sensibiliade
(fonte: https://bizzdesign.com/blog/8-steps-enterprise-architects-can-take-to-deal-with-gdpr/)
Em seguida o aluno deverá aplicar os padrões e princípios para propor a melhoria de arquitetura de informação e aplicacional das plataformas da AMA. No levantamento e descrição da arquitetura deve ser possível avaliar a existência de funcionalidades associadas à informação, nos termos do RGPD, nomeadamente a recolha consentimento e comunicação, gerir/atribuir finalidades, prazos de conservação; efetuar categorização, anonimização, encriptação, apagamento, correção e exportação/portabilidade de acordo com os requisitos do RGPD e Resolução de Conselho de Ministros 41/2018.

 
Figura 2 – Principios de Privacy by design
(fonte: Cavoukian, A.: (2009) “Privacy by Design The 7 Foundational Principles Implementation and Mapping of Fair Information Practices”)
 
Figura 3 – Exemplo de vista de padrão de registo de cliente
(fonte: Cavoukian, A.: (2009) “Privacy by Design The 7 Foundational Principles Implementation and Mapping of Fair Information Practices”)

A aplicação dos padrões e princípios deve ainda considerar a co-habitação de aplicações operacionais, analíticas e sandboxes para investigação, de forma a assegurar o correto tratamento e monitorização. Em particular os padrões e princípios de privacidade propostos devem prever a sua instanciação nos building blocks disponíveis nas plataformas cloud típicas (Azure, AWS ou Google), ou componentes que tenham de ser desenvolvidos à medida.

Os padrões arquiteturais identificados deverão ser instanciados em ferramenta de arquitetura empresarial, de forma a possibilitar a futura aplicação em projetos de sistemas de informação.


Expected results:
1.: Levantamento do Estado da arte de Padrões e princípios arquiteturais
2.	Proposta de padrões de informacional e aplicacional de forma a assegurar “Privacy by Design”;
3.	Instanciação de padrões em ferramenta de arquitetura empresarial, no contexto da Administração Pública 
4. Publicação de artigo. ……

title: Dissertação: Learning temporal and geographic patterns from IPST blood collection data
observations:
Co-orientação da FCUL:
Prof. Sara C. Madeira - sacmadeira@fc.ul.pt
objectives:
The Instituto Português do Sangue e da Transplantação (IPST) is a public institute of the Ministry of Health, and the recognized authority for the collection and regulation of blood donation and transplantation at the national level. IPST operations are organized in three regional centers: south, center and north. Each regional center has the same features, having its own finite resources (e.g. staff and equipment) for blood collections, processing, storage and distribution. In this context, the goal of LAIfeBlood project (DSAIPA/AI/0033/2019) is to provide IPST with new tools to improve efficiency of blood supply operations in Portugal. In particular, LAIfeBlood is particularly focused on: (1) extracting temporal and geographical patterns from historical collection and transfusion data; (2) developing predictive models for the expected collections and transfusions in different temporal and geographic areas; and (3) developing software tools to optimize the planning of collections at the national level according to the availability of IPST teams and resources and collection events.

This thesis is integrated in LAIfeBlood’s work plan and will use IPST historical data to contribute to the first goal: (1) extracting temporal and geographical patterns from historical collection and transfusion data. In particular, advanced pattern mining techniques will be used to learn temporal and geographic patterns from blood collection data.
 
The work plan consists on: studying the problem and related work on blood collection; studying pattern mining approaches for temporal pattern discovery and spatio-temporal pattern discovery; analysing exploratory data using IPST blood collection data; proposing a machine learning methodology to unravel temporal and geographic patterns from IPST blood collection data; implement the pattern discovery proposed methodology; using the pattern discovery methodology implemented to uncover temporal and geographic patterns from IPST blood collection data; and evaluating, ranking and interpreting the results.
requirements: Interest machine learning and data science.Preference will be given to students with approval on a machine learning/data science course.

title: [Dissertação] Equivalence Checking for OutSystems Logic
observations: Miguel Neves, miguel.neves@outsystems.com
objectives: Duplicated code is commonplace in large software projects, and can have a serious impact on their maintainability. This issue is aggravated in projects with several contributors, which may tackle the same problem using very different approaches and, consequently, producing dissimilar but semantically equivalent, and thus duplicated, code that cannot be detected using traditional duplicated code detection techniques. The goal of this project is to implement an equivalence prover for OutSystems logic. Such a prover has potential for becoming a crucial enabler of several applications beyond duplicated code detection, such as automated refactoring and optimization.

title: (DISSERTATION) Acronym and Expansion Extraction
observations: O aluno João Casanova demonstrou interesse neste tema.
objectives:
Acronym expansion is the problem of finding an expansion for a given
acronym in a textual document (e.g., ``ATM'' can mean
automatic teller machine in a banking context or asynchronous
transfer mechanism in a communications context). Acronyms are used in all
kinds of textual documents and articles. They are useful as a shorthand,
however the lack of an acronym expansion in the text
can become a communication barrier with non-expert persons.
Our Acronym Expander
system is available online (http://acronymexpander.inesc-id.pt/). Given
a document (either in a textual format or a webpage URL) as input, it
provides the user with access to a simple table of acronyms found in text
and the corresponding expansions. 

Our system works in two phases: (i) acronym-expansion extraction to
identify acronyms in a given article and to find the expansions in the
nearby environment when available, (ii) disambiguate acronyms that are not
expanded in the text by trying to infer the subject matter (i.e., the
context) of the document and to use defined expansions in
subject-matter-similar documents. Phase (i) is particularly important because
acronyms and expansions have to be correctly identified in text both
to understand the acronyms in a text and to serve as reference associations
for other texts.
In the literature there are several works that explored this problem.
However, it is not clear which is the best approach for acronym-expansion
extraction because the most recent works have not been directly compared
against each other and did not use a common dataset. Moreover, in practice
there is no evidence that the overhead of using training data and the
execution time spent in machine learning based techniques overcomes
rule-based approaches in this task.
To overcome these problems, in this Master Thesis, the candidate should
perform the following tasks:
1) Create a Benchmark using publicly available datasets for acronym and
expansion extraction;
2) Implement recent related work in acronym and expansion extraction;
3) Evaluate the recent related work using the benchmark developed;
4) Explore new approaches that may include a hybrid approach with
rule-based and machine learning.

title: Dissertação: SDN Controller Synthesis
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Prof. Luis Pedrosa (luis.pedrosa@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) and Prof. Fernando Ramos (fvramos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Building the networks that power modern distributed systems has led to new designs and architectures that are often not backward compatible with standard network devices and frameworks. This has led to a recent push for increased programmability and configurability in the network, with different efforts trading off flexibility and performance.

One such approach that has garnered significant traction is software defined networking (SDN). In this paradigm, a logically centralized controller manages a network of SDN switches. The switches can be “programmed” on the fly using a simple set of rules that define patterns for matching packets and the subsequent actions that should be applied to any matched packets. This offers total flexibility for the network control-plane while somewhat limiting the flexibility of the data-plane, allowing it to be implemented in dedicated highly performant hardware.

More recently, the community has been exploring software network functions (NFs), where even the data-plane is implemented in software and new techniques such as kernel-bypass networking have allowed commodity processors to process packets at a significant rate. This offers full programmability in the network, but achieving full line-rate and implementing entire networks can be a challenge.

To program entire networks it would be convenient for developers to design and program the network as if it were one big NF with many logical ports connecting to every single network endpoint. This simplifies development at the expense of deployment. Centralizing packet processing in this manner would pose significant scaling challenges so a hybrid approach, much like what SDN offers, is needed.

In this thesis, we will explore using SDN switches as network accelerators and to synthesize an SDN controller that implements the same logic as a logically centralized NF that is given as input, while offloading as much of the processing to the network as possible. Our specific goal is to build a static analysis tool that analyzes the NF code and subsequently generates an SDN controller that manages the network, setting up rules on SDN switches that achieve the same effect as the NF logic. The end result will be a controller that is compatible with modern SDN deployments, while offering the same programmability of NFs.

The objective of this work is to explore the importance of the audiovisual context in which an emotion is expressed to its recognition.
