title: Dissertação: FPGA (OpenCL) accelerated model checking of regulatory networks
objectives:
Models of biological networks have been studied through simulations using a number of software tools. However, the intrinsic disparity between the sequential nature of microprocessor architecture used in software-based simulations and the highly parallel nature of biological systems may result in prohibitively long simulation times.

In this work, we adopt an alternative approach to simulation of biological systems using hardware-software based emulation.
Previous works on hardware acceleration have reported speedups up to 17,000x when compared to existing software simulation approaches.

Hardware accelerators are often based on reconfigurable logic (FPGAs) which allow to have highly customized circuit implementations, and can be attached to a computer as a PCI-Express accelerator, like a GPU (https://www.terasic.com.tw/cgi-bin/page/archive.pl?Language=English&CategoryNo=158&No=526 ).
The development of hardware accelerators can be done using frameworks such as OpenCL which allows the developer to specify a high-performance hardware-software accelerator kernels without knowledge of low-level system design. This allows Software Engineers to design hardware accelerators without relying on a hardware engineer to implement it.

In this thesis the focus is on the optimization the common model-checker (http://lvl.info.ucl.ac.be/Tools/NuSMV-ARCTL-TLACE) used in the emulation of biological systems, and on the implementation of the most computational intensive parts in the hardware accelerator. The software (C/C++) will be running on the ARM inside the FPGA.

It is expected to have a demonstrator running on an FPGA embedded system.
requirements: Good programming skills and interest in embedded systems/FPGA accelerators is a plus.

title: [Dissertation] A First-Order Solver for Program Analysis
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
Program analysis and verification tools often rely on state of the art SMT solvers to discharge their core logic first order queries. The design and implementation of such solvers is an active field of research, delivering more mature and performant solvers every year [1]. Nevertheless, current solvers only support a limited number of theories, such as the theories of real arithmetic, strings, and bit-vectors. Other theories, such as the theories of sets, lists, multi-sets, and discrete maps, are still scarcely supported and mainly found in specialised solvers designed for the targeted theory. 
At Imperial College London, the Verified Trustworthy Software Specification group developed JaVerT [2,3], the first separation-logic-based tool for JavaScript verification. JaVerT has been the topic of several publications in top-level Programming Language (PL) venues, won a Facebook research award [4], and is currently being used to verify the Amazon AWS Encryption SDK [5]. 

JaVerT has at its core a first order solver with support for the theory of real arithmetic and very limited ad-hoc support for the theories of lists and sets. This solver works by encoding the first order fragment of JaVerT logic into Z3 [6], a world-leading SMT solver developed at Microsoft Research. The **goal** of this thesis is to extend the first order solver of JaVerT with principled support for decidable fragments of the theories of sets and lists (already partially supported) and, for the first time, floating point arithmetic, strings, multi-sets, and discrete maps. 
This project combines theory and practice. The limitations of the proposed solver are to be precisely understood and formally characterised and the resulting implementation must be thoroughly evaluated using appropriate test suites.

[1] D. Monniaux. A Survey on Satisfiability Modulo Theory. CASC’16. 
[2] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT: JavaScript Verification Toolchain. POPL’18. 
[3] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT 2.0: Compositional Symbolic Execution for JavaScript. POPL’19.  
[4] https://research.fb.com/announcing-the-winners-of-the-facebook-continuous-reasoning-research-awards/
[5] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/encryption-sdk/latest/developer-guide/introduction.html
[6] L. De Moura et al. Z3: An Efficient SMT Solver. TACAS’08.
requirements: Strong programming skills.

title: Dissertação || NaaS: No shows as a Sevice
observations: Mais informações vide https://sites.google.com/site/vasconcelosandre/teses/mestrado/temas-mestrado
objectives:
Motivation: 
A no-show is a term widely used to describe a client who has an appointment of some sorts with another entity and, voluntarily or not, the client does not show up to that appointment. This term was originally used by airline companies, when they started to notice that this behaviour was more common than they originally thought, thereby creating a specific name for the phenomenon. Since then, the term has been used by other businesses, such as hotel companies and in the health care sector.
A no-show may be classified in two categories:
•	A voluntary no-show, where the client purposely and without cancelling his or her appointment doesn’t show up to his appointment.
•	An involuntary no-show, where, by circumstances outside the client’s control, the client cannot show up to the appointment.
Although a no-show is always a negative influence on its respective business, in the healthcare sector where the resources are highly specialized the no-show create inefficiencies in the system. A patient that misses an appointment, or just doesn’t arrive on time, will mean that that clinic’s and health professional’s time slot will be unused, which could otherwise be used on another patient. This is an increasing problem if we take into consideration the scarcity of health care professionals in Portugal.

Health care centres try to solve this by overbooking, on which they make more appointments than their available time slots. Although this reduces the chance of having free time slots because of a no-show, just overbooking appointments without a careful study doesn’t solve the problem of a long waiting list. In this context, there are various analytical methods that can be used to predict which patients are most likely to cancel or not show up to an appointment. These methods can range from statistical models to machine learning algorithms. With these methods, there is a lower chance of having a vacant time slot and the impact on the waiting list is not as high.
requirements:
Description:With the increasing amount of information in electronic clinical records there is an opportunity for hospitals to be increasingly intelligent and sustainable. One of the factors that create inefficiency in the hospital environment is the no-show of patient to appointments. While several strategies are implemented to reduce the number of no-shows, such as sending sms as reminders, the development of risk stratification models is also important for better resource management and process optimization. Overbooking can be applied in order to take into account the no-shows. However, overbooking is not an optimum approach once it can lead with delays in consultations with impact in the client satisfaction and increased workload of the healthcare professionals. Consequently, creating a risk stratification score for no-show can contribute to a better process and resources management [1]. 

This thesis is focus in turn into a product the no-show algorithm (based on existing research). The objective of this algorithm is to build a model that is able to make reliable predictions of a patient’s future behaviour in terms of no-show. The algorithm will include into account the behaviour of the general population behaviour as well as specific behaviour of the client in question. 



Expected results:
1.: NoShows as a Service product architecture
2.	Noshows as a Service produtct implementation
3. Noshows as a Service field testing 
4. Paper Publication.

title: Dissertation - Trusted Execution Environment using Intel SGX for R voluntary computing
objectives:
Voluntary computing systems establish an environment where a set of computers can offer their idle CPU cores to other peer computers in the system as well as use the idle CPUs available in the system.
RemotIST is a voluntary computing platform (often also called peer-to-peer cycle sharing platforms) for the R programming language that was developed at the Distributed Systems Groups of INESC ID Lisboa in a sequence of previous master thesis.
The goal of this dissertation is to explore how the trusted execution environment available in all Intel processors with support for Intel SGX can be used to provide guarantees that code executed on a remote peer was actually and correctly executed.
Intel SGX is a special protected execution mode in some modern Intel processors that allows remote nodes to run a program without the need to expose the code or data to the remote node's operating system or applications. 
Intel SGX provides APIs that allow programmers to use the Intel SGX processor features to prepare the code and data, place them on the remote node, run them and retrieve the results.
In this dissertation, the goal is to design a solution that allows running the R runtime as well as the RemotIST support features on an remote Intel SGX processor thereby providing to RemotIST nodes guarantees that their code was actually executed with correction and privacy.

title: Dissertação: ITLingo/EASL: Especificação Rigorosa de Arquiteturas Empresariais
objectives:
No âmbito da iniciativa de investigação ITLingo tem sido definida uma linguagem para especificação rigorosa de arquiteturas empresariais (designada por EASL, Enterprise Architecture Specification Language), baseada no ArchiMate, cuja versão atual se encontra implementada através de uma ferramenta que consiste num sofisticado template MS-Excel, aqui designado por “EASL-Template”.

No âmbito deste projeto pretende-se que o aluno investigue e consolide os seus conhecimentos nas áreas dos sistemas e arquiteturas empresariais, nas suas múltiplas dimensões, tais como negócio, aplicações, e infraestruturas tecnológicas. Pretende-se em particular que o aluno possa explorar os seguintes aspetos em torno da utilização e extensão do EASL-Template (a definir em maior detalhe no decurso do trabalho): 
(i) Identificar e explorar mecanismos de configuração para melhor utilização deste template; 
(ii) Identificar e explorar mecanismos de alinhamento, rastreabilidade e transformações automáticas entre os vários conceitos da arquitetura (e.g., entre componentes aplicacionais e infraestruturas tecnológicas, ou entre termos do glossário e entidades informacionais); 
(iii) Identificar, estender e explorar mecanismos de controlo e execução de projetos, que tem implicações no ciclo de vida da arquitetura, nomeadamente pela inclusão de gráficos e dashboards para visualização de situações AS-IS e TO-BE; e 
(iv) Definir mecanismos de integração/interoperabilidade com ferramentas de modelação (e.g., Archi, Sparxs EA).

Este projeto deverá desenvolver-se ao longo das seguintes fases:
A primeira fase consiste na análise e definição do problema e na investigação sobre a iniciativa ITLingo EASL, bem como o aprofundamento do corpo de conhecimento relacionado com área de arquiteturas empresariais, e ainda a análise de templates e ferramentas de arquiteturas empresariais. 
A segunda fase consiste na análise, utilização e extensão do EASL-Template, de acordo com a linguagem EASL, e considerando ainda a análise da literatura. Estas tarefas deverão permitir explorar os aspetos acima referidos e estender e validar a própria linguagem EASL.
A terceira fase consiste na definição de casos concretos (a definir), que permitam a consequente avaliação e discussão dos resultados produzidos.

title: Dissertação: Point Cloud Super-Resolution
location: IST - Instituto de Telecomunicações, Multimedia Signal Processing Group, North Tower, 10th floor
objectives:
Scope:
Recent advances in virtual reality related technologies have been boosting the usage of 3D visual representation formats, notably point clouds due to their great advantages in terms of user immersion and interaction. A PC is an unordered set of points in 3D space, usually represented by their coordinates, corresponding to the geometry; moreover, each PC point may have other associated attributes, such as color, which will not be addressed in this paper. As more and more PC content is made available, the development of appropriate processing and coding solutions becomes essential since non-compressed PCs require a huge amount of data, thus preventing efficient transmission and storage. Recognizing the importance of PC data for major emerging 3D-based applications, MPEG has just concluded the specification of two PC coding standards for static and dynamic PCs, while JPEG has recently launched a Call for Evidence on Point Cloud Coding, especially addressing scalability and random access.
As for images and video, the point cloud resolution, in this case the number of 3D points in a point cloud, has a significant impact not only on the compression efficiency when the point cloud is coded but also on the final quality of experience as denser point clouds typically lead to better quality while rendering as the surfaces are better represented. 
In this context, super-resolution methods, this means methods appropriately increasing the number of points in the point cloud, may have an important impact in multiple ways. One of them is in terms of compression efficiency since a point cloud may be simplified at the encoder to save coding rate to be later super-resolved at the decoder, to recover a denser, higher quality point cloud.  

Objectives:
In this context, the main objectives of this Thesis are: 
1)	Review and compare the available point cloud super-resolution solutions;
2)	Design, implement and assess a novel point cloud super-resolution leveraging on the already available solutions.

The following steps will be relevant:
•	Gathering of the relevant literature for static point cloud super-resolution
•	Review of the relevant literature and writing of a state-of-the-art review chapter
•	Evaluation of relevant point cloud super-resolution solution(s) available in the literature using suitable quality metrics
•	Design and implementation of an effective point cloud super-resolution solution
•	Performance assessment of the developed point cloud super-resolution solution, notably for coding purposes, using relevant and appropriate test conditions, benchmarks and methodologies
•	Definition of future work addressing the improvement of the developed point cloud super-resolution solution 

Some relevant references are:
[1] F. Pereira and E. A. da Silva, “Efficient plenoptic imaging representation: why do we need it?”, IEEE Int. Conf. Multimedia and Expo, Seattle, WA, USA, Jul. 2016.
[2] D. C. Garcia, T. A. Fonseca, R. L. de Queiroz, “Example-based super-resolution for point-cloud video”, Int. Conf. on Image Processing, Athens, Greece, October 2018.
[3] H. Wu, J. Zhang, K. Huang, “Point cloud super resolution with adversarial residual graph networks”, arXiv:1908.02111.
[4] L. Yu, X. Li, C.-W. Fu, D. Cohen-Or, P.-A. Heng, “PU-Net: point cloud upsampling network”, CVPR, Salt Lake City, UT, USA, June 2018.
[5] C. Dinesh, G. Cheung. I. V. Bajić, “3D point cloud super-resolution via graph total variation on surface normals”, Int. Conf. on Image Processing, Taipe, Taiwan, September 2019.
[6] J. Kammerl et al., “Real-time compression of point cloud streams”, IEEE Int. Conf. Robotics Automation, Saint Paul, MN, USA, May 2012, pp. 778–785.
[7] S. Schwarz et al., “Emerging MPEG standards for point cloud compression,” IEEE Trans. Emerg. Sel. Topics Circuits Syst., vol. 9, no. 1, pp. 133–148, Mar. 2019.
[8] L. Cui et al., “Point-cloud compression: moving picture experts group's new standard in 2020,” IEEE Consum. Electron. Mag., vol. 8, no. 4, pp. 17-21, July 2019.

title: [Dissertação] : Spatio-Temporal Question Answering Leveraging Neural Language Models for Passage Retrieval
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and João Magalhães ( http://ctp.di.fct.unl.pt/~jmag/ ), and it will be developed in the context of the MIMU research project, currently being executed at INESC-ID.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers participating in the project, including a PhD student named Luís Borges that is also working on neural passage retrieval (under a co-supervision with Prof. Jamie Callan from LTI/CMU).

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Question Answering (QA), i.e. the process of computing valid answers to questions formulated in natural language, is gaining increased attention both in industry and academia. Passage retrieval, i.e. the identification of top-ranked passages from documents within a background collection that may contain the answer for a given question, is a crucial component of QA systems. Recent studies in the area have proposed a variety of passage retrieval methods based on large neural language models ( https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.07278 ), using large datasets such as MS-MARCO for model training and evaluation ( see the MS MARCO leaderboard -- https://microsoft.github.io/msmarco/ -- or the descriptions from previous TREC Deep Learning track competitions -- https://microsoft.github.io/TREC-2020-Deep-Learning/ -- for information about current state-of-the-art systems ). 

Spatio-temporal questions (e.g., who was involved in a particular event, or when has a particular event taken place) are among the most frequent on question answering systems, motivating the development of tailored approaches. Spatio-temporal questions are also featured prominently in the MS MARCO dataset ( see http://dx.doi.org/10.4230/LIPIcs.COSIT.2019.12 ), although current neural models for passage retrieval are not explicitly designed to explore spatial and/or temporal properties when deciding on the matches between questions and passages.
	
This MSc research project concerns the development and evaluation of neural models for passage retrieval, with a particular focus on spatio-temporal questions. An initial phase will involve the creation of a novel dataset, corresponding to a subset of MS MARCO, featuring questions that contain references to place names and/or to temporal expressions. Existing open source tools, such as the Mordecai geoparser ( https://github.com/openeventdata/mordecai ) or the HeidelTime/SuTime  temporal taggers ( https://github.com/HeidelTime/heideltime or https://nlp.stanford.edu/software/sutime.html ), will be used to process the textual contents from questions and passages, associating toponyms to geospatial coordinates and temporal expressions to calendar dates. The geo-spatial distance between the sets of coordinates from queries and passages, or the temporal distance between the sets of dates also from queries and passages, will afterwards be used to assess the matches between questions and passages, complementing scores derived from the textual contents. To compute distances between sets of items, one possibility involves the use of metrics such as the Hausdorff distance ( see https://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.02574.pdf ).

The actual neural models for passage retrieval, to be explored within this project, can for instance be based on encoding the concatenation of queries-passages through models like BERT or RoBERTa ( see https://github.com/huggingface/transformers ). The loss functions to be used during model training can explore intuitions inspired on axiomatic approaches for information retrieval ( see https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-15712-8_32 ), enforcing the heuristic that passages containing references that are spatio-temporaly close to the references within the query should, in principle, be more relevant. 

The project will also involve the use of approaches for diagnosing/inspecting the obtained ranking results, for instance through the use of approaches such as Grad-CAM ( https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.05768 ) for inspecting weights associated to use of the neural models for processing particular queries.

title: [Dissertation] VR Immersive Speculative Enactments
observations: Tese a ser co-orientada pelo Prof. Adalberto Simeone da KU Leuven: https://www.adalsimeone.me/
objectives:
Immersive Speculative Enactments (ISEs)​ are a novel concept through which we seek to use Virtual Reality to immerse users in scenarios that are difficult to enact through other conventional means. For example, scenarios set in the past or (near) future. In this way, we can use VR as a tool to study how users would behave in a variety of situations that we can only speculate about, but will not actually be able to observe until the portrayed situation materializes (if ever). In order to improve the effectiveness of this speculative method, one of the proposed new research directions consist in exploring which aspects of the ISE can elicit a more realistic (or adherent) response to the scenario. We propose to recreate one new ISEs, to apply the method in different levels of "future uncertainty".

In this project your goal will be to:

● Reflect on the requirements (in terms of design, interaction, narrative) of the chosen ISE
● Create the Virtual Environment supporting the experience
● Run a user study and use qualitative methods of inquiry to analyze the results

title: Dissertação: IT Risk Management Ontology from representation to optimization using Enterprise Ontology
observations: Co-orientador de docente externo: Ruben Pereira (ISCTE) Ruben.Filipe.Pereira@iscte-iul.pt
objectives:
Objectivos: 
Nowadays information technologies (IT) are present in all organizations and are constantly evolving, faster than ever before. Increasingly complex interdependencies and flexibility demands rapidly changing networked environments make this effect even more pronounced for organizations relying heavily on IT systems to provide services. With the rising importance of IT the weight of IT induced risk increases, and the importance of operational risks in this context will keep raising. Given the impact of scandals have had in enterprises new strategies, models, and more effective ways to manage risk are needed. Enterprise ontology (EO) is an emergent knowledge field, that is applied to complex organizations when explicit definitions of competences, responsibilities, authorities and delegations are demanded. Therefore, this research uses EO to, firstly, represent the essential of IT Risk Management (ITRM) process, and afterwards optimize it. Since the applicability of EO in this field has not been usual in the body of knowledge, this study may be seen as exploratory research. This research ends with the identification of EO’s advantages in ITRM process, lessons learned, conclusion, and future work.

Resultados Esperados: 
1. Levantamento de Estado da Arte
2. Proposta de implementação de ontologia IT RM usando ATLAS (Link Consulting).
3. Avaliação usando design science research (DSR).  
4. Publicação de artigo

title: [Dissertation] A Separation-Logic Solver for Program Verification
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
Recent years have witnessed a series of success stories on the application of program analysis and verification techniques to statically-typed programming languages inside world-leading software companies. The most notable example is Infer [1], a separation-logic-based tool developed inside Facebook that is aimed at lightweight bug-finding of C, C++, Java/Android, and Objective C programs. 
For program analyses to attain proper industrial acknowledgment and uptake, they need to be scalable. Program analyses achieve scalability by being compositional: that is, “the analysis result for a composite program is defined in terms of the analysis results for its parts and a means of combining them” [2]. In fact, compositionality was key for the success of Infer, which analyses millions of lines of code per day as part of Facebook’s code review pipeline. 
Separation logic [3, 4] is a form of program analysis that enables compositional program reasoning. It is at the core of Infer, where it is used for lightweight bug-finding, but it also underpins many academic tools for proving functional correctness properties of programs written in languages as different as C [5, 6], Java [6,7], OCaml [8], and JavaScript [9,10].
Modern separation logic engines use separation logic formulas to represent the state of their input programs and sophisticated pattern matching techniques to solve entailments between these formulas. These techniques are often described in the literature in a non-deterministic fashion, meaning that they cannot be directly used to guide efficient implementations. 

At Imperial College London, the Verified Trustworthy Software Specification group developed JaVerT [9,10], the first separation-logic-based tool for JavaScript verification. JaVerT has been the topic of several publications in top-level Programming Language (PL) venues, won a Facebook research award [11], and is currently being used to verify the Amazon AWS Encryption SDK [12]. 

JaVerT uses a custom-made separation logic solver based on pattern matching as part of its core symbolic execution engine. The **goal** of this project is to re-design the existing solver using recent ideas on sub-goal ordering [13,14] coming from logic programming research, where pattern matching is routinely used in the context of unification [15]. We expect the new solver to exhibit better performance than the existing one, and, more importantly, to be based on a clear well-defined algorithm that others can follow. 

This project combines theory and practice. The limitations of the proposed algorithm are to be precisely understood and formally characterised and the resulting implementation must be thoroughly evaluated using appropriate test suites (example: the separation logic benchmarks from the 2014 competition [16]). 

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial. Good projects may lead to a publication in a verification/PL venue.

title: Dissertation: Creating Game Stories through Social Simulation
location: The work will be conducted at GAIPS - INESC-ID and Laboratório de Jogos, IST- Taguspark.
objectives:
Games heavily rely on the non-player characters (NPCs) to present their narratives. All interactions between characters - from dialogues to resources manipulation - are used to share with the player intricate details about the game story. However, these exchanges are usually supported by an extensive authoring effort. To create believable characters, game studios rely on scripted content to accommodate narrative branching and all possible interactions.
Still, in our daily lives, we see the potential that small social interactions can have in creating new events that we can later recall, share and discuss with others. Usually, they can be framed as interactions between social actors that have certain requirements (e.g. context) and produce certain effects (e.g. resources). Similarly, in games, the interactive nature of this media allows for recurrent encounters with other characters where information is exchanged and resources are transacted. Framing these social interactions into a set of templated actions would allow for the emergence of narratives when simulating a population of agents in a game scenario. Thus, producing plots that emerged from the interactions of NPCs.
As such, in this thesis, you would be exploring how to represent social interactions, namely in games, and how to use them to create game narratives. You will review literature on these subjects as well as examine some commercial video games that attempt to do it. Then, you will formalize these concepts into a computational model capable of representing such interactions as well as evolving a network of characters. Finally, the resulting model would be implemented inside a game scenario to test the impact of your contribution on the player experience.
requirements: Interest in AI, Game Design and Research.

title: [DISSERTAÇÃO] Deep generative models for model-based reinforcement learning
observations:
- Description - 

Higgins et al. [2] recently proposed β-VAEs, a variational approach to learning disentangled latent representations from data in an unsupervised manner. The approach assumes that the data of interest is generated from two sets of latent factors of much smaller dimensionality. The factors are assumed conditionally independent, and the goal of β -VAEs is then to build a generative model such that the latent factors retain, as much as possible, their independence properties.
In this work, the student will explore recent developments in learning disentangled representations, exploiting such ideas in the context of model-based RL. In particular, the goal is to address the problem of learning a generative dynamical model for the underlying decision problem that captures the non- stationary dynamics through low-dimensional latent factors [3].

These learned models will then be combined with reinforcement learning to investigate whether, by learning a single generative model from trajectories sampled directly in the environment, the resulting policy is robust to non-stationary dynamics.

Our work in this task builds on existing approaches that combine reinforcement learning with deep generative models [1], and will be applied in the context of benchmark control tasks.

- References -

[1] K. Azizzadenesheli, B. Yang, W. Liu, E. Brunskill, Z. Lipton, A. Anandkumar. “Surprising negative
results for generative adversarial tree search”. CoRR, abs/1806.05780, 2018.

[2] I. Higgins, L. Matthey, A. Pal, C. Burgess, X. Glorot, M. Botvinick, S. Mohamed, A. Lerchner. “β-VAE: Learning basic visual concepts with a constrained variational framework”. In Proc. 5th Int. Conf. Learning Representations, 2017.

[3] H. Yin, F. Melo, A. Billard, A. Paiva. “Associate latent encodings in learn- ing from demonstrations”. In Proc. 31st AAAI Conf. Artificial Intelligence, pp. 3848-3854, 2017.

title: Projeto: A Physically-based Rendering Course with Falcor
objectives:
Motivation:
Computer Graphics history has several examples of important hardware milestones. They changed the way real time  algorithms could be designed and implemented and created vast opportunities for advances in research. NVidia RTX platform has been changing and extending the possibilities for real time Computer Graphics applications. This platform can produce faithful images using Ray Tracing (RT), which is historically known to have prohibitive performance for real time applications. This landmark creates interesting opportunities for new visualization applications. Any Course on photorealistic rendering, ray tracing and global illumination should contemplate these recent GPU technology advances.

Objective: 
The organization of such Course should  provide exercises and demos to deepen the students’ understanding of the basic principles of light transport. This thesis aims to build pedagogic tools that allow students to easily access the Nvidia RTX platform and enable them to write quickly a RT-based program themselves, like path-tracing, photon mapping, etc.

Description:
The access to the RTX platform will done with Falcor (https://developer.nvidia.com/falcor) which is an open-source real-time rendering framework designed specifically for rapid prototyping. It has support for ray tracing shaders. Falcor is less flexible than using DirectX12 or Vulkan APIs directly but is more productive.

title: Dissertation: Populations in Games with Dynamic Social Roles
location: The work will be conducted at GAIPS - INESC-ID and Laboratório de Jogos, IST- Taguspark.
objectives:
In digital games, players interact with characters across multiple contexts. They establish conflicts and dilemmas for the player, help to support the gameplay dynamics, and serve as a vehicle for the narrative. The outcome of players' interactions with these non-player characters (NPCs) is often subject to a particular context, for instance, the physical surroundings, their previous interactions, or the character's personal drives. Additionally, besides engaging with the player, NPCs can also interact with each other, laying the foundations for the emergence of societies in games.
With the increasingly larger dimension of digital games environment, it is necessary to support the players' experience with believable characters. Still, this believability should not only rely on high-quality graphics; the living actors must exhibit intelligent behaviour, in particular, social behaviour. The player must experience in-game life-like interactions but also perceive interactions between other NPCs as believable; otherwise, the game might fall short of the player's expectations, thus compromising their immersion.
Towards dynamically creating social characters and intelligently populating them in digital worlds, it is necessary to identify prototypical roles that each individual can assume. As in real life, the situation should also prompt game characters to identify which social roles are appropriate while interacting with other NPCs or players. As such, designing characters capable of assuming a social role during an interaction with others, will contribute to the emergence of societies in games. Currently, state of the art on social characters in games is far from allowing the dynamic of social NPCs. On the one hand, there is little to no work on the representation of social roles in games. On the other hand, the advances on complex networks have not yet been explored in NPCs populations.
In this work, you will review the literature on games to get acquainted with the typical social roles assumed by characters and identify their relations, conditions and effects. After that, you will design a computational model to procedurally generate networks of social characters in games based on the previously identified social roles. Finally, this model will be implemented in a game scenario that relies on dynamically populating a virtual world with NPCs to support the gameplay experience.
requirements: Interest and competences in AI, Game Design and Research.

Since every person is different, we believe that it is possible to improve that reaction and therefore their motivation to keep playing if, when creating a tutorial level, we take into account two major factors associated to each player: game/ludic literacy and personality type. By considering their personality and their general knowledge and experience of games, we aim to create an adaptive tutorial level that is tailored for each specific player that will not only teach them the concepts and rules of the game in the best way possible, but also increases their overall enjoyment on their first moments with the game.

title: Dissertation: Haptic feedback BCI system for stroke rehabilitation
observations:
[1] T.D. Sunny et al., Robotic Arm with Brain Computer Interfacing,  Procedia Technology 24 (2016) 1089 – 1096
[2] https://lifesciences.ieee.org/lifesciences-newsletter/2014/august-2014/brain-computer-interface-for-stroke-rehabilitation/
objectives:
"Brain-computer interface (BCI) rehabilitation, combined with haptic feedback [1], show significant improvement in patient outcomes.
(…)
Although physiotherapy and occupational therapy are the most common treatments for those patients, the outcome of these treatments is limited by: (i) difficulty in improving the function of the plegic hand, (ii) difficulty in delivering intensive repetitions to patients with plegic hands for neuroplastic change and functional improvements, (iii) lack of motivation to sustain interest in the repetitive exercises, especially when patients go back home, and (iv) lack of immediate biofeedback.” [2]

The main goal of the project is mounting the skeleton of one of this systems involving a low-cost EEG acquisition system (openBCI) and the Baxter robot,  “a versatile manufacturing robot” under a motor imagery paradigm.

Intentions of movement are intersected by the OpenBCI system using  signal processing algorithms developed and  implemented in the scope of this work to control the arm of the Baxter robot. This haptic feedback is the main aided value of the rehabilitation process using this technological tool in stroke patients.

“The hypothesis of using BCI for stroke rehabilitation is built upon the following basis: (1) motor imagery activates primary motor cortex and associated brain regions which are responsible for motor planning and motor movement, therefore rehabilitation using motor imagery could lead to motor recovery; (2) BCI provides a contingent feedback for stroke patients so as to reinforce the neural pathway of motor control; (3) real-time feedback to patients provides motivation to patients; (4) mechanical/haptic stimulation (eg. robotics) combined with BCI could provide benefits as tangible feedback.” [2]

The main tasks of this project are:
1) Review of the literature
2) System implementation and mounting. Development of the basic routines and software support to operate the  OpenBCI.
3) Design of motor imagery paradigms: i) classic binary, detector for Go/NoGo tasks at right and left brain hemispheres
4) Implementation and testing of the paradigms designed in 3) using data acquired with the system implemented in 2)
5) Real Data Acquisition with volunteers to illustrate the methods implemented in 4)
6) Writing an international conference paper describing the implemented system and the results.
7) Writing the thesis

Results: An operational prototype and two papers in international conference and journal.
requirements: Solid mathematical background and programming experience in Matlab and/or Python.

title: [Dissertation] Explaining Prognostic Models of Neurodegenerative Diseases
location: INESC-ID, Alameda Campus (Rua Alves Redol, 9 - 1000-029 Lisboa)

- This thesis involves challenging aspects recognized by the scientific community; accordingly, the outcome of this work may give rise to the publication of scientific articles.
objectives:
Neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), Parkinson's Disease (PD), Alzheimer's Disease (AD), and Huntington's Disease (HD)) consist in a progressive loss of structure or function of the neurons, leading to the death of neurons. These are incurable diseases, where known treatments can only help alleviate the symptoms at early stages. However, achieving an early diagnosis and discovering disease progression patterns and rates is an important task, as it can help to guide treatments, calendar medical appointments, and aid family members in patient support.

Complex machine learning models, such as deep learning approaches, are performing well in healthcare problems. However, they are hard to understand and physicians do not rely on those models to support their decisions due to the lack of intuition and explanation of their predictions. Thus, this thesis will focus on model interpretability to provide insights into the predictions process of the models and explain why the algorithm came up with a certain prediction or suggestion.

title: [Dissertação] Robust Symbolic Execution for WebAssembly
observations: For more information about this project, please visit: https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~nsantos/msc-topics/msc-topics-WS.html. This work will be performed in collaboration with Pedro Adão.
objectives:
Symbolic execution consists of a successful program analysis technique for bug-finding and verification of multiple programming languages, ranging from statically typed languages, such as C, C++, and Java, to scripting languages, such as JavaScript, and it has been used to check different types of program properties. It has also been adopted in conjunction with static analysis to automatically generate exploits for web applications written in PHP, triggering vulnerabilities such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting. However, so far, there is no native symbolic execution engine for Wasm, making it impossible to symbolically debug Wasm code directly; one can only symbolically execute source-code programs before they get compiled to Wasm. This limitation is considerable, given that new bugs and vulnerabilities can be introduced by the compilation as well as by the interaction of the compiled Wasm program with its execution environment (i.e., browser and JavaScript engine). To fill this gap, our group has started building WASP, a WebAssembly symbolic execution engine. However, although our current prototype is able to symbolically execute Wasm programs, it has only been evaluated with simple programs, which means we do not know if the technical approach we have currently followed will perform well in real-world Wasm programs.

The goal of this thesis is to build WASP II, a robust symbolic execution engine for WebAssembly. Our approach will be to build two prototype engines (P1 and P2), exploring different approaches and then select the best performing one. For P1, we will leverage the preliminary work performed for WASP, which extended the Wasm reference interpreter with support for reasoning about symbolic values by connecting it to the Z3 SMT solver. For P2, we will use Gillian, a language-independent platform for swift development of static symbolic execution tools, and instantiate it to Wasm. We will evaluate the two prototypes on real-world Wasm applications as well as on a synthetic benchmark. Finally, guided by our applications and examples, we will extend the better-performing prototype as-needed with additional symbolic facilities. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. The resulting system will be released as an open source project. If you like programming languages and web application programming, this is the right topic for you.
requirements: Interest in programming languages and web application programming. Willingness to learn WebAssembly.

objectives:

title: [Dissertação] : Automatic Question Generation from Given Textual Sources with Deep Neural Networks
observations:
The project will be supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ), and it will be developed in the context of an ongoing research project supported by INCM and related to the area of conversational search, currently being executed at INESC-ID. 

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including a PhD student named Luís Borges that is also working on Information Retrieval projects.

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Automatic question generation aims to generate natural language questions based on given contents, where the generated questions need to be able to be answered by the contents. The motivation behind question generation is two-fold: (i) transforming customised contents into Question/Answer pairs, which can be easily used to build customized question answering or dialogue systems; (ii) generating large scale datasets of Question/Answer pairs with acceptable quality, which can either be used as additional question answering model training data, or to improve the efficiency of human annotation on question answering dataset construction ( see for example https://arxiv.org/pdf/1906.05416.pdf or https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/2020.acl-main.500.pdf ).

While there are many papers available that address the question generation task, this specific problem is still not as mainstream as Question Answering. One of the reasons is that most of the earlier papers use complicated models/processing pipelines and the authors have made no pre-trained models available. Few recent papers, specifically UniLM (https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.03197) and ProphetNet (https://arxiv.org/abs/2001.04063) have SOTA pre-trained weights available for question generation, but the usage is still somewhat complicated. 

This project will address the study and development of novel question generation approaches, through the in-domain fine-tuning of pre-trained Transformer models ( specifically seq-2-seq models such as T5 -- https://arxiv.org/pdf/1910.10683.pdf ), and specifically exploring mixed training objective that combine sentence level (e.g., through reinforcement learning) and word-level (i.e., the standard cross-entropy loss) signals, to ensure the generation of semantically and syntactically correct question text. 

Experiments will be made with large datasets such as SQuAD ( https://rajpurkar.github.io/SQuAD-explorer/ ) or MS-MARCO ( https://microsoft.github.io/msmarco/ ), measuring system performance through classic metrics such as BLEU, ROUGE or METEOR, and also through more recent proposals such as BERTscore ( https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.09675 ) or BLEURT ( https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.04696 ).

title: [Dissertation] Compositional Symbolic Execution for Typescript
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project may result in a collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
JavaScript is the de-facto language for programming client-side Web applications. It is supported by all major browsers. However, the dynamic nature of JavaScript together with its complex semantics makes understanding its code notoriously difficult, leading to a lack of adequate static analysis tools and buggy programs.

Being a dynamic language, JavaScript does not come with some of the main advantages of statically typed languages, such as informative compiling errors and automatic code completion. Hence, during the last decade, there has been a lot of research on type systems for verifying safety properties of different fragments of JavaScript. Most notably, the TypeScript programming language [1], developed at Microsoft, adds optional types to JavaScript programs and comes equipped with a type system for checking memory and type safety.

The TypeScript type system is known to be unsound [2,3]. Well-typed TypeScript programs can go wrong in multiple ways, for instance due to null-pointer exceptions and array-out-of-bounds errors. The **goal** of this project is to develop a symbolic execution engine [4] for TypeScript capable of discovering such types of errors. 

The new symbolic execution engine is to be developed on top of JaVerT [5, 6], a state-of-the-art symbolic execution tool for JavaScript. More concretely, the student will instrument the TypeScript transpiler to additionally generate a symbolic test suite [7] for the given program and then use JaVerT to run that test suite. The student will also be expected to evaluate the new analysis tool by applying it to real-world TypeScript projects obtained from GitHub. 

[1] Microsoft Corporation. TypeScript Language Specification (v1.8). 2016. 
[2] A. Rastogi et al. Safe and Efficient Gradual Typing for TypeScript. POPL’15. 
[3] G. Biermann et al. Understanding TypeScript. ECOOP’14. 
[4] E. Torlak. A Lightweight Symbolic Virtual Machine for Solver Aided Host Languages. PLDI’14. 
[5] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT: JavaScript Verification Toolchain. POPL’18. 
[6] J. Fragoso Santos et al. JaVerT 2.0: Compositional Symbolic Execution for JavaScript. POPL’19.  
[7] J. Fragoso Santos et al. Symbolic Execution for JavaScript. PPDP’18.
requirements: Strong programming skills.

title: [Dissertation] Understanding the Evolution of the Web
observations:
More information at: 
http://web.ist.utl.pt/jose.fragoso/

This project will be carried on in collaboration with the VetSpec group at Imperial College London.
objectives:
Web applications play a prominent role in the Internet of today. They run on multiple platforms and devices and are increasingly used by people in their everyday lives to accomplish all sorts of tasks, including e-mailing, word processing, online banking, among many others. 
In order to make web applications behave consistently across all platforms, the World Wide Web Consortium [1], W3C, has long been establishing web standards that precisely describe how web applications are to be loaded, executed, and displayed. Such standards are accompanied by official test suites, which browser implementations use to check their conformance with respect to each standard.
One of the most popular web standards is the Document Object Model, DOM [2]. First published in 1998, the DOM was designed to cater for the programmatic manipulation of HTML and XML documents. Since then, the standard has been steadfastly growing. Starting with DOM Core Level 1, which only describes the various DOM node types and the methods they expose, the DOM has grown to include separate specifications of several additional HTML features, such as Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) and UI Events.
In contrast to JavaScript, whose standard is fully adopted by most browser vendors, the degree of adoption of the various W3C standards is highly variable, with browsers explicitly opting not to provide support for novel standard features. For instance, Internet Explorer does not support the Shadow DOM [5], an extension of the DOM API that allows for CSS scoping and DOM encapsulation.
The **goal** of this thesis is to study the adoption of novel DOM features by web applications in the wild. More specifically, the project will consist of an empirical study [6, 7, 8] performed on Web applications that make use of the various APIs defined in the DOM Living Standard. It will comprise the following three main tasks. First, the student will develop an infrastructure to mine applications from software repositories in GitHub, identifying those that make use of any of the DOM APIs. Then, the student will implement a simple static analysis tool to automatically label each web application with respect to the DOM features that it uses. Finally, the student will classify the collected data according to the standard’s versions and potentially identify non-popular features. 

[1] W3C https://www.w3.org
[2] DOM Specification. https://dom.spec.whatwg.org.
[3] https://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-DOM-Level-1-19981001/
[4] Choudhary, Shauvik Roy, Mukul R. Prasad, and Alessandro Orso. "Crosscheck: Combining crawling and differencing to better detect cross-browser incompatibilities in web applications." 2012 IEEE Fifth International Conference on Software Testing, Verification and Validation. IEEE, 2012.
[5] Shadow DOM. https://www.w3.org/TR/shadow-dom.
[6] Kitchenham, Barbara A., et al. "Preliminary guidelines for empirical research in software engineering." IEEE Transactions on software engineering 28.8 (2002): 721-734.
[7] Shull, Forrest, Janice Singer, and Dag IK Sjøberg, eds. Guide to advanced empirical software engineering. Springer Science & Business Media, 2007.
[8] Easterbrook, Steve, et al. "Selecting empirical methods for software engineering research." Guide to advanced empirical software engineering. Springer, London, 2008. 285-311.
requirements: Strong programming skills.

title: Dissertation: Secure Chip to Cloud Authentication
observations: IST/INESC-ID and Truphone
objectives:
The problem:
Authentication and Authorisation are one of the most important security services, being central and highly challenging in IoT applications, particularly in scenarios like the ones envisioned by Truphone (https://www.truphone.com/about/), dealing with smart and secure connectivity. The Things are usually on the low end of capabilities (eg. micro controllers) and are off the shelf undifferentiated devices, so giving them identities and authentication capabilities for them to be able to connect securely to network or third party services can have dramatic impact in the unit cost. 

Context:
This thesis will deal with device authentication and user authentication services in within the context of the Truphone market, focused on developing and providing eSIM technologies certified by GSMA (SAS SM), from which excel the Remote SIM Provisioning (RSP) for consumer devices and M2M. This allows for other parties (such as IoT device manufacturers) to built-in connectivity services or to devices to connect autonomously to a network independently of where in the world they are turned on. However, there is no ready and available way for Thing makers and integrators to leverage mobile networks for authentication. 

The proposed work seeks to find practical solutions leveraging mobile network authentication, eSIM, SIM Applets and other technologies available in this space. The goal is to achieve a seamless, automatic and secure way for having off the shelf Things authenticated and authorized to use third party (Cloud) services.

Scheduling:
The first half of the work will be developed in IST/INESC-ID and the second half will be developed integrated with Truphone's R&D team. A supporting grant may be available during the second half of the work.
requirements: Full dedication to the thesis and some security back ground.

title: Dissertação: Automatic load balancing for high-performance computing
observations: Possibility of research grant.
objectives:
The EPEEC project (https://epeec-project.eu) focuses on new parallel programming platforms for high-productivity of high-performance computing applications for pre-exascale systems. Load balancing is one of the main challenges of HPC applications that aim at scaling to the extreme number of computing nodes of pre-exascale.

This thesis will focus on the problem of load balance in the context of the programming models of EPEEC. To do so, the thesis will focus a specific application: the Particle-In-Cell (PIC) method, a well studied means of investigating the behaviour of different kinds of systems involving electrons, ions, neutrals, molecules, dust particles, etc. Departing from simple baseline implementations of PIC for shared memory (using task-based programming with OmpSs) and for distributed memory (using partitioned global address spaces with GASPI), the thesis will design and evaluate effective approaches to optimize load balance.

title: Dissertação || ERA: Enterprise application Reference Architecture for the public administration
observations: Proposto  por Aluna: Maria Catarina Duarte, 87681
objectives:
Motivation: 

A explicitação de uma Arquitectura dos Sistemas de Informação (ASI) tem um papel fundamental na construção de SI que contribuam pro-activamente  para o alinhamento entre as realidades do negócio e das TI, para definir a estratégica tecnológica adequada, para um controlo e gestão mais eficaz dos SI, para assegurar SI duráveis, flexíveis e adaptáveis às necessidades do negócio, para aumentar a portabilidade das aplicações e facilidade de evolução e alinhamento das TI com as (mutáveis) estratégias de negócio.
Como refletido por [Zachman 1999] e [Boar 1999], entre outros, apesar das muitas potencialidades que advêm da especificação de uma ASI, ainda não é possível representar a arquitetura de sistemas de informação, aos diferentes níveis arquiteturais, na sua relação com o modelo de negócio de um modo normalizado, universal, simples e simultaneamente com a riqueza e rigor necessários à subsequente inspeção e/ou simulação de diferentes cenários de negócio e tecnológicos.
Em particular no contexto da Administração Pública Portuguesa, não obstante de alguns esforços particulares, verifica-se não existir um conhecimento global da arquitetura empresarial, não sendo claro quais as boas e más práticas arquiteturais, nem sendo explicita a arquitetura(s) de referencia que se pretende atingir. A figura seguinte apresenta uma descrição adhoc de alguns componentes partilhados da arquitetura empresarial da Administração Pública.
 
Algumas orientações com impacto na Arquitetura Empresarial da AP são emanadas em diferentes momentos, por diferentes organismos públicos, e em diferentes setores – como o plano global estratégico de racionalização e redução de custos com as TIC na Administração Pública (http://www.portugal.gov.pt/media/420578/pgerrtic.pdf), a Estratégia TIC 2020 (http://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/o-governo/cm/comunicados/20170302-com-cm.aspx), estratégia para as Saude  (http://spms.min-saude.pt/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/6145_Plano-estrategico-2014_2016__2.pdf), guidelines para a Administração Pública (tic.gov.pt) , entre outros. 
No entanto, a ausência de uma uniformização da descrição destas arquiteturas, torna a sua aplicação complexa e subjetiva.
requirements:
Description:Nesta investigação pretende-se, numa primeira fase, proceder ao levantamento do estado da arte em termos de arquitetura empresarial, Arquiteturas de referências, e metodologias de levantamento e definição de Arquiteturas Empresariais (Enterprise Architecture Planning de Steven Spewak, ADM de TOGAF, entre outros ). 

Neste contexto, o aluno deverá selecionar e aplicar metodologia de levantamento de arquitetura empresarial, para os componentes transversais da administração Pública, produzindo artefactos arquiteturais referentes à situação atual da AP, com enfoque principal nas camadas aplicacionais, e ainda ao nível informacional e de negócio – conforme se exemplifica na figura seguinte.

 
Após o levantamento da situação atual (AS-IS) o aluno deve proceder a uma análise de eventuais desalinhamentos na arquitetura aplicacional, face aos processos de negócio, à informação. Finalmente, o aluno deve recomendar uma evolução das aplicações existentes,incluindo a eliminação, substituição, restruturação, otimização, ou manutenção das mesmas, de forma a atingir um cenário TO-BE para a arquitetura aplicacional de referência para a administração pública.
 


Expected results:
1. Proposta de abordagem para levantamento de arquitetura empresarial da AP;
2. Levantamento de situação atual de arquitetura de negócio, informacional e aplicacional da AP (componentes partilhadas)
3. Proposta de TO-BE para arquitetura aplicacional da AP (Componentes partilhadas)
4. Análise de desalinhamentos nas diferentes camadas da arq. Empresarial da AP e proposta de abordagem para gestão do portfólio aplicacional.
5. Publicação de artigo.

title: Project: Creating abolitionist tools for marginalized communities (the new Jim code) in Portugal
objectives: By drawing on the scholarly work of Ruha Benjamin (2019), this project aims to look at the intersections of race, technology design, and urban mobility. A sociological connection between ethnic minorities and public transport is the bedrock for this study. We depart from a series of racial incidents that have marked the experience of public transport by the Afro-descendant community in Lisbon. In a news article published by the newspaper Diário de Notícias on October 28, 2017, for example, we may read testimonials from children who report how racial discrimination develops especially in the context of transportation (Câncio, 2017). To cite a more recent example, it is important to mention the case of Cláudia Simões and her daughter Vitória. Both were removed from a bus, due to the fact that they did not have a transport pass with them, free for children of Vitória’s age. The event and the police brutality to which Cláudia was subjected erupted in the Portuguese public sphere a series of public debates and protests in the streets of several Portuguese cities.
requirements: With this context in mind, we first want to qualitatively understand the mobility context of Afro-descendant children, their needs and demands. Second, we want to invite these children to be co-designers and think with us about what would be necessary to solve the problems raised by them, using participatory design as a means that can eventually generate sociotechnical and educational solutions.

title: Dissertation: Automated Analysis of Ethereum Smart Contracts
objectives:
Blockchain technology has been receiving considerable attention from industry and academia, for it promises to disrupt the digital online world by enabling a democratic, open, and scalable digital economy based on decentralized distributed consensus without the intervention of third-party trusted authorities. Smart contracts, computer programs executed on top of a blockchain, are at the core of this technology, for they allow the creation of new distributed applications. Millions of smart contracts have been deployed on Ethereum, a major blockchain platform for smart contracts, and although they are seen with great potential, smart contracts have been known to have several security problems. Recent attacks on smart contracts and critical vulnerabilities discovered show us the huge financial loss they can impose on the users and warn us for the necessity of having methods that lead to secure and reliable implementations.

Over the last few years several static analysis tools have been developed specifically targeting Ethereum smart contracts. The goal of this project is to contribute to this very exciting and emerging area by extending and improving Smartbugs (https://smartbugs.github.io), our execution framework aiming at simplifying the execution of analysis tools on datasets of smart contracts.

Envisaged contributions might include: a) the creation/integration of new analyses into Smartbugs that are able to discover new vulnerabilities; b) better integration of existing tools in Smartbugs, considering aspects such as bug prioritization.
requirements:
Interested students should:
1. Enjoy programming and learning about new programming languages and technologies
2. Be interested in software engineering and software reliability
3. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

title: [Dissertação] : Argumentation mining from textual documents combining deep learning and reasoning approaches
supervisors: Helena Sofia Andrade Nunes Pereira Pinto (50%)
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Helena Sofia Pinto ( https://www.inesc-id.pt/member/413/ ), and it will be developed in the context of the DEBAQI and DARGMINTS research projects, currently being executed at INESC-ID. 

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including a PhD student named Zuil Pirola that is also working on the DEBAQI project.

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) or Helena Sofia Pinto ( sofia@inesc-id.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
The goal of argumentation mining ( see https://doi.org/10.2200/S00883ED1V01Y201811HLT040 and https://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/full/10.1162/coli_a_00364 for surveys in the area ) is to automatically extract arguments and their relations from a given document (i.e., extracting claims and premises from natural language text, and inferring the structure that associates these elements, for instance based on support/attack relations).

Recent years have seen the development of a large number of techniques in this area, on the wake of the advancements produced by deep learning on the whole research field of natural language processing ( e.g., see recent proposals for end-to-end argumentation mining systems, such as https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/P17-1002/ or https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/W18-5202/ ).

Despite the recent progress, it is still widely recognized that existing argumentation mining systems have a large margin for improvement, as good results have been obtained with some genres where prior knowledge on the structure of the text eases some argumentation mining tasks ( e.g., see https://arxiv.org/pdf/1904.09688.pdf ), but other genres, such as legal cases and social media documents, still require additional work.

Understanding whether a given piece of evidence supports a given claim, or whether two claims attack each other, are complex problems that humans can address thanks to their ability to exploit commonsense knowledge, and to perform reasoning and inference. Despite the remarkable impact of deep neural networks in natural language processing, these techniques alone will likely not suffice to address the complex issues associated to argumentation mining, motivating the development of novel techniques that explicitly take into account knowledge expressed in the form of rules and constraints( e.g., see https://lirias.kuleuven.be/retrieve/467525 and https://arxiv.org/pdf/1905.09103.pdf ).

The MSc thesis will explore the combination of symbolic and sub-symbolic approaches for argumentation mining, specifically focusing on argument unit recognition and classification by labelling arguments on a token-level (e.g., delimiting spans of text supporting or opposing a controversial claim corresponding to the main topic of a document). State-of-the-art approaches for natural language processing ( e.g., based on models such as BERT or RoBERTa -- see https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.08271 and https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.07278 ) will be combined with symbolic approaches exploring reasoning and commonsense knowledge. Most previous neural-symbolic computing approaches explore the idea of enforcing structural constraints intrinsic to the human reasoning process, adjusting the weights of neural networks towards admissible solutions as the learning process advances ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.06088 ). Instead, this project will explore the use of reasoning and commonsense knowledge to augment the available training instances with new and challenging examples. Arguments from existing annotated datasets will be used to create argumentation knowledge graphs ( see https://webis.de/downloads/publications/papers/stein_2020g.pdf ), which will then be expanded through reasoning methods. The resulting representations will then be used to generate additional training data ( see https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/P18-1021/ and https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/W19-8607/ ).

Experiments will be performed with the AURC-8 dataset ( https://github.com/trtm/AURC ), also using the dataset from the argument reasoning comprehension task ( https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/N18-1175/ ). The tests will focus on measuring the improvements introduced by the combination of deep learning methods and reasoning approaches.

Regarding the representation of the arguments in a Knowledge Representation and Reasoning language relevant bibliography includes
https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/11431053_17
and http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.59.5571&rep=rep1&type=pdf

title: Dissertação: Interference Reduction on GNSS (GPS/GALILEO) reception (em parceria com a Deimos)

objectives:
A localização via satélite é uma tecnologia imprescindível para sistemas de navegação tripulados e autónomos, contudo existem ainda alguns desafios a resolver neste âmbito.
O foco desta tese é especificação e desenvolvimento de um sistema HW/SW em FPGA que é capaz de reduzir a interferência de sinais das bandas L1/L5 E1/E5 dos sinais GNSS (GPS/GALILEO).

title: Projeto: ExergyX 2.0 – desenvolvimento de um jogo sobre gestão energética online
supervisors: Tania Alexandra Dos Santos Costa e Sousa (50%)

objectives:
O objetivo desta tese é continuar o desenvolvimento de um jogo para ensino de gestão de sistemas energéticos. Já existe uma primeira versão do jogo que irá ser melhorada neste trabalho. 
O jogo propõe ao jogador desafios sobre potenciais cenários socioeconómicos e energéticos para Portugal para 2050 que atinjam metas ambientais impostas, nomeadamente de CO2. É um jogo de simulação, no qual os jogadores poderão definir componentes qualitativas e quantitativas, tendo por base a caracterização da atualidade e um modelo baseado em evidências encontradas sobre as relações, em Portugal, entre eficiência energética, energia útil e crescimento económico. O jogo está desenvolvido em HTML usando a ferramenta Godot.
Pretende-se adicionar mais cenários e tipos de desafios que melhorem a experiência do jogo.
A finalidade do jogo é suportar o ensino da unidade curricular de Gestão de Sistemas Energéticos e integrar um MOOC. Espera-se que seja feita uma avaliação do seu uso nesse contexto.
requirements: De preferência ter conhecimentos sobre conceitos e tecnologias de jogos e design de interação.

title: [Dissertação] Natural Language 2 SQL
observations: Filipe Assunção, fga@dei.uc.pt
objectives: The emergence of Low-Code Development Platforms (LCDP) enabled developers of various backgrounds to create applications by dragging and dropping components in a visual graphic interface. One of the key-promises of LCDP is to turn everyone in a "no-code" developer. However, much can still be done to attain that goal, smooth the learning curve, and speedup development. With these in mind, the objective of this thesis is to research for approaches to bridge the gap between natural language and low-code. Ultimately the developer shoud be able to state what the application should do, without having to implement it. A classic example is the conversion of natural language into SQL queries. This idea can be extended to all the remaining visual development components. For example, in OutSystems, the developer has to create multiple screens and define the flow between them. The goal of this thesis it to map the previous, and other routines, from natural language specification to the OutSystems language.

title: Dissertação: Reverse Algorithmic Design
supervisors: António Paulo Teles de Menezes Correia Leitão (100%)
objectives:
Algorithmic Design entails the use of algorithms to create digital representations of buildings. Reverse Algorithmic Design creates, from the digital representation of a building, the corresponding algorithm.  Using machine-learning approaches for shape recognition and meta-programming techniques for program generation, an algorithmic representation can be derived that reproduces the digital representation. This program can then be improved using refactoring operations to make it more abstract and more parametric. The resulting program can then be used not only to generate the original building design but also variations of that design, allowing its use in optimization processes.

The goal of this thesis is to research the use of machine-learning and meta-programming techniques in order to generate, from the digital representation of a design, a useful program representation of that same design.
requirements: The candidate should have excellent grades in courses involving machine learning.

title: [Dissertação] Desenvolvimento de Estratégias de HoneyPots
objectives:
Monitorizar o acesso a uma rede é uma tarefa complexa e as ferramentas de monitorização de intrusões (IDS) têm sempre um complicado balanço entre falsos positivos, que levam o utilizador a perder a confiança no sistema pelo constante aviso de ataques inexistentes, e falsos negativos, que são ataques reais que não são detectados por estas ferramentas.
O objectivo desta tese é o desenvolvimento de estratégias de honeypots que permitam a um sistema detectar que está a ser atacado diminuindo assim o seu número de falsos positivos.

Por forma a maximizar a probabilidade de encontrar uma vulnerabilidade, as ferramentas de segurança muitas vezes fazem parsing dos ficheiros Javascript de uma aplicação em busca de urls para desta forma aumentar a sua superfície de ataque. Uma possível estratégia para detectar a presença de um atacante na nossa aplicação pode passar por isso por "plantar" links falsos nesses ficheiros JS e monitorizar o acesso a esses links. O objectivo desta dissertação é por isso o desenvolvimento destas técnicas que permitam a um sistema ficar alerta para a presença de utilizadores que tentam efectuar comportamentos indevidos.
requirements: Interesse em Segurança
