title: [Dissertação] Tree of Life Reconstruction with Heterogeneous Bioinspired Computing
supervisors: Leonel Augusto Pires Seabra de Sousa (50%)
location: INESC-ID, Alameda Campus (Rua Alves Redol, 9 - 1000-029 Lisboa)
observations: This thesis will be developed in the scope of the national project entitled “High Performance and Energy-efficient Processing of Bioinformatic Applications on Emergent Heterogeneous Systems” (HiPerBio). More details at: http://sips.inesc-id.pt/~ilic/hiperbio.php.
objectives:
The reconstruction of the phylogenetic history of all species in Earth (the Tree of Life) represents one of the most outstanding problems in evolutionary biology. In the current research context, the increasing availability of DNA and protein data has encouraged bioinformaticians to undertake phylogenetic analyses with increased degrees of complexity. However, determining the most accurate phylogenetic hypotheses represents an NP-hard problem [1], as the number of possible solutions for the case of just 50 species is nearly as large as the number of atoms in the known universe. 

Recent developments on this topic have been focused on the proposal of bioinspired computing methods to tackle the problem. These approaches have shown significant accuracy and reduced execution time when conducting phylogenetic inferences in real-world scenarios, outperforming traditional heuristic-based methods [2]. These designs show inherent coarse-grained and fine-grained parallelism opportunities, representing a suitable target for acceleration on CPU+GPU systems. 

The main objective of this Thesis is to investigate and evaluate efficient heterogeneous designs of bioinspired methods for phylogenetics. The key idea lies on exploring both customized designs and libraries from the literature (e.g., BEAGLE [3]) in order to determine the most suitable approach (CPU, GPU, or CPU+GPU implementations) to accelerate the code, considering genome / protein problem instances. The prospective student will be encouraged to analyze the suitability of exploiting state-of-the-art parallel platforms and techniques for acceleration purposes, understanding in this way the advantages that imply the combination of high-performance computing and bioinspired computing in real-world scenarios.


[1] M. Steel, Phylogeny: Discrete and Random Processes in Evolution. Philadelphia: Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, 2016.

[2] S. Santander-Jiménez, M. A. Vega-Rodríguez, L. Sousa, Multiobjective Frog-Leaping Optimization for the Study of Ancestral Relationships in Protein Data. IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation, IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA, pp. 1-14, 2018. DOI: 10.1109/TEVC.2017.2774599.

[3] D. L. Ayres, et al., BEAGLE: An Application Programming Interface and High-Performance Computing Library for Statistical Phylogenetics. Systematic Biology, vol. 61, no. 1, pp. 170–173, 2012.
requirements: No prior background in bioinformatics is required. Potential candidates are strongly encouraged to arrange a short meeting to discuss the details of the proposal before applying. Simply send an email to ilic@inesc-id.pt. This dissertation should not be selected by students with other professional commitments during the execution of the work.

title: Dissertação: Large-scale Fast Fluid Simulation over Nvidia GVDB Voxels Framework
observations: Tese de Mestrado a ser atribuída ao aluno Pedro Centeno, nº 86501.
objectives:
Motivation: Liquids exhibit complex and detailed motion across a vast range of scales, from tiny ripples to huge waves; this fact motivates the desire for liquid simulation tools that can handle ever increasing levels of resolution. The Fluid Implicit Particle method (FLIP) is arguably the most widely used simulation algorithm for high-quality liquid special effects. Unfortunately, FLIP simulations can be computationally expensive, as they require a dense sampling of the ﬂuid domain with particles.

Objective: To Implement a large-scale fast fluid simulation method over a a sparse hierarchy of grids represented in NVIDIA GVDB Voxels framework. It should handle tens of millions of particles within a virtually unbounded simulation domain.

Description: The work described in [1] implemented the the fluid-implicit particle (FLIP) method over GVDB Voxels framework. This thesis should analyse the methods described in [2] and [3] and choose one of them for implementation over the Nvidia framework in order to explore the techniques introduced in [1]  for parallel sparse grid hierarchy construction and fast incremental updates on the GPU for moving particles. In addition, it should also to explore the possibility of using the sparse, work efficient parallel data gathering from particle to voxel, and a matrix-free GPU-based conjugate gradient solver optimized for sparse grids deployed in [1].

[1] -"Fast Fluid Simulations with Sparse Volumes on the GPU" - http://www.cs.utah.edu/~kwu/gvdb_sim.html
[2] - "Power Diagrams and Sparse Paged Grids for High Resolution Adaptive Liquids";
http://pages.cs.wisc.edu/~sifakis/papers/power_diagrams_2017.pdf
[3] - "Narrow Band FLIP for Liquid Simulations"; https://www.in.tum.de/fileadmin/w00bws/cg/Research/Publications/2016/NBFlip/nbflip.pdf
requirements: Gosto pelas áreas da Computação gráfica e Física.

title: Dissertação - RAVE-C Realidade Aumentada e Virtual para Engenharia Colaborativa
location: O(A) aluno(a) realizará os seus trabalhos nas instalações do INESC-ID Alameda (nas proximidades do IST) ou Tagus Park (em Oeiras), tendo acesso ao Laboratório João Lourenço Fernandes (http://lab-jlf.ist.utl.pt/). Adicionalmente, ambos os sítios tem à disposição cozinhas devidamente equipadas incluindo máquinas de café expresso.
objectives:
Em grandes projectos de engenharia, é necessário realizar conferências em que não é possível juntar todos os membros na mesma sala,
na mesma altura. Cada engenheira tem disponibilidades diferentes, e a localização geográfica de um membro determina a oportunidade da reunião efectivamente ocorrer.
Hoje em dia existem serviços online de captura e transmissão de vídeo e voz em tempo real. No entanto estes introduzem protocolos desnecessariamente complexos e menosprezados aspectos essenciais de comunicação interpessoal tão importantes no decorrer de uma reunião presencial.
Pretende-se com esta tese desenvolver um protótipo de RV em que os participantes ou os seus avatares estejam presentes num ambiente virtual partilhado com consciencia de si próprios e dos outros participantes, utilizando mecanismos de interacção proxémica.
Este projecto tem várias vertentes, entre as quais se podem destacar:
● A captura de movimentos por uma ou mais câmaras de profundidade (vulgo Kinect);
● Reconhecimento do esqueleto humano;
● Tradução em tempo real da posição de de cada avatar para o mundo físico, projectado em 2D.
Adicionalmente, impõe-se a questão da detecção das intenções de cada colaborador, determinada a partir do contexto (relações de proximidade entre avatares e pessoas no espaço virtual partilhado)

Neste projecto, devem ser consideradas as questões de eficiência de transmissão de dados, uma vez que
conferências remotas e ambientes virtuais colocam são particularmente exigentes em largura de banda.
Desta forma, um dos focos de uma aplicação distribuída, consiste no desenvolvimento de um pequeno servidor, com garantias de eficiência e tolerância a faltas.
No entanto, tendo apenas em conta o apenas o aspecto visual da colaboração, a proposta será responder
aos seguintes desafios:
Quando é que uma pessoa se quer dirigir verbalmente a outra? Quando  quer interagir fisicamente?
Qual é a expressividade que se impõe? Como mostrar mostrar algo que deva ser visível para todos os participantes?
Como detectar que um participante está a tocar / apontar para algo? 
Como juntar novos participantes a uma reunião ou  conferência detectando a sua presença,
olhar ou tom de voz?
Espera-se que a/o aluna/o investigue, desenvolva e teste um protótipo que responda a estas questões, para
contribuir com um avanço na área da realidade virtual, sem recorrer a exclusivamente a equipamento, mas incorporando os elementos virtuais no mundo físico. 
As aplicações possíveis serão inovadoras ao melhorar a socialização entre pessoas a distância simplificando as interfaces e reduzindo protocolos que tornam pouco natural a interacção interpessoal.
requirements: Sera dada preferencia a alunos que tenham gosto pela realidade virtual e desenvolvimento de aplicacoes em rede

title: Projeto: Enterprise Architecture in an Agile world
supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (100%)
objectives:
More and more organizations have Enterprise Architecture Units, with the mission to streamline IT development strategy as to ensure alignment between business and IT. The role of Enterprise Architecture is increasingly clear and understood as fundamental within organizations.
However, Enterprise Architecture approaches do not fit well to agile approaches, because the first requires too much planning and the second requires too little planning.

The goal of the thesis is to propose a method and a configuration on Atlas to support Enterprise Architecture in an organization with agile development process.
Atlas is an Enterprise Architecture tool from Link Consulting (www.linkconsulting.com),  The Atlas is a product developed in Portugal focused on representation and alignment of organizations, which already has the large customer organizations with the Petrobras, EDP, Portugal Telecom, Sonae Group, GALP,  ANACOM, Banco BPI, Fidelity Insurance, among others.

The work will occur inside the Link Consulting Enterprise Archiecture team, with projects tens of organizations, in Portugal and other countries.

title: Project: An Enterprise Architecture Solution for Infrastructure Management
supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (100%)
location: Link Consulting, Av Duque de Ávila 23, 1000 Lisboa
observations: Link provides financial support for transport and lunch fees, when a minimum presence of 3 days at Link each week.
objectives:
Today, organizations are able to have their systems on local infrastructure in data centers or in the cloud, for each of these areas there are specific problems that the management has to consider. Current management tools are specific and focus on the management of the assets on a given infrastructure, but there is no integrated management to have a complete view of what's place, in a data center or in the cloud.
So, for example, there is no support to decide if a given application running in local infrastructure could be migrated to the Cloud. Further, there is also no support for the actual migration process, namely in what concerns the dependencies that the application has with other applications. 
The Enterprise Architecture is an instrument, both in terms of processes and in terms of tools, to structure the management and integrated governance of these environments and applications. 
The goal of this thesis is to configure EAMS to support application and infrastructure management with an integrated view, regardless of underlying infrastructure is local, in datacenter or in the cloud. 
One example of innovative features of the required solution is the analysis of cost models for each environment and to examine the possibility of migration of each application between these policy infraestrutura.

title: [Dissertation] Time-offset compensation for AI-assisted fast channel change on DVB set-top-boxes
observations:
- This thesis will be realized under as agreement between IST and NOS Inovação and it will be jointly supervised by: Prof. Nuno Roma (IST), Dr. Nuno Sebastião (NOS Inovação), Prof. Tiago Dias (ISEL)
- Assignment of this thesis is subject to a prior informal interview with the candidate to assess his motivation and prior knowledge in the fields of research
- This thesis involves challenging aspects recognized by the scientific community; accordingly, the outcome of this work may give rise to the publication of scientific articles.
objectives:
Digital Video Broadcast (DVB) systems typically suffer from a high channel change (zapping) time. Nevertheless, with the recent advent of Artificial Intelligence systems, it became possible to accurately predict the channels that the user will most likely change to. 

Accordingly, locally available resources have been exploited to perform the pretuning of the predicted channels and, thus, significantly reduce the channel change time. Despite its effectiveness, such method is typically limited by the amount of available resources in the set-top-box (STB) (e.g. memory and number of tuners in the STB). To overcome such constraints, other methods have also been devised, in particular, the delivery of stream chunks, on request, via unicast on top of an IP network. 

This approach has the advantage of allowing a fast channel change to any channel that cannot be locally pretuned, although not being as effective as the other one due to the dependency on the network conditions. Moreover, it introduces an additional time-offset in the displayed stream time, because the unicast assisted stream lags behind the locally tuned stream. This additional time-offset is particularly disturbing when live events are being watched (e.g. a football match).

The goal of this work is to design a software module to compensate for the additional time-offset imposed by the unicast assisted channel change method. Such module should control the system’s playback parameters (e.g. the system’s time clock) to smoothly compensate for the playback time offset, as well as to reduce the additional buffer capacity that the unicast assisted pretune requires.

title: Projecto: Automatic Upgrades of Database-layer Releases
objectives:
This thesis will design a system that transforms a version of one database into another (for example, development to production).

Nowadays we have tools, such as Git or CVS, that allow us to change from one version of the code to another in a simple way without breaking anything or without losing information. However, the existing tools to do this type of management in the context of databases are somewhat basic.
 
Most solutions only make a blind assessment between the base version and the target version. This type of solutions covers some common aspects, but they fail to see all small transformations made in the process of transforming one version into another, which can make the difference between a real successful transformation and an apparently successful transformation.
 
The goal is to discover which are the most important transformations in a database (including the basic ones like adding/deleting a table, changing a field from int to varchar, etc.) and then create a solution that does the following:
- first, it allows devops to easily perform the needed transformations on the development database
- second, when it is time to transform the production database into the development (for example, when a new version of the system goes to production), the system has to perform all the small transformations that takes the production database to the target database
- third, in case of data destruction or some potential error (for example, because of a constraint) caused by any transformation, the system should prompt the devop what step to take next
 
An appropriate methodology to achieve these results will be designed by your advisor (taking into account the ideas of the student).

Expected Results:
- Identification of the main operations that affect schema
- Validation of a prototype

title: [Dissertação] : Deep Learning for Semantic Segmentation of Remote Sensing Imagery
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Jacinto Estima ( https://jestima.github.io ), and it will be developed in the context of the MIMU and RiverCure research projects, currently being executed at INESC-ID.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers participating in the project, including a PhD student named João Monteiro that is also working on similar topics.

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Semantic segmentation concerns predicting dense-pixel maps from original input images ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.10230 ), in which each pixel is mapped to a predefined class such as car, tree, building, etc. In remote sensing data analysis, semantic segmentation of aerial images (e.g., collected through satellites, planes or drones) is a crucial research topic with many applications in environmental and urban planning (e.g., segmentation of flooded areas for supporting emergency response, or segmenting building footprints, road-segments, bridges, and other types of man-made structures, for informing urban settlement analysis, forest management, demography studies, etc.). The main challenge in this task relates to the heterogeneous appearance and high intra-class variances of objects on very high resolution images.

Recently, deep learning methods based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have been used to tackle pixel-to-pixel prediction tasks such as the semantic segmentation of aerial images, using fully-convolutional encoder/decoder architectures (see http://segmentation-models.readthedocs.io/) and loss functions specifically designed for segmentation problems (see http://lars76.github.io/neural-networks/object-detection/losses-for-segmentation/). These models use standard convolution operations to downsample the spatial resolution of the input, developing lower-resolution feature mappings which are highly efficient at discriminating between classes, afterwards using the feature mappings in transposed convolution operations to upsample the feature representations into a full-resolution segmentation map.

Many different architectures have been proposed for semantic segmentation, including approaches exploring recent designs such as residual and/or dense connections, tailored pooling and/or attention mechanisms (see http://arxiv.org/abs/1912.10667 or http://arxiv.org/abs/2003.13328), or approaches for introducing equivariances to rotations or changes in scale (see http://arxiv.org/pdf/2002.03830.pdf or http://arxiv.org/abs/1807.11783). Although CNN-based method have achieved remarkable progress, these models face serious overfitting issues that motivate data augmentation strategies (see http://arxiv.org/pdf/1809.06839v1.pdf or ) or proper regularisation schemes. Moreover, human expertise is required for designing and optimising architectures. 

This MSc research project concerns the development and evaluation of neural networks for semantic segmentation of aerial images, leveraging the automated collection of data from services like OpenStreetMap in order to support model training, and addressing the design of novel data augmentation schemes ( e.g., adapted from https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.02781 or from techniques for examplar-based image in-painting, such as https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186/s13640-019-0471-2 ). The models that are to be developed can take inspiration on recent proposals based on neural architecture search, such as the EfficientDet model ( http://arxiv.org/abs/1911.09070 ) or evolved normalization-activation layers (http://arxiv.org/abs/2004.02967), combining these ideas with novel loss functions ( e.g., weighting contributions depending on class frequency as discussed in https://lars76.github.io/neural-networks/object-detection/losses-for-segmentation/ , based on distance maps towards object boundaries such as in https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0924271620300290 , or exploring the idea that training image patches can provide a different contribution depending on their complexity, as measured through landscape ecology indexes - see https://pylandstats.readthedocs.io/en/latest/landscape.html ).

Evaluation experiments will be conducted on standard datasets in the area ( see http://github.com/chrieke/awesome-satellite-imagery-datasets ), with a particular focus on the ISPRS semantic labelling datasets for the cities of Vaihingen and Potsdam. Given the objective of using data collected from OpenStreetMap for model training, specific tests will measure how model accuracy changes as a function of the training data (e.g., ground-truth annotations provided by human domain experts, versus annotations collected automatically from OpenStreetMap). Tests will also be performed with CNN methods for image classification (e.g., for classifying aerial images together with to the segmentation masks collected from OpenStreetMap), in an attempt to predict the consistency/quality of the segmentation maps collected automatically.

title: Dissertação || Trustable Blockchain Interoperability: Incentivizing Public Escrow Parties
observations:
Proposto  por Aluna Catarina Pedreira, 87524
Trabalho realizado com acompanhamento do Eng. Rafael Belchior
objectives:
Motivation: 
The adoption of permissioned networks has seen a significant increase in the last years, with Hyperledger technologies highlighting this adoption. For the case of permissioned blockchains, e.g., Hyperledger Fabric, smart contracts can be leveraged to a wide range of use case scenarios, where entities/organizations need to cooperate, sharing data and/or other assets. However, smart contracts (and the respective ecosystems they support) are tied to a specific blockchain implementation, and the services they can provide rely on the survivability of a particular blockchain, even in the same infrastructure. These types of problems raise the need for blockchain interoperability.
While some blockchain inteorperability solutions are appearing for private blockchains, problems arise, as they require a trusted, private third party (escrow party) to operate. This scheme does not provide the required decentralization tied to the blockchain technology, nor provides a completely trust free environment. Besides, private blockchain interoperability will be always tied to a specific pair of blockchains, not having scalability capabilities. By  enabling Public Escrow Parties, the interoperability can be trustless and scalable.
requirements:
Description:
This thesis helps defining a communication model to enable permissioned blockchain ecosystems to exchange arbitrary data. The solution should be vendor-agnostic and trustless (without a middleman). While the interoperability is a pre-requirement, there are some available solutions that can provide a basis (Hyperledger Blockchain Integration Framework/Hyperledger Quilt). The goal of the thesis, producing a producing a protocol for public escrow party, can aid in several tasks associated with blockchain interoperability, namely blockchain migrations.
Blockchain migration tools reduce the risk of vendor lock-in and the inherent risks to blockchain development, and require a third party. However, a public network could provide this function, given that it is incentivized. The protocol includes:
-How to incentivize the different parties (tokens from the private blockchains? Create an overlay network with public tokens, serving as incentives?)
-How to achieve robustness of the network by achieving equilibrium between participants (using game theory and the notions of, for example, nash equilibrium and pareto optimality)
-How to assure desirable properties such as integrity, confidentiality, and liveness of cross-blockchain transactions.

Expected results:
1.: Literature review on game theory applications to blockchain interoperability
2. Proposal of a  secure public escrow protocol for enabling permissioned blockchain interoperability.
3.	Proof of concept implementation 
4. Paper Publication

title: (DISSERTATION) Optimization of Data Cleaning Programs
observations: O aluno João Caetano, MEIC, demonstrou interesse nesta tese.
objectives:
Data cleaning is recognized as a central feature of data analysis and management tools. Data cleaning aims at converting source data into target data without errors, missing values, duplicates and inconsistencies. A data cleaning program is typically modeled as: (i) a graph of data transformations or through (ii) a set of data quality rules [1]. In (i), data transformations are implemented by data cleaning operators whose execution clean data. In (ii), data quality rules express conditions that data must satisfy to be considered of good quality or else a violation occurs and a data repair that corrects the data must be found. Data repairs are typically selected from the set of possible data repairs using heuristics.
None of these two approaches was primarily developed to handle large amounts of data coming from heterogeneous sources, i.e., forming the so-called Big Data [2]. Only recently, works were proposed to deal with data cleaning for Big Data. Nevertheless, they only focus on specific data cleaning tasks. The authors of [3], [4], [5] and [6] focus on data deduplication for Big Data sets by leveraging state-of-the-art techniques for deduplication into the MapReduce paradigm [7]. BigDansing [8], a data cleaning framework for Big Data based on the NADEEF framework [9], offers a formalism to specify quality rules in a distributed environment. Recently, [10] proposed an approach to optimize data cleaning programs based on a declarative approach.

Objectives: The goal of this work is to improve a first version of a data cleaning optimizer to integrate in a data cleaning prototype called Cleenex [11]. This optimizer includes a cost model that is able to find the best executable data cleaning flow graph, i.e., the one that leads to an efficient data cleaning process. This cost model takes into account that a logical data cleaning operator can be executed by different algorithms and some of these algorithms are executed in a distributed environment. This thesis will focus on the incorporation of the cost external user defined functions, possibly invoked within each  Cleenex operator, in the optimizer cost model. 

Results expected: A prototype of the CLENNEX optimizer where the cost model takes into account the estimated cost of user defined functions and a published paper describing the optimizer.

title: DISSERTAÇÂO: Diagnóstico do cancro de mama usando redes neuronais profundas
supervisors: Jacinto Carlos Marques Peixoto do Nascimento (50%)
location: Instituto de Sistemas e Robótica - Torre Norte
objectives:
Nesta tese propõe-se realizar o estudo em análise de imagem para diagnóstico do cancro mama. Este problema vai ser abordado usando metodologias em deep learning. Especificamente, vai-se usar uma arquitectura recente - a Hyper Dense Net.
O trabalho consiste em realizar a classificação de severidade da lesão da mama. Para isso são usadas imagens de mamografia e de ultrasom. Num primeiro estágio, usam-se somente imagens de mamografia ou imagens de ultrasom, verificando da performance da rede na classificação nestas modalidades em separado. Num segundo estágio, faz-se a extensão para o uso das duas modalidades em simultâneo, para saber se há uma modalidade que é mais predominante que a outra.
Dado que a arquitectura da Hyper Dense Net, é bastante rica há diversos modos de combinar como os dados de input vão ser dados à rede. Especificamente, vão estudar-se os seguintes mecanismo de integração  dos dados:
- Usar dois canais separados na rede. Aqui usa-se uma modalidade de imagem (Ultrasom ou mamografia) por cada canal da rede
- Usar somente um canal, onde os dados de entrada são concatenados logo à entrada (1ª camada) da rede
- Usar um  outro mecanismo que corresponde a uma solução que é intermédia das duas anteriores. Especificamente, usa-se inicialmente os dois canais, realizando-se posteriormente a fusão (ou concatenação) dos dois canais. Aqui o desafio é descobrir qual a melhor camada para realizar a fusão dos dados.

Já existe código (Pytorch) disponível que pode ser usado como ponto de partida para este trabalho
requirements: Deseja-se que o aluno tenha conhecimentos, ou que queira aprender  linguagem de programação PYtorch.

title: Dissertação: FairScheduling@GraalVM
observations: Survey the state-of-the-art of the related work. Design and development of a prototype. Testing and performance evaluation. Writing of a technical paper (10 pages) that frames and presents the work carried out, and describes the results achieved.
objectives:
GraalVM is a novel Java VM implementation designed to achieve better performance (throughput and start-up latency) that can also be used to support applications that mix application code written in different programming languages.

Language runtimes are becoming more and more virtualized and works such as Photons already propose to share the runtime across multiple independent requests of Serverless functions. Runtimes, however, do not support fair resource utilization, something that today is provided by container or system VM technology.

The goal of this work is to implement fair resource scheduling in GraalVM with memory and CPU thread throttling for GraalVM Native Image, with different resource partitioning strategies, and assess performance overheads associated with enforcing each fair resource partitioning strategy using realistic workloads.

title: Dissertation - Runtime reconfiguration of a micro-service replica consistency framework
observations: A tese será co-orientada pelo Eng. João Loff do Grupo de Sistemas Distribuídos do INESC ID Lisboa.
objectives:
Distributed transactional systems provide transactional guarantees to applications.
Existing research has explored and classified the variations in transactional models and the guarantees they provide. These analysis have broken down the details of transaction initiation, execution, validation and confirmation, and the variations that different transactional models take in those steps.

The goal of this dissertation is to develop a programming framework that implements some existing transactional models using a modular approach with standard combinable interfaces. This should allow system architects to use existing components and explore how varied transactional guarantees can be constructed using these standard building blocks.
This work builds on previous experience in creating a similar framework for consistency models in replicated services.

title: Dissertation: Speaker diarization
objectives:
The objective of this thesis is to explore the state-of-the-art in speaker diarization, the problem of determining “who spoke when” in a speech recording. Speech diarization has many applications: it can be used to contextualise transcriptions, improve the results of Automatic Speech Recognition systems, and allow users to search and filter speech segments that correspond to a specific speaker.  In particular, in clinical interviews, having a (two-)Speaker Diarization system able to distinguish between the patient and the physician would facilitate data collection and serve as a pre-processing stage for other speech processing algorithms that aid medical diagnosis.
This thesis has two parts: the development of a generic diarization system, using techniques from speech processing and machine learning, and its adaptation in particular to clinical interviews, where the system will be deployed.

title: Dissertação: Análise de estruturas em ambientes imersivos
objectives:

A avaliação da segurança de estruturas é tradicionalmente feita recorrendo a aplicações do tipo desktop especializadas. No entanto, as tecnologias de realidade virtual podem trazer novas possibilidades. As suas capacidades imersivas aliadas ao uso de elementos gráficos ricos e relevantes podem representar vantagens tangíveis.

Objetivos: Neste trabalho de mestrado propõe-se o desenvolvimento da componente gráfica de uma ferramenta de análise de estruturas que tire partido de ambientes imersivos. Pretende-se analisar as vantagens e limitações e contribuir para uma melhor compreensão das particularidades da aplicação de óculos de realidade virtual neste domínio.

title: [Dissertação] Browser Security
objectives:
XS-Search e XSLeaks são duas vulnerabilidades recentes que consistem em explorar fragilidades da construção da Internet por forma a obter informação privada acerca dos utilizadores. Um caso conhecido é a medição do tempo que uma página/imagem demora a carregar num browser para assim inferir se essa imagem já foi previamente acedida pelo utilizador ou não.

Estas vulnerabilidades resultam de um misto de fragilidades das políticas de segurança mas também de mecanismos internos dos browsers.
O objectivo desta dissertação é estudar os mecanismos de funcionamento dos browsers actuais, as suas especificações e características de sandboxing, e identificar padrões de ataque que poderão violar estas condições de isolamento, bem como medidas que atenuem o seu impacto. Estaremos particularmente interessados em casos de leaks de informação.

title: Dissertação: SmartPubSub@IPFS
observations: Survey the state-of-the-art of the related work. Design and development of a prototype. Testing and performance evaluation. Writing of a technical paper (10 pages) that frames and presents the work carried out, and describes the results achieved.
objectives:
The InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) is a hypermedia distribution protocol, addressed by content and identities. IPFS enables the creation of completely distributed applications. One of the most efficient and effective ways to distribute information is through the use of notifications or other methods which involve a producer of content (publisher) that shares content with other interested parts (subscribers). 

Currently IPFS has a simple working implementation of a pub/sub system under an experimental flag. This implementation relies on a simple network flood and as such is quite inefficient and costly. The goal for this work is to develop a content-based pub/sub system (with subscriptions based on predicates about event content) to disseminate information on top of IPFS, in an efficient and decentralized way, exploring multi-DHT routing and optimizations to the bitswap protocol.

title: [DISSERTAÇÃO] Traffic light control using deep multiagent reinforcement learning
observations:
- Description - 

In this work, the student will investigate the use of deep reinforcement learning (RL) for traffic light control optimization. Several works have addressed traffic light control using RL [4]. It is possible to classify state-of-the-art RL approaches as falling in one of two categories:

• Distributed RL approaches that take advantage of rich multi-agent models of traffic and learn distributed policies for traffic flow optimization that are able to incorporate rich traffic patterns, including disruptive events, pedestrians and vehicles [1].

• Single-agent deep RL approaches that take advantage of the ability of deep learning architectures (namely convolutional networks) to extract high-level information from complex input data and has focused mostly on learning reactive policies to the traffic conditions [2].

This work seeks to combine the best of both categories above. During the work the student is expected to train a network of RL agents [1] building on state-of-the-art RL agent architectures [2, 3]. In particular, the student is expected to investigate multiagent RL in the context of traffic light control.

The work will rely on publicly available traffic simulators – namely SUMO (sumo.dlr.de) – and, if available, traffic information from Lisbon Municipality.

- References -

[1] M. Aslani, M. Mesgari, M. Wiering. “Adaptive traffic signal control with actor-critic methods in a real-world traffic network with different traffic disruption events.” Transportation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies, 85:732–752, 2017.

[2] N. Casas. “Deep deterministic policy gradient for urban traffic light control.” CoRR, abs/1703.09035, 2017.

[3] W. Genders, S. Razavi. “Using a deep reinforcement learning agent for traffic signal control.” CoRR, abs/1611.01142, 2016.

[4] M. Wiering, J. van Veenen, J. Vreeken, A. Koopman. “Intelligent traffic light control.” Technical Report UU-CS-2004-029, University Utrecht, 2004a.
objectives:
• Survey the state-of-the-art in optimization of traffic light control and multiagent reinforcement learning;

• Develop an RL agent ecosystem for traffic light control at city level.
requirements: The student should be comfortable with reinforcement learning and multiagent system basics, as provided in courses such as PADI and AASMA.

title: Dissertação - High Growth - Using Computational Intelligence to Invest in Medium Companies
[Dissertação] Evolução e auto-organização da cooperação
observations:
Para mais informações p.f. contactar os orientadores desta proposta de tese:

Francisco C. Santos (INESC-ID & DEI/IST, Universidade de Lisboa)
email: franciscocsantos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
web: http://web.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/franciscocsantos/
objectives:
A formalização dos mecanismos que explicam e fomentam a evolução da cooperação continua a constituir um enorme desafio. Por ser aparentemente paradoxal e contrária ao princípio da racionalidade (que prevê a maximização dos ganhos individuais), a cooperação continua a ser um fenómeno de enorme interesse científico partilhado por variadíssimas áreas do saber, das duras às ciências biológicas e às sociais. 

Usando princípios de teoria de jogos, dinâmicas evolutivas e simulação de sistemas complexos, esta proposta sugere investigar mecanismos que expliquem como sociedades de indivíduos se auto-organizam, conseguindo dessa forma resolver conflitos sociais através da cooperação. Em particular, a tese deverá focar aspectos relacionados com mecanismos de reciprocidade e/ou investigação de comportamentos cooperativos em redes complexas.  Os modelos a desenvolver focarão a análise processos dinâmicos co-evolutivos. 

No final desta tese é esperado que o/a candidato/a seja capaz de:
i) recorrer às ferramentas de teoria de jogos e dinâmicas de populações para descrever processos evolutivos de auto-organização.
ii) criar e analisar modelos que possibilitem compreender e isolar efeitos de alguns mecanismos de auto-organização responsáveis pela evolução da cooperação observada na natureza.

Resultado esperado: 
Desenvolvimento e análise de resultados de um (ou mais) modelos teóricos. Divulgação dos resultados obtidos.
requirements: A natureza do projecto requer um gosto particular por parte do candidato por áreas de investigação interdisciplinar, permitindo também que alunos das mais diversas áreas de formação se possam candidatar.

title: Dissertation: General Purpose Service Robot
location: ISR/IST’s Intelligent Robots and Systems group (http://welcome.isr.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/labs/irsgroup/) - Torre Norte
observations: The MSc thesis will develop within the framework of the SocRob@Home project and team (http://socrob.isr.ist.utl.pt/dokuwiki/doku.php?id=socrobhome:socrobhome), under which ISR/IST participates regularly in international robot competitions, such as RoboCup@Home (http://www.robocupathome.org) and European Robotics League Consumer Robots (https://eu-robotics.net/robotics_league/erl-consumer/about/index.html).
objectives:
This thesis has the goal of integrating several subsystems of a domestic service robot so as to make it ready to address speech requests representing tasks, e.g. “Go to the kitchen and find the soda can”, or task sequences, e.g., “Go to the kitchen and find the soda can; pick the can; bring it back” to be executed, and actually carry them out. While most involved subsystems are currently available (such as navigation, object recognition, object grasping, speech understanding), and the pipeline speech-to-text  text-to-goals  goals-to-task plan is set up, they lack a tool enabling the robust integration of all the subsystems, adapting to different task domains (implying different types of commands and sentences), and recruiting the subsystems required to execute each produced plan.

The goal of this thesis is to develop a software development system to integrate all the above components for different task domains, and recruit the necessary service robot subsystems, in a general purpose service robot (GPSR, as it is known in RoboCup@Home, where it was first introduced).
requirements: Proficiency in the C++ and/or Python programming language is required.Experience in the Robot Operation System (ROS) framework is expected.

title: [Dissertação] Symbolic Runtime Modeling for Automatic Exploit Generation
observations: For more information about this project, please visit: https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~nsantos/msc-topics/msc-topics-WS.html. This work will be performed in collaboration with Nuno Santos.
objectives:
Automatic exploit generation is a very effective technique for assessing the security impact of existing code vulnerabilities. In general, an exploit consists of a sequence of crafted inputs that can direct an application's execution to a vulnerable sink and deviate its normal execution flow in order to achieve some attacker-defined goal. Exploits unambiguously demonstrate that a given vulnerability is security critical, hence its fixing must be prioritized. To automatically generate exploits, symbolic execution has been proven to yield very good results. In particular, it can be used for symbolic taint tracking of programs. This technique allows us to identify attacks that take advantage of illegal information flows. Exploits can then be synthesized based on path selection heuristics which guide the program's symbolic execution according to specific exploitability goals. However, a particular challenge that occurs in this process is when a symbolic program hits a runtime API call, e.g., Libc functions in C/C++ programs, or JavaScript calls in WebAssembly code. In these cases, since we do not have access to the source code of the runtime environment (library or operating system code), it is no longer possible to carry out with the symbolic execution of the program. This limitation prevents the generation of exploits that take advantage of specific runtime API calls, e.g., format string attacks, which depend on printf.

The goal of this thesis is to develop a language-independent platform for development of runtime-dependent exploit generators. Essentially, this platform will provide symbolic models of runtime API calls named "summaries". Summaries will specify exploitability properties of all functions of the runtime API such that they can be used by symbolic execution engines for the purpose of automatic exploit generation. Using the libc as our case study, these summaries will be developed by analyzing each of the libc's functions and expressing them symbolically. They will then be tested with an existing exploit generation tool for C/C++ programs developed by our team. This work will investigate a way for specifying summaries that can be adopted for different runtime environments and programming languages (e.g., for modeling the JavaScript runtime API for WebAssembly code). This work will begin with the analysis of simpler libc functions, and progressively increase the number and complexity of analyzed functions. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. The resulting system will be released as an open source project. If you like programming languages, and software security, this is the right topic for you.
requirements: Interest in programing languages and software security.

title: [Dissertação] Routing Infrastructure for Censorship-Resistant Overlay Networks
observations: For more information about this project, please visit: https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~nsantos/msc-topics/msc-topics-CA.html. This work will be performed in collaboration with Diogo Barradas, a PhD student with expertise in traffic analysis, censorship resistance systems, and machine learning.
objectives:
Many states all over the world implement censorship mechanisms that prevent free access to information through the outright impairment or blockage of Internet communications. In our research team, we have built a tool, named Protozoa, which allows Internet users located in censored regions to piggyback on WebRTC-enabled streaming applications, such as Whereby.com, in order to establish covert tunnels that can circumvent said mechanisms. A user only needs to make a video call with a friend located in the free Internet region. That friend runs a proxy service that will allow all Internet traffic generated by Alice to securely and secretly cross the boundaries of the censored region and reach blocked services such as Youtube or Twitter. Based on this point-to-point hidden communication capability, our next step is to build CRON, a Censorship-Resistant Overlay Network that will allow those users that do not have direct contacts with trusted peers to access the free Internet region in a mediated fashion, i.e., by leveraging a friend of a friend as a proxy.

Specifically, the goal of this thesis is to design and implement the routing infrastructure that will be necessary to sustain the communications between clients and proxies by stitching up several Protozoa channels along the way. The resulting multi-hop channel will constitute a covert circuit. This thesis will be concerned about addressing all the necessary issues involving the establishment and maintenance of covert circuits, namely: i) architecting an addressing scheme for identifying the nodes in the overlay network, ii) discovering available proxies in the free region, iii) identifying and managing routes between clients and proxies, iv) fashioning covert circuits based on multiple single-hop Protozoa channels, and v) handling churn, faults, and load balancing issues. This system will be built on top of the Protozoa prototype currently available in our team. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. The resulting system will be released as an open source project. If you like building distributed systems, this is the right topic for you.
requirements: Interest in security and distributed systems. Proficiency in C/C++ programming. Willingness to learn the Rust programming language. (CRON will most probably be implemented in Rust.)

title: Dissertação: Exploring the Potential of Aural and Haptic Feedback in a Virtual Reality Dental Drilling Simulator
location: O(A) aluno(a) realizará os seus trabalhos nas instalações do INESC-ID Lisboa no campus Taguspark (em Oeiras) bem como no Instituto Universitário Egas Moniz (no Monte da Caparica).
observations:
Sempre que requisitados, membros da equipa providenciarão formação para que o aluno trabalhe com o software e hardware de forma eficaz e eficiente. 

Co-orientador externo: Dr. Pedro Rodrigues, pmsilvarodrigues@egasmoniz.edu.pt
objectives:
Historicamente, o ensino em Medicina Dentária, mais especificamente em Dentisteria
Operatória em Implantologia Dentária, assenta na simulação dos protocolos em modelos.
Inicialmente restrita a modelos humanos e cadavéricos, a necessidade da repetição conduziu à
emergência de modelos que permitissem repetições, sendo que os fantomas (modelos de
plástico) tenham sido a pedra basilar da formação. Contudo, as limitações dos modelos de
plástico (não permitirem a sensibilidade táctil dos tecidos humanos), dos modelos animais (cuja
anatomia difere da humana) e dos modelos cadavéricos (com crescente escassez de recursos e
com as questões éticas associadas), associadas à subjectividade da avaliação e à necessidade de
inovação, levaram ao aparecimento da simulação virtual. Têm sido apontadas várias vantagens
à utilização dos simuladores de realidade virtual, nomeadamente o aumento do número de
horas de treino, o que coloca o aluno numa fase mais avançada da curva de crescimento, o que
ameniza a transição do ensino pré-clínico para a realidade da vida clínica. Os simuladores
disponíveis m Medicina Dentária exigem maior imersão do utilizador, modelos mais reais e a
simulação de situações de urgência.
O aumento do realismo da simulação deverá incluir um campo operatório virtual do
paciente, bem como a estimulação multimodal sensorial do próprio acto, usando um modelo já
existente que inclui a tecnologia da caneta háptica e óculos de realidade virtual. Além da
sensibilidade háptica de profundidade, a noção visual de profundidade da execução de
cavidades dentárias e ósseas poderá ser dotada de maior realismo com a introdução de
resposta áudio em resposta a padrões de força que traduzem progressão em profundidade dos
tecidos (o que, por seu turno, indica maior proximidade a estruturas nobres e aumenta a
percepção do risco de iatrogenia por parte do utilizador). Recorrendo a estímulos auditivos,
tradutores da penetração em camadas mais profundas (e com diferentes graus de
mineralização), a simulação torna-se mais real. A percepção visual e auditiva da profundidade,
ao expor o aluno a situações de maio risco, permitirá, também, estudar as suas respostas
fisiológicas (como tensão arterial e batimentos cardíacos) em situações de stress clínico
simulado.

O candidato deverá explorar o potencial do simulador existente, introduzir alterações
no mesmo de forma a aproximá-lo de uma simulação mais real, sendo esta nova versão testada
por estudantes de medicina dentária e profissionais do Centro de Investigação Interdisciplinar
Egas Moniz.
As tarefas a desenvolver são:

Tarefa 1 – Revisão da literatura;
Tarefa 2 – Domínio da ferramenta Unity 3D do ponto de vista do utilizador;
Tarefa 3 – Domínio da ferramenta Unity 3D do ponto de vista do developer;
Tarefa 4 – Reconstrução 3D dos modelos ósseos a partir de imagens médicas;
Tarefa 5 – Design de técnicas interacção para a manipulação háptica dos objectos broca e
modelo 3D ósseo;
Tarefa 6 – Design da interface gráfica;
Tarefa 7 – Desenvolvimento do protótipo funcional para treino de restauro de cáries;
Tarefa 8 – Desenvolvimento do protótipo funcional para treino de colocação de implantes;
Tarefa 9 – Testes de usabilidade e avaliação com utilizadores (profissionais e estudantes de
medicina dentária);
Tarefa 10 – Escrita da tese.

Para além da dissertação e apresentação pública, espera-se que o(a) aluno(a) desenvolva
trabalhos de interesse para a comunidade científica levando à submissão de pelo menos 1
artigo em conferência ou jornal internacional.
requirements: É mandatório que o/a candidato/a tenha conhecimentos avançados em programação orientada a objectos. Valorizam-se conhecimentos em Unity 3D, C# e Three.js.

title: [Dissertation] Automatic detection of forest fires: a deep learning approach
observations:
- Assignment of this thesis is subject to a prior informal interview with the candidate to assess his motivation and prior knowledge in the fields of research
- This thesis involves challenging aspects recognized by the scientific community; accordingly, the outcome of this work may give rise to the publication of scientific articles.
objectives:
The proliferation of forest fires in many countries, including Portugal, causes multiple economic and social damages. It leads to the destruction of industrial, commercial and agricultural activities, with a strong impact in employment; on the emission of carbon dioxide leading to a strong environmental impact, and also affects the flora and the wildlife of the affected zones.

For early detection of forest fires, INOV has developed the CICLOPE system which relies on surveillance cameras in the visible spectrum and simple machine learning techniques to automatically detect forest fires. However, the current system has a high rate of false alarms and needs substantial improvement. 

The objective of this thesis is thus to contribute to the development of more accurate machine learning algorithms, by taking advantage of current advances in deep learning.
requirements:
- Knowledge of C programming language- Minimum average grade: >14 in 1st cycle and >15 in 2nd cycle
- Mandatory IPEEC enrolment, except for students with average grade >15
- Personal interview, before thesis application

title: Project: Web App for Covid-19 mobility trends
location: This project will be conducted in ITI / LARSyS at IST under the context of a funded research project.
observations: Students will be able to apply for research scholarships under the context of this project.
objectives: With the Covid-19 pandemic, there is an increased demand for providing citizens with information regarding the occupancy of public spaces. Under the context of an FCT funded research project we have developed a WiFi-based infrastructure that provides real-time information about the presence of people in public places (https://mare.iti.arditi.pt). This infrastructure was developed under the context of a research project in Madeira Islands but we are planning to extend to other areas. This project involves prototyping and developing a mobile app which takes the information from the public infrastructure and then presents it to the citizens also detecting the trends and preferences of their mobility.
requirements: Interest for mobile App development including technologies like Flutter, Material Design, and integration with web services. There is an opportunity to develop smart services based on the big data.

title: Dissertation: Mobile Word Completion Interfaces for Blind People
observations: This work will be conducted in a collaboration with Raquel and Martin Sain Foundation.
objectives:
In recent years, mobile text-entry has experienced numerous innovations leading to greater input speeds and lower error rates. One such leap was word completion, which is familiar to anyone using a modern smartphone. During the typing process the device will suggest the most probable word, allowing users to correct misspelled words or complete them without having to type the remaining characters. Word completion and auto-correct can be beneficial for most users, however the greatest gains are seen by users with slower text-entry rates, such as blind people, whom may struggle to make key selections.

While much work has been published on nonvisual mobile text input in recent years [1-4], there is still a lack of support for nonvisual suggestion selection on these devices, limiting the success of word completion solutions. Where a sighted person is able to quickly scan the entire display for input feedback, content changes, error notifications or auto-complete suggestions; a blind user receives only feedback for a single element at a given time.

In this dissertation, you will: 1) understand the fundamental challenges of nonvisual mobile word completion, 2) design and develop alternative nonvisual word completion interfaces based on [5] (NOT the underlying algorithms), and 3) evaluate the proposed solutions.

In addition to you master thesis, we will advance the state of the art in the field of mobile accessibility and submit a paper to an international conference or journal.

You can check our previous research related to nonvisual mobile text input: http://web.ist.utl.pt/hugo.nicolau/project/textentry.html, http://web.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/hugo.nicolau/project/wordcompletion.html

[1] Hugo Nicolau, Kyle Montague, Tiago Guerreiro, André Rodrigues, and Vicki L. Hanson. 2015. Typing Performance of Blind Users: An Analysis of Touch Behaviors, Learning Effect, and In-Situ Usage. In Proceedings of the 17th International ACM SIGACCESS Conference on Computers & Accessibility (ASSETS '15). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 273-280. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/2700648.2809861

[2] João Guerreiro, André Rodrigues, Kyle Montague, Tiago Guerreiro, Hugo Nicolau, and Daniel Gonçalves. 2015. TabLETS Get Physical: Non-Visual Text Entry on Tablet Devices. In Proceedings of the 33rd Annual ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI '15). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 39-42. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/2702123.2702373

[3] Daniel Trindade, André Rodrigues, Tiago Guerreiro, and Hugo Nicolau. 2018. Hybrid-Brailler: Combining Physical and Gestural Interaction for Mobile Braille Input and Editing. In Proceedings of the 2018 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI '18). ACM, New York, NY, USA, Paper 27, 12 pages. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/3173574.3173601

[4] Hugo Nicolau, André Rodrigues, André Santos, Tiago Guerreiro, Kyle Montague, and João Guerreiro. 2019. The Design Space of Nonvisual Word Completion. In The 21st International ACM SIGACCESS Conference on Computers and Accessibility (ASSETS '19). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 249-261. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/3308561.3353786
requirements: Preference for students with experience in Android development and good social interaction skills.

title: [Dissertação] Automatic Chart Interpretation
objectives:
Charts are one of the most popular procedures to present information to an audience.
However, there is a limited number of tools that are able to extract information from charts.
One of these tools is webplotdigitizer (https://automeris.io/WebPlotDigitizer/), but this
task requires calibration and several inputs from the user. Hence, these tools are not suited
to be integrated in automatic systems that require chart interpretation.

In this thesis, the goal is to automatically extract a tabular representation from the chart using machine 
learning methods (e.g. neural networks) and integrate this procedure in a system that automatically 
synthesizes database queries from charts.
requirements: Knowledge of machine learning algorithms is required.

title: Dissertação: qDocs/SmartContracts – Processos Seguros e Centrados no Cidadão com base em Tecnologia BlockChain e Automação de Documentos
observations:
Orientador: Prof. Alberto Rodrigues da Silva
Co-orientador: Dr. João Saraiva (mdss lda.), joao.saraiva@mdss.pt
objectives:
O qDocs é uma plataforma centrada no Cidadão de automação de documentos geridos de forma distribuída, dinâmica e segura. O qDocs permite a definição e utilização de templates de documentos electrónicos (e.g., documentos de identificação, certificados, relatórios, formulários, questionários) com base na orquestração de serviços e de dados mantidos por diferentes Curadores (i.e., entidades públicas e privadas), e geridos de forma distribuída, dinâmica e segura. O qDocs é também uma plataforma colaborativa que promove e facilita a relação entre o Cidadão e os Curadores em todos os processos que envolvam a solicitação, publicação, acesso, apresentação ou partilha de documentos electrónicos. (Consultar https://qdocs.eu/ para mais informações.)
A tecnologia de contratos inteligentes (smart contracts), baseada em Blockchain, e inicialmente aplicada no domínio das criptomoedas, pretende facilitar e reforçar a negociação ou desempenho de contratos, proporcionando confiabilidade em transações online entre os intervenientes envolvidos (ver e.g. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_contract). Exemplos deste tipo de tecnologias populares são Bitcoin, Ethereum, ou DAML.

Pretende-se com este projeto que o aluno possa desenvolver investigação nas áreas de “document automation systems”, “smart contracts”, e “legal tech”. Nomeadamente, que possa investigar a aplicação e integração da tecnologia de Smart Contract com a plataforma qDocs. Por exemplo, que o registo de operações críticas realizadas pelos cidadãos na plataforma qDocs (e.g., criação de documento, partilha de documento, acesso ao documento, assinatura de documento) possa ser mantido de forma segura e imutável sobre uma plataforma de Smart Contract, com todas as propriedades de segurança inerentes.
Esta investigação deverá ser validada no domínio legal, nomeadamente com entidades que possam prestar serviços de elaboração e assinatura de contratos e de outros documentos com força jurídica (e.g., minutas, contratos comerciais, contratos de trabalho) e também garantir outros requisitos, tais como o reconhecimento e autenticação de assinaturas das partes. 


Este projeto deverá desenvolver-se ao longo de três fases principais:
A primeira fase consiste na aprendizagem e exploração das tecnologias de smart contract e de document automation, e na seleção da tecnologia de smart contract a adotar. 
A segunda fase consiste no desenho e prototipagem da solução qDocs/SmartContracts, que deverá consistir na definição e implementação de transações que devem ser seguras e imutáveis, e suporte à análise e visualização dessa informação.
A terceira fase consiste na definição de um caso de teste (a definir, num contexto controlado) sobre a solução qDocs/SmartContracts, na divulgação, avaliação e discussão dos resultados.

title: [Dissertation] The Feasibility of a Remote VR User Study
observations: Tese a ser co-orientada pelo Prof. Adalberto Simeone da KU Leuven: https://www.adalsimeone.me/
objectives:
Remote testing methods have a long history of use in usability evaluation. For example, to assess the usability of a website. Compared with laboratory studies, remote testing has several advantages, such as low cost, no location restrictions. In the Spring of 2020, most people need to work from home because of COVID-19. Studies that need to take place in the lab, such as user studies that make use of VR headsets, need to be postponed. Remote (or distributed) user studies represent a potential alternative. However, there are several challenges that still need to be addressed, for example:

- How to efficiently design and implement a remote VR unmoderated usability testing and a remote moderated usability testing?
- Are results obtained from remote VR user studies valid, when compared to laboratory VR user studies?

This thesis aims to investigate the feasibility of remote user studies in evaluating a novel interaction technology in VR.
requirements:
1. Strong programming skills in Java, C#, etc.2. Interest or experience in Unity
3. Basic understanding of usability studies

title: [Dissertation] IncidentalVis
objectives:
Com tanta informação à nossa volta, torna-se impossível geri-la de  forma eficaz durante o quotidiano. Atualmente, somos nós que temos de 
investir tempo em sistemas de exploração de dados, caso queiramos obter  conhecimento útil dessa mesma informação. Sendo assim, para evitar 
termos de interromper as nossas tarefas diárias, o futuro passa pela  criação de visualizações que se adaptem ao nosso meio ambiente, para 
transmitirem informação de relance e de forma pouco intrusiva.  Imagine-se, por exemplo, um cenário onde saímos de uma divisão da nossa 
casa que tem a luz acessa, e assim que direcionamos o nosso olhar para o  interruptor (para desligar a luz), aparece incidentalmente uma 
visualização que nos transmite o consumo dessa divisão em comparação com  o resto da casa. Este é um cenário onde existem visualizações que nos 
transmitem informação de relance, contextualizada com o que fazemos e de  forma o menos intrusiva possível, dando uma perceção aumentada do mundo 
que nos rodeia e sem dele perdermos o foco. 

O objetivo deste trabalho é explorar de que forma estas visualizações  incidentais podem ser aplicadas no terreno. É necessário perceber-se que 
tecnologias as poderão suportar (por exemplo com recurso a Realidade Aumentada), como introduzi-las no meio ambiente das  pessoas, e de que maneira podem estar contextualizadas com o que elas 
fazem no momento em que é transmitida informação.

Desta tese resultarão um protótipo e um estudo empírico com utilizadores para se  testarem diferentes abordagens, podendo daí resultar boas práticas para a criação de visualizações incidentais 
neste paradigma de informação obtida de relance e em simultâneo com  tarefas primárias.
requirements: Frequência de Visualização de Informação não obrigatória mas preferencial.

title: [Dissertação] : Key-phrase Extraction Combining Graph-Based Methods and Neural Language Models
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Mathieu Roche ( http://textmining.biz/Staff/Roche/MR/ ), and it will be developed in the context of the DEBAQI and MOOD research projects, currently being executed at INESC-ID. The MOOD project involves a cooperation with researchers from France's National Research Institute for Agriculture, Food and Environment, i.e. the host institution for the co-supervisor.

The envisioned activities also involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including Dr. Miguel Won and a PhD student named Zuil Pirola, that are also working on the DEBAQI project.

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Key-phrase extraction concerns automatically selecting a small set of phrases that best describe the concepts described within a given free text document. The task has many practical applications, e.g. within tools for media monitoring and for supporting the access of scientific publications. One particular application domain for key-phrase extraction are online-based epidemiology surveillance tools, which harness information extracted from the Web (e.g., from social media channels, news articles, etc.) to provide real-time monitoring of activities related to particular health problems. Most of these methods are based on key-phrase extraction (or controlled key-word spotting), assuming that most uses of disease-related keywords on textual documents are motivated by infections or to people contracting these particular problems. 

Supervised key-phrase extraction requires large amounts of labeled training data (i.e., documents in which the relevant key-phrases have been annotated) and generalizes very poorly outside the domain of the training data. At the same time, unsupervised systems have poor accuracy, and often also do not generalize well, as several approaches require the input document to belong to a larger corpus also given as input. These challenges motivate the interest in distantly- and weakly-supervised methods with no need of expensive human annotation ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.12218 ), and also in transfer learning methods based on adapting large pre-trained language models ( see https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/D19-1521/ or https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/K18-1022/ ).

This MSc research project will address the development and evaluation of novel approaches for key-phrase extraction, specifically envisioning applications in epidemiological surveillance. The methods that are to be developed will advanced on previous approaches such as EmbedRank ( https://github.com/swisscom/ai-research-keyphrase-extraction ) and SIFRank ( https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/8954611 ), specifically by exploring pre-trained cross-lingual language models ( e.g., see some of the models available from https://huggingface.co/transformers ) to generate representations for key-phrase candidates independently of the input document's language, and combining these representations with ideas from graph-based methods for key-phrase extraction ( see https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/N18-2105/ and https://arxiv.org/pdf/2003.04628.pdf ). 

Particular attention will also be given to the detection of key-phrases associated to concepts the appear negated in the texts, so that these can be excluded from the results ( e.g., by adapting methods such as those from https://www.nature.com/articles/s41746-019-0108-y.pdf , https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/W13-5635.pdf or https://github.com/ncbi-nlp/NegBio ). Detecting negations is particularly important for epidemiology applications, given that when describing events people often list possible diseases or symptoms excluded from particular situations. 

Evaluation experiments will be conducted over pre-existing datasets focusing on the biomedical domain ( e.g., sub-sets from https://github.com/microsoft/OpenKP or from https://github.com/boudinfl/ake-datasets ), comparing alternative/ablated approaches.

title: Dissertação: Visualização de dados em realidade estendida
objectives:
Descrição: A visualização e análise de dados é uma vantagem dos novos ambientes de realidade estendida. Estes apresentam novas possibilidades relativamente aos sistemas 2D tradicionais, assim como novos desafios.

Objetivos: Neste trabalho de mestrado propõe-se a análise e avaliação comparativa de diferentes métodos de visualização de dados em realidade virtual e aumentada. Nesse âmbito, pretende-se que o candidato desenvolva um protótipo que permita comparar técnicas de representação e navegação. Pretende-se também desenvolver novos métodos que possibilitem a representação de informação em ambientes imersivos.

title: Dissertação: Melhorar o desenvolvimento de jogos baseados em diálogo
location: Este trabalho realiza-se no GAIPS - INESC-ID e no Laboratório de Jogos, no IST- Taguspark.
observations:
Existe a possibilidade, não confirmada, de aplicar a ferramenta numa empresa.
O trabalho pode ser ligado a um projeto de investigação sobre testes automáticos de aplicações interativas – iv4XR (https://iv4xr-project.eu/)
objectives: A criação de jogos com uma forte componente de diálogo passa sempre por uma morosa fase de verificação dos vários caminhos do diálogo para garantir que os objetivos de design são cumpridos. Por exemplo, interessa saber que caminhos garantem um determinado final da história (que tipicamente evolui de várias formas). O processo torna-se ainda mais complexo quando os personagens com os quais o jogador conversa exibem algum comportamento inteligente e não determinístico à priori. Junta-se também o facto de jogadores com perfis diferentes fazerem diferentes escolhas e terem, portanto, uma experiência com o jogo distinta. São vários os fatores que os designers do jogo querem verificar e para isso necessitam de ferramentas adequadas, que permitam simular o comportamento dos jogadores e dos personagens para prever potenciais problemas. O objetivo desta tese é trabalhar numa dessas ferramentas. O trabalho pega numa ferramenta que inclui já algumas funcionalidades que permitem analisar histórias criadas usando a ferramenta Twine (https://twinery.org/), e irá acrescentar funcionalidades mais avançadas. title: [Dissertação] : Deep Learning for Remote Sensing Image Captioning
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Jacinto Estima ( https://jestima.github.io/ ), and it will be developed in the context of the MIMU research project, currently being executed at INESC-ID.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including a PhD student named Rita Ramos that is working on remote sensing image captioning and multi-modal machine learning (under a co-supervision with Prof. Desmond Elliot from University of Copenhagen).

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
The application of deep learning methods in the analysis of remote sensing images has recently attracted extensive attention, with noticeable progress in tasks such as global scene classification, object detection, of pixel-level classification for land cover mapping and semantic segmentation. However, apart from a few recent studies ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1712.07835 and https://www.mdpi.com/2072-4292/11/6/612 ), significantly less attention has been given to the problem of describing remote sensing image content with accurate and concise natural language sentences. This is an exciting research problem that combines natural language processing and computer vision techniques, involving language generation conditioned on the results of processing visual inputs for recognizing objects and relations between objects. Having concise descriptions of remote sensing scenes can support numerous practical applications, such as image retrieval from textual queries, the generation of explanations for scene classification, and intelligence gathering.

Taking inspiration on state-of-the-art approaches for addressing general image captioning problems, researchers have proposed to tackle the problem with methods based on deep neural networks. Most of these methods follow an encoder-decoder architecture that combines convolutional, recurrent, and attention components. An encoder component corresponding to a pre-trained convolutional neural network generates a representation for the image, and a decoder based on recurrent neural networks generates the answer word-by-word, at each step using neural attention to weight parts of the visual input according to relevance for the current prediction.

Despite some interesting previous results, there are several opportunities for improvement over the aforementioned general architecture. In particular, this MSc research project will address the development and evaluation of innovative remote sensing image captioning methods, advancing in several directions over the previous state-of-the-art.

Noting that additional information for the regions covered by the remote sensing images can be extracted from sources such as the OpenStreetMap, one possibility to be explored relates to the use of attribute attention mechanisms, supporting the generation of captions both on the image contents, and on different types of attributes (e.g., names for points of interest, object categories, ground-level photos for the same regions, etc.) extracted from external sources.

The visual encoding and neural attention components ( see https://arxiv.org/1908.06954 ) can also be made to rely on recent developments, namely through the use of state-of-the-art convolutional architectures discovered through automated search, which feature particular connection patterns, pooling operations, or normalization operations ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.11946 , https://arxiv.org/pdf/2003.13328v1.pdf or https://arxiv.org/pdf/2004.02967.pdf ). An interesting consideration when processing remote sensing aerial images, as opposed to ground-level imagery, relates to the fact that invariance to scale and rotation transformations is much more important when recognising patterns (e.g., the absolute orientation of objects is arbitrary, and objects of the same semantic class can be observed in different orientations in the same image). The visual encoding component can thus also be desiged to take these aspects into consideration, leveraging recent ideas proposed in the context of classification and/or segmentation problems ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.06253 and https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8900563 ).

Finally, on what regards model training and the decoder component, improvements can be made over traditional greedy methods (i.e., when generating the answer word-by-word, use the most likely output at each step), through strategies designed to deal with the exposure bias (i.e., accumulated errors caused by different decoding strategies during training and inference) and over-correction (i.e., using strict pairwise matches between predicted and ground truth sequences) problems, e.g. through sampling or sequence-level training ( see https://huggingface.co/blog/how-to-generate or https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.06283 ). The loss function used for model training can also explore multi-task objectives, e.g. under the intuition that the representation for the generated descriptions should encode information useful for retrieving similar contents to the source images ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.04402 ).

Tests will be performed with the publicly available RSICD, UCM and Sydney datasets of remote sensing images associated to textual descriptions ( https://github.com/201528014227051/RSICD_optimal ), contrasting the approaches to be developed (i.e., ablated versions of a final model) against current state-of-the art methods through traditional metrics such as BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE and CIDEr ( see https://github.com/Maluuba/nlg-eval ), as well as more recent metrics such as BLEURT - see https://github.com/google-research/bleurt.
