title: [DISSERTAÇÃO] Use of Learning Mechanisms to Improve Wind Farms Operation Conditions Monitoring
objectives:
Paris agreement established new goals for countries to achieve carbon neutrality. The goals are very challenging imposing two main changes: the electrification of usages increasing the efficiency and the use of carbon-free technologies to generate electricity. In such a scenario, expected to 2050, wind and solar energy will be the major energy primary sources. Concerning wind energy, new onshore wind farms project will be developed but a significant increase in offshore installations is also expected for several reasons: stable and stronger wind conditions, size of generators, visual disturbance, noise pollution, etc. However, the maintenance costs of offshore wind farms are significant representing around 25% of initial investment during their lifetime.

Condition Monitoring (CM) in offshore wind farms can be a powerful tool to reduce the operation and maintenance costs as well as to optimize maintenance actions and outage planning. Condition monitoring (CM) involves observing the components of a wind turbine (e.g. blade fault detection or generator temperature monitoring) or a wind farm (e.g. transformer monitoring) to identify changes in operation that can be indicative of a developing fault. This analysis can be made using different data and comparing information between real measurements and theoretical measurements (digital twins), measurements in wind turbines in the same wind farm and measurements in wind turbines of different wind farms.

The research questions are:

- What are the most suitable machine learning methods to be used in the condition monitoring of (offshore) wind farms (this should be changed to a specific part of the wind farm/wind turbine)?  
- The adopted method should be the same independently of the context (the type of wind farm)?
- The use of error analysis can improve the performance of “traditional” ML algorithms?
- What is the expected impact of the use of the proposed approach (reduction of maintenance costs)?
requirements: The student should have good knowledge of machine learning techniques and have taken courses such as PADI and/or Aprendizagem.

title: Dissertação: Cibersegurança para Sistemas Críticos através de Deteção de Intrusões
supervisors: Miguel Nuno Dias Alves Pupo Correia (60%)
observations: O projeto está inserido no INOV, um centro de investigação do grupo INESC, ligado ao IST, que poderá atribuir uma bolsa.
objectives:
Os sistemas informáticos atuais são muito mais do que os familiares PCs, servidores e dispositivos móveis ligados à Internet ou a uma LAN. Uma categoria interessante são os sistemas de controlo industriais (ICS) usados no contexto do fornecimento de eletricidade, transporte de pessoas ou mercadorias, e unidades fabris, entre muitos outros. Estes sistemas têm uma componente informática mas também sensores e atuadores que interagem com processos físicos e outros: ligam/desligam eletricidade, controlam veículos, etc. 

Esse tipo de sistemas críticos estão tão expostos a riscos de cibersegurança como os outros, mas a sua falha é muito mais problemática. Por exemplo, em dezembro de 2015 e 2016 uma campanha de ataque denominada CrashOverride afectou dezenas de centrais elétricas na Ucrânia, deixando centenas de milhares de milhares de pessoas sem eletricidade durante horas em pelo inverno.

A eficácia deste tipo de ataques expôs as limitações que os atuais sistemas de deteção de intrusões (IDS) possuem em identificar ataques contra este tipo de redes. Esta limitação fez com que surgissem novos IDS com base em identificação de anomalias ou desvios comportamentais nesses dispositivos, e identificar possíveis abusos cometidos sobre os sistemas físicos que controlam. Estas abordagens distinguem-se entre si na forma como é realizada a identificação de intrusões. IDS com deteção de anomalias recorrem tipicamente a técnicas de aprendizagem automática do comportamento espectável do equipamento monitorizado. No entanto, o subconjunto de IDS com base em especificação evitam o período de aprendizagem recorrendo a configuração de sistema onde é explicitado o comportamento espectável do sistema.

O projeto insere-se neste contexto da deteção de intrusões com base em especificação. Em concreto, o objetivo é investigar novos métodos que automatizem a configuração necessária dos sistemas IDS com base em especificação de forma a reduzir o esforço exigido à sua aplicação em contexto de ICS. Além disso o projeto irá aplicação essa solução no contexto da deteção de intrusões em um ou dois ICSs reais.

A investigação terá como caso de estudo o sistema de deteção de intrusões baseado em especificação, BP-IDS (Business Process-based Intrusion Detection System) que tomará partido dos novos métodos desenvolvidos de forma a automatizar a configuração requerida pela IDS. Espera-se que com a investigação realizada no decorrer desta tese se consiga observar que os métodos propostos são adaptáveis às características impostas pelos sistemas de controlo industrial, eficazes na redução da carga de configuração manual exigida pelas IDS baseadas em especificação sem que se assista a um decréscimo na qualidade de deteção efetuado por estas IDS.

O plano de trabalho consiste nas seguintes fases:
- Revisão do trabalho relacionado.
- Concepção e concretização da solução.
- Avaliação experimental da solução proposta.
- Escrita de um artigo científico e da dissertação.
requirements: O candidato teve ter bons conhecimentos de cibersegurança, sendo aconselhada a frequência da cadeira de SIRS.

title: ​Dissertação: Network motifs in multi-graphs
objectives:
Network motifs are statistically over-represented sub-structures (sub-graphs) in a network, and have been recognized as "the simple building blocks of complex networks". Study of biological network motifs may reveal answers to many important biological questions.

The main difficulty in detecting larger network motifs in biological networks lies in the facts that the number of possible sub-graphs increases exponentially with the network or motif size. Nevertheless, some tools exist for the identification of network motifs.
One software tool to find motifs in graphs, gtrieScanner [1,2], uses the g-trie data structure to efficiently count occurrences of subgraphs on larger graphs. However, it fails to provide means to find motifs with particular labels on edges.

This thesis will focus on the identification of motifs in biological networks, using a motif finding tool, e.g. gtrieScanner.
Biological data is available in the http://yeastract.com database [3], with the S.cerevisiae network and the networks of closely related species.
Additionally, the motif finding tool will be extended to support finding motifs satisfying a given label, and motifs across multiple graph/species (multi-graphs).

[1] https://www.dcc.fc.up.pt/gtries/
[2] Ribeiro P. and Silva F. G-Tries: a data structure for storing and finding subgraphs. In Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery, Vol. 28(2), pp. 337-377, Springer, 2014
[3] Teixeira et al. YEASTRACT, an upgraded database for the analysis of transcription regulatory networks in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Nucleic Acids Research, 46(D1): D348-D353
requirements: Good programming skills. Interest in graphs is a plus.

title: [Dissertation] A Visual Open-Source Architectural Simulator of Modern Computing Systems
observations:
- Assignment of this thesis is subject to a prior informal interview with the candidate to assess his motivation and prior knowledge in the fields of research
- This thesis involves challenging aspects recognized by the scientific community; accordingly, the outcome of this work may give rise to the publication of scientific articles.
objectives:
The increasing complexity of modern computing systems, makes it difficult to design and specify architecture characteristics without accurate simulators. Although many emulators and simulators have been proposed in the latest years, it is often difficult to visually assess and inspect the performance bottlenecks due to the conflicting influence of multiple factors.

The objective of this thesis is to develop a visual architectural simulator, with a graphical front-end, that is able to emulate/simulate modern computing systems composed of either simple of complex pipelines, complex cache and memory hierarchies and peripherals. Hence, the simulator, developed in an object-oriented programming language, will feature a front-end module capable of supporting different ISAs, and a back-end module capable of either emulating instruction execution, or accurately simulating the processor behaviour, by emulating the working of each processor pipeline.
requirements:

title: [Dissertação]: Behaviour Detection in Oceanary Fishes
supervisors: Helena Sofia Andrade Nunes Pereira Pinto (50%)
observations:
Para mais informação contactar H. Sofia Pinto sofia(at)inesc-id.pt 
(https://www.inesc-id.pt/member/413/) ou Alexandre Bernardino alexandre.bernardino@tecnico.ulisboa.pt (https://sites.google.com/view/alexbernardino/home)
objectives:
No âmbito da colaboração com o Oceanário de Lisboa, temos desenvolvido soluções para o tracking de peixes nos seus vários tanques. Uma vez que cada ambiente tem as suas especificidades (por exemplo, o tanque principal tem uma cor azulada que dificulta distiguir os peixes ao longe; no tanque de recife de coral os peixes deslocam-se muito mais rápido do que no tanque principal) temos usado diferentes técnicas de forma obter soluções que providenciem bons resultados para as diferentes condições em cada um dos tanques/aquários. Por exemplo em
https://fenix.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/cursos/meic-a/dissertacao/1691203502343354 usamos técnicas clássicas de processamento da imagem para identificar e seguir os peixes que entram no campo de visão de uma camâra fixa. Neste momento estamos a usar as técnicas mais recentes da área de visão envolvendo algorítmos de aprendizagem automática, deep learning, para efectuar o seguimento/tracking de um conjunto de peixes dado inicialmente.

No âmbito da presente proposta de Tese de Mestrado pretende-se desenvolver soluções que ajudem os biólogos do Oceanário a detectarem, monitorizarem e identificarem comportamentos nos indivíduos das várias espécies que habitam o Oceanário usando técnicas de  IA, por exemplo, Deep Learning.

Por um lado, estamos interessados em perceber comportamentos desviantes que podem indicar que o animal pode estar doente, por exemplo um peixe que deixa de ir comer, ou que não se mexe muito.
Por outro lado, estamos interessados em perceber comportamentos que se repetem, podendo esta repetição ter períodos muito diferentes - há comportamentos que se repetem cada dia, por exemplo comer, descansar; que se repetem anualmente, por exemplo rituais de reprodução.
Claro que os comportamentos dependem da espécie, e claro que têm alguma variabilidade dentro da mesma espécie, de indivíduo para indivíduo.
requirements:
Commitment and availability to work on the project (e.g., not recommended for students with other professional activities);
Interesse nos seguintes tópicos: Inteligência Artificial, Deep Learning, Processamento de Imagem, Detecção de Padrões.

title: Dissertação || GP3: Governance blueprints of Programs, Projects and Portfolios
supervisors: Maria do Rosário Gomes Osório Bernardo Ponces de Carvalho (50%)
observations: Proposto  por Aluno: Duarte Meneses : 69740
objectives:
Motivation: 
O tema de Governo (Governance) nas organizações, com uma sólida base de conhecimento nas mais diversas disciplinas de investigação, tais como a área de gestão e de sociologia das organizações, entre outras, tem particular relevância no contexto dos projetos, programas e portfolios das organizações. Projetos, enquanto ‘organizações temporárias’ e únicas visam dar resposta ao cumprimento de um objetivo estratégico da organização, sendo cada vez mais importantes para a sobrevivência da organização.

A definição de blueprints (vistas ou diagramas) que explicitem os atores e roles de governo associados no domínio dos projetos, programas e portfolios da organização é um desafio no contexto da Arquitetura Empresarial da organização.

Pretende-se assim propor viewpoints da arquitetura empresarial (para desenvolver blueprints organizacionais) que explicitem os atores e roles de governo associados no domínio dos projetos, programas e portfolios da organização.
Assim, o aluno começará por proceder ao Levantamento do estado da arte da Governanção de programas, projetos e portfolio no contexto da arquitetura empresarial. Este levantamento deverá incluir frameworks de modelação de arquitetura empresarial, de estratégia, governação e gestão de projetos, e ferramentas de modelação de arquitetura empresarial (incluindo Archimate e Motivation extension; Framework; TOGAF; UML, BPMN; BMM; UAF). 

Tendo por base uma framework de arquitetura empresarial o aluno deve proceder a proposta de viewpoints para modelação da Governance de Programas, Projetos e Portfolios.

Finalmente os viewpoints propostos deverão ser aplicados na produção de bluepints (vistas) para a explicitação de modelos de governane em projetos, programas, portfolios, no contexto da arquitetura empresarial de uma organização que tem a seu cargo a produção de bens e serviços fundamentais ao funcionamento do Estado Português.

1. Proposta de viewpoints para modelação da Governance de Programas, Projetos e Portfolios no contexto da arquitetura empresarial.

title: Dissertação: Increasing privacy in interactions between robot and humans using Blockchain - testing in an healthcare environment
objectives:
Os sistemas de informação hospitalares apresentam um conjunto significativo de desafios para o Engenheiro Informático. A privacidade localiza-se, hoje, no topo destes desafios afectando uma multiplicidade de pessoas que trabalham, ou usam, cuidados de saúde. Por outro lado, os robots quando inseridos nos ambientes hospitalares introduzem uma capacidade acrescida de benefício social, mas também de recolha de dados em grande quantidade. Estes dados têm que ser tratados atendendo aos requisitos legais, p.e., impostos pelo RGPD. Assim, torna-se clara a necessidade de encontrar novas soluções que suportem esta preocupação. Neste sentido, o Blockchain é uma solução que contem propriedades compatíveis com os requisitos de privacidade impostos pelo RGPD. 
Em específico pretende-se testar uma plataforma já existente, sendo para isso necessário efectuar um levantamento do contexto existente com uma clara definição das variáveis dinâmicas mais relevantes existentes.

Assim, são esperados os principais resultados: 1. levantamento de estado da arte sobre soluções e implementações conhecidas na comunidade científica e empresarial, tendo em vista a identificação exacta do problema a ser resolvido; 2. representação de um modelo conceptual que vise propor uma solução para o problema identificado; 3. definição, de testes de um protótipo que permite integrar dados do ambiente com interacção social entre robot e humanos e a solução Blockchain; 4. avaliação dos resultados obtidos no ponto 3 como justificação para a correcta solução escolhida no ponto 2.; 5. publicação de artigo(s) ao longo da execução da tese.

title: [Dissertação] : Classification of Chest X-Ray Images with Deep Neural Networks for Detecting COVID-19
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Arlindo Oliveira ( http://web.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/arlindo.oliveira/ ), and it will be developed in the context of an ongoing collaboration between INESC-ID and Hospital da Luz Learning Health. objectives:
We are nowadays witnessing a significant outbreak of COVID-19, which can lead to pneumonia visible to medical imaging methods such as X-Rays or CT scans. Chest X-Rays, in particular, are both common and relatively cheap, thus being extensively used in hospitals as part of clinical protocols to diagnose COVID-19 (i.e., chest X-Ray images are often collected when patients with suspected coronavirus disease are admitted to a hospital and, if evidence for the disease is found, other imaging procedures and/or tests can be performed).

Despite the high generalization ability, the traditional use of X-Ray images for the diagnosis of COVID-19 requires expert radiologists to analyze the images. In this context, automatic image classification methods leveraging recent developments (e.g., modern methods based on deep neural networks are already successful at identifying pneumonia from X-Ray images, with a performance rivalling that of expert radiologists) can contribute to a faster diagnosis.

Some recent studies have already reported in the use of deep neural network methods for diagnosing COVID-19 ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.02731 , https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.09420 or https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.05436 for reviews on the use of computer vision and artificial intelligence methods for the diagnosis of COVID-19 from medical images ) and, even if discriminating between COVID-19 and other types of pneumonia remains a challenging problem, we argue that automatic classification methods can be effectively used to prioritize resources (e.g., to prioritize the selection of images to be analyzed by expert radiologists, or to prioritize patients for further imaging studies or RT-PCR testing).

This MSc project will explore the use of deep convolutional neural network architectures for the analysis of chest X-Ray images, aiming at discriminating between healthy patients, patients diagnosed with COVID-19, and patients diagnosed with other types of pneumonia. The neural classification methods can explore transfer learning from large datasets of chest X-Ray images, and they can integrate recent developments related to the use of state-of-the-art convolutional architectures discovered through automated search, which feature particular connection patterns, pooling operations, or normalization operations ( see https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.11946 , https://arxiv.org/pdf/2003.13328v1.pdf or https://arxiv.org/pdf/2004.02967.pdf ). Particular attention will be given to (a) the use of attention mechanisms, which can also facilitate interpretability and the estimation of severity for COVID-19 (e.g., by highlighting larger regions of the images showing evidence supporting the classification), as well as to (b) the use of anatomical priors that can provide information on image areas more likely to influence the classification ( e.g., see https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.02343 ).

Tests will be performed with publicly available datasets ( e.g., see https://github.com/ieee8023/covid-chestxray-dataset, https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.04569 and https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.11597 ), contrasting different classification methods (e.g., ablated versions of the model that is to be developed).

title: Dissertation - A modular framework for transactional systems
observations: A tese será co-orientada pelo Eng. João Loff do Grupo de Sistemas Distribuídos do INESC ID Lisboa
objectives:
Distributed transactional systems provide transactional guarantees to applications.
Existing research has explored and classified the variations in transactional models and the guarantees they provide. These analysis have broken down the details of transaction initiation, execution, validation and confirmation, and the variations that different transactional models take in those steps.

The goal of this dissertation is to develop a programming framework that implements some existing transactional models using a modular approach with standard combinable interfaces. This should allow system architects to use existing components and explore how varied transactional guarantees can be constructed using these standard building blocks.
This work builds on previous experience in creating a similar framework for consistency models in replicated services.

title: [Dissertação] SureThing Location Proof Transparency
observations: Pedro Matias Carvalho (86449)
objectives:
Location Based Services (LBS) provide geographic or topological context to mobile applications. The location is detected by the devices and then trusted by the applications, although they are subject to failures and frauds. 

For some applications, having the real location of the device is critical, and they require the location to be a certified attribute. In other words, they require Location Proofs (LPs).
In the SureThing framework (http://surething.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/), as in other existing architectures, a Certificate Authority (CA) is a trusted entity that may have different roles such as keeping the list of participants, validating their identities and issuing LPs.

Similar to what happens to web certificates in the TLS Public-Key Infrastructure (PKI), whenever a trusted CA gets compromised, the system is no longer safe and fraudulent certificates can be issued. In order to improve the safety of PKI, Google has proposed Certificate Transparency (CT) (http://www.certificate-transparency.org/), a protocol in which CAs register the issued certificates into a public log. Anyone can have access to the log and monitor the activity of CAs or the logs issued for some domain they are interested in. 

In the present Location Proof Transparency (LPT) work, the aim is to improve the safety of Location Based Services. We are developing a tamper-proof public log specifically designed for Location Proofs. We make use of Verifiable Data Structures such as the ones implemented in Google’s Trillian (https://github.com/google/trillian) in order to create the append-only verifiable public log. We are also adapting existing monitoring mechanisms and propose mechanisms for ranking the trust in users and location witnesses.

The goal of this work is to implement a prototype for LPT and evaluate it, using the expertise and data from the SureThing project team. 

Referências:

B. Laurie, A. Langley, and E. Kasper. Certificate transparency. RFC 6962, June 2013.

O. Gasser, B. Hof, M. Helm, M. Korczynski, R. Holz and G. Carle. In log we trust:  Revealing poor security practices with certificate transparency logs and internet measurements. Passive  and  Active Measurement, pages 173–185, 2018.

Q.  Scheitle,  O. Gasser,  T. Nolte,  J. Amann,  L. Brent,  G.  Carle,  R.  Holz,  T.  Schmidt,  and  M. Wählisch. The rise of certificate transparency and its implications on the internet ecosystem. In Proceedings of the Internet Measurement Conference, page 343–349, 2018.

title: [Dissertation] Unveiling progression patterns in Neurodegenerative Diseases
location: INESC-ID, Alameda Campus (Rua Alves Redol, 9 - 1000-029 Lisboa)
observations:

- This thesis involves challenging aspects recognized by the scientific community; accordingly, the outcome of this work may give rise to the publication of scientific articles.
objectives:
Neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), Parkinson's Disease (PD), Alzheimer's Disease (AD), and Huntington's Disease (HD)) consist in a progressive loss of structure or function of the neurons, leading to the death of neurons. These are incurable diseases, where known treatments can only help alleviate the symptoms at early stages. However, achieving an early diagnosis and discovering disease progression patterns and rates is an important task, as it can help to guide treatments, calendar medical appointments, and aid family members in patient support.

Many collaborative projects and independent studies have been performed with the objective of studying these diseases, discovering biomarkers, predicting the prognostic of patients, and unveiling progression patterns. In most cases, this results in multiple data acquisitions (time series), with multivariate and heterogeneous data, and missing values. The objective of this thesis is to exploit temporal data and sophisticated machine learning techniques (e.g., deep learning) to unveil the progression patterns and rates of neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Dissertação || Enabling Enterprise Blockchain Interoperability
observations:
Tese realizada com acompanhamento do Eng Rafael Belchior
Para mais informações vide https://sites.google.com/site/vasconcelosandre/teses/mestrado/temas-mestrado
objectives:
Motivation: 
The adoption of permissioned networks has seen a significant increase in the last years, with Hyperledger technologies highlighting this adoption. For the case of permissioned blockchains, e.g., Hyperledger Fabric, smart contracts can be leveraged to a wide range of use case scenarios, where entities/organizations need to cooperate, sharing data and/or other assets. However, smart contracts (and the respective ecosystems they support) are tied to a specific blockchain implementation, and the services they can provide rely on the survivability of a particular blockchain, even in the same infrastructure. These types of problems raise the need for blockchain interoperability.
requirements:
Description:
The Hyperledger Quilt already enables a specific type of blockchain interoperability using the Interledger Protocol, i.e., allows payments across any payment network using the Interledger protocol. A relatively recent Hyperledger Lab, "Hyperledger Labs Blockchain Integration Framework" is creating a communication model to enable permissioned blockchain ecosystems to exchange on-chain data or custom assets independently of the platform (e.g., Hyperledger Fabric, Quorum, etc.).
Nevertheless, to the best of our knowledge, no Hyperledger project is tackling general blockchain interoperability for both public and private blockchains or studying the impact of blockchain interoperability, particularly on the Hyperledger ecosystem.
This thesis aims to explore how can permissioned blockchains interoperate, in particular Hyperledger Fabric instances.
This thesis is expected to give a strong contribution to the Hyperledger ecosystem in terms of the state of the art in blockchain interoperability. Some questions that this project aims to answer are:
How can we interoperate Hyperledger technologies with other blockchains?,
How can Hyperledger initiatives position themselves to tackle blockchain interoperability?,
What standards we require to define middleware between blockchains?
What are the consequences of employing smart contracts with external processes and data (the external part means another connected blockchain)?,
The key to the survivability of this technology? 

In other to try to answer those questions, in this thesis will start by studying some of the most prominent blockchain interoperability solutions already available or being proposed, and how they can be used to promote and strengthen Hyperledger technologies.  Then, it will design and develop a framework for creating, deploying and maintaining services with several blockchains. The applicability of the solution to be proposed is to be demonstrated through the exploration of a use case, implementing several blockchains (including Hyperledger Fabric) to increase the dependability of blockchain-powered services administrated by several stakeholders, serving as a proof-of-concept.
More information: https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/INTERN/Towards+Blockchain+Interoperability+with+Hyperledger
 






Expected results:
1. Literature review regarding permissioned blockchains interoperability 
2. Proposal of a framework for creating, deploying and maintaining services with several blockchains 
3. Proof of concept implementation 
4. Paper Publication

title: PROJECT: A Flow-based Management Framework of IT Infrastructures
observations: Thesis Proposal agreed with student Miguel Oliveiras nr. 87689
objectives:
The DevOps "culture" advocates software engineering best practices and tools in order to ensure continuously evolving complex systems, promoting a tight collaboration between the developers (Dev) and the teams that deploy and operate the systems (Ops).

Current solutions and tools lack mechanisms for the ease of Design and for continuous deployment and evolution of the systems across different spaces (from IoT, to edge, core and clouds) as well as for the continuous quality assurance, such as mechanisms to ensure end-to-end security and privacy, and mechanisms to allow continuous testing of IT Infrastructures (within emulated and simulated infrastructures).

At the Network level, the dynamism of Software Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Functions Virtualization (NFV) might even make easier to design, and build infrastructures with more flexible services and capabilities, making possible to link network functions through Service Function Chaining (SFC) to produce new services.

For the continuous deployment and evolution of these systems, the management of the lifecycle of all the different assets is a must, and can be performed through a Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT). This technology can capture all transactions and state changes that occur with an asset of the Infrastructure (hardware, software, and associated contracts), providing a single source of truth (immutable system of record available in near real-time) for the core information about each asset, so that no matter what happened to an asset, all stakeholders and systems would know its status.

This project intends to propose and develop a Proof-of-Concept toolset to enable trustworthy DevOps in the realm of IT Infrastructures, with a tool that aims at improving the management, the continuous delivery and continuous orchestration of these systems, also ensuring their traceability.


The tool should be able to:
- be a programming tool, with a Graphical User Interface (GUI) browser-based (e.g., JavaScipt),
- follow Infrastructure-as-Code principles, for wiring together hardware devices, APIs and online services,
- invoke transactions that create, configure, update, and delete assets 
- manage and monitor servers networks and services, and automate sysadmin related tasks,
- visually compare the live IT environment state before and after a deployment, as part of the automated Continuous-Integration/Delivery (CI/CD) pipeline.

A PoC prototype shall be built, deployed and tested. The results obtained shall be validated based on real scenarios to be defined. 


Recommended Tools and frameworks:

- Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT): Hyperledger Fabric (https://www.hyperledger.org/projects/fabric)
- Hyperledger tools: Hyperledger Composer (https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/)
- Container technology: Docker (https://www.docker.com)
- SDN Network Emulator: Mininet (http://mininet.org)
- A Python-based SDN controller such as Faucet (https://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=3015763)

title: [Dissertação] Exact Methods for Multiobjective Combinatorial Optimization Problems
observations:
Andreia Próspero Guerreiro: andreia.guerreiro@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
José Rui Figueira: figueira@tecnico.ulisboa.pt
objectives:
In multiobjective optimization problems, the goal is to find the solutions that simultaneously optimize two or more objective functions. 
One example is the problem of finding a route that simultaneously minimizes fuel consumption and travel time. Due to the usually conflicting nature of objectives, typically there is not a single optimal solution, but a set of optimal solutions. Each optimal solution in this set is better than any other in some objective but worse in another objective. Although in some cases methods to enumerate all optimal solutions may be appropriate and desirable, in other cases the set of optimal solutions may be too large, and the Decision Maker (the person, or entity wanting to finding a solution to the problem) is not interested, or cannot analyze, all of them. An alternative is to find a good subset of optimal solutions, called a representation, to present to the Decision Maker.

The goal of this thesis is to study and develop exact algorithms for classical multiobjective combinatorial optimization problems, such as the unconstrained multiobjective optimization problem, considering approaches to enumerate, and/or to find a representation of, all optimal solutions.
requirements: Boa capacidade para implementar algorítmos.

title: Dissertação: NF Composition Synthesis
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Prof. Luis Pedrosa (luis.pedrosa@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Recent work has been exploring software network functions (NFs), a collection of techniques that enable processing packets entirely in software, allowing commodity servers to replace inflexible network equipment. Processing packets at line-rate has been a challenge, but recent techniques like kernel-bypass have enabled packet processing at throughputs of 10s of Gbit/s and latencies of 100s of ns, making such options competitive with dedicated hardware.

In some cases, however, developers and operators may not find a single NF with all of the features that they wish to deploy, but rather find a combination of NFs, each with only a subset of those features. Fixing this will typically require a developer to undertake the tedious effort of building a detailed understanding of both code bases to subsequently refactor them to merge in the desired functionality.

Recent work in verifying NFs [1], explored using symbolic analysis to build a sound and complete representation of the entire behavior of an NF. In that case, this representation was used to check the behavior against a specification for correctness but, in this thesis, we propose using it to facilitate the merger of two or more NFs to combine their functionality. In many cases, such functionality can be seen as logically orthogonal and the merger could be fully automated. For more complex cases, we will also explore novel forms of conflict resolution.

Our specific goal is to build a static analysis tool that analyzes the code of each of the constituting NFs and subsequently generates a new one combining their features. For example, the system could merge an IPv4 router with an IPv6 one to build a dual stack system or combine a NAT with an IDS.

References:
[1] A. Zaostrovnykh et al., Verifying Software Network Functions with No Verification Expertise, SOSP'19

title: Dissertação: Stateful@Streams - Stateful Functions for Approximate Stream Processing
observations: Survey the state-of-the-art of the related work. Design and development of a prototype. Testing and performance evaluation. Writing of a technical paper (10 pages) that frames and presents the work carried out, and describes the results achieved.
objectives:
Stateful Functions is an open source framework that reduces the complexity of building and orchestrating distributed stateful applications at scale. It brings together the benefits of stream processing with Apache Flink and Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) to provide a powerful abstraction for event-driven architectures.

The goal of this work is to leverage Stateful Functions in Flink in order to design and develop an extension to this distributed stream that achieves increased scalability and performance, with adaptable resource management driven by service-level objectives regarding performance (latency, throughput), result accuracy, and resource management; ultimately supporting more efficient Graph streaming. 

The overall model is to be governed by application-defined criteria (e.g., accuracy, latency) and resource budgets definable by the client applications, according to a Quality-of-Data model. Thus, all data input, including late events can be monitored and assessed against different guarantees, so that only when QoD criteria of a specific stream application is about to be exceeded, more resources are engaged to process the streams, e.g., faster, with more accuracy, etc. This way, stream processing only uses those resources required to provide useful results to the application.

title: Dissertação: ZIP-Graphs
observations: Survey the state-of-the-art of the related work. Design and development of a prototype. Testing and performance evaluation. Writing of a technical paper (10 pages) that frames and presents the work carried out, and describes the results achieved.
objectives:
The goal of this work is to design and develop an extension to graph storage (e.g., DGraph, Neo4j, JanusGraph, Nebula Graph) and optionally to the storage components of graph processing systems (e.g., GraphX on Spark and Gelly on Flink) so that the graph data stored is made more space-efficient, without degrading performance and, hopefully, even improving it.

One way to achieve this is by employing summarized data representations that allow reducing space occupied by data while enabling direct access to data components (as opposed to typical compression). Graph representations to explore include k2-tree, WebGraph, sparse matrices that should support reducing storage, allowing dynamism (i.e., update-able data) and allow the implementation of popular graph algorithms in order to assess their performance against popular graph workloads.

title: Dissertação: Plenoptic Point Cloud Coding
location: IST - Instituto de Telecomunicações, Multimedia Signal Processing Group, North Tower, 10th floor
objectives:
Scope:
With the emergence of consumer grade devices providing 3D geometry information, such as 3D scanning sensors and light field camera arrays, the way visual data is captured and transmitted is changing. Most often, these new devices provide additional geometry and color information about the visual scene, by means of novel optics, sensors (e.g. infrared), illumination (e.g. reflected light) and signal processing techniques. 
Nowadays, the point cloud representation has attracted significant attention since it enables a whole new set of applications, such as free-viewpoint video, advanced content manipulation (e.g. refocusing or relighting), natural user interaction (e.g. controlling devices by gestures) and gaming. The point cloud model represents the visual scene through the positions of a set of 3D points located on the objects’ surfaces, defining the so-called geometry, and some associated attributes, e.g. color, reflectance and normals. 
Most often, point cloud representations only include a single color per 3D point. However, this approach is not fully realistic, since the color of surfaces in the visual scene may change depending on the viewing angle, especially when the surfaces have different physical properties (e.g. reflectance). This Thesis focus on a more complete representation of the point cloud, called plenoptic point cloud, where every 3D point has different colors corresponding to multiple viewing directions. Since this very rich, realistic and immersive representation requires a very high amount of data, appropriate coding solutions need to be designed for efficient storage and transmission. While MPEG has already developed standard point cloud codecs for single color per point representations, coding solutions for plenoptic point clouds are less common.

Objectives:
In this context, the main objectives of this Thesis are: 
1)	Review and compare the available plenoptic point cloud coding solutions;
2)	Design, implement and assess a novel plenoptic point cloud coding solutions, notably for the attributes, leveraging on the already available solutions.

The following steps will be relevant:
•	Gathering of the relevant literature for static point cloud coding, mostly for color attribute coding
•	Review of the relevant literature and writing of a state-of-the-art review chapter
•	Evaluation of relevant plenoptic point cloud coding solution(s) available in the literature using suitable quality metrics
•	Design and implementation of an efficient plenoptic point cloud codec which is able to compress color attributes associated to a varying number of directions
•	Performance assessment of the developed plenoptic point cloud codec using relevant and appropriate test conditions, benchmarks and methodologies
•	Definition of future work addressing the improvement of the developed point cloud codec

Some relevant references are:
[1] C. Zhang et al., “Point cloud attribute compression with graph transform”, IEEE Int. Conf. Image Process., Paris, France, Oct. 2014.
[2] F. Pereira and E. A. da Silva, “Efficient plenoptic imaging representation: why do we need it?”, IEEE Int. Conf. Multimedia and Expo, Seattle, WA, USA, Jul. 2016.

[6] R. L. de Queiroz and P. A. Chou, “Compression of 3D point clouds using a region-adaptive hierarchical transform,” IEEE Trans. on Image Processing, Vol. 25, No. 8, pp. 3497-3956, Aug. 2016.

title: [Dissertação] Auditing System for Attack Investigations of Microservice-based Web Applications
objectives:
Microservices are currently adopted as the prime architectural style for building web applications. Instead of relying on a classical 3-tier monolith, the application logic at the backend is split into multiple internal web applications (micro services) that maintain local persistent state and expose a service through a REST API. Thus, client HTTP requests are first handled by a frontend server, which in turn serves them by performing remote microservice calls. However, while this architecture offers excellent scaling and maintenance properties, it introduces new challenges in attack investigations. In particular, in the aftermath of a data breach caused, for instance, by an SQL injection attack, it is very difficult and time consuming to determine the source of the attack because it typically entails the analysis of multiple microservices and their interdependencies. Moreover, in a time where organizations are heavily pressured by the law (i.e., GDPR) to promptly report to its customers any occurrents of such incidents (not later than 72 hours after becoming aware of it), it is crucial to provide adequate tooling support that allows network administrators to swiftly investigate attacks, and determine the source of vulnerabilities in a sound, efficient, and timely manner.

The goal of this project is to build an auditing system for attack investigations of microservice-based web applications. The system will consist of three main components: event collection probes, an event aggregator, and a query engine. Event collection probes are deployed in every microservice and will monitor all microservices that are involved in servicing any given client request. Collectively, the event probes will implement dynamic taint tracking, where every client request will be labeled at the frontend server with a unique tag and further propagated across subsequent microservices invocations. Event probes will then log the resulting event reports on the event aggregator. For efficient taint tracking, we will explore two ideas: intercept network requests at the OS library level, and propagate tags by tunneling all remote invocations using the MPLS network protocol. The event aggregator will store the collected event reports efficiently by imediately correlating them (through tag analysis), and storing only a graph-based representation of the end-to-end sequence of microservice invocations per client request. This representation (a call graph) will be stored in a forensically-sound manner. Lastly, the query engine will allow the network administrator to perform data provenance queries which aim to determine all client requests that have touched some particular data items, e.g., data that was found to have been leaked. By combining call graphs with a data location model (which tells which microservice is responsible for which data type), the system will be able to serve queries for all client requests that have had access to the data in question within a particular time window, and generate legally-compliant auditing reports. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. The resulting system will be released as an open source project.
requirements: This topic is already reserved for a concrete student.

title: Dissertation: Verifying Cryptographic Components of Password Managers
observations: Orientador externo: José Bacelar Almeira (jba@di.uminho.pt)
objectives:
This project is part of the PassCert research project, a CMU-Portugal exploratory project that will build an open-source, proof-of-concept password manager that through the use of formal verification, is guaranteed to satisfy properties on data storage and password generation. The selected candidate will be a member of the research team, participating in the meetings with the CMU researchers, collaborating on research papers, and possibly presenting their work at international conferences.

Password managers are important tools that enable us to use stronger passwords, freeing us from the cognitive burden of remembering them. Despite this, there are still many users who do not fully trust password managers.

The goals of this project are: i) to do a survey on important security properties that cryptographic components of password managers must satisfy; ii) to produce certified implementations for the critical cryptographic components identified. These include both the password generation algorithm and the password-based encryption scheme adopted to protect the password database. To tackle this, we will combine Jasmin and EasyCrypt. 

Jasmin is a framework targeted to the development of high-speed, high-assurance cryptographic components. It is structured around the verification friendly Jasmin programming language and its predictable compiler, formally verified in Coq, and capable of exploiting low-level architectural features such as vectorised instructions and specialised instructions sets. Easycrypt is a proof-assistant oriented to the formalisation of game-hopping style security proofs, that supports reasoning on a probabilistic imperative language (pWhile). Jasmin programs can be (semantically preserving) embedded in Easycrypt's pWhile language, enabling formal reasoning about functional or security properties (e.g. execution time independent from secret data) [1, 2].

The PassCert team has been actively engaged in the development of both tools, as well as involved in most use-cases mentioned above. Moreover, this task might benefit directly from some of the cryptographic schemes that have been addressed in the aforementioned works (e.g. Chacha20 stream cipher or Poly1305 message authentication code).

[1] J. B. Almeida, M. Barbosa, G. Barthe, A. Blot, B. Grégoire, V. Laporte, T. Oliveira, H. Pacheco, B. Schmidt, and P.-Y. Strub. "Jasmin: High-assurance and high-speed cryptography." CCS 2017
[2] J. B. Almeida, M. Barbosa, G. Barthe, B. Grégoire, A. Koutsos, V. Laporte, T. Oliveira, and P.-Y. Strub. "The Last Mile: High-Assurance and High-Speed Cryptographic Implementations." S&P 2020
requirements:

2. Be interested in security and software reliability
3. Be willing to learn new concepts and tools, and to apply them in real-world scenarios

Knowledge of and/or interest in formal verification of software is desirable (e.g. knowlege of Coq or Dafny)

title: Dissertação: Importance Sampling of Many dynamic lights for Real Time Ray Tracing
objectives:
Motivation:
Monte Carlo ray tracing offers the capability of rendering scenes with large numbers of area light sources—lights can be sampled stochastically and shadowing can be accounted for by tracing rays, rather than using shadow maps or other rasterization based techniques that do not scale to many lights or work well with area lights. Current GPUs only afford the capability of tracing a few rays per pixel at real-time frame rates, making it necessary to focus sampling on important light sources. While state-of-the-art algorithms for ofﬂine rendering build hierarchical data structures over the light sources that enable sampling them according to their importance, they lack efﬁcient support for dynamic scenes.

Objective: 
This thesis aims to implement the algorithm described in [1] which is capable to maintain the hierarchical light sampling data structures targeting real-time ray tracing. The results should be based on a real-time path tracer already implemented in Vulkan.
[1] https://research.nvidia.com/sites/default/files/pubs/2019-07_Dynamic-Many-Light Sampling//MPC19.pdf

Description:
The algorithm is based on a two-level BVH hierarchy that reduces the cost of partial hierarchy updates. Performance is further improved by updating lower-level BVHs via reﬁtting, maintaining their original topology.

title: Dissertation: Managing Exploration Using Procedural Content Generation based on Player Behaviour
observations: This theme was proposed by André Leite (86383).
objectives:
Level design, mechanics, and content exploration are all crucial factors to consider while designing a game. Procedural Content Generation is a good way to achieve variety in these components, but it is a general solution that lacks personalization. Some players might go through the game without ever exploring certain levels, or the mechanics the game has to offer. On the one hand, the player might want to leave that part out of his experience. On the other hand, they might not have explored enough of the game to find out about it. This work explores how to use Procedural Content Generation based on past player behavior to manage exploration of the game mechanics and levels.

Main sub-goals:
( 1 ) Literature review (semester 1)
( 2 ) Computational model (semester 1 and 2)
( 3 ) Test scenario implementation (semester 2)
( 4 ) User studies (semester 2)
requirements: This thesis proposal is open to all MSc students from the Master Degree in Information Systems and Computer Engineering of Instituto Superior Técnico. Preference will be given to students that finished the following curricular units: Computer Graphics for Games, Artificial Intelligence for Games, Game Design, Game Development Methodologies.

title: Dissertação || ISP: Information Security enterprise architecture Patterns
observations: Mais informações vide https://sites.google.com/site/vasconcelosandre/teses/mestrado/temas-mestrado
objectives:
Motivation: 

No domínio da cibersegurança encontra-se estabelecido em Portugal o Quadro Nacional de Referência para a Cibersegurança  (QNRCS) como o referencial a seguir. Este consubstancia-se numa visão homogénea e inclusiva da realidade organizacional (pública e privada) portuguesa no que diz respeito à necessidade de implementação de medidas de identificação, proteção, deteção, resposta e recuperação contra as ameaças que possam colocar em causa a segurança das suas redes e sistemas de informação e, desta forma, da sua informação
Por outro lado, foi estabelecido em Resolução de Conselho de Ministros (RCM 41/2018) um conjunto de requisitos mínimos das redes e sistemas de informação, tendo em visto o cumprimento do Regulamento Geral de Proteção de Dados (RGPD).
Ambos estes referenciais, o último de implementação obrigatória para a Administração Publica, necessitam de uma arquitetura empresarial de referência que favoreça a implementação dos requisitos técnicos necessários ao seu pleno cumprimento.
Adicionalmente, a gestão de incidentes de segurança de informação tem ganho cada vez mais importância nas organizações, porém existe também pouca certeza sobre quais os modelos e metodologias que compõem e guiam o leque de intervenção da gestão de incidentes de segurança de informação. Muitas vezes estas competências são emanadas das próprias regras e recomendações que dizem respeito à gestão de incidentes. Segundo a ISO20000, a gestão de incidentes tem como objetivo principal restaurar os serviços acordados para o negócio o mais rapidamente possível ou para responder a solicitações de serviço. 
Com a evolução das organizações, a certificação passou a ser um requisito para o negócio. Como tal, para uma empresa ser certificada na norma ISO27001:2015 é necessário que tenha um processo de gestão de incidentes de segurança de informação implementado, com as respetivas responsabilidades definidas.
Neste universo de normas e referenciais, onde a gestão de incidentes de segurança de informação é cada vez mais vista com maior cuidado por parte das organizações, não se encontram muitas certezas sobre qual o modelo a seguir para implementar de uma forma correta a gestão de incidentes nas organizações.
requirements:
Description:
O QNRCS propõe uma implementação processual orientada à gestão do risco, que permite às organizações a tomada de decisão de forma priorizada e informada, no contexto da cibersegurança. Estas decisões devem, sempre, estar igualmente orientadas à garantia da confidencialidade, disponibilidade e integridade na prestação do bem ou serviço para uma determinada organização.



Neste âmbito, entende-se risco como uma circunstância ou um evento identificável, com um efeito adverso potencial na segurança das redes e dos sistemas de informação
 


A segurança de informação suporta hoje em dia toda a atividade da organização e como tal tem que existir um alinhamento entre a arquitetura de informação da organização (incluindo as entidades informacionais da componente de segurança da informação), com a arquitetura de aplicações e com a arquitetura tecnológica que tem que suportar as restantes componentes arquiteturais.

Assim, nesta tese, o aluno deve começar por proceder ao levantamento do Estado da arte da Segurança de Informação e seus impactos na arquitetura empresarial.
Em seguida, com base na revisão da literatura, devem ser propostos padrões arquiteturais de segurança de informação aplicados ao contexto nacional, designadamente ao nível informacional, para dar cumprimento aos requisitos presentes tanto na QNRCS como na RCM 41/2018. Da mesma forma, devem ser propostos padrões aplicacionais para cumprimento desses requisitos. E, por último, devem ainda ser explorados os padrões ao nível tecnológico.


Finalmente, os padrões arquiteturais de segurança de informação propostos, deverão ser instanciados em iniciativas da AMA de forma a verificar a sua adequação.



Expected results:
1.: Levantamento do Estado da arte de Segurança de Informação aplicado a Arquitetura Empresarial
2.	Proposta de padrões de arquitetura empresarial para implementação de segurança de informação no contexto nacional;
3.	Instanciação de padrões em ferramenta de arquitetura empresarial, no contexto da Administração Pública 
4. Publicação de artigo.

title: [Dissertação] : Deep Learning Methods for Processing Digitized Herbarium Specimens
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Jacinto Estima ( https://jestima.github.io/ ), and it will be developed in the context of a research project that was recently submitted by INESC-ID, in collaboration with the Centre for Ecology, Evolution and Environmental Changes (cE3c) of the University of Lisbon ( http://ce3c.ciencias.ulisboa.pt/ ).

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Hundreds of herbarium collections, currently in Natural History Museums and other similar institutions, have accumulated a valuable heritage and knowledge of plants over several centuries. Recent initiatives started ambitious preservation plans to digitize this information and make it available to botanists and the general public through web portals. Such information is crucial for the study of plant diversity, ecology, evolution, or genetics. However, thousands of sheets are still unidentified at the species level while numerous sheets should be reviewed and updated following more recent taxonomic knowledge. Computer vision and machine learning approaches applied to herbarium sheets are promising ( e.g., see https://doi.org/10.1186/s12862-017-1014-z , https://doi.org/10.1080/23818107.2018.1446357 , https://doi.org/10.1002/tax.596014 or https://bdj.pensoft.net/article/21139/ ), but recent methods based on deep neural networks are still not well studied in this particular problem domain, in comparison to other areas.

This MSc research project will explore and evaluate the accuracy with which deep learning methods can be potentially exploited for processing herbarium images for cataloguing purposes, specifically envisioning (i) the identification of species, and (ii) the extraction of other metadata elements for supporting the indexing of herbarium images. Particular attention will be given to the processing of labels typically present within these images, containing hand-written and/or typewritten information on the names of collectors, the date and location of the collection, and the species identification.

Deep learning approaches based on convolutional neural networks ( e.g., models such as EfficientNet or YOLO-V4 -- see https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.09070 or https://arxiv.org/abs/1506.02640 ), currently achieving state-of-the-art results in a variety of image segmentation and object recognition problems, can be exploited for the recognition of the limits of the various labels existing in the images of species. Text recognition methods will then be used for metadata extraction ( e.g., see https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4086207/ ). In this regard, existing tools/methods such as those developed in previous projects like tranScriptorium ( see http://transcriptorium.eu/ or http://transkribus.eu/ ), Primeros Libros ( http://sites.utexas.edu/firstbooks/ ), or StanDAP-Herb ( https://doi.org/10.1093/database/bay103 ) can be explored and customized for transcribing the text within these labels. Particular attention will be given to the recognition of dates, as the correct handling of dates allows to establish a chronological ordering for the existing labels.

Experiments will be performed with publicly available datasets ( e.g., see https://bdj.pensoft.net/article/31817/ ), and also with images from the Portuguese National Museum of Natural History and Science.

title: Dissertação: Implementação de protocolos de encaminhamento por caminhos ótimos em hardware programável
supervisors: João Luís Costa Campos Gonçalves Sobrinho (50%)
observations:
1.: Co-orientação com João Sobrinho, Professor do DEEC.
2.	Trabalho pioneiro.
objectives:
Idealmente, numa rede de computadores os pacotes de dados são encaminhados ao longo de caminhos ótimos, considerando critérios de otimalidade definidos pelos operadores, tipicamente baseados em parâmetros de desempenho [1,2]. O desenvolvimento de protocolos (algoritmos distribuídos) para este fim é um desafio exigente pois os requisitos de otimalidade têm de ser garantidos simultaneamente com respostas rápidas e automáticas às alterações no estado da rede [3,4].

Infelizmente, a inovação nesta área tem sido lenta. Apesar de alguns avanços na investigação, a implementação e implantação de novos protocolos desenvolvidos teoricamente tem sido muito limitada. O problema principal está na inflexibilidade dos comutadores de rede: os protocolos suportados são definidos em momento de fabrico, dificultando a implementação e experimentação de novos protocolos em redes reais. 

Felizmente, a situação está a mudar. Os avanços mais recentes em redes de computadores traduzem-se numa maior programabilidade, quer no plano de controlo, com as Redes Definidas por Software [5], quer no plano de dados, com o desenvolvimento de dispositivos de comutação de pacotes programáveis. Relativamente a estes últimos, um primeiro protótipo foi apresentado em 2013 [6], e o primeiro comutador comercial, o Barefoot Tofino, surgiu em 2016 [7]. Estes novos dispositivos permitem ao operador definir exatamente como devem ser processados os pacotes na sua rede, através de uma linguagem de alto nível (e.g., a linguagem P4 [8,9]). Deste modo, torna-se possível, pela primeira vez, implementar novos protocolos e implantá-los imediatamente em redes reais. 

Pretende-se com este trabalho desenvolver protocolos de encaminhamento ótimos, de acordo com critérios de otimalidade a definir, implementá-los e avaliá-los em hardware programável (nomeadamente, num Barefoot Tofino que temos no nosso laboratório). O principal desafio é o modelo de programação destes dispositivos, que apresenta restrições computacionais muito significativas, como o trabalho recente do nosso grupo de investigação tem comprovado (e.g., [10]). Por um lado, a memória volátil é escassa [11]; por outro, para se poder garantir o processamento ao ritmo elevado deste equipamento (na ordem dos Tbps) as instruções executadas são de natureza muito simples [12]. A título de exemplo, a linguagem P4 não contempla ciclos de execução, apontadores ou operações de multiplicação, e as operações de acesso a estado (leitura, escrita) são muito limitadas. Em compensação, o hardware permite executar muitas instruções por unidade de tempo. 

Em suma, o desafio desta proposta consiste em desenvolver protocolos de encaminhamento que possam ser descritos por máquinas de estado simples, mas com a possibilidade de executar um elevado número de instruções por unidade de tempo, de modo a poderem ser implantadas imediatamente em redes reais.

title: Dissertation: Testing the Security of a System to Support Students Studding Abroad
supervisors: Miguel Nuno Dias Alves Pupo Correia (100%)
location: Distributed Systems Group ( https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/ ), INESC-ID Alameda (preferred) or IST Taguspark (alternative) or remote work (if the situation requires it)
observations: Uma bolsa será paga a partir de setembro se o resultado da primeira parte (projeto) mostrar que a tese irá cumprir os objetivos.
objectives:
Versão em PDF: https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~mpc/PropostasDE4Adez2020.pdf

This thesis is going to be developed in the context of project DE4A in which INESC-ID (an IST research unit) is a participant (https://www.de4a.eu/). The thesis will be developed in the #SecDep Team ( https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~mpc/team.html ), in the Distributed Systems Group ( https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/ ), at INESC-ID (https://www.inesc-id.pt/).

The European Union is promoting the automation of processes that involve transferring documents between countries. Security is a critical aspect. Project DE4A aims to automate processes related to university students that move from one country to another, while ensuring the authenticity of the documents presented (e.g., the bachelor or master certificate).

This thesis is about one of the two directions of that process: a student coming to study at IST from a university abroad after finishing his bachelor or master (licenciatura, mestrado).

The thesis has two aspects: 

The first is to implement a service for a student from another European country to get his documents from his university when applying to IST. 
The idea is to create a server where the student can apply to IST, which automatically gets the student certificate from his origin university. 
The communication with the university abroad is not part of the project (its a component that already exists, a Docker container with REST API). The objective is to implement only the rest of the functionality: interaction with the student and authentication (using the Citizen Card).

The second aspect has to do with the objective of putting the server online: it has to be very secure. Therefore, the second aspect involves creating (adapting) a methodology to test the security of the service and actually do the tests. Techniques such as vulnerability scanners and static analysis will be considered.

The work plan has the following phases:
- Study of the background and related work
- Design and implementation of the server and methodology
- Experimental evaluation 
- Writing of the thesis and a scientific article

objectives: Esta tese tem como objectivo desenvolver bots capazes de desempenhar uma tarefa específica (reservar um bilhete de comboio ou um hotel, por exemplo), mas, ao mesmo tempo, capazes de “tagarelar” com o utilizador, caso este os desafie. Em foco estará a língua portuguesa (portanto, mais limitada em dados que a língua inglesa) e também a possibilidade de treinar o bot de um modo não excessivamente pesado sob o ponto de vista computacional. O treino do bot irá ser possível com diversas soluções técnicas alternativas, usando diferentes recursos computacionais, que serão avaliadas e escolhidas de acordo com métricas de desempenho recolhidas historicamente e no momento de execução, de modo a permitir a melhor experiência de utilização.

title: Dissertação: Deep Learning-based Video Coding
location: IST - Instituto de Telecomunicações, Multimedia Signal Processing Group, North Tower, 10th floor
objectives:
Scope:
The emergence of deep neural networks is the most prominent advance in the field of machine intelligence during the past decade and has enabled a significant performance boost for several visual information based tasks. This boost is driven by several factors, notably cheaper and powerful hardware, vast amounts of data and more sophisticated data models. Deep neural networks are currently the state-of-the-art for several computer vision and image processing tasks, such as object recognition, image classification, image denoising, inpainting, saliency detection, among others. 
Image coding fully based on deep neural networks (DNNs), also known as deep image coding systems, has become an active area of research recently. Motivated by the excellent performance of deep neural networks in several computer vision tasks, such as image classification and object recognition, but also image coding, several works have attempted to bring this new technology for the video coding arena to leverage on recent development in convolutional neural networks, recursive neural networks and even generative adversarial networks. These novel coding solutions offer the promise of outperforming state-of-the-art standard hand-crafted codecs, such as H.264/AVC and even HEVC. 

Objectives:
Promising image coding results have already been achieved using different types of deep neural networks, such as autoencoders. Some first solutions have also emerged for deep learning-based video coding but the field is still rather novel. Thus, the main objectives of this Thesis are: 
1)	Review and compare the available deep learning-based video coding solutions (those using a deep learning-based architecture and not deep learning for optimization in conventional architectures);
2)	Design, implement and assess a deep learning-based video coding solution leveraging on the recent advances in deep neural networks and deep learning-based coding, in general.

In this context, the following steps will be relevant:
•	Gathering of the relevant literature for deep learning-based image and video coding
•	Review of the relevant literature and writing of a state-of-the-art review chapter
•	Comparison of relevant deep learning-based video coding solutions available in the literature based on several objective quality metrics
•	Design and implementation of an efficient deep learning-based video codec based on the solutions already available in the literature
•	Performance assessment of the developed video codec using relevant and appropriate test conditions, benchmarks and methodologies (objective and subjective)
•	Definition of future work addressing the improvement of the developed video codec

title: Dissertação: Suporte para coerência causal transaccional em ambiente de micro-serviços.
observations:
Este tema já foi acordado com o aluno João Rafael Pinto Soares (87675).

Preferencialmente, o trabalho deverá ser desenvolvido no espaço do Grupo de Sistemas Distribuídos do INESC-ID.

Se a evolução da COVID-19 obrigar a manter medidas de confinamento, o trabalho será realizado maioritariamente por tele-trabalho, com acompanhamento frequente por video-conferência.
objectives:
A coerência causal transaccional (TCC) é um modelo que foi desenvolvido para sistemas de computação na nuvem geo-replicados que permite oferecer transacções não-bloqueantes com garantias mais fracas que os sistemas que oferecem "serializability" of "snapshot-isolation". Recentemente, surgiu a idea de usar estes modelos para facilitar o desenvolvimento de aplicações baseada em micro-serviços. Tipicamente, para assegurar a capacidade de escala e o desacopolamento entre os micro-serviços, estas aplicações evitam a utilização de transacções. No entanto, isto torna o desenvolvimento do código mais complexo.  A TCC emerge como um modelo de coerência que pode facilitar o desenvolvimento de aplicações baseadas em micro-serviços.

O objectivo da tese é estudar técnicas para adaptar os sistema de TCC desenvolvidos para sistemas armazenamento chave-valor de forma a que possam ser aplicadas em sistemas baseados em micro-serviços.

O plano de trabalho consiste nas seguintes fases:

- Revisão do trabalho relacionado.

- Concepção e concretização de mecanismos para suportar TCC em ambientes de micro-serviços.

- Avaliação experimental da solução proposta.

Os resultados esperados são os seguintes:

- Relatório com o levantamento e análise do estado da arte.

- Um conjunto de novas técnicas para assegurar a atomicidade e a coerência das transacções.

- Uma avaliação destas técnicas usando um protótipo.

- Um artigo científico descrevendo estas contribuições.

- Uma dissertação de mestrado.
requirements: O candidato deve ter bons conhecimentos de sistemas distribuídos. A frequência da disciplina de DAD é aconselhada.

title: Dissertation: Efficient Proof-of-space approaches for permissionless blockchains
observations: This topic is assigned to student João Martinho, nº 86454
objectives:
The most prominent permission less blockchains, such as Bitcoin and Ethereum, rely on proof of work (PoW) or proof of stake (PoS) as the fundamental schemes to reward miners. 
PoW has a substantial energy footprint while PoS lacks convergence guarantees.
Proof-of-Space (PoSp) is a promising approach that relies on disk space, rather than computing power, to ensure the security of the system.
However, state of the art approaches PoSP still require the partial use of PoW or PoS. 

The goal of this thesis is to extend a PoSp approach with Byzantine Fault Tolerant algorithms that do not rely on PoW or PoS for security, and build a prototype in the Ethereum network.

Bibliography:
Etherspace: Practical Proof-of-Space for Blockchains. IST 2019
Proofs of space. Cryptology ePrint Archive, Report 2013/796, 2013
Beyond hellman’s time-memory trade-offs with applications to proofs of space. Cryptology ePrint Archive, Report 2017/893

title: [Dissertation] Task and Motion Planning for Intelligent Agents/Robots
location: The work will be conducted at INESC-ID Alameda/TagusPark.
objectives:
Objectives:

Many task in games, robots, or any other intelligent agent requires planning simultaneously at a logic level (e.g. should I open this door?), and at a continuous level (e.g. what motion should I execute to jump over this obstacle). Usually both problems are considered in separate, logic planning using methods such as A*, or STRIPS, and continuous planning using methods such as dynamic programming or control methods. The main problem is that I good logical plan might be very difficult to execute and so there is a good advantage to do both simultaneously.

In this thesis work we will learn and test popular methods, improve them and/or use them in new settings. 

We can consider extensions to multi-agents systems, consider mixing planning and learning, consider distributed approaches, and improve the efficiency with the use of learning and/or heuristics.

On alternative we can apply such methods in new situations. This can include use TAMP methods for test computer games, develop a new intelligence for cooperative games.

Take into account the students interest this work can be applied in robots (real or simulated), in computer games (e.g. geometry friends, or any other including discrete and continuous decisions), or any other type of intelligent agent.

title: Dissertação - Learning predictive models for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis using patient profiles
observations: This thesis proposal was written for Eleonora Auletta.
objectives:
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is a rapidly progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by progressive loss of motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord, leading to muscular weakness and ultimately death. Life expectancy is 3 to 5 years after disease onset, there is no cure or known causes, and disease heterogeneity makes it difficult to understand its underlying mechanisms. ALS is also the most common neurodegenerative disease in young adults. Thus, finding a cure/ways to slow disease progression, improve patients’ prognosis, and promote patients’ quality of life are nowadays research challenges. In this scenario, ALS community, actively investigating biomarkers with the scope to contribute to earlier diagnosis and more precise monitoring of disease progression, concerning the need for advanced machine learning models to understand the heterogeneity of patients (impacting disease presentation and progression patterns). Although complex genetic framework changes can sustain part of this heterogeneity, it would be important to understand these differences in the rate of functional decline, using machine learning models learnt from demographic data, clinical phenotype and environmental profiles, together with longitudinal data from clinical follow-up. This would allow to explore differences in disease management and medical complications between groups and provide relevant information to design optimised disease management strategies, including end-of-life decisions, respecting a precision medicine approach. 
In this context, this thesis aims to advance precision medicine and improve supportive care in ALS by proposing machine learning models for prognostic prediction in ALS based on patient profiles: groups of patients with similar characteristics at diagnosis or similar disease progression patterns. These models will be learned from a large dataset of genotype-phenotype data and clinical temporal data already collected by national FCT project NEUROCLINOMICS2 (2016-2019, PI Sara C. Madeira) and European JPND project OnWebDuals (2016-2019, PI Mamede de Carvalho). 
Clinically relevant endpoints for prediction can be defined using the ALS Functional Rating Scale-revised (ALSFRS-R), an instrument used to evaluate the functional status of ALS patients and monitor functional change in a patient over time. Important targets concern the prediction of specific clinical endpoints aiming to anticipate patient care and prolong survival: 1) speech combined with non-vocal communication or loss of useful speech; 2) need for intermittent assistance or full assistance for self-care; 3) gait support or no purposeful leg movement; and 4) respiratory symptoms, need for non-invasive ventilation (NIV). 
The work plan is as follows:
1 - Study thesis problem and related work on patient stratification and machine learning for prognostic prediction
2 - Identify patient profiles (patient stratification) using advanced clustering algorithms/clustering ensembles 
3 - Evaluate patient profiles 
4 - Design supervised learning approach for prognostic prediction using patient profiles 
5 – Identify disease progression pattern specific to patient profiles 
6 - Evaluate prognostic models using patient profiles and patient profiles coupled with disease progression patterns
7 - Write the thesis
requirements: Interest on bioinformatics and data science. Approval on both data science and computational biology courses.

title: Dissertação: Vulkan-based Interactive Global Illumination development in Android
objectives:
Motivation:
The rapid increase of performance on low-power graphics processors has made a big impact. More advanced computer graphics algorithms are now possible on a new range of mobile devices. Indirect illumination is an important element for realistic image synthesis, but its computation is expensive and highly dependent on the complexity of the scene and of the BRDF of the involved surfaces. While off-line computation and pre-baking can be acceptable for some cases, many applications (games, simulators, etc.) require real-time or interactive approaches to evaluate indirect illumination.

Objective: 
To compute, in an Android mobile device, real-time indirect lighting in a dynamic complex scene by using a voxel- based cone tracing technique: https://research.nvidia.com/sites/default/files/publications/GIVoxels-pg2011-authors.pdf

Description:
To implement, by using the low level Vulkan API, the sparse voxel octree (SVO) structure that can render scenes with several dynamic objects in real-time. The data structure should be capable of supporting cone-tracing method and support both indirect specular and diffuse illumination as well as ambient occlusion.

title: Dissertation: Reasoning about persistent and concurrent data structures that operate on non-volatile memory (NVM)
objectives:
It is expected that the shift towards non-volatile memory (NVM) technologies will revolutionise real-time and data-intensive processing applications, since it allows applications to run without incurring the latency penalty of going out to storage. However, designing and implementing correct persistent concurrent data structures that take advantage of NVMs is a challenge. Research on techniques that can establish correctness of these data structures is extremely necessary but still very scarce. The goal of this project is to contribute to this by surveying existing techniques and potentially developing new reasoning techniques that can be used to establish correctness of persistent concurrent data structures.

This project will consider existing data structures, such as lock-free queues (Friedman et al 2018) and hashmaps (Schwalb et al 2015), but we will also attempt to obtain implementations for new
data structures (e.g. persistent versions of the data structures available in java.util.concurrent).

References:
Friedman, M., Herlihy, M., Marathe, V. and Petrank, E., 2018. A persistent lock-free queue for non-volatile memory. ACM
SIGPLAN Notices, 53(1), pp.28-40.

non-volatile memories. In Proceedings of the 3rd VLDB Workshop on In-Memory Data Mangement and Analytics (pp. 1-8).

title: [Dissertação] PriVeil integration in SecOps ecosystem
objectives:
Existing solutions allow cybersecurity threat information sharing using anonymization filters to prevent leakage of sensitive information. However, relevant details can be lost during the process, and prevent the information from being useful. Participants must be willing to provide their sensible, but unaltered, information to the platform and likewise be able to gather trustworthy information published by other participants. Studies have shown that companies would be more willing to participate if they were assured to have full control over the shared data, without disclosure of private knowledge, and were able to trust information received from other participants.


The PriVeil (privacy veil) work is a threat information sharing system design that is able to match participants with identical security vulnerabilities, encouraging cooperation to identify these issues while retaining full control over their private data. Privacy-preserving techniques like Homomorphic Encryption and Secure Multi-party Computation are used to assure that no sensible information is unwillingly disclosed by the system.

The current prototype needs integration with existing security tools such as MISP and OpenVAS that allow it to be used in actual deployments.
