title: ​Dissertação: Attractor reachability estimation in logical models
objectives:
Logical modelling has been successfully used to study regulatory networks. Model dynamics can be represented as State Transition Graphs (STG), where nodes represent states and edges represent state transitions. STGs grow exponentially with the size of the model, motivating the development of numerous algorithmic approaches. Dynamical properties of interest typically relate to the existence and reachability of attractors, representing states of interest.

To quantify attractor reachability, a modified Monte Carlo simulation algorithm, denoted AVATAR [1], has been proposed to estimate the probability of reaching a set of attractors and to identify them if not previously known. In particular, it permits the probability estimation of reaching an attractor from a (set of) initial state(s) under the assumption of equiprobability of concurrent transitions to successors states.
AVATAR is implemented in the GINsim modelling and simulation tool [2], supporting: asynchronous updates, where each concurrent transition represents a single component update; synchronous updates, where all components are updated in a transition to a single successor state; and priority classes, where the selection of updated variables is directed by priority classes [3].

This thesis will focus on the definition of partial priority classes for the specification of priorities between a restricted set of components, as well as the assignment of non-equiprobable probabilities to concurrent transitions.
The resulting work will be used by the AVATAR algorithm to assess and quantify attractor reachability on real case biological models.
These functionalities, priority settings and Avatar extension, would be integrated in the GINsim software.
requirements: Good programming skills. Interest in graphs is a plus.

title: Dissertação: Gestão Ágil e Eficiente de Projetos: Foco nos processos de Execução e Controlo
objectives:
No âmbito da iniciativa de investigação ITLingo PSL (Project Plan Specification Language) tem sido definida uma linguagem para especificação rigorosa de planos de projeto (linguagem PSL, cuja versão preliminar se encontra disponível a partir de https://github.com/ITLingo/PSL), e também um template MS-Excel que permite de forma simples e eficiente a gestão de projetos. Os desenvolvimentos realizados até à data têm-se centrado principalmente nos processos de planeamento do projeto, pelo que nesta investigação se pretende explorar os mecanismos e boas práticas relacionados com os processos de Execução e Controlo.

No âmbito desta investigação pretende-se que o aluno investigue e consolide os seus conhecimentos nas áreas da gestão de projetos informáticos, processos/metodologias de desenvolvimento de sistemas (processos ágeis e tradicionais), nas suas múltiplas dimensões, tais como âmbito, recursos e organização, comunicação, tempo, custos, qualidade, risco. Pretende-se em particular que o aluno possa explorar os seguintes aspetos (a definir em maior detalhe no decurso do trabalho): 
(i) Definição e extensão de templates de planos de projeto segundo diferentes processos (e.g., Scrum, OpenUP, Kaban, RUP); 
(ii) Definir mecanismos de alinhamento e rastreabilidade entre conceitos da gestão de projeto, e.g. entre objetivos, user stories, tarefas, recursos e artefactos; 
(iii) Definir mecanismos de execução e controlo do projeto, nomeadamente gráficos e dashboards para visualização do desempenho do projeto; e 
(iv) Definir mecanismos de integração/interoperabilidade com sistemas colaborativos de gestão de projetos (e.g., Microsoft Project, Wrike, Atlassian).


Este projeto deverá desenvolver-se ao longo das seguintes fases:
A primeira fase consiste na análise e definição do problema e na investigação sobre a iniciativa ITLingo PSL, bem como o aprofundamento do corpo de conhecimento relacionado com a gestão de projetos (e.g., PMBoK, SWBoK), e ainda a análise de templates e ferramentas de gestão de projeto. 
A segunda fase consiste no desenvolvimento e extensão de modelos (templates) de planos de projeto de acordo com a linguagem PSL, e segundo diferentes processos/metodologias (ágeis e tradicionais). Estas tarefas deverão permitir explorar os aspetos acima referidos e estender e validar a própria linguagem PSL.
A terceira fase consiste na definição de projetos concretos (a definir), que permitam a consequente avaliação e discussão dos resultados produzidos.

title: [Dissertation] OrderWarp - Visualizing big data streaming ordinal data
objectives:
As técnicas tradicionais para visualização de informação lidam com conjuntos de dados conhecidos à partida e de pequenas dimensões (mesmo milhares de items é pouco, neste contexto). Se quisermos visualizar Big Data precisamos de algo novo. Temos já uma abordagem que permite ir agregando os dados progressivamente. Cada visualização representa um intervalo de tempo. À direita é real-time, imediatamente a seguir podemos estar a olhar para um agregado dos últimos minutos, em seguida das últimas horas, etc. Mas importa que não se perca o contexto, que se perceba para onde vão os valores…

Já está em estudo uma solução para dados quantitativos (time series). Mas… será que conseguimos o mesmo para dados ordinais? Ou talvez até mesmo categóricos? Será esse o objetivo deste trabalho

Como mostrar dados ordinais seguindo a filosofia descrita acima. Como os agregar, a diferentes escalas de tempo? Não podemos fazer médias, mas há outras coisas que podemos usar. Qual será a melhor forma de o fazer e representar graficamente, de modo a que um analista consiga, mesmo assim, manter o context da sua análise?

title: [Dissertation] Leveraging LLVM IR to automatically map Deep Neural Networks in reconfigurable accelerators
observations:
- This thesis will be also supervised by Dr. Nuno Neves, from INESC-ID (Nuno.Neves@inesc-id.pt)
- Assignment of this thesis is subject to a prior informal interview with the candidate to assess his motivation and prior knowledge in the fields of research
- This thesis involves challenging aspects recognized by the scientific community; accordingly, the outcome of this work may give rise to the publication of scientific articles.
objectives:
Recent advances in Deep Neural Networks (DNN) provided important algorithmic breakthroughs in many domains, such as computer vision, speech recognition, natural language processing, drug discovery, genomics, etc. Such breakthroughs have been achieved through deeper and non-uniform neural networks, by integrating new layer types (e.g, convolutional and/or recurrent layers), new activation functions and through advances in the training methodologies. 

However, the computational requirements of these algorithms, allied with the ever-increasing amount of data availability, have pushed the computing capacity of off-the-shelf processing architectures (e.g., CPU and GPU) to their limit. This drove a renewed interest to dedicated accelerator architectures in the industry. However, these new architectures (e.g., Google 's TPU) mostly focus on accelerating the inference phase. In fact, the training phase is still performed in off-the-shelf systems, making developers wait several weeks to train a DNN, a problem which is expected to worsen as DNNs become sparser, more complex and less susceptible to acceleration.

To tackle this issue, a new DNN accelerator is currently under development that exploits reconfigurable technology to enable architecture adaptation. It aims at providing support for both the training and inference phases by dynamically reconfiguring its architecture, to suit the computational requirements of each phase and to match the neural network topology, making the execution as efficient as possible.

Accordingly, the aim of this thesis is to investigate new compiler techniques to automatically detect the computing structure, topology and data-flow characteristics of a DNN and map them to the accelerator under development. These new techniques will leverage the LLVM compiler intermediate representation (IR) language to infer opportunities to reduce numerical precision, apply vectorization and introduce approximate computing techniques as a mechanism to accelerate DNN applications in reconfigurable hardware.

title: Dissertação: Framework of a multi-architecture Internet
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Fernando Ramos (fvramos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
The Internet is the most successful global communication infrastructure ever built. This is as undeniable as the widely recognized limitations of its architecture [1]. The most acknowledged architectural flaw is the lack of security in the original design, leaving the Internet vulnerable to various (and increasingly common) attacks. The research community responded to this problem with various clean-slate redesigns of the Internet, including security approaches [2,3], inter-domain designs [4], or information-centric networks [5]. So far, none of these clean-slate designs have had a significant impact on the commercial Internet, since the Internet architecture is deeply embedded both in networking hardware and in the end-host software. Put simply: the Internet is very hard to change.

Fortunately, recent advances on flexible networking hardware and fast networking software can finally pave the way for a radical change. On the one hand, the emergence of programmable packet switches (e.g., the Intel Barefoot Tofino) that allow the definition of packet processing using a high-level language (e.g., P4 [6]) and run at Tbps scales to meet the performance requirements of today’s networks. On the other hand, recent end-host developments including fast packet processing platforms (e.g., Intel DPDK) and SmartNICs allow network functionality to be placed at the edge with little to no performance penalty.

In this project the student will leverage these advances towards the design of a framework for a multi-architecture Internet. We will consider different approaches for inter-operation, including translation-based (e.g., Plutarch [7]), and tunnel-based (e.g., Trotsky [8]). The student will have access to the latest programmable networking hardware (including SmartNICs and a Barefoot Tofino we have in our lab). One of the main challenges is  to understand the computing models of the different target platforms. For instance, to guarantee line rate processing, and thus to run 100x to 1000x faster than the alternatives, the Tofino model enables only simple operations and access to (limited amounts of) stateful memory. In designing the framework the student will need to pose important research questions, including what types of architectures are deployable using hardware switches, and what is the best placement of functionality (hardware vs software) of the various interoperation (sub-)mechanisms. 

There is a pressing need for new architectures, primarily to improve Internet security (e.g., using the SCION architecture [2,3]), but also due to the emergence of new applications (e.g., a new class of demanding AR/VR applications may benefit from information-centric approaches such as NDN [5]). Interoperation will not only enable these multi-architecture networks, but in doing so will make clean-slate architectures such as SCION or NDN deployable today.  

The student undertaking this project will have the opportunity to study and work with the most advanced networking platforms, to collaborate with leading experts on network architecture and network programmability, and to innovate in this field. If successful, the results of the project can represent a highly relevant contribution towards a multi-architecture Internet.

The project will be co-advised by Fernando Ramos, Associate Prof. at IST, and Aurojit Panda, Assistant Prof. at New York University, co-author of Trotsky [8]

References:
[1] David D. Clark. Designing an Internet. MIT Press. 2018
[2] https://www.scion-architecture.net
[3] David Barrera et al., The SCION Internet Architecture, In Communications of the ACM 60 (6), June 2017
[4] Joe Touch et al., A recursive network architecture. ISI, Tech. Rep, 2006, 626.
[5] Lixia Zhang et al. Named data networking. ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, 2014, 44.3: 66-73.
[6] https://p4.org
[7] J. Crowcroft et al, “Plutarch: An argument for network pluralism,” SIGCOMM Comput.Commun. Rev., vol. 33, no. 4, p. 258–266, Aug. 2003.
[8] J. McCauley et al. Enabling a permanent revolution in internet architecture. In SIGCOMM '19

title: Dissertation: Sketch-Driven SQL Synthesis
observations: Viviana Bernardo 87709
objectives: In several domains, such as data science and low-code development, users must manipulate tabular data, but are likely to lack the necessary programming skills. However, one can easily provide examples of such data manipulations without any knowledge of SQL. The state-of-the-art for SQL query synthesis from input-output examples has advanced significantly in recent years. Nonetheless, there exist scenarios where it may be required for the synthesized query to follow a specific template. One such example is web/mobile app development in OutSystems, where the synthesized queries should follow the template of Aggregate nodes whenever possible. In program synthesis terminology, such a template is referred to as a sketch. The goal of this project is to develop an SQL synthesizer for synthesizing SQL queries, from input-output examples, that satisfy a given template.

title: [Dissertação] Traceless Execution Support for Censorship-Resistant Tools
observations: For more information about this project, please visit: https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~nsantos/msc-topics/msc-topics-CA.html. This work will be performed in collaboration with Diogo Barradas, a PhD student with expertise in traffic analysis, censorship resistance systems, and machine learning.
objectives:
Many states all over the world implement censorship mechanisms that prevent free access to information through the outright impairment or blockage of Internet communications. In our research team, we have built a tool, named Protozoa, which allows Internet users located in censored regions to piggyback on WebRTC-enabled streaming applications, such as Whereby.com, in order to establish covert tunnels that can circumvent said mechanisms. In addition to our system, there are currently a number of other tools for enabling censorship-resistant and anonymization Internet communications. Although the existing tools have different functionalities and properties, they all share a common drawback: the fact that they require the execution of software that leaves traces on the user's computer. If a user is forced to let a state-mandated agent physically inspect his device, these traces may reveal attempts to access prohibited content, and the user be severely penalized by the state. This limitation is a major deterring factor for the widespread adoption of privacy-enabling tools (PETs), including ours.

The goal of this thesis is to design and implement Calypso, a framework for the development and deployment of PETs that can be used for short term usage sessions -- private sessions -- while minimizing the digital traces of execution left on the users' devices. Specifically, the idea is to develop an "anti-forensic shell", i.e., a packaging and an execution runtime where the PET's software is enclosed. This shell will ensure that all operations that require the interaction with the operating system (e.g., accessing the file system or the network) will be treated in such a way as to prevent permanent changes in the system that could be detected by the usage of state-of-the-art forensic tools after the termination of a private session. To achieve this end, this work will be done in two stages: i) study the digital traces left by representative PET software (e.g., TOR), and ii) develop a framework for mitigating these traces. One particular hypothesis that will be explored in ii) will be to leverage the browser as a platform for the deployment of the PET tool, and the usage of WebAssembly for encapsulating the PET software and execution environment. We expect this work to make original scientific contributions. The resulting system will be released as an open source project. If you like forensics and distributed security systems, this is the right topic for you.
requirements: This topic is already reserved for a concrete student.

title: Project: Real Time Process Monitoring & Mining
supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (100%)
objectives:
The goals of this thesis is to develop algorithms to forecast the staffing needs of busines process based process monitoring and mining. 
Organizations have models of business processes to better optimize their operations. Many algorithms and solutions exist to perform process mining based on the traces in information systems, to improve and better understand their process.
However, they do not consider the aspect of managing the staff that is actually involved and performing the business process activities. One of the key aspects of managing business processes is to know how many people should be assigned to each activity to simultaneously fulfill to goals:
•	minimize the number of people assigned to each process task
•	minimize the risk to fail a SLA (Service Level Agreement), namely the time required to process a given case/instance.
These are contradicting goals, given the more people one assign to tasks the more likely one fulfill the SLA. The reality is a little more complex since there are no robust models for human productivity, both the inputs and the process staff changes in a day to day basis.

This thesis should develop algorithms on top pof Atlas tool by Linkconsulting, that is able to monitor business processes in almost real time, to provide forecast information about tomorrow´s  need to staff process´s activities

title: Dissertação: Performance Evaluation of Software Architectures for Digital Humanities Repositories
objectives:
The LdoD Archive of the Fernando Pessoa's Book of Disquiet was developed using technologies that integrate TEI (XML) descriptions of documents with an object-oriented framework based on the Fénix Framework, which is defined using DML specifications. In a previous thesis a modular architecture was defined for the LdoD Archive software, such that it can be easily reusable for the creation of software products for the Digital Humanities field. 

In this thesis we intend to extend this solution also have a microservices architecture and compare the performance of the three architectural solutions: monolith, modular and microservices.

title: Project: Task Allocation in a BPM tool
supervisors: Pedro Manuel Moreira Vaz Antunes de Sousa (100%)
observations: Esta dissertação está reservada à aluna Romana Ferreirinha
objectives:
O produto edoclink é uma solução de automação de processos e gestão documental com centenas de clientes em Portugal e mais centenas de milhares de utilizadores. 
 
O edoclink, suporta a especificação e a posterior execução de processos como é esperado numa solução de BPM. 
Quando aparece uma nova atividade para executar, esta é atribuída a um colaborador com o perfil indicado.  Cada colaborador tem assim uma lista de tarefas para executar.

Pretende-se com esta dissertação a realização de um módulo avançado de alocação de tarefas que permita especificar uma série de critérios, cada um com a sua prioridade) a aplicar na atribuição de tarefas aos colaboradores. Apenas como exemplo damos algumas dos possíveis critérios.

•	Desempenho: Atribuir a tarefa ao elemento do grupo que irá assegurar uma execução mais rápida, tendo em conta a lista de tarefas e a celeridade média de cada colaborador naquela tarefa
•	Qualidade: Atribuir a tarefa aos elementos que menos vezes implicaram o refazer da tarefa.
•	Especificidade: Atribuir aos colaboradores com especificidade para executar aquele tipo de tarefa, documento, etc.  
•	Flexibilidade: Atribuir aos colaboradores que menos vezes executaram esta tarefa

O edoclink disponibiliza os indicadores necessários ao cálculo dos critérios referidos.

title: DISSERTAÇÂO : Classificação e Deteção por mapas de saliência de lesões na mama em imagem multimodal
supervisors: Jacinto Carlos Marques Peixoto do Nascimento (50%)
location: Instituto de Sistemas e Robótica - Torre Norte
objectives:
Nesta dissertação pretende-se realizar o estudo para a classificação de severidade de lesão no tecido mamário. Este estudo tem duas fases distintas:

1 - Classificação:
Num primeiro estágio quere-se classificar se uma dada imagem contem ou não a lesão. Para tal, vão se usar imagens de mamografia para classificar a severidade da lesão. O classificador consiste numa rede neuronal densa, que na sua arquitectura, tem ligações ente todas as camadas de convolução. Posteriormente, podem ser utilizadas outras modalidades de imagem como sendo Ecografia e volumes de Ressonância magnética, realizando-se de novo a classificação nesta modalidades.

Como estágio final da classificação, propõe-se o uso da multimodalidade (isto é, o uso de mamografia ecografia e ressonância magnética), onde agora estas trê modalidades são introduzidas na classificador. Para isso, as modalidades são agora concatenadas à entrada da rede.

2 - Deteção
Para os casos onde as imagens foram classificadas como positivas, ou seja, contendo lesões (que podem ser benignas ou malignas), realiza-se agora a localização da lesão que justifique esse diagnóstico. Para isso são gerados mapas de saliência, onde as regiões salientes obtidas correspondem à localização das lesões. Para a geração do mapa de saliência podem ser usados dverso encoders, como por exemplo, a U-net muito vulgarmente usanda em imagem médica.

Faz-se notar que existe já código disponivel, devendo o candidato continuar e finalizar o trabalho que entretanto se encontra em curso

title: Dissertação: FaaS@GraalVM
observations: Survey the state-of-the-art of the related work. Design and development of a prototype. Testing and performance evaluation. Writing of a technical paper (10 pages) that frames and presents the work carried out, and describes the results achieved.
objectives:
GraalVM is a novel Java VM implementation designed to achieve better performance (throughput and start-up latency) that can also be used to support applications that mix application code written in different programming languages.

Curently, in GraalVM, serverless functions cannot be executed concurrently in the same language runtime. Photons proposed automatic data isolation to allow sharing the language runtime. However, Photons still allows functions to share the same heap space, leading to inefficient memory management leading to performance and latency overheads.

The goal of this work is to study and take advantage of GraalVM features (i) Java ahead of time compilation, providing very low startup time, and ii) Isolates, a separate allocation area that can be attached to functions) in order to support the implementation of thin serverless functions in GraalVM native image by implementing Photons in GraalVM taking advantage of Isolates and ahead of time compilation.

title: Dissertação - Multivariate time-series modeling and forecasting of shellfish contamination
observations: The work will be supported by a strong collaboration network between INESC-ID, IT, NOVA LINCS, and IPMA, inserted in the scope of the FCT funded project "MATISSE - A machine learning-based forecasting system for shellfish safety" (DSAIPA/DS/0026/2019, Principal Investigator: Marta B. Lopes).
objectives:
The aim of this proposal is to develop multivariate time-series models to predict shellfish contamination by biotoxins based on historical biological and meteorological data collected during the last 4 years by the Portuguese Institute of the Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA). The ultimate goal is to minimize the risk to public health, and the negative economical impacts that closures to harvesting lead in the shellfish industry.
Harmful algal blooms (HAB) are responsible for shellfish contamination by biotoxins, which poses a risk to public health. To minimize the risk of foodborne illness after consumption of shellfish, IPMA has in place a monitoring program for marine toxic phytoplankton and contamination of shellfish along the Portuguese coast. Seawater and shellfish samples are collected at a weekly basis and whenever toxin levels exceed the safety limits shellfish harvesting is temporarily banned.
The work will involve the following steps:

1. Review state-of-the-art multivariate time-series models, in particular, probabilistic graphical models;
2. Implement modeling and software pipelines for monitoring toxic phytoplankton and shellfish contamination and for predicting outbreaks (HAB events and shellfish contamination);
3. Model evaluation, interpretation, and validation.
4. Write the thesis.
requirements: Interest in machine learning and good implementation skills. It is preferred, although not mandatory, that students are knowledgeable about algorithms and data structures, object-oriented programming, artificial intelligence, and optimization. Students with good marks in courses related to the thesis topics will be preferred.Minimum average mark required: 15 (Bachelor).

title: [Dissertação] : Deep Learning Methods for Predicting Missing Data over Time Series of Remote Sensing Imagery
observations:
The project will be co-supervised by Bruno Martins ( http://web.ist.utl.pt/bruno.g.martins/ ) and Jacinto Estima ( https://jestima.github.io/ ), and it will be developed in the context of the MIMU and MATISSE research projects, currently being executed at INESC-ID.

The envisioned activities involve collaborating with other researchers at INESC-ID, including a PhD student named Rita Ramos that is working on remote sensing image captioning and multi-modal machine learning (under a co-supervision with Prof. Desmond Elliot from University of Copenhagen).

Students interested in this proposal should contact Bruno Martins ( bruno.g.martins@ist.utl.pt ) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Continuous, consistent, and long time-series from remote sensing observations are essential to monitoring changes on Earth's surface. However, analyzing such data sets is often challenging, due to missing values introduced by cloud cover or missing orbits. Different methods have been presented to estimate missing values in remote sensing imagery, although there are still relatively few approaches exploring recent advances in deep learning with convolutional neural networks ( see https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8276645 , https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301479720301638 or https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/8316243 ).

This MSc research projects concerns the development of new and accurate spatio-temporal prediction methods for replacing missing values in remote sensing data sets. Particular models to be considered can perhaps extend the previously proposed MetNet ( https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.12140 ), STConvS2S ( https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.00134 ), or SARDINE networks ( https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3380972 ), for instance through the use of learnable inputs ( https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.05930 ), advanced pooling methods ( e.g., https://arxiv.org/pdf/2003.13328v1.pdf or https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.10667 ), or novel activation-normalization functions ( https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.02967 ).

An interesting consideration when processing remote sensing images, as opposed to ground-level imagery, relates to the fact that invariance to scale and rotation transformations is much more important when recognizing patterns (e.g., the absolute orientation of objects is arbitrary, and objects of the same semantic class can be observed in different orientations in the same image). Convolutional neural networks for processing remote sensing data can thus also be designed to take these aspects into consideration, leveraging recent ideas proposed in the context of classification and/or segmentation problems ( see https://github.com/QUVA-Lab/e2cnn , https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.06253 and https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8900563 ).

Experiments will be performed with different types of remote sensing datasets/products publicly available/searchable through portals such as NASA's Giovanni ( http://giovanni.gsfc.nasa.gov/giovanni/ ), including vegetation indexes ( e.g., https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod13c2v006/ ), oceanographic variables ( e.g., https://cmr.earthdata.nasa.gov/search/concepts/C1549096450-PODAAC/2 ), or weather measurements ( e.g.,  http://airnet.caiyunapp.com or https://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/datasets/TRMM_3B42_7/summary ). In all cases, the experimental protocol involves collecting sequences of observations for particular regions, simulating the occlusion of image parts and finally assessing the reconstruction quality through metrics such as the mean absolute error or the mean squared error.

title: Dissertação: NC-DCN: Coding the future data center networks
observations: Students interested in this proposal should contact Fernando Ramos (fvramos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt) for additional clarifications, and for scheduling an initial interview.
objectives:
Datacenter networks (DCNs) need to support low-latency and high-bandwidth continuously, to meet the stringent requirements of modern cloud applications. Quickly recovering from network failures is therefore an essential requirement of a modern DCN [1]. However, existing solutions [2-4] are either slow in responding to failures, present scalability problems, and/or add complexity and higher network costs.

The goal of this project is to design NC-DCN, a high-performance, highly robust data center network that uses network coding as its foundation. The rationale for this approach is that the ability to code network packets has been shown to improve a network's throughput, robustness, and security [5]. Given the fundamentally different packet processing required by this new paradigm, until recently it was impossible to perform network coding in real hardware, creating a barrier to its wide-spread adoption. Fortunately, the emergence of programmable switches (such as Intel/Barefoot Tofino [6], the world’s fastest) and of a language to program them (such as P4 [7]) have eventually changed the state of affairs, and enabled very recently the development of the first network coding (NC) switch by our team [8].

We anticipate the preliminary design of NC-DCN to have the data center network divided into two classes of devices: preparatory switches at the network edge and network coding switches to form the network fabric. The network fabric performs coding and recoding operations, while the network edge serves as a preparatory stage for the complex coding operations applied within the fabric.

An NC-based fabric can be a disruptive approach to the design of future data center networks. As part of such an exciting project, the student will have the opportunity to leverage our previous work [8] as an initial step to the design and evaluation of a first prototype of NC-DCN on a cutting-edge programmable switch we have in our lab (Barefoot Tofino [6]) using the P4 language [7].

The project will be co-advised by Fernando Ramos (Associate Prof. at IST), and Muriel Medard (Prof. at the MIT, and a leading expert on network coding). Salvatore Signorello (post-doc at FCUL) will also be a collaborator in the project. 

References:
[1] ARZANI, Behnaz, et al. "007: Democratically finding the cause of packet drops". In: 15th {USENIX} Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation ({NSDI} 18). 2018. p. 419-435.

title: Dissertation: Force Field calculation for Biomolecules
observations: Orientação Externa: Doutor Francisco Fernandes (francisco.fernandes@ist.utl.pt) com 50%
objectives:
Context:
At the molecular level, almost every biological function, process and interaction is guided by attraction and repulsion forces between the atoms.
Think of it as a giant pool of spherical magnets with different sizes, forces and charges.
A Force Field comprises not only these atoms’ energies, but also their type, radius, bonds, distances, angles, etc.
But to determine the direction, speed and overall movement of each atom, we need to calculate the contribution of the forces of every other atom over this one.
If we consider a system composed of thousands of atoms, this problem, as well as the time necessary to computationally calculate it, grows immensely.
Therefore, more efficient ways to solve it are required.

Goal:
This work aims to use space-partitioning techniques and data structures, such as Octrees or Bounding Volume Hierarchies, to tackle this problem in acceptable running times.
We can divide the 3D space into volumes of different sizes and store in each one the average of the forces of all the atoms inside each one.
Then, to calculate the influence of the Force Field over each atom, we can simply query the volumes where he is included into, instead of querying all the other atoms.

Description:
You will have to study and test different Computer Graphics 3D Acceleration Structures and their performance;
implement a Particle-System-like concept tool to calculate the forces over each atom and to simulate their movements across time;
come up with improvements and optimizations to the Force Field calculation method;
acceleration via GPUs is not required, but welcome.
requirements: Conhecimentos de Computação Gráfica, em particular na área de Visualização e interesse na área da Biologia

title: (Dissertation) A game theory-based incentive framework for the next-generation vehicular networks
location: Zoom and/or Skype and INESC-ID Lisboa (Rua Alves Redol 9, 1000-029 LISBOA) and/or Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade de Lisboa (FCUL, Campo Grande)
objectives:
With the rapid development of 5G communication systems, the advancements of vehicular communication technology in assisting Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) can effectively improve passengers’ safety and provide infotainment for enjoyable journeys [1]. There have been significant advancements in electronics aiding car drivers, along with communications outside the vehicle, e.g., vehicle-to- everything (V2X), to enable mobile Internet and entertainment. Together with V2X connectivity, data collected from infrastructure Road Side Units and various other sensors placed on roads, buildings and pedestrians, which constitute the next-generation vehicular networks, hereafter Internet of Vehicles (IoVs), could be disseminated to the vehicle cloud hence ensuring efficient emergency warning notifications, the management of the city traffic levels, and provide drivers with congestion control information.

However, security is a key challenge in ITS for IoVs since, nowadays, there exists a plethora of security attacks that can negatively impact its reliability [2]. Some examples of common threats to vehicles in ITS include denial of service, jamming, man in the middle, Sybil, eavesdropping, and broadcast and message tampering.

When further investigating individual behaviors and by considering that each vehicle or group of vehicles is controlled by a rational entity, vehicles might misbehave (maliciously or not) by reporting false safety messages while using valid security credentials, what is critical for the most ITS-based applications [3]. This problem is further exacerbated by the absence or impracticality of centralized control in vehicular environments. Conventional incentive schemes allow nodes to learn from their surroundings, i.e., from neighboring vehicles, and then assess the veracity of reported events and the honesty of vehicles. However, these schemes have their own vulnerabilities, such as false accusations and praise, which can be exploited to manipulate the entire network for the benefit of malicious vehicles/entities.

The aim of this project is to design a novel evolutionary game theory-based incentive framework by considering social norm complexity and past reputations [4] to improve cooperation among vehicles.

Implementation of the incentive framework on a simulator, with the respective performance evaluation.  

The project shall follow the following phases:
1) Study of the State-Of-The-Art and related research work;
2) Study of a simulator (e.g., NS3 - https://www.nsnam.org/), implementation of multiple scenarios considering all IoV elements;
3) Implementation of the evolutionary game theory-based incentive framework to improve cooperation among vehicles;
4) Definition of evaluation plan, including test cases, metrics and evaluation criteria;
5) Writing of the dissertation and extended abstract.


References
[1] N. Magaia, Z. Sheng, P. R. Pereira, and M. Correia, "REPSYS: A robust and distributed incentive scheme for in-network caching and dissemination in Vehicular Delay-Tolerant Networks," IEEE Wirel. Commun. Mag., pp. 1–16, 2018.
[2] C. Bernardini, M. R. Asghar, and B. Crispo, "Security and privacy in vehicular communications: Challenges and opportunities," Vehicular Communications, vol. 10. pp. 13–28, 2017.
[3] N. Magaia and Z. Sheng, "ReFIoV: A Novel Reputation Framework for Information-Centric Vehicular Applications," IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology, pp. 1–1, 2018.
[4] F. P. Santos, F. C. Santos, and J. M. Pacheco, "Social norm complexity and past reputations in the evolution of cooperation," Nature, vol. 555, no. 7695, pp. 242–245, Mar. 2018.

title: [Dissertação] Ambulance Assignment for Medical Emergencies
objectives:
In Portugal, the response to a medical emergency is coordinated by INEM (Instituto Nacional de Emergência Médica).
The number and type of emergencies varies according to time windows and geographic location, since it is only
natural that emergencies are correlated with human behaviors.

Whenever there is an ambulance on hold to be assigned to an emergency, there is a waist of resources since
each ambulance must have a crew assigned to it. 
Instead of maintaining a fixed number of ambulances ready to answer to emergencies, the availability of these
should follow the patterns of the expected number and location areas of emergencies. The goal of this thesis
is to determine the optimal number and location of ambulances in specific time windows such that there is always an
available ambulance to answer a request. In the context of this thesis, real data from INEM emergency responses
and ambulances will be used as the basis for the optimization models.

title: Dissertação: Enterprise Architecture Dynamic Evolution Decision using Simulation and Machine Learning
objectives:
https://sites.google.com/view/teses-si-sergioguerreiro/home/enterprise-architecture-dynamic-evolution-decision-using-simulation-and-ml?authuser=0

Enterprise architecture (EA) is a discipline that provides management with appropriate indicators and controls to steer and model the enterprise during change. However, the management of such change is a challenging task for enterprise architects due to the complex dependencies amongst EA models when evolving from initial (As-is) to posterior (To-be) states. 
The challenge is to research an approach supporting design decision during EA evolution, by assisting enterprise architects in computing best alternatives to a posterior state. In doing so, the EA artifacts dependencies are modelled and their evolution during change identified. This model is, then, processed using a control schema to inform EA design decisions. 

Resultados Esperados: 
1. Levantamento de Estado da Arte sobre soluções e implementações conhecidas na comunidade científica e empresarial.
2. Proposta de modelo conceptual que integre os modelos de representação de Enterprise Architecture com os processos de decisão organizacionais.
3. Definição, desenvolvimento e teste de ambiente para simulação das diversas alternativas arquitecturais, de acordo com critério(s) de avaliação pré-definido.
4. Avaliação do modelo conceptual anterior por (i) instanciação num ambiente real no contexto empresarial e (ii) instanciação em ambiente simulado, usando design science research (DSR). 
5. Publicação de artigo(s) ao longo da execução da tese.

title: [Dissertação] High-Performance Machine Learning in Biomedicine: Towards Efficient Epistasis Detection
supervisors: Leonel Augusto Pires Seabra de Sousa (50%)
location: INESC-ID, Alameda Campus (Rua Alves Redol, 9 - 1000-029 Lisboa)
observations: This thesis will be developed in the scope of the national project entitled “High Performance and Energy-efficient Processing of Bioinformatic Applications on Emergent Heterogeneous Systems” (HiPerBio). More details at: http://sips.inesc-id.pt/~ilic/hiperbio.php.
objectives:
The relationship between genes and diseases (such as glaucoma, Alzheimer’s, and autoimmune conditions) represents one of the main topics of research in genome wide association studies. Given a dataset composed of genetic markers from multiple individuals, categorized as case or control depending on the presence (case) or absence (control) of the disease under study, epistasis detection is aimed at finding the combination of k interacting markers that most likely leads to the occurrence of the disease [1].

The application of traditional exhaustive searches no longer represents a feasible approach for epistasis detection in current research contexts. For instance, a moderate dataset comprising 500,000 genetic markers implies 125 billion interactions for the basic case of k=2. Furthermore, complex diseases are only explained by means of interactions among k>3 genetic markers, significantly increasing the computational cost. Machine learning (ML) has recently arisen as a sound approach to address this problem, leading to significant results in real-world scenarios [2]. However, the rising complexity of state-of-the-art datasets and the interest in studying high-order, multi-effect, and multi-way interactions beyond case-control scenarios [3] demand novel, high-performance ML-based methods for efficient epistasis detection.

The main objective of this Thesis is to explore ML techniques to improve the solution of complex, high-order epistasis analyses. The key idea lies in investigating the application of well-established ML algorithms to prune the search space of epistatic interactions, comparatively evaluating the accuracy of each algorithm on detecting subsets of the most likely interactions supported by the input data. The targeted ML techniques include support vector machines, neural networks, Bayesian networks, random forest, and gradient boosting. Self-adaptive ML configuration based on evolutionary computation (EC) [4] and problem-aware optimization approaches will also be investigated in the scope of this Thesis. The prospective student will be encouraged to critically analyze state-of-the-art ML approaches, understanding the main challenges to be addressed in real-world contexts and proposing innovative methodologies (ML+EC) to tackle hard-to-solve biomedicine problems.

[2] B. Li, N. Zhang, Y. Wang, A. W. George, A. Reverter, Y. Li, “Genomic Prediction of Breeding Values Using a Subset of SNPs Identified by Three Machine Learning Methods”. Frontiers in Genetics, Vol. 9, Article 237, pp. 1-20, 2018. DOI: 10.3389/fgene.2018.00237

title: Dissertação: FPGA (OpenCL) accelerated model checking
objectives:
Models of discrete event systems have been studied through simulations using a number of software tools. However, the intrinsic disparity between the sequential nature of microprocessor architecture used in software-based simulations and the highly parallel nature of such systems may result in prohibitively long simulation times.

In this work, we adopt an alternative approach to simulation of discrete event systems using hardware-software based emulation.
Previous works on hardware acceleration have reported speedups up to 17,000x when compared to existing software simulation approaches.

Hardware accelerators are often based on reconfigurable logic (FPGAs) which allow to have highly customized circuit implementations, and can be attached to a computer as a PCI-Express accelerator, like a GPU (https://www.terasic.com.tw/cgi-bin/page/archive.pl?Language=English&CategoryNo=158&No=526 ).
The development of hardware accelerators can be done using frameworks such as OpenCL (https://www.khronos.org/opencl/ ) which allows the developer to specify a high-performance hardware-software accelerator kernels without knowledge of low-level system design. This allows Software Engineers to design highly customized hardware accelerators without relying on a hardware engineer to implement it.

In this thesis the focus is on the optimization the common model-checker (http://lvl.info.ucl.ac.be/Tools/NuSMV-ARCTL-TLACE) used in the verification of discrete event systems, and on the implementation of the most computational intensive parts in the hardware accelerator. The software (C/C++) will be running on the CPU whereas the accelerated functions on the FPGA.

It is expected to have a demonstrator running on an FPGA system.
